algorithms.bodyText: Rutgers, edited by K. A. Norris. London: Blandford Press Ltd., 1968. Price 21 s. When reviewing Vols. 1 and 2 of the first (English) edition of this work Avicultural Magazine 1966, 72 , no. 2, p. 66) I warmly recommended them 3 ut with the reservation that I did not agree with all the statements therein, hat the terms " species " and " variety " were wrongly used as if they vere synonymous and that a few (only) of the colour plates gave a faulty mpression. This volume deals with the passerine birds. Its author is obviously, as 1 stated previously, a bird-lover in the best sense of the word and one great virtue of the book is that it does not give the impression that birds are " no :rouble at all " to keep. Practically all of the species likely to be readily obtainable, besides many that are not, are dealt with. There are 147 :oloured photographs depicting (unless I have miscounted) 146 different species. The least satisfactory photographs in the previous edition have been replaced by better ones. The colour reproduction of many of the others is better in this edition although it is worse in the Mountain Bluebird on plate 143. Anyone who has had anything to do with getting coloured illustrations into a book will, however, know the trials and tribulations involved and that perfection is, as Cicero said of good government, "A thing to be hoped for rather than a possibility." Perfection has not been

*.achieved with all these illustrations--though I think it has with the Rainbow Bunting on plate 81--but they are mostly very good. The commonest flaw is for russet and chestnut to appear too fiery and brilliant (e.g. plates 94, 95, 68) but, as it can look a bit that way in the live bird in certain lights, it is, perhaps, a fault on the right side. There still appears some small confusion over species, races and varieties. The latter word is, for example, used on page 144 in precisely the same context in which " species " is correctly used on the previous page. The races of the Avadavat and Golden-breasted Waxbill are treated as races nomenclatorially but referred to as species (pp. 145 an( ^ I 54 )* I am doubtful of the claim (p. 58) that hybrids have been produced between the Canary and Chaffinch and, from my own experience of this and other corvine species, I most emphatically do not believe that, when Lanceolated Jays fail to breed successfully, the cock " is generally the cause of all the trouble," a statement for which no evidence is given. These strictures should not, however, deter anyone from buying this book. It is an excellent work and would, in my opinion, be cheap at twice the price.

A Sussex reader reminds me that Eagle-Owls were formerly kept and bred at Arundel Castle. I did not include these birds in my summary of breeders because they were very probably Virginian Eagle-Owls Bubo virginianus virgimanm I do not think I can do better than quote William Borrer (The Birds ot Sussex, page xvii) (1891): " Concerning the Owls formerly in the Keep of Arundel Castle, which I believe were generally supposed to be Eagle Owls, and were mentioned as such by Mr. Knox in O. R. p. 91, as they were for many years a great attraction to visitors, a few words may be expected, though they have no claim to be called Sussex birds. I may say that when I saw them many years ago I had no doubt that they were the Virginian species, in which opinion I am confirmed by the following notice in ' The Beauties of England and Wales,' vol xiv. p. 82, by F. Shoberl, where, speaking of the Keep of Arundel Castle, he says: " The Owls which are kept here were a present to the Duke from North America." This was published m 1813. Mr. J. PI. Gurney kindly made enquiries for me of the present Duke, who most courteously gave all the information in his power, stating that he believed it to be the fact that the Owls were introduced into the Keep by Charles, the nth Duke, who died in 1815, and that some were still remaining when he himself came to the title in i860, but that during his minority they gradually disappeared from the Castle, though two were remaining in a garden in the town up to the end 01 1009. Mr Mostyn, the Duke's agent, kindly forwarded me a letter from an old man, tor many years the custodian of the Owls, who states that they occasionally bred in the Keep, producing but one egg in the season, and hatching it; but in 1859 one bird laid three eggs, which produced three fine young, which grew to maturity. Une 01 the Owls, which had long been known as Loyd Thurlow, at last laid an egg, w c was the subject of considerable amusement. Mr. Gurney had a cutting from the
algorithms.table: ' West Sussex Gazette ' of 1859, stating that one of the Arundel Owls, believed to b the original " Lord Thurloe," had just died, supposed to be about a hundred Years old.** * \
algorithms.reference: J. H. Gurney (On the Comparative Ages to which Birds live, Ibis, 1899, 3 *, quotes the West Sussex Gazette account, and gives the added information that the death of this bird left seven birds in the Keep, one of which was 63 years old Gurnev does not appear to have been convinced that these birds were other thar European Eagle-Owls. A. A. Prestwich. The Editor does not accept responsibility for opinions expressed in articles, notes, or correspondence.
algorithms.listItem: Rules of the Avicultural Society Revised, by the Council, 13 th September, 1968 1. The name of the Society shall be The Avicultural Society and it shall have for its object the study of British and foreign birds in freedom and in captivity. Domesticated birds shall be outside the scope of the Society. 2. The Avicultural Society shall consist of Ordinary, Life and Honorary Life Members, and Honorary Fellows. The last shall be restricted in number to ten, and be elected by the Council. 3. Any person over the age of seventeen interested in aviculture is eligible to apply for membership in the Society provided:-- (a) that every applicant shall be admissible only as an individual seeking Membership in his or her own right and that no firm, company, corporation or other body or organisation, nor any person as an accredited represen- tative of any such body or organisation shall be eligible for admission, and (b) that every applicant for admission as a Member of the Society must
algorithms.bodyText: himself duly complete and sign the application for admission form. Every applicant must be proposed by a Member of the Society. The name and address of every person thus proposed, with the name of the Member proposing him shall be published in the next issue of the Magazine. Unless the applicant shall within four weeks after the publication of his name in the Magazine, be objected to by at least two Members, he shall be deemed to be duly elected. If two or more Members shall object to any applicant the name of such applicant shall be brought before the Council at their next meeting, and the Council shall have power to elect or disqualify him from election. If five Members shall lodge with the Honorary Secretary
algorithms.listItem: objections to any applicant he shall not be elected, but the signatures to the signed objections must be verified by the Scrutineer. 4. The year of the Society, with that of each volume of the Society's Journal, which shall be known as the Avicultural Magazine , shall commence with the 1 st of January and end on the 31st of December following. 5. Every Ordinary Member shall pay an annual subscription of #2 , or such sum
algorithms.bodyText: as the Council shall from time to time approve, to be due and payable in advance on the 1st of January in each year; and, on payment of the subscription shall be entitled to receive copies of all the numbers of the Society's Magazine for the current year. Every new Ordinary Member shall pay an annual subscription of #2 on election and subsequently on the 1st of January of each year. New Members failing to pay their first annual subscription within two months immediately following their election shall have their election annulled. New Members elected after the 1st of October in any year shall have the option after election of paying their first annual subscription for that year, or of having their membership deemed to commence on the 1st of January of the following year. In the latter case new Members must inform the Honorary Secretary accordingly within one month of election, and if they fail to pay their first annual subscription before the following 1st of March they shall have their election annulled. 6. Members may compound their future annual subscriptions. The composition fee shall be on an age basis and shall be on a scale such as the Council shall from time to time approve.
algorithms.listItem: 7. Any Member whose annual subscription is one year in arrears shall, ipso facto, cease to belong to the Society, but shall be eligible for re-admission to the Membership at the descretion of the Council, on his paying the arrears. 8. Members intending to resign their Membership at the end of the current year of the Society are expected to give notice to the Honorary Secretary-Treasurer before the 1st of December, so that their names shall not be included in the " List of Members ", which shall be published annually, or at the discretion of the Council, in the first number of the Magazine. 9. If, in the opinion of the Council, any Member shall have acted in a manner
algorithms.bodyText: injurious to the interests or good name of the Society, the Honorary Secretary- Treasurer shall be directed to send a registered letter to that Member stating the nature of the offence together with the name of the informant, or the source of information, and asking for an explanation. After allowing reasonable time (not less than a clear fortnight after the despatch of the Honorary Secretary- Treasurer's letter) for a reply, or for appearing in person before the Council if the Member so requests, the Council, providing not less than seven are agreed, shall have power to remove such Member's name from the List of Members. The name of an Honorary Fellow may be removed from the List of Members by the Council if it is considered that the qualification for such Fellowship has been lost. 10. The government of the Society, and the direction of its concerns, shall be entrusted to a governing body, known as the Council, which shall consist of the following, to be elected from among the Members of the Society:-- The President, who shall hold office for five years and shall, at the end of that period, be ineligible for immediate re-election. One or more Vice-Presidents, but not exceeding five in number, each of whom shall hold office for five years and be eligible for immediate re-election on expiry of this period. The Editor of the " Avicultural Magazine ", who shall hold office for five years, and be eligible for immediate re-election on expiry of this period. The Honorary Secretary-Treasurer, who shall hold office for five years, and be eligible for immediate re-election on expiry of this period. The Assistant Secretary, who shall hold office for five years, and be eligible for immediate re-election on expiry of this period. Fifteen other members, each of whom shall serve for five years and shall, at the end of that period, be ineligible for immediate re-election. Nominations to serve on the Council other than nominations by the Council itself shall be in writing and in the form approved by the Council from time to time, such form providing for a proposer and seconder and the signature of the nominee expressing his willingness to serve if appointed and to be delivered to the Honorary Secretary not later than 1st October in any year for vacancies in the year following. All appointments to the Council and elections of Officers of the Society shall be made by and at the absolute discretion of the Council. An Officer of the Society may hold an appointment together with that of President or Vice- President at the same time. 11. The Council shall have power to terminate the period of office of the Editor of the " Avicultural Magazine ", or of the Honorary Secretary-Treasurer, or the Assistant Secretary at any time by giving twelve months' notice, or by giving shorter notice if they deem an earlier change to be imperative, and any of these Officers is expected to give the Council twelve months' notice of an intention to resign before the expiration of the period for which such Officer was elected.

12. In the event of a vacancy occurring in the office of Editor of the " Avicultural Magazine ", or in that of the Honorary Secretary-Treasurer, or in that of the Assistant Secretary, the Council shall have power to appoint an Acting Editor, or Acting Honorary Secretary-Treasurer, or Acting Assistant Secretary, as the case may be, to serve until a new election can be made. At the expiration of the term of five years in every case it shall be competent for the Council to nominate the same Officer (except the President) or another Member, for a further term of five years, unless a second candidate be proposed by not less than twenty-five Members of at least two years' standing. Such proposal, duly signed and containing the written consent of the nominee to serve, if elected, in the capacity for which he is proposed, must reach the Honorary Secretary-Treasurer on or before 1st September. 13. If any Member of the Council does not attend a meeting for two years in succession the Council shall have power to elect another Member in his place. 14. The Editor shall have an absolute discretion as to what matter shall be published in the Magazine (subject to the control of the Council). 15. The Honorary Secretary-Treasurer and the Editor shall respectively refer all matters of doubt or difficulty to the Council. 16. The Council may appoint sub-committees for particular purposes. Member- ship of such sub-committees shall be restricted to Members of the Society, but not necessarily to members of the Council. The Council shall designate the Chairman and the Secretary of each sub-committee. The President, or a Vice-President in his absence, may attend any meeting of a sub-committee, but shall not have a vote unless he has been appointed a member of that sub-committee. 17. The Council (but not a committee of the Council) shall have power to alter and add to the Rules, from time to time, in any manner they may think fit. 1 Sr Should a Member wish any matter to be brought before the Council direct such matter should be sent to the Honorary Secretary-Treasurer with a letter request- ing that it be brought before the Council at the next meeting. 19. Seven Members of the Council shall form a quorum at any meeting, and no business shall be transacted unless such a quorum is present. A decision of a majority of the Council shall be final and conclusive in all matters. 20. The Council shall have power to expel any Member from the Society at any time without assigning any reason.

Members shall be those persons from any country interested in aviculture, elected in the manner prescribed. Life Members shall be those Ordinary Members who have compounded their annual subscriptions. Honorary Life Members shall be those Ordinary Members who have had an unbroken membership for fifty years (after which they shall not be required to pay any further annual subscriptions): or those Ordinary Members who have rendered signal service to the Society. Honorary Fellows shall be aviculturists elected on grounds of high distinction in the subject or in services contributing to its advancement. Whenever the context or meaning requires it, words implying the singular shall imply the plural, and male-female, and vice versa.
algorithms.sectionHeader: AWARDS The Society's Awards THE SOCIETY'S MEDAL
algorithms.bodyText: (Instituted 1 st November , 1896 )

The Medal may be awarded at the discretion of the Council to any Member who shall succeed in breeding, in the United Kingdom, any species of bird which shall not, in the opinion of the Council, be known to have been previously bred in captivity in Great Britain or Northern Ireland. Any Member wishing to obtain the Medal must send a detailed account for publication in the Magazine within about eight weeks from the date of hatching of the young, and furnish such evidence of the facts as the Council may require. The Medal will be awarded only in cases where the young shall live to be old enough to feed themselves, and to be wholly independent of their parents. The question of awarding a Medal for the breeding of local races or sub-species of species that have already been bred shall be at the discretion of the Council. No Medal can be given for the breeding of hybrids. The account of the breeding must be reasonably full so as to afford instruction to our Members, and must appear in the Avicultural Magazine before it is published or notified elsewhere. It should describe the plumage of the young, and be of value as a permanent record of the nesting and general habits of the species. These points will have great weight when the question of awarding the Medal is under consideration. In every case the decision of the Council shall be final.

The President's Medal was instituted in 1955, to enable the Council to confer conspicuous honour on those Members whom it might from time to time consider deserving of special honour at the hands of the Society.

The Knobel Award was instituted in i960. It will be awarded from time to time, at the discretion of the Council, to Members of the Society resident overseas, for breeding successes meriting special recognition. THE EVELYN DENNIS MEMORIAL AWARD The Evelyn Dennis Memorial Award was instituted in 1962. It will be awarded from time to time, at the discretion of the Council, to Members of the Society for an outstanding contribution to aviculture.

The Certificate of Merit was instituted in i960. It will be awarded from time to time, at the discretion of the Council, to Zoological Societies, Pheasant and Waterfowl Trusts, etc., in recognition of meritorious success in breeding and rearing birds in captivity.

algorithms.bodyText: 'STIMULITE' NECTAR FOOD is a COMPLETE NUTRI- TIONAL food in highly concentrated form. It is highly beneficial to alllivestock, whether it be Humming Birds, Sun Birds or other Nectarines, Insectivorous Birds, Fruit- eaters, Canaries, Finches, Parrakeets, Parrots, or any kind of animal. This supreme food should be available to them at all times. Recently there has been some advocacy of a sugar and protein diet for Humming Birds, such a diet is very deficient in nutritional value. PROTEIN is produced within the body by METABOLISM from the nutrients in the food consumed. A diet, to be fully nutritional, has to contain all the essential vitamins. A, D, E, C, and the full vitamin B Complex, Bl, B2, B6, B12 (known as the animal-protein factor), the full context contains Thiamin, Riboflavine, Nicotinic Acid, Pantothenic Acid, Pyridoxine, Folic Acid, Inositol, Choline and Biotin. Only a food containing all of these can be termed COMPLETE. Metabolism can only convert the food into protein if the food also contains the following amino acids : Arginine, Histidine, Lysine, Trypotophane, Phenylalanine, Methionine, Leucine, Isoleucine and Valine. All these factors are necessary for a fully nutritional food, they are not hearsay, but SCIENTIFIC FACTS which can be verified.

(Chlorophonia flavirostris ) By Mrs. K. M. Scamell (Newdigate, Surrey, England) This rare Chlorophonia is found in Ecuador with possibly a subspecies i Colombia. However, in The Birds of Colombia , by Meyer de Schauen- ;e, P- 353, a hen from Colombia is described together with a cock from cuador, as no male specimen appears to have been collected in the former Duntry. The descriptions given are as follows: Length 4 in. S Head, throat, chest and sides of body, back, wings and tail bright green, upper back crossed by a broad yellow collar. Lower breast and belly yellow, separated from the green of the breast by a narrow chestnut band. Iris white, bill yellow or salmon, legs salmon. 9 Bright grass green, centre of breast, abdomen and the under tail- coverts bright yellow. Bill reddish brown, feet and legs reddish yellow. Iris white. We were fortunate in buying a cock bird from a London dealer last May id, as can be seen from the coloured photograph, it corresponds with the )ove description. Incidentally, the photograph was taken on one of iose very wet days last June by a visitor from Sweden, a Mr. Thomas . M. Brosset from Gothenburg. The bird is not unlike a miniature irrot and has a penetrating whistle when it wants to attract attention, irticularly if it is hungry. We had the greatest difficulty in weaning it om the banana diet it came over on from Ecuador. It spent the summer onths alone in a small aviary, but it feels the cold and we have now caged in our conservatory where the minimum temperature is about 55 0 F. has now (late November) almost completed its moult, and though I itered it for the National Exhibition of Cage Birds at Alexandra Palace, doubted if its feathering would be completed in time for the Show. I feed this little bird on the same diet I give to about a dozen of the ore delicate softbills such as Manakins and Festive Tanagers, and as I ive now modified the recipe and method of preparation since I mentioned A

MRS. N. HOWARD--BREEDING THE CERAM ECLECTUS PARROT it in my report in the Magazine, on " Breeding Festive Tanagers ", I give this briefly below: For one day's requirements for 12 small birds, I use oz. each of finely minced lean heart meat, tomato, pureed carrot, dried breadcrumbs or rusks and minced Fdam cheese. I do all the mincing in a Moulinette and stir in the breadcrumbs and cheese into the wet ingredients with a fork, adding i\ teasponfuls of Gerval-Protein or Super Hydramin. I then add 1 diced small sweet apple and 1 diced pear plus about a dozen cut-up grapes. The whole batch is divided between the morning and evening feeds, the latter being held in a domestic fridge until required. No live food is given.

(Lorius roratus roratus) By Mrs. N. Howard (Codsall Wood, Wolverhampton, England) My pair of the Ceram race of the Eclectus Parrot (Lorius roratus roratus ) differ from the New Guinea or Red-sided race (L. r. pectoralis ), of which I have two pairs, in aspects of both behaviour and appearance. The Ceram birds are very shy and also very docile and can be handled safely. The hen is brilliant red on head and neck, with a band of 2 to 3 in. of rich lightish blue across the breast and continued round the back of the neck as a collar. The wings, back and rest of the bird are a deep maroon. The cock is rich green, less red on the sides than the Red-sided race, black under the tail and with the whole body faintly washed with black. The birds were given plain canary seed, paddy rice, sunflower seed, millet spray, together with sweet ripe pears and grapes. In general the) are rather different feeders to other Eclectus Parrots. The cock eats onl) plain canary, the hen white sunflower and paddy rice, and both eat a large amount of fruit. I would say they are 75% fruit-eaters. They were housed in an aviary with a brick-built heated house and 2 long outside flight. A nest-box was given them, placed on a platforir near the roof. It was roughly made of 1 in. wood, placed on its side ant not upright, and was 2 ft. long, 13 in. high and 12 in. wide, with the usual round hole. I had this pair for six years. In 1966 the hen laid two clear eggs ir January and again in May, but in September two chicks were hatched but died at the age of six weeks. In 1967 the pattern was similar unti. August, when one chick was hatched but died at eight weeks. In 196^ she again laid clear eggs in January and April. Very little notice was taker after this until July when she was again sitting on two eggs. On 24th Jul) one chick hatched, and the second the next day.
algorithms.reference: MRS. N. HOWARD--BREEDING THE CERAM ECLECTUS PARROT
algorithms.bodyText: After the earlier failures I had little hopes of rearing them but decided to Iter the feeding. Having a very large garden of fresh sweet garden peas I ecided to give these in great quantities, after having tried all the other reen food and found that they would not eat it. They took these, and Iso had their usual amount of ripe pears and grapes and seed. The hicks made very good progress, growing rapidly and feathering quickly, dy trouble then began when the garden peas were finished. I knew rom past experience that pomegranates were required. They were not et available from our shops, but a large London store obtained a supply 3 r me and my troubles ended. The male chick was out of the nest at even weeks, followed by the female in a few days, neither entering the nest gain. The nest-box was removed after a few days to make more room on the latform for the chicks and the hen. The male bird was fully feathered, nd with flight feathers, at eleven weeks. Both were feeding themselves y this time. The food supplied was boiled Patna rice with milk and agar added, half a pound of grapes, three pomegranates, one large ripe ear, two millet sprays, two morning coffee sweet biscuits, and one cob of weet corn. The cock chick is rather shy, but the hen chick is just the averse. It was evident from very early on that the chicks were a pair, le skin of the hen chick being a different colour from that of the cock, and i first feather it is the same colour as the hen. At the time of writing they re flying. As described, Mrs. N. Howard has bred the Ceram Eclectus Parrot Lorius roratus roratus). It is believed that this may be a first success, .ny member or reader knowing of a previous breeding of this subspecies 1 Great Britain or Northern Ireland is requested to communicate at once ith the Hon. Secretary.
algorithms.sectionHeader: 4 ALAN LENDON--THE BLUE-CHEEKED ROSELLA THE BLUE-CHEEKED ROSELLA--A NEW BIRD IN AUSTRALIAN AVICULTURE
algorithms.bodyText: By Alan Lendon (Adelaide, Australia) This bird, which nowadays is generally considered to be a well-defined race or subspecies of the well-known Pale-headed or Mealy Rosella, if correctly designated Platycercus adscitus adscitus , as the original description of the species by Latham in 1790 was from a bird considered by Gregory Mathews to have been collected at Cooktown in northern Queensland. Consequently, the better known race, originally described and depicted by Lear in 1832, is correctly labelled P. a. palliceps. Subsequent descriptions of the blue-cheeked bird as amathusiae by Bonaparte in 1850 and as cyanogenys by Gould in 1855 are invalid, although reasonably appropriate, The range of the species extends from the northern extremity of Cape York Peninsula throughout most of eastern Queensland and across the border into north-eastern New South Wales; on the western side of the Great Dividing Range it comes south approximately as far as a line joining Moree and Inverell, whilst on the coast it reaches the Clarence River Whether there is a gradual and imperceptible transition from the northerr race to the southern, or whether there is a gap in the distribution or < sharply defined change as apparently occurs between the two races of th( Eastern Rosella (P. eximius ), the writer has been unable to ascertain Keast refers to an isolate in the Bowen area (lat. 20 *) but the source of this statement has not been discovered. However, the blue-cheeked certainl) comes as far south as Mareeba and probably to Cardwell (lat. 8*), whik the southern race goes north at least to latitude 21 0 and probably further Gould figured the Blue-cheeked in his Supplement to the Birds Oj Australia (pi. 63), whilst a lovely plate by Roland Green in Mathews Birds of Australia (Vol. 6, pi. 304, p. 338) depicts typical examples of botl races. The Emu (Vol. XXX, pi. 14, p. 81) published a plate by Nevilk Cayley showing both sexes of the common race and a male of the northern It is worthy of note that, in northern New South Wales where th< ranges of the Pale-headed (P. a. palliceps ) and the Golden-mantled (P eximius cecilae ) Rosellas overlap, hybridization occurs to a considerabl< degree. The relationship between the two races is best described as similar t( that between the Eastern Rosella (P. eximius eximius ) and its Golden mantled subspecies (P. e. cecilae , formerly splendidus ). The Blue-cheeke( differs from the southern form in at least four important respects. Firstly the margins of the mantle feathers are a creamy yellow colour, peculiarly suffused with pale blue, as opposed to the golden yellow of the bette known race. Secondly, the cheek patches are, as the vernacular nam< implies, almost entirely blue, rather than white with a blue lower border Thirdly, the upper breast and sides of the neck are pale yellow to a variable extent as against uniform blue. Finally, the rump is yellowish-blu<

athcr than bluish-green. Seen side by side, males of the two races look o be closely allied but different birds. Females of the blue-cheeked race iave noticeably smaller bills and rounder heads and are appreciably luller in most colours. The first occasion that I saw this species in life was in February 1955, vhen there were three adult birds in the collection of Sir Edward Hallstrom' ^.t that time he was uncertain of their identity and thought that they ould have been hybrids between the Pale-headed and the Northern losella [P. venustus ). Sir Edward successfully bred this variety on a jreat many occasions thereafter, almost certainly the first recorded ireeding anywhere. The author acquired an immature pair of these birds early in 1965; hey were in rough plumage and very timid, obviously recently trapped, hey took some time to quieten down but eventually did so and moulted ito fine plumage. It was not until they were moved to new aviaries in the Adelaide Hills in 1966 that they showed any disposition to go to nest. >aying was commenced in the spring, the male having previously been xtremely attentive to the female, offering her regurgitated food almost on-stop. It is estimated that between eight and ten eggs were laid in an bliquely-hung log, but each was broken after two or three days. The log \0x25A0 as then moved and suspended in a vertical position, whereupon five more ggs were laid and incubated very closely by the female. Of this clutch, nly one egg hatched after an incubation period of approximately twenty ays; when the remaining eggs were removed, one was found to contain a illy developed embryo, another a partially developed one and the other no were infertile. Between four and five weeks after hatching, the young ird left the nest; it appeared certainly a hen by the size and shape of the ead and this subsequently proved to be correct. Its immature plumage as merely a considerably duller version of the adult; it was observed to ave a bath on the third day after leaving the nest and appeared independent fits parents in about two weeks. Adult plumage was attained by a partial loult at about the age of five to six months and it was shortly afterwards iven to a friend who had an unmated male; however, it succeeded in reaping, and if it has survived it is probably producing unattractive yhrids mated to an Adelaide Rosella ( P . adelaidae) male! In the spring of 1967* the old pair hatched three young which survived >r about a fortnight and were then found dead one morning with full \0x25A0ops; it is thought that the hen may have ceased brooding and a cold ight ensued. A second clutch later the same season was deserted when ie lid of the log somehow became detached; three eggs contained embryos 1 the point of hatching. This subspecies has become quite common in local aviculture in recent iars and has bred freely in the eastern states. The Adelaide Zoo has "ed it successfully on several occasions, but I am not aware of any other iccess in South Australia to date.
algorithms.sectionHeader: 6 T. S. THOMSON--BREEDING THE PURPLE-HEADED GLOSSY STARLING BREEDING THE PURPLE-HEADED GLOSSY STARLING
algorithms.bodyText: (Lamprocolius purpureiceps) By T. S. Thomson (Hoole, Cheshire, England) I had kept Purple-headed Glossy Starlings (.Lamprocolius purpureiceps) liberty in the past and they were an obvious selection for including ir controlled liberty experiments involving several other species. Thre< Starlings were purchased in the late summer of 1967 an d housed in ar unheated aviary together with Zebra Finches, Silverbills, Firefinches Cordon Bleus, Spice Birds, Tri-coloured Nuns, Orange Weavers anc Red-eared Waxbills. No aggressiveness was noticed. The aviary flight was 40 ft. x 12 ft. and the shelter 40 ft. x 7 ft-, th< flight opening into a 70 ft. x 7* ft- compartment which was also cultivate! as a vegetable garden. T he birds were given access to this latter breeding compartment in February, all nest-boxes and nesting sites having beer fixed therein, and a flock of 50 Budgerigars from an adjacent aviary wen also released into this compartment. I did not consider the Starlings to be tame. They did not take meal worms from the hand as had some of their predecessors. The three kep together through the winter but in early spring one bird tended to keej apart on its own, and the first indication of any breeding inclination wa an attack by one of the pair on the third bird, which was removed after second attack occurred. The cultivation of the garden necessitated spells of duty in this aviar compartment and I was pleasantly surprised to discover that the Gloss; Starlings had a nest with two eggs, a third being added later. 1 he egg were mottled all over and like a Blackbird's in colour, but more rounde< in shape. The hen Starling continually left the nest when the aviary was entered I expected more eggs and did not realize that incubation was in progress On most occasions when the hen returned to the nest she carried a piece 0 leaf, frequently dead brittle laurel leaf. This was used as a nest lining Pear leaf in the green state was also used and this practice continued unt the young were nearly a week old. The nest was built in a lovebird-size nest-box, dried grasses forming a shallow cup-shaped cavity in about 6 ii of this material. There may have been some grasses in the box before th Starlings started building. The Starlings ignored Zebra Finches nesting 6 ft. away and a Budgeriga occupying a box 9 ft. from the Starlings' nest; no harrying of near neigb bours was observed. Unlike the British Starlings nesting in an adjoinin aviary, only the hen Glossy incubated the eggs.

T. S. THOMSON--BREEDING THE PURPLE-HEADED GLOSSY STARLING J The Glossy Starlings had wintered with a staple diet of Haith's Softbill Dod plus over-ripe apples, no live food being offered. Maggots are bred n the premises from early spring and supplies were available to feed the en on leaving the nest during the incubation period. About 20 maggots time were taken. A pair of Blackbirds were rearing a family at this eriod and it was found best to feed the maggots to the hen Glossy on her wn. The nest-box was occasionally inspected. The cock bird voiced his bjection to such intrusions, especially after the young hatched, with arsh cries and sometimes would make a pass at human intruders. The first indication of eggs having hatched came when the hen carried a ingle maggot to the nest. For the first few days only one maggot at a time /as taken, this being first beaten on the perch by the hen. The young /ere a few days old before the cock started feeding and from then on he did ally 50% of the work. Two young hatched together and the third fully day later. The latter never caught up with the two nestmates, there eing a slight difference in size right up to fledging. The young were five days old when the entire roof of the 70 ft. x 70 ft. reeding compartment was removed. One advantage of liberating birds rom such an extensive area is the fact that they are well equipped for free ight. The timing of this operation is governed by the state of nesting of le various species. Weather conditions also have a bearing on the nnual liberation involving over 100 birds. If there had been the slightest doubt about losing the Starlings on beration, the cock bird could have been confined to an adjacent aviary, ^ith normal methods of release where an exit/entrance is made in the viary netting, it might be prudent to either train the cock or hen first, fis depending on the species. Before liberation the Starlings used to search the vegetable garden, nding various forms of live food to supplement the ever-present bowl of laggots. At this time the home-produced supply of mealworms was at low ebb, only a few per day being available. On liberation the Starlings Don found craneflies in the lawn and foraged systematically in neigh- ouring gardens. A local sports ground with acres of close-mown grass rovided welcome supplies of live food. A supply of mealworms was purchased, but with the young making ood progress the parents were encouraged to forage for themselves, lowever, they were given maggots and mealworms in the evenings, the >rmer being ignored if sufficient mealworms were offered. About 50 to 00 per evening were taken in billfuls of 12 to 15 a time. Mealworms ere arranged in the beak as regularly as the teeth of a comb. The lealworms in larvae form were preferred to the pupae. The parents were ctive late in the day. A few large brown moths were also found and on ire occasions a medium-sized earthworm would be included in a beakful f live food. The Starlings would swoop down from trees to take large

8 T. S. THOMSON--BREEDING THE PURPLE-HEADED GLOSSY STARLING spiders thrown down on a concrete path. Various beetles, woodlice and earwigs were also taken, but such offerings formed an insignificant proportion of the amount of live food collected by the birds themselves. They also sampled ripe strawberries and other fruits, but only live food was fed to the young up to and immediately after fledging. The parents usually alighted io to 20 ft. from the nest-box, and after surveying the area made one or two bounds to the nest. Prior to fledging, the young were fed at the entrance without the parents entering the box. The young frequently called in the nest and flapped their wings in practice for flight. The two advanced young left the nest and followed their parents about. The third youngster was heard to call for prolonged periods, and with the cock Starling only making infrequent visits to the nest-box it was decided to supplement his efforts by hand-feeding. The hungry young one readily accepted mealworms but was not so keen on maggots. Bantam eggs were hardboiled daily for young Pheasants, and the young Starling consumed half an egg per day. The eyes of the young were dark with no trace of the parents' brilliant yellow. At the time of writing, the young are four months old, the irides are gradually turning light grey. In the nest the wings and tail were glossy while the head and body feathering was dull. At three months the first glossy feathering appeared in the head and body. Nest sanitation was first class compared with the native species. The hen Starling regularly deposited the faeces on top of a liberty Budgerigar nest-box about 100 ft. from the nest. A month after fledging, the two young, now self-supporting but still flying with the parents, were caught up. They were wild compared with the part hand-reared young one, which is now very tame. During their month of free flying the young rarely entered the aviary proper with their parents. Softbill food, with mealworms and maggots mixed in, was placed in the shelter in an effort to accustom the young to aviary conditions. All roosted somewhere beyond the garden, and with Tawny Owls always active, and the need to " domesticate " the young, the confinement to the aviary could not be prolonged. This no doubt ruled out any hope of a second round. The " catching up " and " domestication " of birds bred at liberty is an essential part of the controlled liberty cycle. Our native species of Starling has been bred by me for eleven years by a combination of the liberty system and normal aviary conditions, the main object being to study the stamina of the species after breeding for several generations from aviary-bred stock. Future plans must now include the building up of a strain of the Purple-headed Glossy Starling on the lines practised with the British species. The controlled liberty system offers possibilities of establishing strains of various foreign species.
algorithms.sectionHeader: KERRY MULLER-RAISING THE CRESTED WOOD PARTRIDGE
RAISING THE CRESTED WOOD PARTRIDGE AT THE NATIONAL ZOOLOGICAL PARK
algorithms.bodyText: (Rollulus roulroul) By Kerry Muller (Washington, D.C., U.S.A.) On 12th August 1965 we received two female Crested Green Wood Partridges (Rollulus roulroul), commonly called " Roulrouls ", for the collection at the National Zoo. We were delighted to acquire these, as they are rather uncommon and valuable in captivity and one of the most beautiful of all the game birds. The male has a red fan crest, red legs, dark chestnut wings, black body plumage and a white fore-crown, while the female, with her bright green head and body and light chestnut wings, is equally attractive. Both sexes have a bare red patch surrounding the eyes. Having received the two females we made every effort to obtain a male, and in July 1966 we finally obtained a fine wild-caught male from Malaya. At first he was very wild and shy; however, he soon settled down with one of the females, ignoring the other completely. These birds were housed in an L-shaped indoor exhibit that is approxi- mately 10 x 20 x 8 ft. high. Within the cage or aviary is a small shallow pool and the aviary itself is heavily planted with bamboo and semi-tropical plants. Housed with the Roulrouls were several other Malaysian birds, including Bulbuls, Babblers, a Shama Thrush, Fairy Bluebirds, a male Black-breasted Rain Quail and a Hooded Pitta. After the birds had paired they exhibited an increased activity, searching the plantings and aviary floor for small twigs that they moved from place to place. At this time the female began laying eggs indiscriminately about the aviary, and these were removed and placed in our electric incubator. To aid the female in her nesting activities we added pine needles to the floor. These are obtained by the bale and are used for mulch in various aviaries. The needles were readily accepted, and she soon had constructed a substantial nest that was shaped roughly like a hemisphere, with an entrance hole on one side just wide enough to admit the hen. When the hen is sitting she is very difficult to observe, as she often partially blocks the entrance hole with pine needles. Also, when she leaves the nest she covers the eggs with pine needles and feathers. One rather spherical white egg is deposited daily, the average clutch ranging from 4 to 6 eggs. The eggs that were placed in the incubator (at a temperature of 99*5* F. and a relative humidity of 85*) hatched in 22 days, and all the young emerged strong and active. When the Roulrouls began manifesting nesting activity I started searching the available literature at my disposal for information dealing with raising Roulrouls in captivity, and was unable to find any account on this subject;
algorithms.sectionHeader: KERRY MULLER--RAISING THE CRESTED WOOD PARTRIDGE
algorithms.bodyText: therefore, I was forced to develop my own methods, which I will pass on to the reader in case he (or she) finds himself in a similar situation. When the parents hatch their own eggs and are allowed to raise the young, they do an outstanding job. We have never lost a young bird left with the parents. After hatching, the male assumes an equal role in domestic duties and usually half the young will be under his care. The parents are very solicitous of the young and are constantly offering them bits of food in their beaks. The young instinctively look for food from their parents' beaks and do not normally seek food from the ground until the fifth day. The parents are very courageous in the defence of their young, par- ticularly the male, and any other bird approaching within 3 feet will be immediately driven off. All young Roulrouls are fed the following twice daily: Game Bird Startena (Purina) mixed with A & D feeding oil, " mockingbird mix ", ground cooked egg, chopped greens, finch seed mix and mealworms. The primary diet for the first five days is mealworms, then they begin to consume egg and Game Bird Startena. In addition, the adults get a small amount of chopped fruit, bread-and-milk mix and ground raw meat. In contrast to the success we have had in raising young Roulrouls left with their parents, we have found that the road to hand-raising them is beset with several difficulties. The young are removed from the incubator when they are completely dry and placed in a 3 ft. square brooder by themselves. We have found we must try and imprint the newly-hatched Roulrouls to our hand, as they must be hand fed for the first five days and will not pick up food normally from the ground. If they are put with other species of baby game birds, such as pheasants or chickens, they will invariably try to feed from the bills of the other young birds and con- sequently starve to death. This would probably be true also of a foster parent such as a bantam hen. We have found that several young hatched together do much better than a single chick, as there is some competition to see which one will get the food first when proffered by the fingers, and this tends to stimulate feeding within the group. It is very difficult to hand-raise a single bird; they just seem to fade away. When we tried to put newly-hatched young with those already hatched a week or more, the older birds would often pick on the younger ones. We had very good luck in introducing newly-hatched young to parent birds who had hatched young themselves within a 36-hour period of the incubator-hatched ones. The incubator-hatched young, not yet im- printed, blended perfectly into the family group within 30 minutes. All parent birds accepted incubator-hatched young readily. As soon as the incubator young had settled into the brooder and began feeding from the hand, we began offering them bits of Game Bird Startena and ground cooked egg, as well as mealworms. On the fifth day they
algorithms.sectionHeader: KERRY MULLER--RAISING THE CRESTED WOOD PARTRIDGE 11
algorithms.bodyText: should begin eating the food mixture from the feed pan, and the quantity of mealworms must be curtailed sharply, for the birds are very susceptible to dietary upsets at this age as well as from 9 to 14 days. This does not seem to hold true for young reared by the parents, who perhaps induce them to eat a wider variety of food as well as to get a great deal more exercise. We initially start the brooder young at 90* F., and after a week lower the temperature to 8o* F. At two weeks it is lowered to 75 0 F. They should not be kept at a lower temperature until grown, and even the adults prefer 75 0 F. or above. When first hatched the young are surprisingly large in relation to the egg. This is due, in part, to a good covering of down with which they are well endowed. In colour they are a combination of black and dark brown with flesh- coloured beak and legs. The eyes are black. A complete description is as follows: Median line of forehead and crown, superciliary line, lores, eye ring, front of eyeline, sides of nape, rump, sides of breast and shoulders are black. Sides of crown, auricular area, back of eyeline, rear of nape and back are dark brown. Throat, belly and vent are lighter brown, shading to dark on the sides. At five days the primaries are beginning to show; by seven days they are well grown and the secondaries and wing coverts are showing. These have a chestnut distal half and a darker brown base, which gives the appearance of barring when the wings are closed. When the chicks are two weeks old they begin to assume their first plumage. This closely resembles the female, with the exception of the lower breast and belly that are a dull black with greenish tones. At this age the two sexes can be differentiated by the colour of the wings: The female's wings are a light chestnut brown; in the males, the brown is a darker shade. The young partridges retain this colouring through the age of about 12 weeks and then begin to attain the adult plumage. At this time they should be removed from their parents, as the adult male will often try to kill the young cocks. The first year, we hatched 25 young and raised 17 to maturity. This season we have hatched 24 young and raised 22 to maturity. The sex ratio has been almost even. I hope to see this beautiful species become well established in captivity. There can be no more beautiful and pleasing game bird in any collection, and with the ever-increasing human population expanding into the remain- ing wild areas of the world, the time is rapidly approaching when these birds and many others will no longer be available to aviculturists from the wild. Upon the aviculturists falls the task of either successfully establish- ing and maintaining the species or losing them for the aviculturists of the future.
algorithms.address: 12 C. R. EDDINGER--HAND-RAISING PASSERINE BIRDS IN HAWAII
algorithms.sectionHeader: EXPERIENCES WITH HAND-RAISING PASSERINE BIRDS IN HAWAII
algorithms.author: By C. Robert Eddinger
algorithms.affiliation: (Department of Zoology, University of Hawaii, Honolulu, Hawaii, U.S.A.)
algorithms.bodyText: During the three years that I have lived in Hawaii I have hand-raised seven species of passerine birds: House-Finch ( Carpodacus mexicanus frontalis ), House-Sparrow ( Passer domesticus ), Ricebird ( Lonchura punctulata ), White-eye ( Zosterops palpebrosus japonicus), Common Myna ( Acridotheres tristis ), Brazilian Cardinal ( Paroaria cucullata ), and Hawaii 'Amakihi ( Loxops v. virens). All but the last named are species that have been introduced into the Hawaiian Islands. The 'Amakihi is a bird found only in the Hawaiian Islands, belonging to the endemic family of Hawaiian Honeycreepers (Drepanididae). An excellent discussion of the advantages of working with hand-raised birds and suggestions for the diets and aviary maintenance of insectivorous birds in captivity are provided by Berger {The Jack Pine Warbler, 44: ^ 5 ~ 7 2 " 1966). It was under Dr. A. J. Berger's supervision and through his constant encouragement that the following experience was gained. Obtaining and Handling the Birds The campus of the University of Hawaii provides an excellent habitat for the breeding activities of many of Hawaii's introduced birds. The six species of introduced birds that I hand-raised were all from nests on cam- pus. The Hawaii 'Amakihi were collected by Dr. Berger from two nests taken in his study area on the slopes of Mauna Kea on the island of Hawaii. " The optimum age for most passerines would seem to be the age at which the feathers are beginning to unsheathe and before the fear reaction develops " (Berger, op. cit.). The optimum age will, of course, vary with the species. I collected House-Finches, House-Sparrows, Ricebirds and White-eyes that were half-feathered. These birds gaped readily and showed no fear reaction. Mynas and Brazilian Cardinals that were half- feathered, however, had already developed the fear reaction and would not gape. Because Mynas are common on campus, I have had the oppor- tunity to do more work with them. If the fear reaction has developed in the nestling Myna, the bird will just sit there and starve. I tried various means to elicit the gaping response, including simulated figures of the adult birds. I found nothing to overcome this fear reaction in the Myna. 1 he Brazilian Cardinal also develops the fear reaction before it is half- feathered, and is best taken from the nest when the feathers are just beginning to unsheathe. The 'Amakihi that I hand-raised were about half-feathered when collected and gaped readily.
algorithms.reference: C. R. EDDINGER--HAND-RAISING PASSERINE BIRDS IN HAWAII
algorithms.bodyText: A good test before collecting is to tap on the nest lightly with your finger and make a " squeak ". If the birds gape readily, then you are in luck: if they crouch down in the nest, then, if possible, select a nest with younger nestlings. I have tried force-feeding Mynas, and it is a tiresome and often unrewarding experience. Some birds will gape after being force-fed once, but more often the force-feeding must be continued. I found it best to collect the nest itself, or, if hand-raising only a few of the nestlings, to place them in an old nest. The young settle down in the nest, can be fed easily, maintain good nest sanitation, and remain in the nest until approximately normal fledging time. I put the nest and the young nestlings into a small box that could be covered at night. With the box on my desk, I could go about my other work while caring for the birds. Because I was attending lectures and teaching laboratories, it usually was necessary for me to carry the nestlings with me so that they could be fed when hungry. I carried the nestlings in a plastic lunch-bucket which also contained feeding forceps and a small container of prepared diet. The lunch-bucket could be closed after feeding and the nestlings would then settle down in the nest. I agree with Berger (op. cit.) that the birds should be fed on a demand schedule. When a bird is hungry it will give a food call and gape. The demand schedule must be learned for each species. Some birds, as the White-eyes, will eat only a little at a time but must be fed often. My White-eyes demanded food every 8 to 10 minutes during part of the nestling period. Other birds, as the Myna, may eat more at a time and go longer between feedings. My Mynas demanded food only once every two hours. The food must be placed deep in the bird's throat to trigger the swallowing reflex. Older nestlings and fledglings may grab the food from the feeding forceps. The birds may be conditioned to a specific whistle, " squeak ", or other noise to induce gaping. The birds early learn to recognize the person who is feeding them. After one or more of the young birds fledged, I placed their nest in a small cage supplied with perches and adequate room for the birds to take short flights (some of the birds returned to the nest at night). The small cage enabled me to reach the birds easily for hand-feeding. I placed small feeding cups near the perches, and hand-fed the fledglings from the feeding cups. As the fledglings developed they would fly to the feeding cups and peck at the food. When the birds became independent they were transferred into an aviary. Even after the birds have become completely independent they show a definite responsiveness to their foster parent. The fear characteristic of most wild birds that have been caught as adults and caged is lacking in hand-raised birds. The hand-reared birds go about their normal activities in close proximity to the observer. Herein lies the joy of hand- rearing.
algorithms.address: 14 P. HADDOCK--HYBRID LESSON'S X TURQUOISE-RUMPED PARROTLETS
algorithms.bodyText: Very little has been published on diets for hand-raising nestling passerine birds in captivity or for keeping the adult birds alive and healthy. I feel that too often the diets used are limited to hamburger or bread soaked in milk. The following table is the result of considerable experi- mentation with various foodstuffs. These diets have been successful for us and we have experienced very low mortality rates.

algorithms.sectionHeader: BREEDING HYBRID LESSON'S x TURQUOISE- RUMPED PARROTLETS
algorithms.bodyText: (Forpus coelestis x F. cyanopygius) By P. Haddock (Ellesmere Port, Cheshire, England) I introduced a male Lesson's Parrotlet (Forpus coelestis ) and female Turquoise-rumped Parrotlet (F. cyanopygius) into a small aviary 8 ft. x z\ ft. x 6 ft. with a small adjoining shelter, which already housed two pair of Budgerigars. The aviary was situated in a backyard, since at the moment I have no garden. The Parrotlets appeared to ignore the Budgerigars. In the aviary shelter I had placed three Budgerigar nest- boxes, one placed on end with a layer of peat covering the bottom. After some eight weeks the cock Parrotlet started occasionally feeding the hen,

and mating on the perches was observed twice. Both the Parrotlets refused to allow the Budgerigar hens to enter any nest-boxes to lay, and I removed all the Budgerigars. The hen Parrotlet laid four eggs and started incubation on approxi- mately 27th July. I did not see the hen again for three weeks, the only proof of her existence being the cock entering and leaving the box when feeding her, and the droppings present on the plants in the flight. At the end of this period, still not having seen the hen nor heard any chicks, I looked into the nest-box and saw four chicks. The chicks progressed slowly, and the hen was now seen occasionally on hot days. After approximately six weeks three fledglings left the nest (two hens and a cock), one young dying just before fledging. The young were wild and frightened at first, but are now settling down. Three days after the young had left the nest the hen died. I have no idea what was wrong with her. The young went into the nest-boxes to roost at night. I wonder whether the behaviour of the Budgerigars which were present at first may have stimulated the Parrotlets to begin nesting?

(Muscicapa striata) By D. Blacktopp (Cheshunt, Herts., England) This species was bred in an aviary more by accident than design, and I have therefore only a little information on it. The following notes might, however, be helpful to other aviculturists. On 2nd September 1967 two young Spotted Flycatchers [Muscicapa striata ) were brought to me by a park-keeper, having been found in a nest when a tree was felled. I hand-reared them, and during the winter kept them in a birdroom where the temperature was maintained at about 50* F. by a paraffin heater and a tubular electric heater. The fighting was controlled by a time-switch to provide light extending the day from 06.00 to 21.00 hrs., and a dull red bulb remained alight throughout the night. The flycatchers shared the flight with a pair of Common Redstarts (Phoenicurus phoenicurus). In April 1968 the flycatchers were put into an outside aviary which they shared with a pair of Blue-headed Wagtails (Motacilla f. flava). The aviary was one of a row and measured 12 ft. from front to back, 3 ft. in width and 6 ft. 2 in. in height. The rear end and 3 ft. of the sides and 6 ft. of the roof were covered in to form a shelter. This was, however, rather dark inside when the vegetation had grown, and it was difficult to

see what was happening in it. The vegetation included ivy, honeysuckle, bamboo and various low bushes, and the front and top were partly over- grown by a Russian Vine, giving additional cover but partly obscuring the view. In order not to disturb the birds too much they were fed through a feeding hatch in the front of the aviary, the hatch being of sheet metal, and the food being placed on a small shelf behind it, sheltered by a transparent plastic hood. The birds were fed on gentles, " Farex " baby food mixed with milk, "Avivite " soft food, and grated cheese. At intervals they were given a few mealworms. "Abidec " multivitamin drops and " P.Y.M. " yeast preparation were regularly added to the food. A variety of nest- sites were put up in the aviary, both in the shelter and open flight, mainly for the benefit of the wagtails since I did not expect the flycatchers to breed. In May a certain amount of squabbling and bill-snapping was noticed. During a period of a week or more the cock was seen to carry a particular piece of twig about with him; and at the same period he began to spend most of his time at the front of the aviary while the hen kept to the back. Subsequently this became the normal pattern and as a result the absence of the hen during incubation was not immediately apparent. I did not normally enter the aviary, and as long as both the birds were present and fit I left well alone. My fiancee had undertaken most of the feeding of the birds, and during August she told me that the flycatchers were fighting more than usual. On the evening of 7th August I looked in and found to my surprise that two fledged and apparently independent young were being chivvied by the cock. Since the fighting continued I took a chance and removed them to the birdroom, and while in the aviary made a search and found that the nest had been made in an open-fronted box fixed at the very back of the shelter. The nest was composed of a little fine moss, and feathers shed by the wagtails. The two young seemed a little more nervous than the hand-reared parents but settled down to feed independently. At the time of writing both are doing well. As described above D. Blacktopp has bred the Spotted Flycatcher (Muscicapa striata). It is believed it may be the first success. Any member or reader knowing of a previous breeding of this species in Great Britain or Northern Ireland is requested to communicate at once with the Hon Secretary.
