algorithms.sectionHeader: HERBERT MURRAY--BREEDING NOTES--SEASON 1 968 I 7 BREEDING NOTES-SEASON 1968
algorithms.bodyText: By Herbert Murray (Brentwood, Essex, England) The larger tanagers are easy to keep in aviaries, are reasonably hardy, and taken on the whole are easy birds to get to go to nest, although the final result is not always as good as one would expect. I have now managed to breed three species of these larger tanagers, have had partial success with a fourth species and have in addition bred one of the smaller species. In 1968 I bred for the first time the Crimson-backed Tanager (. Rhamphocelus dimidiatus ), which as a possible first breeding has been reported more fully elsewhere in this journal. The other species previously reared were the White-shouldered Black Tanager ( Tachyphonus luctuosus), the Ornate Tanager ( Thraupis ornata ), the Rufous-crowned Tanager ( Tangara cay and), and the partial success was with the Golden-backed Tanager ( T . chrysotis). The following notes on these might be of interest. It will be seen from the above that tanagers are probably as easy as any of the softbills to rear, but there is a great deal of difference in the way the various species behave. The White-winged Black Tanager has been bred several times, and is relatively easy. I bred these birds to the third generation without loss of vigour, but they became increasingly territorially-minded and murderous as they became more domesticated. As they are powerful birds and very swift they can cause a lot of damage in a mixed collection. The hens are fearless of man, and many broods are reared in a year if the birds get the chance. The usual brood is two young, and the great advantage of these birds for aviary breeding is that although they feed their young with mealworms given whole, they will also feed their usual soft food and this is a great help as it varies the diet. When the young of the first brood are self-supporting the parents do not drive them away, but all the birds both old and young stay together. These tanagers are very fond of blowflies. The nest is a rather flimsy affair usually placed in gorse, and the hens are so steady that they never leave the nest when anyone approaches. The Ornate Tanager I have bred to the second generation, and here the rearing and general behaviour of the birds is the same as that of the White- winged Black Tanager. The only real difference that I have seen has been in the fact that my birds built in parakeet boxes. The Golden-backed Tanager is a very lovely bird, and this is a species that I have not managed to rear to maturity, mainly, I think, because the parents would only feed live food to the young. Another interesting breeding I have managed to achieve this year is the Yellow-winged Sugar Bird ( Cyanerpes cyaneus). This bird has been bred a number of times previously, but the breeding took place where I could observe the birds quite closely and the following notes may perhaps be of interest. This breeding also took place in a communal aviary, and

as the cock came up to full breeding condition he became very aggressive and was soon in charge of the planted subtropical aviary. He was very fast and no bird disputed his power. A neat, rather deep, nest was built in a tall-growing fuchsia, and in time two young hatched. The mother worked very hard to feed these youngsters, but the cock was much more interested in showing off and fighting anything that came along. One could be very anthropomorphic here, but I will not labour the point. The length of the beak of the young when small was about the same as in any soft-billed bird, and when the young flew the beak was only about half the length of the adult bird, but the beak grew rapidly and was soon as long as in the adult bird. The coloration of the young is similar to the adult hen, but with rather a grey tinge. Unfortunately one of the young birds has a twisted beak, but it seems to be able to feed itself without any bother. The other young bird is quite normal. A further round of young are due to fly as these notes are being written, but the nest is not easy to observe, and as it just rests on the plant, and as far as I can see is not attached in any way, one cannot pull the plants about much. Both nests were built about 3 ft. from the ground, but I think this is only coincidence as I have had a nest built previously much higher, but here the eggs did not hatch. As with tanagers, the young birds are not driven away when new young are in the nest, but continue to fly about with their parents. The young Sugar Birds were fed mainly on small flies, and it intrigued me very much to see how the hen held these. She would catch a beakful, about six to ten insects, and these would be stowed away neatly as they were captured, the body of the fly being held in the middle of the beak and the wings projecting out of the sides, giving a sort of frill effect. The insects were not bunched together at all, but were spaced evenly up the beak. This sounds easy to do, but how does the bird do it? If one supposes that she is holding five flies which fill the beak to half its length, how does she insert the sixth fly in its place as presumably the first five are being held against the upper mandible by the tongue? It is a pretty problem and I do not know how she does it, but she certainly does. These birds will also feed their normal soft food to the youngsters, which is a big help. It is usually the cock bird that does this, presumably because it is so much less work than hunting. I first saw the young being fed with soft food when about three days old, but such feeding was irregular and probably depended on the number of flies available. Once the young Sugar Birds can fly they are fed a lot of banana. This is picked off the fruit in reasonably large lumps, and stuffed into the young bird. Sugar Birds are amusing to breed, and have been bred a fair number of times, but I think if the birds were in a small aviary it would be necessary to have some good cultures of fruit flies going. My biggest disappointment this year has been with the Purple-bellied Parrot (Triclaria cyanogaster or T. malachitacia). I have two pairs of

these rare and lovely birds which I imported from Brazil about four years ago. In many ways these birds differ from any other South American Parrot I have ever kept. They were tricky to get on to normal food when first imported, but it did not take them long to settle down to a normal diet. I tried to breed these birds in small aviaries in the summer of 1967, but had no success. I decided that this year I would really try to get them to breed. It has always been my experience that birds in individual aviaries spend all the summer trying to get at the nest-box in the next compartment, so for the whole of last winter I left them in a large aviary 48 ft. x 17 ft. containing a number of nest-boxes in different sites. There was a heated shelter in this aviary 8 ft. x 17 ft. The birds spent a great part of the daylight hours in the flight, going in and out of a nest-box that seemed to attract them, but suddenly in February they went to nest in a box in the shelter. This was a relief, since although the birds seemed hardy I did not want the hen to nest outside at that time of the year. To my great satisfaction I heard a young bird in the nest after the hen had been sitting for about three weeks, but then the question arose, on what do these birds feed their young? Nothing seems to be known about their habits and feeding in the wild, and birds which come from rain forests in Brazil would certainly feed their young on something other than monkey nuts and seed. Soft food and live food they would not touch, although I have seen them catch flies on the wing with the same circular flight as that of a Spotted Flycatcher. Fruit, which they would never touch if put into a feeding pot, they would sometimes eat if hung on a perch, but in my opinion a great deal of the natural food of these birds is obtained from leaves and bark. When I heard young the question became acute. Bark I could manage, but normal green food at that time was out of the question, so I let them into my subtropical aviary knowing that they would find some fresh growth there. They liked this very much, but did not completely destroy everything. I ceased to hear the young after about 1 week, but the cock went regularly to the box, and, as I thought, got on with feeding the young, but when I finally looked in the box about six weeks later there was one dead youngster that had died at about a week old. This was most disappointing, but I have had previous experience of birds ^oing all through the breeding cycle if young are lost. As nothing much seems to be known about these birds, the following lotes may be of interest. When first imported--probably they were /oung birds although they were already in adult plumage--they seemed 0 need a lot of green bark and leaves. They will also eat the algae growing on wood, and will catch flies. They take a lot of nectar. Seeds md monkey nuts are eaten but not much fruit, but they will eat hawthorn )erries, blackberries, elderberries and grapes. These birds play together ike lorikeets, and seem indifferent to man rather than friendly. Where )erries contain stones, as in hawthorn, only the pulp is eaten. Other soft )erries seem to be eaten whole.

When fully adult and paired their previous tolerant and friendly acceptance of other parrot-like birds, or birds of any size above finches, ceases and they become very savage. The smaller fry in an aviary they ignore. Their flight is very swift and much more like that of an Australian Parakeet than a South American Parrot. Where a Pionus or Amazon Parrot flies swiftly but heavily, these birds fly much more lightly, and I have seen them fly like a shrike with long glides with only the tips of the wings moving, but the speed and accuracy of the flight of these parrots is superb. When first imported they flew everywhere, and seldom walked or crawled in the way of a typical parrot, but I have noticed recently that they crawl much more than they used to. The call is quite distinctive, difficult to describe, but is quite musical and unparrot-like. As soon as the hen decides to sit, she gives up feeding herself, and once she really starts brooding she hardly leaves the nest. About a fortnight after hatching she does come out of the box for a time, but never goes more than a few feet away. She sits on guard, usually about 6 ft. from the nest, while the cock bird does the foraging. As far as I could see she made no attempt to feed herself or search for food until the young would have been about a month old had they lived. There was no sign of a second brood. The other pair made no attempt to nest. The birds have completed a moult which takes a long time, and the cock of the second pair has grown a number of odd gold feathers which gives him a mottled effect. The coloration of these birds is a deep mossy green similar to a cock Eclectus, the wings and tail are bluish, and the cock has a large purple patch on his lower stomach. The beak is distinctive, being large, heavily hooked, and nearly white in colour. Like all birds coming from really dense forest, Purple-bellied Parrots spend a lot of time motionless and with the head held forward and the shoulders humped. Most parrots when dosing, rest their heads on their back, always with one eye showing, but these parrots never seem to do so, but sit looking rather like hawks. One gets the impression that they may be partly insectivorous in the wild, but I have no real proof of this except that I have definitely seen them catch flies, but their speedy and beautiful flight would certainly tie in with this. Most of these parrots imported in recent years seem to have died fairly quickly, and in view of the export restrictions from Brazil it looks unlikely that any more will be imported, so I most sincerely hope that I shall at last be successful in rearing them. Golden-breasted Buntings {Embenza flaviventris) laid but did not hatch, but taking the year overall it has been the poorest breeding season I have had. Never have the birds looked so fit and in such bounding health, and never have they produced fewer young.
algorithms.sectionHeader: J. DELACOUR--BIRD-BREEDING AT CLARES IN 1 968 21 BIRD-BREEDING AT CLERES IN 1968
algorithms.bodyText: By J. Delacour Although the weather was cold and wet most of the spring and summer, the last breeding season can be considered as fairly satisfactory. Dr. P. Ciarpaglini has now settled down at Cleres and he has been able to re- organize many things which had been perforce neglected during the long illness of the late Frank Fooks. His great skill and experience as a bird veterinarian has resulted in the saving of many young birds which could not have survived otherwise. In a park heavily stocked with birds, brought over from all parts of the world during half a century, practically all parasites, bacteria, viruses and other disease-causing organisms flourish, and it certainly is the case with us. Appropriate treatment is thus essential from the beginning if chicks are likely to live. We were lucky again with Emus, seven of which were hatched in April and easily reared. Later on, two dozen Rheas were raised, half of them white. Ostrich eggs proved infertile. Over 400 waterfowl were successfully reared. There were Black- necked Swans (9), and Emperor, Grey-Lag and Bar-headed Geese. A pair of Pacific Black Brants, adult-caught in Eastern Siberia three years ago, unexpectedly laid four eggs. The young were rapidly reared by the parents, who had incubated their clutch in the middle of a lawn on which thousands of visitors walk; but the gander kept them at a distance and no one disturbed the nest. The young are delightfully tame. A pair of Red-breasted Geese nested, but the eggs were stolen by vermin. Magellan, Ruddy-headed, Ashy-headed and Andean Sheldgeese bred normally; a pair of the latter had a brood of eleven. There were a good many Common, Ruddy, South African and Paradise Shelducks, and two Magellan Crested Ducks. Also Fulvous Whistling Ducks (40). Large numbers of ducks were reared, of the following species: Greenland,
algorithms.reference: Philippine and Lesser Grey Mallards; Laysan, Chestnut, Cape, Marbled, Puna, Chilean Sharp-winged, Garganey Teal; Northern and Chilean Pintails; Falcated, Redbilled Ducks; Chiloe Wigeon; Carolina, Mandarin and Maned Woodducks; Red-crested, Rosy-billed, Red-head, Common White-eyes, Australian White-eyes, Baer's and New Zealand Black Pochards. A female American Ruddy Duck, in our possession for fifteen
algorithms.bodyText: years, laid for the first time and hatched eight ducklings, one of which only was reared, due to accidents. It was the more unexpected that the old female has partly assumed a masculine plumage the last three years, having a black head and white cheeks. It is interesting to report that a pair of Cape Teal laid four times between March and September, each time successfully. It confirms that some southern hemisphere species may have a very long breeding season.

We now have suitable pairs of many species of waterfowl which do not figure in this list, particularly a pair of Trumpeter Swans sent by the U.S. Government. We hope to have much to report next year. A pair of Tasmanian Water Hens, at liberty in the park, reared five young in April. They had two more broods during the summer, but they inexplicably failed to rear them. Gough Island Moorhens, in an aviary, hatched several chicks, but reared only one. A pair of Andean Giant Coots ( Fulica gigantea ), reputedly flightless, did fly away from the lake in October, probably following migrating in the company of Common Coots. Many Peafowl were reared, but the Brush Turkeys met with an accident. The male that had produced eight young in 1967 was hurt in fights with Peacocks and died in June, with the result that only one chick came out of the mound. We have now two males and four females well settled down in two different parts of the park, and a young male in reserve. Many Pheasants were raised: Blue Eared, Cheer, Hume's, Malay and Siamese Firebacks, Tonkin Red, Sonnerat's and Ceylonese Junglefowls, Grey Peacock Pheasants (eight from one pair), Edwards', etc., and many Chinese Quails. We keep few Parrakeets, but three Crimson-wings, eight Bourke's and many Lovebirds were reared. Young doves were not as numerous as we had expected, probably due to the inclement weather. We, however, reared a fair number of Wonga- wongas, Longtailed (Macropygia rnichall), Brush and Common Bronze- wings, Green-wings, Australian Crested, Grey-headed ( Geotrygon caniceps ), Peaceful, and other small species: Columbina cruziana and passerina, and Metriopelia caeciliae. An old pair of Blue-headed Doves (Turtur brehmeri) for the first time produced young ones. For the last ten years, they had been tried in various outdoor aviaries and greenhouses, but they never nested. They were finally placed in a large indoor flight also inhabited by various passerine birds, and they soon started nesting. Squabs were hatched, but they never survive long if left to the parents. We had to take them out when ten days old and hand-rear them. During 1968 we have acquired new birds and made up pairs of many species of which we only possess odd specimens. We are also improving our breeding accommodation and we hope therefore to have greater success to report in 1969.
algorithms.figure: JOHN P. RYDER--EGG-EATING BY WILD LESSER SNOW GEESE 23 EGG-EATING BY WILD LESSER SNOW GEESE (Anser caerulescens) By John P. Ryder (The Department of Biology, University of
algorithms.bodyText: On 5th July 1968 I observed a pair of Lesser Snow Geese eat one of their own eggs at an island nesting colony of Ross's Geese ( Anser rossii) and Lesser Snow Geese at Karrak Lake (67* 15' N, ioo* 15' W), in the Canadian Arctic. The egg had been 2 ft. out of the nest for six days. I broke the egg accidentally while checking the remainder of the clutch (four eggs). The Snow Goose pair returned to the nest site immediately after my departure. The female went to the broken egg and began eating the contents. A few seconds later the male joined her and within two minutes the yolk and albumen had gone. The female then returned to her nest and started incubating. The male stood nearby within the nest territory. In six summers of research at Ross's and Lesser Snow Goose nesting colonies, this was the first time that I observed wild geese eating their own eggs (see Ryder 1964, 1967, 1969). It would, however, seem to have a definite selective advantage in Arctic nesting geese. Firstly, the yellow coloured yolk could possibly attract predators such as the Glaucous Gull (Larus hyperboreus), Herring Gull (L. argentatus ), Parasitic Skua ( Ster - corarius parasiticus) and Long-tailed Skua (-S', longicaudus ) to the rest of the clutch. Eating the egg contents would thus eliminate or at least decrease the chances of predation. It remains enigmatic why the geese did not dispose of the egg shell after eating its contents. Surely the broken shell acts as an attractant to predators. Secondly, the Snow Geese could have eaten the egg contents simply because they were hungry. Arctic nesting geese lose considerable body weight during the nesting season. Breeding female Ross's Geese lose up to 800 grams (44% of the average body weight) during egg laying and incubation (Ryder 1967). I tend to agree with Bergin (1968) who postulates that Budgerigars ( Melopsittacus undulatus) may have evolved egg-eating as a nutrient saving mechanism in the natural environment where food is scarce. Although food is not scarce on the mainland tundra during the nesting season, it is lacking at the island nest site where the geese spend most of their time (Ryder 1969). I find it difficult to explain why the geese do not break more abandoned eggs if the contents serve as an obvious reserve food source which, in this case, was recognized and readily accepted. The ideas expressed are based on only one observation, but I think the egg-eating phenomenon in wild and domestic birds has rather important ecological and evolutionary implications which require further study. Aviculturists have an excellent opportunity to observe and document such " abnormal " behaviour under controlled conditions.

algorithms.table: # # # BREEDING OF THE VULTURINE GUINEA-FOWL (Acryllium vulturinum ) AT DAWS HALL WILDFOWL FARM By Major Iain Grahame (Daws Hall, Lamarsh, Suffolk) My first experience of Vulturine Guinea-Fowl was, I am ashamed to say,
algorithms.bodyText: when I shot about a dozen of these beautiful birds in Northern Kenya about ten years ago. In 1964, on my return to this country, I started to keep ornamental waterfowl and pheasants, and was determined at the first available oppor- tunity to include species of guinea-fowl in the collection. Four \ ulturine Guinea-Fowl duly arrived by air from Nairobi in the summer of 1966. They were housed in an aviary 8 yd. by 9 yd. with a small shelter in one corner, and fed on a mixed diet of corn and turkey growers pellets. Like all birds of the family Phasianidae, they like nothing better than live insects, and were given a quantity of blowfly maggots once or twice a week. I was surprised, considering the barren thorn scrub which is their natural habitat, at the amount of grass that they consumed, but there is no doubt that this forms an integral part of their diet. During winter nights or when snow was on the ground, they were shut up in their shelter and were given an infra-red lamp when the weather was particularly cold. One bird lost condition and died during that winter, leaving two cocks and a hen for the following year. On 1 st December 1967 one egg was found lying in the pen. This proved to be infertile. In 1968 one male became noticeably aggressive towards the other, and the hen started laying on 1st August. This egg was immediately lifted, and a chicken's egg of similar appearance put in its place, but the latter was eaten by the guinea-fowl. A second egg was laid in a different place four days later and exactly the same thing happened. When the third egg was laid, two days later, a dummy egg was used as a
algorithms.figure: Chicks at io days old, showing the intricate markings on head and neck. Copyright] f Major Iain Grahame At 9 weeks, blue feathers have appeared on the breast, neck hackles are
algorithms.figureCaption: beginning to grow, but the head still has downy feathers. Avicult. Mag.
algorithms.sectionHeader: MAJOR IAIN GRAHAME--BREEDING OF THE VULTURINE GUINEA-FOWL 25
algorithms.bodyText: substitute, but the hen promptly deserted this prospective nest and laid her subsequent eggs in different places. Thereafter the eggs were lifted when dropped and no attempt made to replace them. Altogether, 18 eggs were laid, in three haphazard clutches, the last one on 1st October, after which the birds moulted. The eggs were creamy-white and pointed, size 50 x 36 mm. The eggs were placed under broody hens, and transferred to an electric incubator as soon as they began to chip. Hatching results were as follows:
algorithms.figure: No. of eggs Fertile Hatched Incubation 5 1 1 24 days 4 2 1 25 days 4 4 3 23 days 3 3 3 24 days 2 2 2
algorithms.bodyText: There was an electrical failure during the night that the last two chicks hatched, and unfortunately both were dead by the morning. The remaining eight chicks were reared without any problem, and at the time of writing the oldest is 12 weeks and the youngest 5 weeks. Each batch of guinea-fowl was ready to come out of the incubator 24 hours after hatching, and were transferred to a brooder heated by a bright- emitter infra-red lamp, together with one or two bantam chicks that had been hatched at the same time. It was thought that the bantam chicks would exercise a quiet restraint on their companions and encourage them to feed. They did have a quietening effect on the guinea-fowl, but in each case the guinea-fowl started feeding of their own accord within seconds of being put in the brooder. They were given small maggots, turkey starter crumbs and duckweed (Lemna miner). At four weeks they were put on turkey growers pellets, and corn was introduced to their diet at six weeks. Vulturine chicks are yellowish-buff, with finely marked dark brown pencilling on the head and nape, as can be seen in the photograph. The bill and legs are flesh-coloured. Almost from birth they emit, when frightened, a miniature edition of the " churring " warning call of the adult. Blue feathers appear on the breast at 8 weeks, but the down on the head is not replaced by baldness until they are over 16 weeks old. The first breeding of Vulturine Guinea-Fowl in this country was by J. C. Parr in 1884. Since then, to the best of my knowledge, the only other successful breeder has been W. R. Partridge, in Worcestershire, who reared more than 30 between 1962--64. Unfortunately, he lost more than half of his first clutch from gape-worms and blackhead, and subsequently experienced leg weakness at 10--16 weeks. This was apparently partially rectified by including limestone grit and cod-liver oil in the diet. As my chicks have had both from an early age, I hope to avoid this trouble.

A. J. CLARE--BREEDING THE YELLOW-BACKED LORY A number of interesting points emerge from Partridge's breeding records, viz.: He has had eggs as early as May. He, too, has experienced egg-eating by the birds. The incubation period he records is 27-28 days, four days longer than mine. On at least two occasions the hen guinea-fowl successfully hatched and reared her own young. Not only did the cock bird frequently brood the chicks during the day, but it was for him only that the young birds fed for the first few days. Considering the very large numbers of Vulturine Guinea-Fowl kept in zoos and private collections in this country, it is surprising that so few breeding records have been achieved. There must obviously be certain basic requirements to their breeding in captivity, and from my very
algorithms.listItem: limited experience I tentatively put forward three factors: (1) They must be given a sizeable pen, not less than 50 square yards, and preferably much larger. (Partridge has had good results in a J-acre orchard.) (2) Plenty of grass is essential, and the addition of live insects to their diet is important. (3) Their feet are extremely susceptible to frost, and they must be given adequate protection in the winter.
algorithms.table: # # # BREEDING THE YELLOW-BACKED LORY (Domicella garrula flavopalliata)
algorithms.bodyText: By A. J. Clare (Headington, Oxford, England) I purchased a pair of Yellow-backed Lories in the spring of 1967. They were placed in an aviary 16 ft. x 6 ft. x 4 ft. wide. They settled down very well and became very tame, coming to the wire for titbits of apples, bananas, etc. Food was placed in a shelter attached to the end of the aviary, which also had a large nest-box in which they slept. They wintered very well, with no ill effects, and showed no discomfort at the cold and damp of their first English winter. In March 1968 I added a large hollow log, approx. 2 ft. 6 in. round, 20 in. deep, inside which was 4 in. of peat, sawdust and shavings. They took to the log immediately, going in and out all the time and deserting their earlier nest-box. Eventually I discovered two eggs, white, and resembling pigeon's eggs. Both birds seemed to share incubation. The laying date was not known, but the eggs were found on 14th May; and

PROF. CARL NAETHER--UNDERSTANDING BIDRS IN CAPTIVITY 27 on 27th June two chicks were discovered. It was too dark to distinguish much in the log. Both adult birds were very excited and would display all the time by the entrance to the nest-log. I was informed that to rear Lories plenty of mealworms, maggots, fruit and seed were necessary. These I supplied, but the parent birds left it all and continued to feed the chicks on a mixture which I make for them from Complan, Farlene, Robinson's Baby-rice, sugar, condensed milk, and Bovril. I feed my twelve pairs of Lories and Lorikeets on this mixture and none of these birds will now take fruit or seed. By the 1 ith July the chicks had grown quite a bit, and although the eyes were not open feather quills covered the body. If, as I have read, the chicks are naked for the first three weeks, then these young might be about five weeks old. On ist August the young had their eyes open, quills opening to deep red feathers, and the body more covered in red down. The bills were black. On 16th August yellow feathering was showing on the back. The parent birds remained very tame and were not bothered by my looking at the chicks. On 3rd September the young were peering out of the entrance hole and on 16th September left the nest, full feathered and very strong in wings and body.
algorithms.table: # # * UNDERSTANDING BIRDS IN CAPTIVITY By Professor Carl Naether (Encino, California, U.S.A.)
algorithms.bodyText: If thirty-odd years of keeping birds have taught me anything, it is that each and every bird, regardless of species, is an individual. This fact becomes especially noticeable when one keeps a number of birds belonging to the same species. Close observation soon reveals conspicuous differ- ences of behaviour on the part of this or that member of the group. And as one gets to know the various members better and better, one begins to appreciate, as well as to respect, their distinctive traits more and more. Being an individual and being also dependent for all his daily needs on his keeper, a bird in cage or aviary deserves understanding treatment. Such keeping calls for supplying him, first of all, with his fundamental needs. To learn exactly what these needs are, the keeper should gather as much factual information concerning the bird's native surroundings, food, shelter, breeding and other essential aspects of his natural behaviour as he can. Most public libraries are well stocked with good books and maga- zines on birds of all kinds; there can, therefore, be little excuse for any bird-keeper pleading ignorance of this subject. Moreover, visiting fellow fanciers--actually seeing how they care for their charges and talking with them--usually yields important and practical suggestions for the care of one's own feathered flock. However, these suggestions should be applied

PROF. CARL NAETHER--UNDERSTANDING BIRDS IN CAPTIVITY cautiously and gradually, since the conditions under which fanciers keep birds vary decidedly. Ordinarily, two groups of birds are kept in confinement--those imported after their capture in the wilds of foreign countries and exported, and those raised in captivity. Since the numbers of the latter do not usually meet the ever-increasing demands by aviculturists, wild birds are being constantly imported to make up the difference. By nature very shy and fearful of man, their enemy, wild birds must receive humane treatment from the very beginning of their keeping if they are to adjust themselves to life in captivity. At all times they must be handled with gentleness and with patience. Especially frightening to any bird, particularly a wild one, is to be caught up with a net, having first been chased from pillar to post. If an aviary bird is to be caught, it is best to catch him in a trap that is suitably baited. The caught bird should be held in the right hand by simply placing one's forefinger gently but firmly around his neck and against one's thumb. Under no condition should a bird ever be held by the wings or any part of his body be squeezed tightly, since it is so easy to injure birds, especially smaller ones. Most birds dislike being held by human hands. Since the experience shocks them, they should be sub- jected to it only when absolutely necessary. It is always best to leave captive birds alone (except, of course, those especially trained) just as much as possible so that they may live as contentedly as their confinement permits. Before one places a bird in either cage or aviary for the first time, his new home should be in complete readiness, with everything needful for his welfare provided, so that he will not have to be disturbed for some time. Since he is already made nervous by being placed in new surroundings, frequent fussing with him will only aggravate his condition. He should be left alone--be given ample time to accustom himself to his strange environment. When attending to the wants of birds in aviaries, one should move about slowly and deliberately. Any sudden movements frighten birds, and it takes them some time to overcome fright. It is best always to follow a set routine, which they will soon come to recognize and to expect. This applies especially to feeding, which to this writer is the most delightful daily chore of his hobby, since it brings him into fairly close contact with his feathered friends. I make it a point to wear clothes of the same colour whenever I go into my aviaries and to go about my tasks leisurely. My birds recognize me on sight the moment I enter their abode, some of them flying to my hand for titbits, others darting to the feed-dishes soon after I leave. Feeding time is a most propitious time for taming birds, for in their eagerness to be fed they seem to forget their shyness of man. If you wish to induce a bird to take food from your hand, then you should stand very still, holding the food in your outstretched hand, and wait patiently for the
algorithms.reference: PROF. CARL NAETHER--UNDERSTANDING BIRDS IN CAPTIVITY
algorithms.bodyText: bird to approach. Depending on the kinds of birds you keep and the way in which you treat them, more or less time will elapse before one or more of them will come near you. It is very important that you let the bird come to you, that ordinarily you do not go to him. Often repeated, this simple procedure will soon be taken advantage of by the birds as an opportunity to get titbits without fear of harm, with the result that in time more and more birds will become reasonably tame and confiding. Many bird enthusiasts, especially those keeping softbills, call to their birds at feeding time, using the same phrase or phrases each time, and rewarding those that obey the call with mealworms or other titbits. Once thoroughly used to the call, they will come readily, even if they do not get something to eat every time. To learn to understand birds in captivity it is best to start with only a few, unless, of course, one has had previous experience with them. A pair of the handsome Pekin Robins, whose essential requirements are comparatively simple, kept in a roomy cage or small aviary, will furnish any amateur bird fancier with a delightful beginning and study. And if perchance induced to breed, their family affairs, in particular their nest- building and rearing of young to maturity, will provide a rich source of unusual and often amusing enlightenment for both young and old. It means having a small but lively and characteristic touch of nature right in the home. Such a beginning serves as an excellent introduction to the secrets of satisfactory bird-keeping, and one requiring but little expendi- ture of effort, time and money. Having gained valuable experience from this simple beginning, the bird- keeper, if he be still enthusiastic over his project, can now enlarge it by attempting to breed other species, whose needs, while often somewhat different, are yet in many respects similar. Or, he may like a given species so much as to want to study its habits more thoroughly over a period of years. Which calls to mind a good friend who is so carried away with the charm and the beauty of song of the European Blackbird that he has indulged in breeding this lovely songster for many years, and with increas- ing success and satisfaction. This pleasant concentration has yielded him such a wealth of practical knowledge of the bird s behaviour and requirements in captivity as to establish him an authority on the keeping and breeding of European Blackbirds. In this connection, I would recommend always a gradual and considerate start with insectivorous and frugivorous birds, such as robins, thrushes, flycatchers, tanagers, honeycreepers, and the like. These birds, which, incidentally, have been my special pleasure for over 30 years, are much easier to tame than most seedeaters. Theirs is an intriguing individuality, manifesting itself in every important aspect of their behaviour. In fact, some specimens show so much individuality that they become very pleasing personalities, easily recognizable by their unique actions. Over the years it has been my privilege to keep three Shama Thrushes, those

PROF. CARL NAETHER--UNDERSTANDING BIRDS IN CAPTIVITY vivacious, excitable birds from far-off India, whose musical ability in some instances rivals that of our best-singing mocking-birds. The last Shama I had for well over io years. All three were tame and would readily take mealworms from the hand. If any of them were caught up and handled, they would shriek defiance. The first two I kept in a large cage indoors, giving them the liberty of the room once a day; the third I kept outdoors summer and winter. " Bobby ", the first one, a truly magni- ficent bird with glossy plumage and beautiful long tail, began very soon after arrival to imitate the barking of our cocker spaniel, as well as the sounds of birds singing in the neighbourhood. Given the freedom of the room, he would suddenly swoop down on the dog, trying to attack him. Resenting this show of aggressiveness, the cocker would snap at the Shama. The two never became friends. The second Shama, whom we called " Mister ", not as fine a songster as the first one, paid practically no attention to the cocker pups we had at the time, except to mimic their barking almost perfectly. If in their playfulness they approached the high stand on which the bird's cage rested closely, " Mister " would begin to scold, the while whipping his long tail vigorously up and down. Let loose in the room, he made no attempt to fly at the dogs who eyed him curiously. Seemingly, they hardly existed for him. My third Shama Thrush, whom we simply called " Shama ", I kept with a pair of Mountain Witch Doves in an outdoor pen, where he enjoyed life for io years. An accomplished mimic, his repertoire included the cackling of hens, the barking of dogs, and some of the finest notes from an Indian Starling's short melody. Whenever I went into his aviary, he would come near me, all the while whistling and frolicking in lively fashion, as if displaying to a prospective mate. To birds accustomed to flying about at will in meadow, field or forest, crowding is the worst punishment which any keeper can inflict on them. Aside from being wholly unnatural, such treatment puts captive birds constantly on the defence, since they have nowhere to escape and to relax. Moreover, birds which are crowded together for any length of time, whether in cage or aviary, soon develop strong tendencies to bully their fellows and will often attack and even injure them seriously. Crowded birds do not--cannot--act naturally. Assuredly, under such abnormal conditions they will neither sing nor breed--two abilities which evidence well-being and contentment. Sympathetic treatment of birds in confinement demands roomy, comfortable cages or aviaries in which they can at any time get quickly out of the way of others of their kind and stay out of the way. Many of today's manufactured cages, while ornamental, are in size and in other practical avian requirements unsuited to house birds. It is surely no exaggeration to assert that during the last 50 years American bird-cages have been but little improved--a very good reason why genuine birdlovers
algorithms.reference: PROF. CARL NAETHER--UNDERSTANDING BIRDS IN CAPTIVITY
algorithms.bodyText: Duild their own cages and aviaries, often patterning them after English md German models. Kind and thoughtful treatment of captive birds demands also that if members of different species are to be kept in the same enclosure they must be congenial; otherwise, continued bickering and fighting will prevent the occupants from acting naturally and from showing their best in song, in plumage and in breeding. Certain species of softbills, being gentle by nature, get along nicely with fellow occupants; other species, being aggressive by nature and often known as troublemakers, cannot be placed in mixed collections without running the risk not merely of destroying the sociality of the whole group, but of causing vicious fighting with consequent loss of life. In most cases, only judicious experiment and very careful observation for several weeks can disclose which species of birds may be kept together safely and harmoniously. In an aviary 6 ft. long, 6 ft. high and 10 ft. deep, planted with honeysuckle and leafy shrubs, I have accommodated a mixed collection of softbills, including honeycreepers, silver-eared mesias, blue-winged sivas, yuhinas, banana quits, various tanagers, spectacled and other thrushes, and orioles, almost all males and all living together peaceably and quite contentedly. It is clear that if I had kept these birds not for singing and beauty of plumage but for breeding, I would have been able to keep but very few pairs in the same aviary, since at the beginning of nesting time the males would have fought for their respective breeding territories. Beginners especially have a stong tendency to overestimate the capacity of their aviaries, adding more and more birds to their collections so that very soon crowded conditions will prevail, making life for most occupants miserable. Strangley enough, occasionally I have seen careless " pack- ing " of birds into too much limited space in prominent zoos in this country, whose facilities for keeping them should be models of modern and thoroughly humane enclosures. In all aviculture, it is well to remember that as natural, living entities, birds are fully entitled to the very best possible treatment which we can provide for them in confinement, and that ignorance and neglect of their basic daily needs are to be avoided at all costs.

algorithms.bodyText: By J. J. Yealland The Roadrunner ( Geococcyx californiana ) of south-western parts of North America had never been represented in the collection until a pair, bred at the San Diego Zoo and presented by the San Diego Zoo authorities, arrived early in October. This cuckoo, as its name implies, is a swift runner that may sometimes be seen along roads. Chaparral Cock is another name and this derives from the type of country favoured by the birds, for low-growing evergreen oak and other low vegetation is known as chaparral. Reptiles are a favourite food of the Roadrunner, so much so that it is often depicted with a lizard grasped in its beak: small mammals and probably nestling birds, beetles, etc., are also eaten. It is said that the Roadrunner is so swift and agile that it can outmanoeuvre a dog, and Dresser wrote in 1865 that " when tamed, as these birds often are, they become expert mousers, but are so mischievous as hardly to be suffered in the house ". There are two species in this genus, the other, G. velox, occurring in Mexico and parts of Central America. A Black-billed Humming Bird (Chlorostilbon gibsoni melanorhynchus ), presented by Mr. W. H. Brown, is another new species. It is also known as the Green-fly and is certainly one of the smallest of the family. A Little Bunting (Emberiza pusilla), presented by Mr. J. Trollope, is also a new species. This is a rare vagrant to England, " about eleven " being recorded in the 1946 edition of The Handbook of British Birds. Two Grey Francolins ( Francolinus pondicerianus) from Mr. W. A. Newlands, a pair of Pheasant-tailed Jacanas from Dr. K. C. Searle and two Black-crested Finches (or Pigmy Cardinals) from Mrs. V. Whitaker Carr are other presentations of particular interest and are species that have not been in the collection for some considerable time. A pair of Brown- necked Parrots ( Poicephalus robustus suahelicus), a pair of Green Broadbills and two pairs of Fairy Bluebirds are other accessions of note.

algorithms.bodyText: Oregon, U.S.A., has bred Peale's Peregrine Falcon Falco peregrinus pealei. A pair of Falcons, taken as nestlings some six years ago, reared a young male during the summer, 1968. At the time of the report it was five months old and in perfect condition.

Longevity. The two female Lyre-birds in the Adelaide Zoological Gardens died within three weeks of each other in November 1967. They had been in the Gardens since February 1949, and were respectively about eighteen and nineteen years old when they died. They regularly nested and laid their annual eggs (one each), but unfortunately no male was avail- able until 1966, too late apparently for any breeding to take place.

J. S. Rigge was awarded the Society's Medal in 1962, for breeding the Green-winged Macaw Ara chloroptera. He now writes that his original breeding pair " have this year (1968) reared three perfect young ones. Although the pair have nested and reared young each consecutive year since 1962, making a total of thirteen young reared, this is the first time that all three eggs have hatched. Three eggs have been laid on these occasions, in fact two or three seem to be the normal clutch."

" We have done it at last--after 42 years of effort I have bred Ninox strenua ! Yes, success has been scored this week after almost a lifetime of continuous attention to the powerful owl, the most temperamental, most nervous, most incompatible ' bird extraordinary ' among all predators in feathers." Thus Alec Chisholm {Australian Aviculture , September, 1968) announces the breeding by David Fleay of the largest of Australian owls-- the Powerful, also called Great Scrub-Owl and Eagle-Owl. One young one was thriving at the time of the announcement.

The goth Annual Report , 1967-68, Royal Zoological Society of South Australia says that during the period under review 141 birds of 35 species and varieties were reared. This is a larger total of birds bred but in fewer species. For the second year in succession a mound-hatched Brush Turkey was successfully reared, and for the fourth year in succession a Blue and Yellow x Scarlet Macaw hybrid was reared. Noteworthy also was the breeding of a Kookaburra: it is believed this is the first time this species has been bred in captivity in South Australia.

algorithms.bodyText: To the Magazine, i960, January-February number, I contributed " On Mandarin Duck Hybrids a summary of records of crosses in which the Mandarin is reputed to have been one of the ducks involved. At that time it was agreed by many of the foremost authorities that the Mandarin possesses a number of chromosomes differing from that of all other Anatidae. This fact was said to make hybridization extremely unlikely, if not actually impossible.

Since then Paul A. Johnsgard has taken considerable pains to review the literature, examine museum skins and locate living examples of " possibles He makes known his findings in Bull. B.O.C ., 1968, 140-148. From these it appears that the Mandarin has crossed success- fully, both ways, with the Carolina or Wood Duck, and with a male Laysan Teal--all these hybrids relate to the U.S.A.

In the Magazine, 1968, 222-223, John Yealland reported the breeding of the Tasmanian Waterhen Tribonyx mortieri at the London Zoological Gardens. I thought this might be a first breeding but it appears that success was obtained, albeit unknowingly, at the Bristol Zoo during 1967. Curator G. R. Greed writes: " We imported six of these birds from Basel Zoo in March, 1967. One of them died a few weeks later. Of the remainder, one pair was kept in our Gardens in Clifton and bred, but the youngsters were eaten by Sacred Ibis. The other three birds were transferred to our Crane Sanctuary (on our country estate, near Bristol). An abandoned nest was found and when we made a check in December, 1967 there were four birds. Therefore, we presume that one was hatched, but because of the conditions we did not see it until it was fully grown. As the birds were virtually free-range and not kept in the Zoo, we did not report the breeding. Incidentally, in our Crane Sanctuary we have five selected pairs--two Sarus, two Manchurian and one White-naped. We succeeded in getting four pairs to nest and eleven eggs were laid. Unfortunately only the Sarus proved fertile."

W. H. Collard, Director, Natal Zoological Gardens, South Africa, writes: " During one of my visits to England I purchased a pair of Rufous- necked Weavers, but despite many near-misses we were unable to breed from them. Recently one of the keepers allowed the hen to escape into an adjoining aviary. Rather than bring her back we decided to introduce the cock bird into the fresh aviary. To our pleasant surprise, just over a month later, we noticed a fledgling on the perch. And this after twelve years, as they were purchased in 1956. Another interesting breeding is that of two hybrid lorikeets. The male parent was a Forsten's and the female a Scaly-breasted x Forsten's. The hybrid female (seen by Mr. Yealland during his recent visit to our Gardens) is very much like a Scaly-breasted, except for some orange flecks on the breast and a slight resemblance of the Forsten's collar. The two young ones are green, but with much brighter breasts than their female parent, and light blue heads, very similar to an Edwards' Lorikeet.

algorithms.bodyText: We were able only to establish that the smallest parrot is any one of several species of Micropsitta , measuring a little over 3 in. in length (1968, 225). It is perhaps a little unfair to ask museum workers to decide which is the largest parrot. In the skinning process several inches could unintentionally be added to the length of the larger parrots. Also it does rather depend on what one means by the largest. If the size is to be judged by total length then it must surely be the Red and Yellow or Scarlet IVIacaw Ara macao which measures about 36 in* Followed by the Red and Blue Ara chloroptera and the Hyacinthinus Anodorhynchus hyacinthinus, both of which measure some 34 iti, but if size is to be based on actual body size then possibly one of the five races of the Great Black Cockatoo Probosciger aterrbnus would take pride of place. Incidentally, these cockatoos measure 29-31 in. overall, so they rank quite high in this respect. algorithms.bodyText: It is interesting to note that bird-watching has now become established as an outdoor sport or occupation for young people and the present volume is one of a series, each written by an expert in his field. No one better could have been chosen for bird-watching than R. M. Lockley who has devoted his whole life to the subject and established the first British Bird Observatory in 1933 on the Welsh island of Skokholm. I he present work contains chapters on how to make useful notes and permanent records, on counting birds and how to identify each species by its appear- ance, flight, voice and habits. The author describes in simple language the psychology of a bird's mind, bird song, the nesting season, territorial behaviour, migration and navigation, and his book should appeal to begin- ners of any age. There are 29 illustrations and a cover design by Behram Kaparia. E. H. The Editor does not accept responsibility for opinions expressed in articles, notes, or correspondence.

It is highly beneficial to all livestock, whether it be Humming Birds, Sun Birds or other Nectarines, Insectivorous Birds, Fruit- eaters, Canaries, Finches, Parrakeets, Parrots, or any kind of animal. algorithms.sectionHeader: BREEDING IN CAPTIVITY OF THE BLACK- NECKED CROWNED CRANE
algorithms.bodyText: (Balearica pavonina) By Dr. H. W. Clarke and Dr. L. Amadei (Ravenna, Italy) In 1953 my good friend, Dr. Luigi Amadei of Ravenna, bought from . Busacchi of Bologna, a well-known importer of exotic animals, a pair Black-necked Crowned Cranes [Balearica pavorina). The male bird, )wever, died of paralysis some five years later, and was replaced by lother male of the same species, considerably more handsome and better jveloped, which had been in the possession of a private collector in plogna for almost ten years. I now record the words of Dr. Amadei, who has very kindly agreed, at y request, to give some particulars on the breeding he obtained together ith some previous observations. : " In 1967 I noticed that the male of my pair of Crowned Cranes was turting the female, and according to what my housekeeper told me, had tually fertilized her. " Later, during that summer, the female laid three eggs, which were t upon by the male and female birds alternately, in a nest roughly instructed on the ground with boughs and dry leaves, by some wire ;tting separating one of my chicken-runs and a privet hedge. After >out a fortnight, the eggs were inspected and unfortunately turned out be infertile. " This year f 1968) I did not notice any signs of courtship or fertilization, owever, the female laid, in the old nest, a first egg on 15th July, a second 1 17th July, and a third and last on 19th July. I must admit that I did )t attach much importance to this brood, first of all because I had already -en disappointed by the laying of the previous year, and then because the ace where the Cranes had laid was continuously disturbed by workmen, rries, etc., because in my country house--situated in the Municipality Cotignola in the Province of Ravenna, where the two birds are kept-- pairs were being made to the walls and central heating installed. All is, naturally, considerably disturbed the female while she was sitting on e eggs and she went away from the nest several times. In spite of all

38 DR. H. W. CLARKE AND DR. L. AMADEI-BLACK-NECKED CROWNED CRANE this, on 17th August, at an interval of some two hours, two chicks hatched; the third egg had mysterously disappeared before the two chicks were hatched. For all the investigations made, the mystery of its disappearance was never cleared up. "A few hours after hatching, the parent birds took the two chicks for a walk in a meadow in front of my house; this meadow was where the paii usually stayed. " Right from the first, I noticed that one of the chicks was not growing at all: it tottered and was neglected by the parent birds, perhaps becaust it was less lively, and it was not fed as frequently as the other. This, chick survived eight days only. The other one, on the other hand developed normally and at the time of writing (20th October 1968) is almost as tall as its mother. Many photographs of the young bird, at various stages, were taken by my friend, Dr. H. W. Clarke of Rome. " Habitat The young bird grew up and developed in a meadow in front of th< country house of Dr. Amadei; the meadow is partly planted with trees firs, juniper, thuya and Pinus pinea. The rest of it is a natural meadov with a few bushes here and there. The area of this meadow is ca. 1,00c square metres; part of it is fenced off with wire netting, part is contiguous with the house, and part with a boundary wall which separates the meadov from the neighbouring property.

As this is a particularly important subject, which undoubtedly has had ; favourable influence on the growth and development of the chick, I agaii report the words of Dr. Amadei, who writes as follows: " I was able to ascertain that the parent birds brought, even from thei usual habitat, various insects for food (Diptera, Orthoptera, etc.). I believe however, that the food consisted for the most part of small earthworms In my opinion this food has had the greatest influence on the survival an< subsequent growth of the chick. As usual with these birds, the food wa not pushed down the young bird's throat, but offered to it, and it took am swallowed it. As I had neither live nor frozen insects at my disposal, had to supplement the food, in order to round off the nourishment of th young bird adequately, with larvae of " meat flies " (which are for sale fo the use of anglers): bread and milk, balanced animal food, minced ox hearl small fish and a mixture of insect-eating birds. " The morsels most acceptable to the young Crane in the first perio were the larvae of meat flies and bread and milk, in addition, of course, t the insects the parent birds got for it. " When about 50 days old, the young bird started to feed also on cereak especially green rice and grain. It is very fond of mole crickets an grasshoppers, which however I have difficulty in getting.
algorithms.reference: D. F. BRUNING--BREEDING OF THE RUFF
algorithms.bodyText: " Today, when over two months old, the young bird has its body to a ;ood part covered with feathers, and the remiges and retrices are already isible. At the back of the head a protuberance can be noted, announcing he coming of the characteristic golden tuft of the Crowned Cranes." After these interesting notes of Dr. Amadei, I have to add that a not legligible part of the result obtained is due to him: the care, attention and >assion Dr. Amadei lavishes on his Crowned Cranes are, I believe, more inique than rare. And these birds of his--which I have often seen enter ven their owner's house--have lost their wild state completely and seem o know and love the man who cares for them so well. I took a few photographs of the young bird when it reached the age of o days. It enjoys perfect health.
algorithms.figure: # # # BREEDING OF THE RUFF, Philomachus pugnax (Linnaeus), AT THE NEW YORK ZOOLOGICAL PARK By Donald F. Bruning, Ornithologist (New York Zoological Society, New York, U.S.A.)
algorithms.bodyText: Ruff, Philomachus pugnax , bred at the New York Zoological Park in 968, and observations were made on their growth rate. Ruff have bred arely in captivity and this may have been the first time they have bred in forth America. In March 1968 ten adult birds, four ruffs and six reeves, which arrived t the Zoo 12th April 1967* were placed in the " Lagoon " scene of the aquatic Bird House. The Lagoon is 53 feet long and 24 feet wide, with early one fourth of this area consisting of a large irregular pool. The ubstrate is sand (fine beach sand or white quartz) except for the three foot ide planter along the back and side walls which contains soil. Pittosporum )bira is the major background plant. With a few Ficus nitida and fontia Palm trees it helps hide the exhibit walls. Skylights over the ntire exhibit supply all of the light that the exhibit receives. Other birds
algorithms.figure: 1 the exhibit were as follows: 4 Black-winged Stilt, Himantopus h. himantopus 2 Black-necked Stilt, Himantopus h. mexicanus 8 Egyptian Plover, Pluvianus aegyptius aegyptius 1 Eastern Sooty Tern, Sterna fuscata fuscata 5 Lesser Flamingo, Phoeniconaias minor 4 Andean Flamingo, Phoenicoparrus andinus 14 James's Flamingo, Phoenicoparrus jamesi 4 European Golden Plover, Pluvialis apricaria apricaria 2 Hudsonian Curlew, Numenius phaeopus hudsonicus 1 Greenshanks, Tringa nebularis 1 Black-bellied Plover, Squatarola squatorala 13 Kittlitz's Sandplover, Charadrius pecuarius pecuarius
algorithms.bodyText: D. F. BRUNING-BREEDING OF THE RUFF The ruffs were fed twice a day, at 9.00 a.m. and 3.00 p.m. Feed consisted of a mix for soft-billed birds, hard-boiled egg, chopped horsemeat, chopped butterfish, Vitamycin and Caradee. No peculiarities of feeding were observed. Cage temperature is maintained above 50* during the winter and it varies upward during the spring and summer or on any bright day as more heat comes through the skylights. Day length varies seasonally due to natural lighting. During May and June much breeding activity was observed and all four ruffs displayed. No true " lek " formed although the males displayed prominently and showed definite lek behaviour even though a true lek was not possible due to the other birds in the exhibit. On 26th June 1968 four newly hatched downy chicks were seen being brooded by their mother. The nest had gone unobserved during incu- bation because it was located within the thickest background plantings. The display grounds were within the largest open area of the exhibit about a third of the way from the left end of the exhibit and about midway between the pool and the back wall. The nest was located nearly ten feet away. The reeves all used the planted areas to hide in as did a couple of subdominant ruffs. A pair of Black-winged Stilt, Himantopus h. himantopus , which had just lost two of their chicks, was observed trying to claim the four ruff chicks on 26th June. The reeve attempted to protect her chicks, but was unable to withstand the stilts' attacks. For protection, the reeve and her chicks were moved into a separate cage. The reeve accepted the new surround- ings and started brooding the chicks almost immediately. A heat lamp was placed above the birds in case the disturbed reeve failed to brood. The chicks possessed extremely long legs and toes in proportion to the rest of their bodies. The following measurements were taken from two of the chicks and from the adult reeve on 28th June:
algorithms.figure: Tarsus Culmen Toes, right Digit no. 4, 3, 2 Toes, left Digit no. 4, 3, 2 Adult Reeve 40 mm.
algorithms.bodyText: The chicks started eating small bits of fish and horsemeat, hard-boiled egg and mealworms when they were two days old. When they were eight days old and the reeve became aggressive toward them and had to be removed from the cage. After the removal of the reeve the chicks continued to grow rapidly. As they approached adult size it became evident that three were ruffs and one was a reeve.

algorithms.bodyText: Although the three ruff chicks increased their weights an average of fourteen-fold in three months and the reeve increased by nine-fold; culmen measurements increased by 100%; while tarsus lengths increased less than 50% and digit length by less than 10%. There are locomotor advantages in long legs and big feet but those of Philomachus pugnax seem exceptional and worthy of further study.
42 MRS. B. M. MARSAULT--EGG-LAYING BY GUILLEMOTS IN CAPTIVITY

By Mrs. B. M. Marsault (Exmouth, Devon, England) In 1968 a pair of Guillemots, Uria aalge , laid an egg at the Bird Hospital, run by my husband and myself, at which seabirds were being rehabilitated. The history of the two individuals concerned is briefly as follows: COCK BIRD (from notes kept, 14th November 1964 to 27th August 1966.) | 14 th November 1964--Admitted, having been picked up at Budleigh J Salterton, oiled all down from breast to tail and vent. In winter plumage. Bird totally exhausted and unable to stand and very weak. Was force-fed at first with difficulty. Washed in pure soap flakes solution and rinsed t copiously. 15 th November --Bird fed all day by picking up small herring fillets when thrown in front of him. Walking a few steps on the whole of the foot before flopping forwards. Continued to walk like this for three days before spending longer periods upright, started taking fish from forceps. 20 th November --Started walking on toes for short periods, feeding well. j 21 st November --Swam in the bath but became quickly waterlogged.. Fed well until 28th November when he was not interested in fish.! Intestinal antiseptic given in capsules. Ate hardly anything for three days.; Capsules continued. 2 iid December --Feeding better, taking herring fillets and sprats. 16 th December-- Started taking fish from a dish of sea water. Diet supplemented with vitamins. Progress continued uneventfully. It had a bath every other day. Fe well, taking up to 28 sprats a day. Weight constant at 1 lb. 14 oz. to 1 lb. 15 oz. Very tame, his best friend w r as our Alsatian dog from whom he hated to be parted. He became waterproof 18 months after admission and moulted into summer plumage in July 1966 for first time. April 1965--Several other oiled Guillemots arrived. HEN BIRD (from notes kept 14th May 1966 to 29th August 1966). Picked up oiled in Cornwall in January 1966 and transferred to the Exeter R.S.P.C.A. clinic by road. The conditions here were appalling Surviving birds were sent by road to another R.S.P.C.A. centre nead Taunton. By May 1966 the original number of oiled birds sent fronr Cornwall to Exeter and then Taunton, which had numbered 250, hac dwindled to eight. The eight birds were taken to the coast in May foi release, but two of them refused to go and were taken back to Tauntor where one died within 24 hours and we were asked to take the iemainin^ bird which was admitted here on 14th May. The bird was in fairly goo(j condition but not waterproof. It was hand fed. Weight in May 1 lb 9 oz. Extra vitamins given. Good progress. Weight in August 1 lb njoz. Settled with other convalescent Guillemots and one Razorbill Alca torda. The birds were put out in the garden during the day but always brough into the house at night until 1st September 1966 when they were installer

MRS. B. M. MARSAULT--EGG-LAYING BY GUILLEMOTS IN CAPTIVITY 43 in a pen on the lawn, size 10 x 10 ft. with a small plastic children's paddling pool containing fresh water. Covered sleeping quarters 10 x 5 ft. opened off the pen, the door of which was shut every night. The birds are still in this pen but the grass has been replaced by beach sand. Two enclosures are now used. The depth of sand varies. One group of Guillemots and Razorbills have deep sand in their outer run, and shallow sand in their sleeping quarters; the other group live on shallow sand in both compart- ments. Both enclosures have small freshwater pools. The birds go into their sleeping quarters about an hour before nightfall, of their own free will, and are frequently in there during the day. The door is shut because the other enclosure is open to the sky, and cats or other creatures could easily disturb or harm the birds. The wire-netting covered frames which enclose the outer run are 4 ft. high and it is not infrequent to find a Guillemot standing on top of this or walking about on the thick plastic-covered roof of the sleeping quarters! Sometimes we find one of them outside the pen, running up and down, trying to find a way through the wire-netting. It never seems to occur to them to fly back inside, but it is always evident that they are glad to be back with the others, when we replace them. The birds are now fed exclusively on sprats, which we buy directly from the trawlers at Exmouth or Teignmouth. My husband then sorts and packs them into plastic bags holding 3 lbs. (this saves waste) and then they ire put into the freezer. Before using, we allow the fish to thaw naturally, md they are given to the Guillemots and Razorbills in flat enamel dishes lolding sea water. We allow on average 12 sprats per head per day, 6 in :he morning and 6 in the evening. Sometimes they eat more; and they nust be the right size, which is rather tedious, that is, not more than 4 inches long although they can be smaller. The dishes are left on the ground and the birds help themselves. The other birds now in the pen ire Guillemots--admitted April 1965, January 1966, April 1966, August [966, February 1968; Razorbills--admitted January 1966, February 1968. I have had some trouble with foot injuries and infections, but mostly during the first eight weeks of treatment, before the birds are put out into :he outdoor enclosures. The most important thing seems to be to provide soft material for them to stand on, in the hope of preventing pressure sores rom developing on the soles of their feet. We use thick plastic foam sheeting, and the birds have frequent baths, which help to keep their feet mpple. I have used various ointments to massage their feet, such as deodorised cod liver oil cream. Sometimes I have had to keep a dressing n place to prevent formation of a wound, or to protect a wound already ormed. Trouble with overgrown beaks has only occurred with two birds. )ne beak became very long and then broke or peeled off, but once I had to 'ut the beak as it showed no sign of separating. Razorbills also shed a ayer of their beaks, and I have seen the same thing with a shag and a :ormorant. It seems as though a new beak is growing under the old one,

44 MRS. B. M. MARSAULT--EGG-LAYING BY GUILLEMOTS IN CAPTIVITY which is lifted up and then shed. If, however, the old beak is not shed it continues to grow. In May 1968 the cock and hen Guillemot in question were seen mating on several occasions. At the same period a pair of Razorbills mated frequently. These birds were Torrey Canyon victims. We had hopes of a Razorbill egg, but in vain. A second pair of Guillemots also mated fairly frequently, again without result. 1 he nesting data for the first pair is as follows: ist--2nd June --Hen bird appeared to be slightly off colour with slightly ruffled feathers and eyes half shut some of the time. 3 rd June --Hen discovered with an egg about 3 p.m. and which had certainly not been there before lunchtime. Hen looked rather exhausted and all the other birds were very interested and gathered round the egg. The cock bird was most attentive and brought fish to the hen. The egg was laid in the sleeping quarters against one of the walls.
algorithms.listItem: 4 th June --Hen on egg apart from a short while morning and evening when she left it to go into the pool and then preen her feathers. All birds still very interested and the cock bird of another pair seen mating, constantly chivvying the cock with the egg. 5 th June --Hen off egg morning and evening for a short while to bathe preen and feed. Bird looked normal again. Others slightly less interested. Cock still attentive. 6 th June --Hen off egg for about three hours from 10.30 to 1.30 p.m.
algorithms.bodyText: Meanwhile the cock fussed around the egg, sometimes with one foot on it, looking as though he ought to do something about it. Hen back on egg 1.30 p.m. and remained for the rest of the day. Cock bird kept bringing her offerings of fish, twigs, leaves, and feathers. These he brought from anywhere in the outer or inner enclosure, and it was not a question of simply moving something from one side of the egg to the other, but the egg was nearly always surrounded by these offerings. W e do not think that this had anything to do with nest building, but were brought as gifts. This theory would seem to be supported by the fact that fish were brought more often than leaves, twigs. 7th June --Hen on egg all morning, off for a short period in the afternoon to bathe, preen and feed, then sitting for the rest of tne day. %1hJune--As yesterday. Egg now surrounded by gifts brought by the cock. 9 th June --Hen off egg mid morning to bathe preen and feed and the cock was very busy trying to arrange the egg under him, and he took a' great deal of trouble to get it in the right place. He then sat on it for a short while, but as soon as he left it the hen obviously encouraged him to return, accompanied him back to the egg and supervised his reinstallatior on the egg. A short while later the egg was seen to have been turneo round and left in the direct sunlight and neither bird incubated it for a short period. The hen then returned to sit for the rest of the day. 10 th June --Cock on the egg mid-morning for 15 to 20 minutes. During

MRS. B. M. MARSAULT--EGG-LAYING BY GUILLEMOTS IN CAPTIVITY 45 the afternoon the cock was seen with a fish in his beak and trying to get the hen to let him take over the incubation. He finally succeeded after much growling and grunting. algorithms.sectionHeader: NOTES ON KEEPING COCKATOOS AND COCKATIELS
algorithms.bodyText: By Mrs. E. L. Moon (Miami, Florida, U.S.A.) I was so kindly asked by your secretary for something for your magazine, and I would like to air a few pet peeves at the makers of cages for these birds. When I began raising my baby Cockatiels I felt there was no cage on the market fit for them. The most important thing is horizontal wires instead of vertical! With the ordinary parrot cage vertical wiring with only one or two horizontal stay wires the birds get their heads out above the stay wire and then cannot hold on to the vertical wires tight enough with the feet to climb up and loosen the head. The owners come home and find the bird hanging dead. If you only knew the number of letters I have received on this, since I answered the Cockie Question and Answei Column in "All Pets " you would not blame me for growling, and wishing I could smash every one of such things. Then there are those tall rounci ca g es --women buy them--so that the bird doesn t take up so much house-room. One I have seen does have the wire going round it, but is shaped like an ice-cream cone for all the wires to catch the droppings anc no clean floor space for food. The other is like a vertical tube, some or 12 in. or 15 in. in diameter. Now what good does a bird get, even < parakeet, from that? It cannot fly straight up such a thing--you migh just as well have a little 12 in. x 12 in. canary cage. And in these als( the food is so easily contaminated. I was recently sent a picture of on< of my baby cockies on a cage, and it was one I had not seen, like a Chinesi lantern. It did not look too comfortable, with the wires so close togethe and not enough food containers. So if I were a cage maker I would make a cage of five pieces, four side and a top with a minimum of 2 ft. long, 2 ft. high, 18 in. wide. [I woul< say that this was too small, see Avicultural Magazine, 72 , pp. y 12 Asst. Ed.] There should always be four cups for food and they shouU be parrot-size--one for sunflower seed, one for small seed, one for watei and one for soft food, and these should be fixed to the sides, otherwis
MRS. E. L. MOON--KEEPING COCKATOOS AND COCKATIELS

you have to set dishes on the floor of the cage to be dirtied on and a nuisance to remove and clean. I do not like cups held in by plastic guards since the bird can chew these and pull them up, spilling the food, but plastic cups themselves are O.K. All four can be fitted across the front of the cage making it easier to care for them. For the door it is nice to have a drop door that forms an alighting platform. A swing in the cage is O.K.., most cockatoos like it. I like the perches arranged so that they are not over one another. 1 hree perches and a swing are enough. A little dish may be hung inside for grit, it is no use wasting it on the floor. I use paper on the floor, and always cut plently beforehand--to last a week or ten days--and roll one out each day, rather than fold and fix daily. But the main thing is the horizontal wires to save dear little lives. For the big birds I use a perch. This can have a square base, or one curved side, and fits into a corner but with castors for easy rolling. The base is of three-quarter inch plywood with metal sides for 18 in. or so to ''top the birds climbing up, high enough so that the bill cannot reach the op. A tree or a pole with a number of perches set at angles is fixed in the -entre of the base with nice cedarwood shavings on the floor, very easy :o clean and do not need it often. Food and water dishes on the floor. This way you can walk up and pet your bird without pulling him out of a loor and upsetting him. I usually cut all birds wings--not like an old chicken but so that it looks pretty when closed but gives some chance >f catching it if it gets out. I cut the outermost two primaries, leave the lext three, then cut the remainder of the primaries and some secondaries eaving the secondaries nearest to the body intact, and taking care not to :ut the greater coverts which hide the cut bases. I have nothing fancy and have made most of my cages, pens and nest- x)xes myself. For the big birds I use mostly metal trash cans; with )penings at both ends, the need for which I learned the hard way having a ockatoo male drive " his hen to nest--and kill her there. I tried vooden nail kegs--only to have a hole chewed in them and the eggs on he floor when about ready to hatch. And I never use a tall nest-box, aying the trash cans down instead of standing them upright as when a >ig baby is all spread out on the bottom, especially where there is more han one, a parent often jumps down and breaks a wing. The long cans >n their sides give ample room for both parents and any number of babies o walk about. The birds do not care if they are not pretty and I always ay about their house and my own as well (I keep about 35 birds in my >edroom) if visitors do not like it they need not stay so long--or come *ack so soon. I live for my birds--loved them all my life--so much that mother sed to say if ever I had children and they had no feathers she feared I '*uld not like them. Well I did raise two little girls, and am now past eventy-four and great-grandmother of five, and I love them all! I cannot " e very well today and had to be in bed most of the day so please forgive ie notes--but I tried--anything for the birds.
D. M. REID-HENRY--AFTERNOON'S BIRDING IN RHODESIA

By D. M. Reid-Henry (Woodford Green, Essex, England) Twenty miles or so to the north east of Salisbury just off the IVltokx road there is a farm surrounded by rocky hills and bush. On this farm al the usual Rhodesian crops are grown and the land is irrigated by wate from a dam thrown across a stream to form a small lake of about six acre in area. It was in September or early in October i960 when I first visited thi farm, and I returned several times at different seasons, for it was ai enchanting place with a wealth of interest for a naturalist. On the frowning rock kopjes that backed the homestead there was resident Lanner falcon who had developed the bad habit of raiding th farmer's domestic ducklings. He had tried to shoot her, and altnougi she had then so far eluded him I feared the days of her depredations wer numbered, and unless she mended her ways she would one day lose he luck and her life. The day I have in mind, I arrived after a drive from town with packe lunch and tea and after calling on the farmer's family went down to th dam a mile below the house. The lake above the dam was not particularly interesting. There wer occasional sand-pipers and small waders on its muddy surroundings and Coot or two on the water. A Black Tern in its winter plumage beat il seemingly lazy way to and fro over the lake surface seeking some mors< of aquatic life to eat. The sun was hot and the air beginning to take 0 that oppressive character that precedes the coming of the rains. Ottei used this lake as I deduced from the presence of a " slide ", but I do n( think their comings had been noted or someone would have soon tried t catch or shoot them. These animals are not very popular on priva 1 waters because they eat the fish and water creatures which attend to tf mosquito problem. On one side of this lake the land was somewhat marshy with a fe young fig trees standing on the drier hillocks. Here the grass was coan and gave good shelter to quails, francolins and, at this time of the ^e< crakes and other skulking secretive birds. The other side, which w"' most conveniently reached by crossing via the dam-wall, was woodt with a mixture of brachystegia bush, acaciae and various other fairly lari trees. Of undergrowth there was little but the grass grew tall and yellowe at the end of the dry season. Beyond this belt of woodland the groun became rocky, and one had to begin scrambling up the sloping rock sic of a granite hill which rose about two hundred feet on average above tl farmland below. Brightly coloured lizards, disturbed from their baskii in the sun on the naked rock scampered speedily away to the safety of crevice, and far above in the rich blueness of the sky, a Black-breastc
