algorithms.bodyText: iarrier-eagle circled on still wings watching the ground below for some mwary snake to provide a meal by getting caught! On these granite tills, or kopjes, vegetation is sparse, and somewhat of a different character \0x25BAecause the soil is only deep enough in hollows and clefts to support the row th of trees. Natural dents of shallow nature show a growth of mosses nd where a small pool can form the grass may grow strongly in its nvironment until the soil gives out on to bare rock again. Aloes put heir roots down into cracks, and stunted low thorn bushes are to be found round the bases of " candleabra trees ", or Euphorbia. On one of the limbs of this bush I found a tangle of rubbish hung on a horn. This would not have been noticed at all except that on my passing lose by, a tiny bird flew out of the " rubbish " and investigation showed to be the home of a Little purple-banded Sunbird Cinnyris bifasciatus. But the most rewarding place on this farm from a bird-watching point f view lay just below the dam wall. The wall itself was about fifty yards >ng and made of banked earth reinforced with concrete slabs. The uice gate let the water into a network of shallow streams and these met bout fifty or sixty yards below to form again the single watercourse that robably had been there before the dam was made. Here then was a )ugh triangle of well-watered ground of a third or half an acre with a ne array of big trees and a fairly thick undergrowth of bushes. At the me of which I write, fortune arranged that a very popular fig tree was in uit and the wealth of birds that came uninvited to the feast was an ffculturists dream of delight. There were several Black-collared arbets Lybnis torquatus , a pair of Amethyst Starlings Cinnyricinclus ucogaster , a Broad-billed Roller Eurystomus glaucurus, a pair of Meyer's arrots Poicephalus meyeri , (whose nest I found in a hollow tree two undred yards away) as well as four species of sunbirds who were gorging iemselves on a rich harvest of small caterpillars in the top canopy of a 11 mountain acacia tree. Two European rollers Cor arias garrulus were i evidence shortly down the stream, and a newly arrived flock of European ee-eaters Merops apiaster (of which the seeming majority were young rds of the year) were desporting themselves from a dead tree that stood vay from this small patch of dense bush. I could hear the " snick " their beaks quite clearly as they arrested small insects passing by eir look-out tree. A Striped Kingfisher Halcyon cheliculi was occupied ith the murder of a large green grasshopper on a rock which stood out the grass nearby, whilst the whimsical noises of a Purple-crested ourie Gallirex porphyreocephalus were heard from time to time. But the cream was still to come: a thin shrill piping was heard approach- es from the lake, and then within fifteen yards of my head a tiny Malachite ingfisher Corythornis cristatus perched with a small fish in its beak. It is at once greeted by four young Kingfishers which I had not seen, mded over its booty to the nearest of its brood, and flew away. The

50 J. J. YEALLAND--BREEDING PRINCESS STEPHANIE'S BIRD OF PARADISE young Kingfishers showed no alarm as I came closer, but remained per- fectly silent and still and I watched them for some minutes before my attention was turned elsewhere. As I was retracing my way from this rewarding introduction I noticed a Heuglin's Robin Cossypha heuglini slip away from the top of a dead tree stump on which grew a profusion of moss and vegetation. Upon investi- gation I found a nest with four gaping young within! I decided to leave the place immediately because the bird would not return if I remained in sight, and tempting though the discovery was, there was such a plethora of interesting birds about I could well afford to take myself away. I would return another day: such a place as this would richly repay manv visits, and I had plenty of time to devote. This day's outing came soon after my arrival in Rhodesia, and it was not very long before I went to many other places every bit as pleasant and interesting. As I have said, I did go back on several occasions during the next eighteen months, and whilst my first thrills remain in my memory very vividly, there were so many other trips to places where the scenery was different and grander that it is hard to express an opinion as to whether this early sortie was better or poorer than others from a birding viewpoint. The whole country of Rhodesia offers such valuable returns for the student of wild birds that one cannot easily state a preference for any one area. What I find particularly pleasing is that everywhere one is con- fronted with variety. Are you interested in sunbirds? go to Inyangt in the Eastern highlands when the aloes are in bloom! Birds of prey?- you will see them anywhere. Waterfowl?--any small farm dam will hav< something to show, and when the traveller has used up all his time and < sizeable lump of his resources, there will yet be other, possibly bette places still to visit, and one can never know if next time one s experience will outshine all that went before. Africa is never a bore!
algorithms.sectionHeader: BREEDING OF PRINCESS STEPHANIE'S BIRD OF PARADISE AT LONDON ZOO
algorithms.bodyText: By J. J. Yealland A pair of Princess Stephanie's Birds of Paradise (Astrapia stephania j from among a collection presented by Sir Edward Hallstrom in 1965 wa put into one of the outdoor aviaries at the Bird House and, as ahead recounted, nesting took place twice during 1967 when the first chick live for 21 days and the second for 10 days. In 1968 the first two eggs wer broken, the chick from the third nest lived for only a few days, and, whe all hope had been abandoned for that season, the mother added a litt material to the nest and at last succeeded in rearing a chick. Mr. Boehm has related his experiences in the breeding of this species i his aviaries at Trenton, New Jersey, and his account of events was mu(

I. J. YEALLAND--BREEDING THE GREY-BACKED THRUSH AT LONDON ZOO 51 Ahat we observed except for the violent scenes and even murder. So far rom killing her mate, our female was chased by him whenever she came )ff the nest, so he was always removed as soon as the single egg was laid ind incubation began. As already reported some nest reinforcement was lecessary, but the mother was not at all discomposed by this. The chick, 1 fine strong bird, left the nest on the 27th day and was fed by the mother or long after this. The food available to her was a substitute insectile nixture, fruit, mealworms, maggots, locusts and, as already reported, her avourite food--freshly killed mice, but so far as we could tell, for the food ed by her to the chick was always regurgitated, mealworms were mostly iffered to it. The mealworms were given in a dish containing the vitamin md mineral supplement Vionate; bonemeal was also put onto the food, so hat it is reasonably certain that the young one received some of these terns. This is the first of the Paradisaeidae to be bred in the Gardens.
algorithms.sectionHeader: THE BREEDING OF THE GREY-BACKED THRUSH AT LONDON ZOO
algorithms.bodyText: By J. J. Yealland The Grey-backed Thrush, Turdus dissimilis hortulorum , is a native of astern Asia, breeding in north-eastern parts and wintering in south-eastern Tina and parts of Indo-China. A second race lives in the area to the outh-westward, including East Pakistan, Assam, Burma, northern Thai- ind and parts of Indo-China. La Touche says that it is a bird of the awer hills and plains and that its range in China is apparently restricted to he maritime provinces; he also says, quite rightly, that it is a fine songster. Dr. K. C. Searle sent a pair to us in December 1965 and one died during he following autumn so he sent us a replacement in July 1967 and in the pring of 1968 the first nest, composed largely of mud with some fine rass built into it, was made about seven feet up on a window ledge. Four chicks were reared by early June and they appeared to leave the est early, urged to do so by the parents, we suspect, for immediately nother clutch was laid in the same nest. These were hatched, but were illed when a bird from the next aviary got into the thrushes' compart- ment. The third clutch, also in the same nest, was then laid and two hicks were fully reared. After this, we took away the nest, but a new ne was soon built in the same place and eggs were laid but no chicks were ?ared. The birds were fed on the substitute insectile mixture, together with mealworms and cleaned maggots. The eggs are of a bluish-green colour ith large reddish-brown spots and the six young birds proved to be one male and five females.
algorithms.sectionHeader: \0x25A0BREEDING THE TASMANIAN WATERHEN AT LONDON ZOO
BREEDING OF THE TASMANIAN WATERHEN AT LONDON ZOO
algorithms.bodyText: By J. J. Yealland In early November 1967, we received a pair of the Tasmanian Waterhen or Native Hen (Tribonyx mortieri) which had been bred that year in the Basel Zoo. They were put out on the Three-island Pond in the Spring of 1968 and in August they nested, laying seven eggs of which two hatched on the 5th September. , The nest was well hidden among plants growing close by the surrounding moat and within a few feet of passing visitors. Moorhens live and breed on the islands, but it is only occasionally that they are treated with any hostility by their much larger and more powerful relatives; when the chicks hatched the parents were rather more aggressive and sometimes drove ducks as well as the Moorhens from the island; from which, to begin with the chicks did not stray. The care of the chicks appeared to be carried out in a casual way and not long after they hatched I saw, one evening, both parents out in the middle of a nearby lawn as is their usual habit, and I thought that the chicks must have died, but then, as if it had just remembered something, one of the birds raced across the lawn and on to the island where it re-appeared a few moments later with both chicks. Evidently the young ones were sometimes left under the bushes, often they were separated and as often as not away from the parents, though just occasionally, and presumably at night, they were brooded. Grass is a favourite food and as the adult waterhens are easily able to cross the moat and to wander about the lawns and as in the rather wet summer there was a plentiful growth of grass there was never any shortage. In addition the birds can eat corn which is given to the waterfowl, biscuit- meal and minced meat. On the 6th October one chick died, but the other is now almost as large as the parents. While the chicks were quite small a platform of vegetatior was built by one or both parents at some distance from the nest and close by the water's edge, but the birds were never seen to use it during the da) though may have done so at night. The parents have nested, but un- successfully, since their first attempt. Tribonyx mortieri has been bred or a number of occasions at Basel, and if I remember rightly, a pair wit! their family were wandering about the lawn in the Antwerp Zoo in th< summer of 1964. Other European (and Australian) zoos have also beei successful in breeding this species.
algorithms.sectionHeader: !\0x25A0 J* YEALLAND--BREEDING THE MAGELLAN EAGLE-OWL AT LONDON ZOO 53 BREEDING OF THE WEST AFRICAN WOOD-OWL AT LONDON ZOO
algorithms.bodyText: By J. J. Yealland In April 1956 a tame West African Wood-owl (Ciccaba woodfordii mchalis ) was received and ten years later three more from Liberia were presented. All four have lived together ever since, being put into an mtdoor aviary for the summer and brought into a slightly warmed place or the winter. In May 1968 one of the three birds made a scrape in a deep layer of peat noss on the shelter floor and, so far as is known, only one egg was laid and his duly hatched, though the precise incubation period is not known. I he southern race is said to nest in the open hollow of a tree, or some ;imilar situation, and sometimes in an old nest of some large bird. We do lot provide hollow logs or nesting-boxes for owls, for if we did the birds vould roost in them and would never be seen, but in our experience even he owls that nest in hollow trees will do so on the peat moss of the floor ind, of course, the nest is screened by a sheet of hardboard as soon as ncubation starts. Of the clutch size Mackworth-Praed and Grant say )f the eastern and southern races " usually only one ", but Bannerman ,iays of the west African race " two would be the usual number laid ". The tame bird, which is the smallest of the four, seems to have been the ather, for it was sometimes standing by the nest. The remaining two )irds, so far as is known, took no interest in the proceedings. The young iird was of a pale buff-grey, browner on the back and with large whitish pots on the outer scapulars; it was fully reared and is now in the San )iego Zoo. The main food of the birds is mice, but pieces of raw lean meat are ometimes given. There are five races of Ciccaba woodfordii in forested parts of Africa and n parts of Arabia and it is believed that this is the first breeding of the pecies in this country.
algorithms.sectionHeader: BREEDING OF THE MAGELLAN EAGLE-OWL AT LONDON ZOO
algorithms.bodyText: By J. J. Yealland In August 1948 a specimen of Magellan Eagle-Owl, Bubo virginianus acurutu , was received from Paraguay and ten years later another was ollected by Mr. David Attenborough on the B.B.C.'s Zoo Quest to 'araguay. On occasion in recent years the birds attempted to nest and a ingle egg was laid each time, but was broken. This past year (1968), owever, a successful nesting took place and a chick hatched and reared.

54 DR. h. schifter--BREEDING blue-naped and speckled mousebirds The nest was a scrape made in a deep layer of peat moss on the shelter floor. A hardboard screen was fixed up as soon as the egg was laid and incubation began, and no doubt this gave the mother a sense of seclusion from the passing visitors. Two (rarely three) eggs are said to be the clutch of the northern Great Horned or Virginian Eagle-Owl ( B . v. virginianus) and it was this race that was bred at Wargrave in 1928, the Society's medal being awarded for this success. Rats, mice and pieces of raw lean meat formed the diet, mice being the main item. When the chick, which was hatched on about the 30th April, was in its sub-adult plumage, it much resembled the parents; it appears to be a female and since this breeding took place the father has died, his age at the time of the arrival was not known. This appears to be the first breeding in this country of the most southerly of the 16 races of Bubo virginianus.
algorithms.table: * * * BREEDING EXPERIENCES WITH BLUE-NAPED AND SPECKLED MOUSEBIRDS By Dr. Herbert Schifter (Museum of Natural History, Vienna, Austria)
algorithms.bodyText: In the May-June issue of the Avicultural Magazine 1966, 72 , I have already recorded the successful breeding of Red-faced Mousebirds ( Colius indicus ) in my aviaries. I received them in 1961 and since 1962 they have bred regularly. As part of a wider study I have also kept and bred Blue- naped and Speckled Mousebirds ( Colius macrourus & C. striatus) and to date the three species have raised a total number of more than 100 young. So I would like to give some additional notes to my earlier account. The Blue-naped Mousebird ( Colius macrourus ) may be regarded as the prettiest species of the group, as it is adorned with a patch of blue feathers on the neck and the soft parts at the base of the bill and the naked skin around the eyes are coloured red. Blue-naped Mousebirds also have the longest feather crests of all colies and like to erect them to full height when they are disturbed. Their range extends north of the Equatorial woods in Africa from Senegal to Somaliland and south to Tanzania where they are to be found in more open country and even in the towns as in Khartoum. I obtained my Blue-naped Mousebirds from a bird dealer in the Nether- lands and all ten specimens of the consignment were in good condition when they arrived in Vienna in September 1961. Later on two of them were transferred to the Zoo of Schonbrunn but the others were housed in an indoor aviary similar to the one where my Red-faced Mousebirds had already thrived for some time. I was very glad when I observed that the

DR. H. SCHIFTER--BREEDING BLUE-NAPED AND SPECKLED MOUSEBIRDS ^5 Blue-naped Colies soon formed four pairs and already in the following spring made first breeding attempts. But they were not successful before October 1962, when the first young of this species was reared. A second ane died just before leaving the nest, but there were two more broods in November and December 1962, and two Blue-naped Mousebirds were latched and reared. In 19^3 3.11 pairs of this species bred with varying mccess, the best raising 10 young from seven broods. In 1964 successful breeding continued though the female of my best pair hurt its leg and died n March 1964. The first breeding success from specimens already latched in my aviaries also took place in 1964, when birds which were hemselves reared only in January of the same year raised one young in November. Because the number of my Blue-naped Mousebirds had ncreased considerably I had to transfer a lot of specimens to various zoos md aviculturists where some of them are still living. Of the specimens I kept, one male died in February 1965 but now (in September 1968), seven years after I received them, four specimens are still hriving, though they are becoming old and already last year stopped all seeding attempts. Nevertheless, both the old males still sometimes )erform their curious display which consists of jumping up and down on a >erch several times, often for a minute or longer, until the females approach or copulation. These specimens have finally become quite tame and >ne of the males, which is now living with my hand-reared Red-faced dousebirds, likes to sit between them on their human friend's shoulder. I also obtained the Speckled Mousebirds {Colius striatus ) in 1961. I vas glad to see that my four specimens soon formed two pairs, which also *red for the first time in 1962. Though the Speckled Mousebird is the pecies of this family most frequently kept and was bred in Great Britain s long ago as 1912 and 1914 (according to a note by Mr. Prestwich) and ecently also in Denmark (see A. V. Nielsen in the German avicultural )urnal Die gefiederte Welt, Vol. 84, i960), in England (Mrs. D. K. Draper 1 Foreign Birds, Vol. 24, 1958) and in the San Diego Zoo (Kenton C. 'int in the Intern. Zoo Yearbook, Vol. 4, 1962) I was very glad that my pecimens also bred because I then had the opportunity to compare the reeding behaviour and the development of the young of both main roups of the colies, the first represented by Coitus macrourus and C. idtcus and the second represented by C. striatus. At first I housed my peckled Mousebirds in an aviary together with various waxbills and quails ut after a few months I built a new aviary measuring 3 m. in length, 2 m. 1 height and 1 -2 m. in depth where they settled very well and soon lowed some interest in the nesting-sites I had fixed in the aviary. In autumn 1962 both pairs bred successfully each producing four young om two broods. After an interrupted brood one of the imported females f this species died in March 1963, but the surviving male soon continued reeding affairs with a young female, hatched in my aviary, and three lung were reared in April 1963. There were four young in the nest

56 DR. H. SCHIFTER--BREEDING BLUE-NAPED AND SPECKLED MOUSEBIRDS when I looked in it on the 7th of April, but the day afterwards the smallest fledgling had been trampled by its older and stronger brethren. Another breeding of this pair took place in June and two young were reared. Successively two, three and two young respectively were hatched and reared in July, September and November 1963. In 1964 this pair continued to breed though I had to interrupt some broods to take embryos from the eggs for further studies. My second pair of the Speckled Coly bred again in 1963 also rearing two young in January and one in February-March. After they had raised another young in April, I observed some fighting between the two pairs living together in an aviary and therefore I removed this pair to another similar aviary. There the birds bred again having three more successful broods in 1963, but each time rearing only one young. In the following years breeding was again successful. Therefore I had to transfer some specimens to various zoos and in the Zurich Zoo, Switzerland, they have been very successful in breeding them. A note about this event appeared in the Avicultural Magazine 1968, 74 , 2, (see page 65, recorded by Christian R. Schmidt). In 1965 I also had to transfer the remaining Speckled Mousebirds from the Zoological Institute of the University of Vienna to my own quarters, where I housed them in a glass-house, measuring 4 m. in length and 2 m. in width, together w r ith the specimens of the other two species. There the old birds bred again in 1966 and were thriving until the male of the first pair died in August 1967, after exactly six years with me, and the female of the second pair died after six and a half years in February 1968. One specimen of the birds received in 1961 is still living and has even bred with a younger female, but the eggs proved infertile this year. In winter when they w ill be transferred to a heated shelter in my house I will again separate the Speckled Mousebirds from the other species, but next year I hope to put them together again. When housed together it is very interesting to observe that the specimens of Red-faced and Speckled Mousebirds never keep together, though there is some allopreenmg between Blue-necked and Red-faced Colies. Because Red-faced and Speckled Mousebirds sometimes even attack each other I prefer to sepa- rate them in winter when there is not enough space available. As I had done with the Red-faced Mousebird I also studied the breeding behaviour and the development Qf the young in Blue-necked and Specklec Colies. I was very glad to see that my results which had already beer published in Vol. 94 1967 Zoologisches Jahrbuch , Abt. Syst. agree almosi exactly with those of Mrs. M. K. Rowan, whose account on the Colies 0: South Africa appeared in the Ostrich , Vol. 38 1967. I think, however that the differences between the two main groups (the one being repre sented by the Red-faced and Blue-naped Mousebirds, while the Speckle( Mousebird and probably all the remaining species belong to the secoru group) are sufficient to support even generic separation of Urocolius fron

DR. H. SCHIFTER--BREEDING BLUE-NAPED AND SPECKLED MOUSEBIRDS 57 Colius because the differences comprise not only morphological but also )ehavioural aspects. I will deal elsewhere with these problems only living here an abridged account of my results so far as they may be of nterest for aviculture. There are already some differences in nest-building, the Speckled Mouse- birds using more grass and rootlets than Blue-naped and Red-faced vlousebirds, which prefer twigs and which will breed in nesting-sites ixed in the aviaries sometimes almost without any nesting material. I he nest-building duties are shared between male and female, though the nale is usually much more eager to bring nesting material to the nest vhere the female will fix it. Later on lining (especially green leaves) will >e brought to the nest, even during incubation until the young hatch. The eggs of all three species are nearly similar in size but the eggs of Colius macrourus more pointed and reddish-brown speckled like those >f Colius indicus. The eggs of Coitus striatus are creamy-white, some- imes being smeared or soiled after longer incubation, but always without *lotches, and can therefore be easily distinguished. The clutch-size bserved in my aviaries ranged from 2 to 6 in Colius striatus and from 1 in a young pair) to 4 in Coitus macrourus , the eggs usually being laid on onsecutive days. I have no evidence that in these species two or more emales have laid in the same nest as has been recorded from South Africa y Rowan, but I have accidentally observed this in the Red-faced Mouse- *ird when the aviary was somewhat overcrowded in 1964. In this year I nee had six eggs in one basket and nearly always two adult birds were rooding in the nest. The embryos which I had taken from these eggs ere in quite different stages of development supporting the conclusion iat two clutches were laid in the same nest. The only fledgling which I -ft in the nest was then raised by three or four birds together. In other roods also I have observed that more than the breeding bird took part in taring the young. Moreover, in the Red-faced Mousebird I always had lutches consisting of 2 or 3 eggs. On the contrary the six eggs of the peckled Mousebird mentioned above were laid at regular intervals so that am convinced that they were laid by one female only. Recently the old lue-naped Mousebirds have had clutches consisting of single eggs only hich, however, proved infertile. As also recorded by Rowan mousebirds begin to brood immediately ter the first egg of a clutch is laid. Both parents take part in incubation ith several changes during the day, and the female sits on the nest during ie night. I he eggs are never left unless the birds are greatly disturbed id therefore it is not easy to control the nests regularly without irritating ie birds. I here are no behavioural ceremonies when exchanging icubation duties, but the males sometimes bring green leaves or other isting material to the nest. As I have already stated in my account on ie Red-faced Mousebird the incubation period is surprisingly brief and 1 an average is only 11 days in my Speckled and Blue-naped Mousebirds;

58 DR. H. SCHIFTER--BREEDING BLUE-NAPED AND SPECKLED MOUSEBIRDS young sometimes even hatch after io |days. The mousebirds also usually cease to brood after 12 or 13 days if no young are hatched though my tame colies have sometimes even brooded up to three weeks. There was always a high percentage of failure but as this is also recorded by Rowan in natural surroundings in South Africa it need not be a consequence of the conditions under which the mousebirds were kept in the aviaries. As I have stated above for example many clutches consisting of two or three eggs with only one young hatched. As the mousebirds start to incubate as soon as the first egg of the clutch is laid the young hatch at different times and the oldest nestling may have grown to considerable size when the last one hatches. The youngest may then be trampled by the older nestlings which has also been recorded by Mrs. Rowan. This occurred in the above mentioned clutch of six eggs of Colius striatus when four young hatched, but only three were successfully reared. On the contrary, in another nest of the same species a second young hatched five days after the first. Nevertheless both young w r ere successfully reared though the older one left the nest some days before the smaller nestling. I have never observed such enormous intervals between the young of one clutch in the Blue-naped Mousebird. This species is thus more like Colius indicus. ^ Newly-hatched mousebirds are " curious-looking creatures " as Van Someren had already stated in the Ibis more than 50 years ago. The) then weigh only P5~2 g. and have a total length of 33--35 young of the Speckled Mousebird are covered with sparse down, even or the head and neck, w-hile those of the Blue-naped Coly are nearly naked They thus very much resemble the nestlings of the Red-faced Mousebirc which have only very little down and also entirely naked heads and necks On the third and fourth day after hatching the primary quills and rectrice: already start to appear and they grow quickly during the following days Before the end of the first week most of the body feathers are ahead] sprouting and even on the head the quills are appearing, beginning wit! those in the middle of the head which later on will form the feather-crest In the nestlings (of all species of mousebirds) a conspicuous patch of bar skin is situated behind the crest and it is slightly differently shaped in th various species. In the adult colies it is also present but is usually covere< by the long crest-feathers and only visible w T hen the crest is stiongl erected. The feather webs also begin to emerge from their sheaths oi the sixth or seventh day after hatching and therefore the young are almos totally covered w T hen they are just more than one week old. The eye. which are closed in the first days, are narrowly opened on the fourth c fifth day after hatching, but vision does not seem to be well establishe before the beginning of the second week in the nestlings post-embryon< life. There are some morphological differences between Blue-naped an Speckled Mousebird's nestlings which may be mentioned here. Fir:

DR. H. SCHIFTER--BREEDING BLUE-NAPED AND SPECKLED MOUSEBIRDS 59 the rump of the young Blue-naped Colies is grey as in the adult specimens, and also in the young and old Red-faced Mousebirds. On the contrary, in \oung Speckled Mousebirds a line of yellowish feathers appears on the middle ol the rump on the sixth or seventh day after hatching, therefore conspicuously contrasting with the brown feathers beside it. Laterally these feathers are followed again by yellowish ones, thus forming a nice pattern of stripes which has been also recorded by Rowan from South African nestlings of Colitis stnatus. This pattern is best developed at the beginning of the second week, later on the yellow feathers soon being covered by the brown feathers beside them, and it totally disappears when the nestlings are only two weeks old. This rump colour appears to be usual in the young of all subspecies of Cohus striatus because Herbert Friedmann has also recorded it for Kenyan Speckled Mousebirds in 1930. surprisingly the adult White-backed Colies ( Colius colius ) have a quite similar pattern on their backs. T he development of the beak of the nestlings is also very interesting. The young of the Speckled Mousebird have a yellowish-green upper mandible and a blackish lower-one, unlike the adult specimens which have .he upper mandible black (except for a bright spot on the culmen in northern subspecies of Colius striatus ) and the lower one silvery grey. The nestlings of the Blue-naped Mousebird have grey beaks only slightly greenish tinged and with no difference in colour between lower and upper mandible, thus resembling very much the beak of the young Red-faced Mousebirds. Like them they have also bulbous swellings at the base of he lower mandible which are somewhat similar to those in nestling wood- peckers and honey-guides, d hese swellings are already present when the voung hatch and they are fully developed at the end of the first week and it the beginning of the second. Later on they are slowly reduced and have ilmost disappeared after a month. The swellings are the same colour as he beaks and are somewhat more prominent in the young Red-faced ^olies, but also well developed in the young Blue-naped Mousebirds see plate 1). These swellings are, however, not the only difference petween the nestlings of Colius macrourus or C. indicus and C. striatus pecause the colour of the tongue and the gape is also different. Blue- laped and Red-faced Mousebird nestlings have pink tongues and gapes, v hile Speckled Mousebirds have black gapes and a yellow spot on the ongue thus giving the mouth of this species quite a different appearance, n all species I have observed the adult specimens have blackish gapes and ongues. A conspicuous white egg-tooth is also present in the young of >oth species dealt with here. In the nestlings of Blue-naped and Speckled dousebirds the egg-tooth persists usually 8 to 10 days after hatching, ' hile in the young of the Red-faced Mousebird I have seen it disappearing ( nly in the third week at the end of the nestling period. The beak of the young Blue-naped Mousebird darkens, beginning at the ip when the bird is about three weeks old, but remains whitish pink at the

60 DR. H. SCHIFTER--BREEDING BLUE-NAPED AND SPECKLED MOUSEBIRDS base and only becomes red when the bird is at least two months old. A similar colour change is to be seen in the young of the Red-faced Mouse- bird (with the base sometimes also becoming black before brightening to red) while the young of the Speckled Mousebird at the end of the first month shows a slight darkening not only proceeding from the tip but also from the base. In this state the young are easily identified by their speckled beaks which do not show the colour distribution of the adults before they are about three months old. Though the young mousebirds grow rapidly they only reach half the size of the adults when they leave the nest for the first time. In the Speckled Mousebird this may occur on the ioth or nth day and only slightly later in the Blue-naped Mousebird especially when the birds are frightened and the adults utter alarm notes. Usually they stay somewhat longer in the nest and leave it for the first time when they are about fourteen days old. Then they hop and climb more than fly which they do not do well before they are 16 or 17 days old. At this stage they also return to the nest and stay there during the night always accompanied by one parent bird, but they may sleep with the adult birds outside of the nest at the end of the third week after hatching. Therefore it is difficult to give an exact nestling period for mousebirds, but the span of 17! days given by- Moreau, Skead and others (all cited by Rowan) agrees with my experiences in captivity-bred specimens. I would say that Red-faced Mousebirds*: generally have a slightly longer nestling period than Blue-naped ant Speckled Mousebirds. As I have already stated the young are less thar half the size of the adult birds when they leave the nest but are already capable of flying. This is rather rare among birds, but seems to be a rule in the colies. Full-size is only reached when the young birds are aboul two months old, but even later they can be easily identified by the lack 0! red on the beaks and the pale colour of the naked skin around the eyes (ir Blue-naped and Red-faced Mousebirds) and by the speckled beaks anc shorter feather crests in Coitus striatus. The young colies are fed by the adults with regurgitated food (young 0 the Speckled Mousebird also take food from the beaks of the adult; especially when they have already left the nest) and they do not feed b) themselves until they are 5 to 6 weeks old. Only in the Speckled Mouse- bird have I observed that the young were sometimes independent from tht parents when they had only reached an age of about 4 weeks. Sometime: the young were still fed when the adults had again started to incubate Then the young even occasionally return to the nest to sit beside th< brooding parent, but sometimes they may also visit nests of other pair; and behave there in the same way unaffected by their hosts (which as fa as I have seen have never fed the strange young). On the contrary olde young from previous clutches may sometimes assist their parents n rearing young of the next brood and may feed them even longer than thei parents do.

algorithms.bodyText: DR. H. SCHIFTER--BREEDING BLUE-NAPED AND SPECKLED MOUSEBIRDS 61 Colies can also be kept together with their young when these are already jrown up because close connection persists in these highly sociable birds. So allo-preening continues between all members of a family group and they vill also roost together in the tight clusters which are typical of these birds. * have had the experience that the young neither disturb the breeding iairs nor are they attacked by the adults. Sometimes I had twenty or nore colies belonging to the same species in an aviary but there were no erious disputes among them (when specimens of different species are kept ogether some caution is necessary). On the contrary the young birds did lot breed successfully as long as they were kept with their parents. So llue-naped Mousebirds which I transferred in the aviary of the Speckled holies bred there successfully for the first time in November 1964 and ontinued breeding in 1965 at intervals of exactly two months (in the *ther pairs the intervals were much more irregular and often much horter). I had similar experiences concerning the remaining species. \0x25A0 herefore I will conclude that mousebirds may breed exceptionally when hey are only six months old but will usually only do this when they have eached an age of about one year. Otherwise breeding activities may ontinue over 5 or 6 years. A Red-faced Mousebird received in March 961, bred for the last time in September 1967 (one young being hatched nd reared) and died in July 1968, while a male Speckled Coly also received ill 1961 is still involved in breeding activities together with a five-year- id female but now seems to produce only infertile eggs. The following are some notes concerning the feeding of my colies, he Blue-naped Mousebirds are fed in nearly the same way as the Red- iced Colies which prefer bananas. Therefore they are always provided /ith them in considerable quantities. In addition the Blue-naped Colies Iso take pears, apples and especially lettuce. The Speckled Mousebirds, owever, are not so fond of bananas and prefer other fruit such as oranges, rapes, melons, soft apples and pears and they eat especially great quanti- es of lettuce. Like the other mousebirds they are also regularly provided ith white bread soaked in milk, a food they like very much. All my Dlies are also given honey-water which is very useful for adding vitamin lixtures such as Sanostol and Protovit. They prefer a softbill mixture nly for feeding young but they refuse it when they are not involved in reeding activities. I had the best breeding results when the mousebirds were kept in large ldoor aviaries with high temperatures usually ranging only from 20 to D C. Now they only breed when they are housed in the glasshouse Bring the summer months and in the winter are kept in smaller aviaries mfortunately it is not possible to heat the above-mentioned glasshouse). 1 my birdroom I always have a temperature of 18 to 20*C. Colies evertheless can stand lower temperatures without harm if it is dry. s Mrs. Row^an has recorded even from South Africa they on the contrary e very susceptible to wet and cold and therefore aviculturists should be

62 F. BARNICOAT--EARLY S. AFRICAN MEMBERS OF THE AVICULT. SOCIETY cautious about housing them in outdoor aviaries in colder climates, when the flights are not provided with sufficient shelters. In zoos the best results have been achieved by keeping them in indoor aviaries where the} thrive especially in the large planted flight aviaries which have beer recently constructed in many zoos. Kept under good conditions colies wil certainly prove satisfying and even charming aviary birds; an opinioi which I can confirm without doubt after more than seven years experience of keeping and breeding these odd and peculiar creatures.
algorithms.sectionHeader: SOME EARLY SOUTH AFRICAN MEMBERS 01 THE AVICULTURAL SOCIETY
algorithms.bodyText: By F. Barnicoat (Johannesburg, South Africa) In bird-fancying circles in South Africa the names of Frederick Meese and Robert Cleugh are legendary. Both belonged to the Avicultura Society in the thirties. Meeser had made a fortune through promoting greyhound racing, bu his real interest lay in bird keeping. His vast collection of parrot-like an- softbilled birds, which included one of the leading studs of Budgerigars i the country at that time, was beautifully housed in extensive aviaries in th spacious grounds of his home. Merely the amount of fruit set out for th birds used to stagger the lucky visitors to these aviaries. From this establishment, too, came a delightful parrot story. Durin the War a parrot from a captured German boat somehow got into th; collection of birds. To all who approached it would loudly shout " He Hitler! " The response this drew from people at that time might well b imagined. Before long the loud " Heil Hitler! " was followed in a deepe more gutteral tone by " B.Hitler "! Frederick Meeser died about 1948 and his collection, valued at # 12,0c or more was left in his will to the Johannesburg Zoo. A range of aviari( was erected there in his memory, but the rare birds were not successful! bred and very few survive now. The other avicultural showpiece in Johannesburg was the aviaries < Monty Kneen, a wealthy stockbroker, who often travelled to Sout America and elsewhere more or less for the purpose of acquiring ra; birds. In the very select suburb of Houghton he had his aviaries blaste out of the solid rock of a north facing ridge. Possibly even more absorbed in the hobby was Robert Cleugh. He ra a prosperous fumigating business, but found time to maintain an amazir collection of rare birds in a small suburban garden, practically every inch < which was given over to aviaries. " President of the South African ar Foreign Wild Bird Club " stands behind Robert Cleugh's name in tl membership list of the Avicultural Society. He was a keen exhibit*

. BARNICOAT--EARLY S. AFRICAN MEMBERS OF THE AVICULT. SOCIETY 63 ad sharer of his avicultural experiences. In many ways he was the ersonification of the South African and Foreign Wild Bird Club, which id not survive him for very long. Meetings were usually held at his ome where everything was geared to bird keeping activities. He had a ne library of bird books in a prominent position in his dining room, and t the bay window in a very large, fancy cage he kept a King Bird of aradise, the only one ever to be privately owned in South Africa. It is about a quarter of a century since I last visited Mr. Cleugh. He as then quite an elderly man and I remember the various Jays and other rge softbills he kept separately in large cages, but most of all he enthused /er a pair of Red-headed Parrot Finches he had just received from Cape- nvn. They were in an aviary all to themselves and he was hoping to breed om them. I doubt if he did because his own life with its very long and *ep association with aviculture was not destined to continue very much nger. I tried to locate the house again the other day. It is in a part of )hannesburg no longer fashionable. No trace of the aviaries remained, at in the small front garden was a fish pond with the remains of the mcrete figure of an eagle perched on the side. There could be no istake. Present day fanciers, who often take our long tradition of shows, show ge designs, schedules and the like for granted, owe much to the boundless ithusiasm of this and other early South African aviculturists, some of horn had brought what they knew about the hobby from Britain. Having collected an almost complete set of Avicultural Magazines, I as familiar with the very charming articles by C. N. Abrahams of Cape- wn which were published in the late thirties and early forties, and so hen I travelled the nine hundred odd miles to Capetown for the South Mean National Bird Show in 1961 and saw that one of the foreign wild rd judges was C. N. Abrahams, I decided to make a point of meeting m. He had retired and had not kept birds for years, but, as he was vered for his experience, his services as a judge were still sought. I ould think so too, on perusing the list of birds in his aviaries recorded the Avicultural Magazine of February 1938. I found him a charming man, and he wanted me to meet his wife, whom was bringing to the show on the Saturday afternoon if she could make She was in very poor health but could just get about and managed to me. So over a cup of tea they told me of their many delightful visits to r. Cleugh in Johannesburg, and they brought out some old copies of e Avicultural Magazine. These were precious possessions although cy had long since ceased to be members of the Society. The little boy, lose birthday present of three pairs of waxbills had been recorded as ving triggered off the hobby, had not grown up to be interested in eping birds; and bird watching, rather than bird keeping, had come to

M. F. COUPE--CASSOWARY AND EMU AT CHESTER ZOO be their hobby. Yet how thrilled they were to learn that David Seth Smith was still alive and now, approaching ninety, was the honourec president; and that Miss Knobel, whose gracious letters and encourage W ere vivid in their recollections, was a vice-president and still si actively associated with the Society. Mr. Abrahams had been harbou master and recalled helping Walter Goodfellow get fruit for his collectioi of birds as he passed through Capteown. They had coloured slides of the famous Royal x Red-headed Parrot Find hybrid (reported in the Avicultural Magazine of January-Februar 1945) and both its parents, taken many years afterwards of these bird when stuffed and reposed in a glass cabinet in the South African M^useum I was let into the secret that Mrs. Abrahams had really had most to d< with the writing of the articles. I recalled the problems caused by th Argentine ants, " the Japanese Army as they had referred to them becaus of their small size, and the description of how carefully the aviaries had ha< to be constructed to meet the difficult climatic conditions. ^.es she said, " those aviaries were well built and are still standing. I ca them his monuments, and sometimes when the South Easter is blowing gale we hear a crash and I say, ' There goes another piece of your monu ments! A year or so later I was looking through the South African Nation; panel of judges and read, " Mrs. Abrahams (deceased) ".
algorithms.equation: * * * CASSOWARY AND EMU AT CHESTER ZOO By M. F. Coupe
algorithms.bodyText: In 1962 a Cassowary (Casuarius casuarius) arrived at the Zoo and in 19^ was positively identified as a hen, as she laid an egg. Unfortunatel) mate could not be obtained for this bird. The flightless birds at Chester Zoo are accommodated in spacious opt paddocks at the rear of the Monkey House. At the beginning of 1967 a young pair of Emus arrived and were plact in the next paddock to the Cassowary. After a while the Emus start* fighting, so were put in separate paddocks, a male being accommodate in a pen adjoining that occupied by the female Cassowary. The Emu and Cassowary certainly looked quite friendly through tl wire mesh but it was a complete surprise to find the two birds together c Tuesday, 5th November 1968. Upon investigation it was found that tl Cassowary had simply kicked down the door separating the two enclosur and had gone to visit her friend. Keepers went inside the enclosure to separate the two species, as it w thought that they could easily damage each other. As soon as they we inside the Cassowary started to attack and being such a dangerous bi they beat a very hasty retreat.

algorithms.bodyText: These two birds are still together and are extremely friendly towards ich other but the Emu will try to attack the other Emu through the fence, e are keeping a watchful eye on the two birds and they are proving a ther unusual exhibit at the Zoo. [Since these notes were written we have managed to separate the Emu and issowary. However, we have been unable to introduce the Emu to his mate due the aggressive behaviour of both birds.]
algorithms.sectionHeader: BIRD PELLETS--AN OPPORTUNITY FOR AVICULTURAL STUDY
algorithms.bodyText: By David E. Hanson (Aberlour, Banffshire, Scotland) Before the reader turns hastily to the next article, let it be said imme- ately that there is nothing objectionable (or smelly) about a bird pellet! he majority of readers will be quite familiar with the term " pellet ", it it may be just as well to summarize the facts. A bird pellet is a iherent, compacted mass consisting usually of the indigestible portions 1 the bird's food, and is ejected through the mouth. A number of papers have been written on this subject, and many have 1 ncluded that pellet analysis does not provide a reliable indication of a Ird's food. Despite this some fairly extensive food studies have been inducted which make considerable use of pellet analysis, particularly in le families of " hawks ", " owls ", " kingfishers ", " bee-eaters ", 'waders " and " shrikes ". For such analyses to be of the utmost value, it is necessary to know a itle about the frequency of pellet ejection, pellet returns of food items, This is most conveniently accomplished by studying birds in iptivity, whilst of course the very nature of the bird's being in captivity uy influence the factors which it is intended to investigate! A number of studies have been completed, almost exclusively with the )wls " and " hawks ". The results indicate that for the owls in :neral, pellet analysis gives a fairly complete and accurate picture of the rtebrate food, although quantitative assessment of invertebrate food is licult if not impossible. Young birds are able to digest more of the t nes in their food, it appears, than adults. With the hawks, there is considerable disagreement amongst authors yarding some species, although most concede that qualitative but not antitative analysis is practicable. In general, hawks digest more of the *eous material in their food than the owls, young birds more so than ults. Miss Hibbert-Ware's study of the pellets of the Common Heron Ardea erea explains why it is that the pellets of this species do not give a mplete picture of the vertebrate food, but H. C. White found that the ilets of the Kingfisher Megaceryle alcyon provided a reliable indication

of the fish diet of that bird. He also found that young Kingfishers digested more of the fish bones than did adults. In these days of the increasing rarity of some of our most beautiful birds, for example the Kingfisher Alcedo atthis , an investigation into food habits could make greater use of pellet analysis, thereby lessening the need for stomach analysis which in the absence of fresh natural corpses must necessitate the further reduction of populations of these birds. In addition to the possible " use " to which information regarding pellets can be put, there is surely a case for collecting data " for its own sake The writer has never been able to see a " use " for the wealth of data on birds' eggs, or indeed for the numerous collections of eggs, but he would not suggest that the studies were " useless ! Bird pellets have been sadly neglected in the past, partly perhaps because of the " unpleasant " nature which is often mistakenly ascribed to them, but largely because of the difficulty of finding them in the wild. When one considers the minute size and often friable nature of the pellets of the smaller passerines, it is not difficult to see how easily they may be over- looked. In addition to this the birds do not eject their pellets in con- venient places or in the same place! In the wild, possibly the surest way of obtaining information, short of witnessing the act of ejection, is to investigate recently used nests. A recent search through the nest of the Tree-creeper Certhia familiaris by G. P. Mawson has produced some good examples of the pellets of this bird, and the writer has found pellets in the nest of a Hedge-sparrow Prunella modularis. This sort of information is interesting, but it does not indicate how frequently pellets are ejected, nor the nature of the returns in relation to the food items. It is here that the aviculturist has several decided advantages: (i) he knows the nature of the food; (ii) he can " find " a pellet with relative ease; (iii) he knows approximately when each pellet is ejected, that is if the bird is in a relatively small cage. In the following list of families, in which there are species known tc eject pellets, many are included on evidence of the habit in captive birds In some instances there is doubt, or conflicting evidence, and such families are marked (?).

algorithms.bodyText: Many readers will possess birds of these and other families. Perhap they have already noticed that such birds are in the habit of ejectin pellets; it is impossible to " miss " the ejection of pellets by some species In the study of " owls " and " hawks " the ground has been fairly we covered, and the interested reader is referred to the papers listed at th end of this article. It will be noticed that some of the papers consider th same species, and there must be countless species which have never bee studied at all! For the majority of the families listed here very little is known concernin the ejection of pellets, and there are many questions waiting to be answered
algorithms.listItem: (i) Does a particular species eject pellets? (ii) How regular is the habit? How does this depend upon the natui of the food? What portions of food are t ejected (not eaten)? (iii) To what extent are the food items altered when returned in pell< form? Is the material evidence in a pellet a useful guide to tl food eaten? (iv) What is the size variation of the pellets? (v) What is the shape variation of the pellets? (vi) What is the consistency of the pellets?
algorithms.bodyText: Here follows a summary of a little investigation into the pellet formatic of a Rook Corvus frugilegus--an opportunity afforded by the arrival of bird with a broken wing, which has since lived in captivity. Notes on the pellet formation of a Rook (Corvus frugilegus) Captive bird studied. Food. Juvenile rabbits, lizard, mice, " pet food ", bread, dead birc etc. (Bones of adult rabbits, rats, rejected.) Study started 8.5.68. Frequency of ejection of pellets. Between 8.5.68 and 24.5.68 mclusi 16 pellets were ejected at irregular intervals, i.e. average of one per da>
algorithms.reference: 25.5.68 smaller than usual pellet. 26.5.68 smaller mis-shapen pellet. 27.5.68 and 28.5.68 no pellets ejected. 29.5.68 badly formed pellet ejected . . . the last!
algorithms.bodyText: Despite an unchanged diet, the bird has to my knowledge ejected d pellet since. Since writing this a few badly formed pellets were iund, and it is possible that others broke up on ejection and were distinguishable from the floor covering. Cotitent of pellets. Of the vertebrate remains eaten by the bird, very tie trace appeared in the pellets. Egg-shell was to a great extent digested. The bulk of each pellet was taken up with sawdust--the material used r covering the cage bottom (although the food was usually placed on ates). Grit was always available to the bird, but it was not often apparent in e pellets. The " pet food " containing a mixture of grain types usually appeared one or more items per pellet. Shape of pellets. Generally pointed at one end. Size of pellets. Average of 14: 29-6 x 13-9 mm. Length range: 15-40 (mode 35) mm. Width range: 9-16 (mode 15) mm. (the mode being the most common value). An examination of the pellets of wild Rooks during the spring might idicate that their diet is principally vegetarian. Very little trace of ;imal food appeared in the pellets of the captive Rook despite a diet insisting of about 75% animal food.

In the absence of some existing organization to which data concerning ! Nets could be sent (or from which data may be obtained), a group of Tividuals in several countries, The International Bird Pellet Study l ' ou P> has been formed. Now about two years old, the Group aims only e keeping in touch those interested in pellets, and to collect data scattered t 'oughout ornithological and avicultural circles regarding the habit. Information, however little in quantity, regarding the ejection of pellets species in families other than the Accipitridae, Falconidae, Tytonidae d Strigidae will be added to the data already collected, and aviculturists 3: asked to communicate to the writer, at Aberlour House, Aberlour, fnffshire, Scotland, AB 3 9 LJ., any observations they may make. It is the intention to publish the accumulated data eventually, although it time is yet a long way off! In the meantime such information as we v^e will be made freely available to someone studying a particular family genus.

Aviculture and the Introduction of Non-native Species Within recent times some of the disastrous results of introducing specie from one region of the earth to another have become so well-known tha no one can now argue that such introductions could be done with impunit and without careful study. The International Union for the Conservatioi of Nature's Commission on Ecology has issued a statement within the las few months drawing to the attention of various governments the legislation and administrative measures needed to control this introduction of non native species; but apart from the government of the United States whic ! has become a little apprehensive about bird importations, and the Austra lian Government which has taken rather drastic action, few seem to hav seriously considered the part that aviculturists may play in deliberate 0 inadvertent introductions. There are several trends and occurrences in present-day avicultur which may give cause for concern. One is the increase in the keeping c birds at partial liberty. This is sometimes done in an attempt to breed bird that has otherwise proved too difficult, or may merely be used i order to give birds with cramped quarters greater liberty. Another is th tendency for some aviculturists to release small flocks of some species which are available cheaply from dealers, in the hope that they will sta nearby. In both instances the people concerned can probably feel tha they are presenting little danger to our native birds by so doing. Froi past evidence it would seem that few foreign birds survive our winter: although they may move around considerably, and Budgerigars hav occurred with migrating birds on lightships! If, however, one specie does prove to be hardy this is precisely the kind of bird that will be give

her encouragement, and the fact that nothing has " got away " so in this part of the world does not mean that it never will, he main danger here is that if such experiments become popular and ely advocated in avicultural writing then aviculturists in other, more mrable, climates may well be encouraged to emulate them, with strous results. .nother worrying thing that has occurred is requests to various bird- )ing organisations from aviculturists abroad, in less well-developed ntries, for numbers of individuals of our commoner native species ch they intend to release in their own countries. This should never be nitted. Some such requests have come from South America where the :ad of agriculture and urban development is fast destroying native Nation and where the native birds are being rapidly reduced. Where I drastic changes are taking place there is inevitably a time-lag before e, at least, of the native species adapt themselves to their new environ- it. If, during this crucial period, foreign birds already adapted to the lged environment are introduced they will fill the vacant niche and the ve species will be robbed of an opportunity to adapt themselves; while petition with the new invaders may in some cases be the final factor in ging about their extermination. his is not idle theory. It was changes of this kind which enabled the ise-Sparrow and Starling to establish themselves widely in North irica. In Australia the Spice Finch from Asia, brought in as a cage- , has established itself in the north-east and is spreading and driving the native grassfinches; while in some urban areas the Spotted Dove Palm Dove occupy the places which should be filled by the smaller it species of dove. is up to the aviculturists themselves to show a responsible attitude in matter. If we do not ensure that our birdkeeping is so organised that es not threaten the existing wild bird population directly or indirectly, re likely to find that legislation will be imposed upon us from outside h will seriously curtail our activities, e would therefore make the following pleas:
algorithms.listItem: 1. All aviculturists should take extreme care when allowing birds >erty for any purpose, and should try to ensure that they do not escape rmanently and can be enclosed again without difficulty. 2. Aviculturists should not liberate birds at random just to see if they II stay nearby. 3 - Liberation experiments of any kind should not be generally en-
algorithms.bodyText: uraged and should be actively discouraged in climates where mild nters or other favourable conditions might enable the birds to ablish feral populations. 4 - No aviculturist should even contemplate supplying birds to persons other countries who intend to liberate them and attempt permanent roduction without proper official sanction.

A Common Heron has just flown over. There is nothing remarkable i that as " Fish Birds ", as my Kentish gardener calls them, are occasionall to be seen fishing in one of our ponds. It does, however, remind me the some years ago there was, and maybe there still is, a small colony c Common Herons at Lyra Geo, near Stromness, Orkney. The Commo Heron normally nests in high trees, but is fairly adaptable and a variety c sites are recorded in Witherby--" small trees, bramble-clumps, or 0 ground among heather, on islands, ledges on face of cliffs, among reeds b lake side, and once recorded on ground in wood and on shingle on beach In Orkney there are practically no trees, at least none suitable for a heronn and there these birds took up their abode in the cliffs.

algorithms.title: Buff-throated Sunbird
algorithms.sectionHeader: ,lVI CULTURAL MAGAZINE THE JOURNAL OF THE AVICULTURAL SOCIETY
algorithms.bodyText: fl. 75 .--No. 3 .--All rights reserved. MAY-JUNE, 1969

(Nectarinia adelberti) By A. A. Prestwich (Edenbridge, Kent, England) There are two races of Nectarinia adelberti: adelberti (Gervais), Sierra Leone to Ghana (Gold Coast). eboensis Jardine, Togoland to south-eastern Nigeria, vliss Chloe Talbot-Kelly has depicted a male and a female, life size, on a mgo flower. The type of this species was obtained by Adelbert, supposedly in Sene- and was described as Cinnyris adelberti by Gervais, in 1834. Shelley
algorithms.listItem: 96) transferred it to the genus Chalco?nitra, and it is now included in 1 vast Nectarinia Illiger. > ery little appears to have been recorded concerning this sunbird.
algorithms.bodyText: Electors seem to be interested in little other than recording, in the past < netimes not too reliably, the area in which their specimens were obtained, s indeed very strange how often they make the excuse that any particular >d was too far away, in too tall a tree or in too dense scrub, etc, or else it v> too dark to allow observation. And yet they manage to collect it, ner dead or alive! L S. Webb introduced this and numerous other sunbirds, to aviculture, brought some from the Gold Coast in 1937. The London Zoo Report hat year lists it as new to the collection; and C. T. Maxwell exhibited 11; at the " Crystal Palace National Show " (Dorland Hall, Lower ^ent Street), in January the following year. There have, of course, " n others since. "he only really informative account is appropriately by Webb. It is uth quoting extensively: In company with Superb Sunbirds (Cinnyris superbus), Olive-bellied : 1 birds (C. chloropygius ), Olive Sunbirds (Cyanomitra verticalis), and \0x25A0 or three species of Anthreptes, as well as numbers of Bulbuls (Pycno- ' ls barbatus ), Buff-throated Sunbirds congregate in the tall bombax r 's, gaining sustenance from the large scarlet flowers, which are such an sistible attraction to all nectar-feeding birds. During the months of mary and Tebruary--the period of efflorescence of the bombax trees in Aanti Buff-throated Sunbirds could be seen frequently, but in March f see med to disappear completely, whereas most of the other Sunbirds
algorithms.reference: A. A. PRESTWICH--THE BUFF-THROATED SUNBIRD
algorithms.bodyText: remained to feed on the flowers of bananas and paw-paws, etc. It is quil likely that the former migrated to another district where the bombax wei flowering later. " Like most species of the genus Chalcomitra , it does not become confidingly tame as some of the Anthveptes or Cinnyvis , but its striking an unusual coloration and graceful movements combine to make it one ( the most desirable of the nectarinidae. " Owing to their feeding habits, Buff-throated Sunbirds are exceeding difficult to capture alive. Bombax trees grow to a great height and tl lower half of the trunk is branchless, and so climbing them in the humi enervating heat of the Gold Coast forest is an arduous proceeding. Til crevices in the bark harbour colonies of vicious black ants which emeq in thousands as one labours up the tree, and if one can survive this 01 slaught and reach the branches it is to discover that the fun has only ju: commenced, for here large red ants that make their nests among the leav advance from all directions i with intent to do bodily harm . " Both these varieties will fight an intruder like maddened warriors ar swarm over him in incredible numbers inflicting painful bites. Added this, swarms of small flies, resembling minute bees in shape, are attract* to one's eyes for the moisture, and hover in front of them with an annoyir zigzag flight. " The upper trunk and branches of bombax trees are studded wii protuberances with sharp thorny tips so that it is almost impossible climb them without getting one's arms badly torn . The Nigerian eboensis differs from the Senegal by the darker chestn (less rufous) of the breast and belly of the male and by a slightly pal throat. The female appears to be lighter coloured on the underparts, tl breast being pale yellowish-grey marked with pale brown. Sir William Jardine (1843) says this sunbird was first obtained by Mj Thomson, one of the surgeons to the Niger expedition. He names Nectarinia eboensis , Thomson, Eboe Sun-bird. According to Bannerman: " S. Marchant writes concerning the birds Owerri Province that it is not often seen and appears to be rare, apparent being restricted to kurimis and the vicinity of tall trees, often in t neighbourhood of native villages. He remarked that it usually remai high above ground in the highest trees where it is difficult to obsen Perched thus it has been heard giving its loud, typically Sunbird song ' tseep . . . tseep . . . tseep ' in a level key. Finally, Mr. and Mrs. H. Marshall inform me that they have noted that it is particularly fond trees on which there are hanging ants' nests. They often observed the Sunbirds hovering in front of such nests apparently picking off the ants William Serle collected in Eastern Nigeria during 1952-55. He writ* " The species seems well adapted to the thickly populated, intensiv* farmed ' forest ' country of the south. Specially partial to high trees the vicinity of water. The clearly defined straw-coloured throat is

::ellent field mark in the adult male. Very active, especially in the ttest, sunniest hours. The course of sustained flights is undulating id high. I have observed a male in ' butterfly ' display flight singing :>sionately. Nine [of 16] of those collected had eaten insects, but from :id observation it seems to be chiefly a nectar eater, and five stomach : Rents that were tested tasted strongly of sugar
