algorithms.figure: * * * THE SPECTACLED JAY-THRUSH (Garrulax canorus) By Yeo Kok Hoe (Singapore)
algorithms.bodyText: The Spectacled Jay-Thrush is a favourite cagebird among Chinese Eciers. It is so for two reasons. Firstly, for its exquisite song which spares favourably with the best bird songs of other lands. In Singa- ce and the Malaysian territories, as a songbird it ranks at par with the oma and the Red-whiskered Bulbul (a native songbird which seems to d a special attraction for the Malay bird fanciers). Secondly, for its gnacity. Like the Magpie-Robin noted for its fighting qualities, the 1 cky Jay-Thrush is often trained as a fighting bird by gamblers and ced against other birds in illegal contests where money changes hands wagers. depicted in art and extolled in literature, this Chinese songbird is >orted in large numbers from maritime Fukien Province in South .ina to Southeast Asia, Hongkong being the chief collecting and distri- 1 ing centre. It is strange that despite the presence of large numbers of ;ed specimens in Southeast Asia no local colonies have yet been estab- ed by escaped birds in these regions. V native of the vast sprawling hill forests of Szechuan Province, South- ct China, it is now widespread in South China ranging into the northern 1 vinces in the summer season. There are no sub-species, although the
algorithms.footnote: 8o
algorithms.bodyText: existence of an albino bird is mentioned in an old Chinese encyclopaedi published some decades ago in Shanghai. For some quaint reasons fanciers in Singapore group the bird into the " Canton " and the Shang hai " types, the latter being purported to be of bigger size and mor immaculate feathering. The plumage colour is brown with a tinge of grey on the belly. Slightl darker or lighter shades of brown occur in individuals. " Golden brown is the most attractive. The distinctive feature is a bluish-white ey rim extending backwards like an eyebrow, hence the Chinese rendering c the name--" Huamei " which means painted eyebrows. About eigl inches in total length, the bird has a fairly thick body and noticeabl short rounded wings. In the wild state, it probably favours deep wooc and forests, spending its time in the underbrush searching for insect wild seeds and berries, constantly flicking and swishing its tail as it mov< along in small foraging parties in the non-breeding season. I had tl occasion to observe a bird of mine which escaped into the garden. Durir the brief period before recapture, it skulked among the bushy hedges an fence creepers or hopped rapidly up the branches of the Casuarina tree It was very hard to spot even while perching on the swaying tip end of branch. Constantly on the move, its calls added to its elusiveness, caged specimen is restless and noisy. At times it performs seeming endless hops up and down the cage. The sexes are alike and difficult to differentiate. The female is general smaller and lacks the song of the male. The female call is a series monotones which are always answered by a male within hearing in a she burst of song. There are no records of breeding as only cock birds a kept as pets. Of hardy constitution, the Spectacled Jay-Thrush is however prone overgrown beak and claws. Large sized perches help towards keepu the claws trim, the thick, rough-surfaced types with their natural contc tions being favoured. Because of the excitable nature of the bird, fancit are reluctant to handle their birds for clipping for fear of frightening t birds. Cases are not uncommon where birds are reduced to nervousm and frightened into total loss of song. The problem is solved by gluing strip of fine quality sandpaper along the underside of the perch. If a bird to be handled for some reason or other, it should be caught with little fi to avoid fright and excessive dropping of feathers. As regards the ovt grown upper mandible, it is taken care of by providing the bird witl cuttlefish bone to peck with. There is also a tendency to develop hs horny scales on the legs and toes. This unsightly condition is accentuat by not bathing the bird regularly. The staple food is " egg rice a traditional Chinese birdfood form prepared by frying unpolished rice with beaten egg yolk to a degree crispness so that it keeps fresh for long period without deteriorate Raw food in the form of live skinks are fed to the bird. The insectivon

;3ect of the diet consists of king-size grasshoppers which abound in agapore in the " lallang " areas and secondary forests and are offered for i.e by professional collectors who go as far afield as southern Johore, a ighbouring state to the north of Singapore. Grasshoppers are a song mulant and are fed to the birds without restraint. Unlike mealworms, :2y do not cause any ill effect. A generous supply of grasshoppers given ily to the Spectacled Jay-Thrush will keep the bird in full song through- :t the year except when in moult. The Spectacled Jay-Thrush is a great bather and in Singapore where the rather is hot, bathing should be a daily routine to be observed without 1 or the bird will soon loose its feather condition. Fanciers in the fiurbs leave their caged birds overnight in the open to catch the morning w which is good for the feathers. When bathing the bird, a cage with ] hallow bath-pan is required. Full spraying should be avoided whenever :ssible as this excites the bird and fails to wet the feathers sufficiently, le best time for bathing is in the afternoon hours in the heat of the day aen the bird will take to its bath without undue delay and soak itself oroughly provided the bathing-cage is placed in the sun and at a regular ae. The song of the Spectacled Jay-Thrush is loud, full-throated and :isists of a variety of melodious phrases of about three to half a dozen tes of varying scales repeated two or three times in rapid succession, le style of delivery is not quite unlike that of the Mockingbird. A rson who has not heard the song before is bound to be delighted by the :iuty of the clear ringing notes. The full song is heard in the morning and this gradually softens in pitch id intensity towards noon when it is maintained in an undertone at inter- s with sporadic bursts of song. To enjoy the full beauty of the song, a fancier needs to take his bird for a oil in the countryside in the early hours of dawn when it will render its :5t and employ all that it has in its repertoire. The tones heard in the *rning quietude among trees and blossoms take on a new depth never xeived when the song is rendered in the confines of the living room. \s in most cases of beginner fanciers, when the initial enthusiasm of dkeeping wears off and the birds are neglected, abatement culminating complete cessation of song sets in. I had a good songster, a one-time :itest singer so to speak, in this condition. It sat on the perch with ffTed bodyfeathers, oblivious to the world, only rousing itself to feed and Ink. It perked up on the introduction of a new bird. It is at least en years old now as I have kept it since February 1964. The feathers ve somewhat lost their gloss and the tail feathers refuse to grow. I call 1 Champion " as it is my best singer and is able to produce a surprising iety of notes. Although it has now reverted back to its old singing pit, its notes have somehow lost their original timbre and power. Age - 1 prime factor in the gradual loss of song.

Like the Shamas and the Magpie-Robins, individual birds vary singing capability and style. A good songster is able to give a superlati 1 rendering of all the typical Huamei refrains which are a delight to the es The cock bird is an accomplished mimic and if kept with other songbiri will incorporate their call notes in its song. My birds are able to imita with remarkable likeness the calls of my neighbour's Red-Whisker< Bulbuls and the staccato notes of my pet leafbird. If one whistles tl opening bars of a song or play flute music on the amplifier, a cock w: invariably respond and burst into a wild medley. Sudden darkening the sky followed by rain has similar effect of inducing the bird to sing. The cock Spectacled Jay-Thrush is extremely pugnacious and the sig of another male specimen will induce it to display a series of challeni postures--quivers its wings, fluffs its body feathers and utters low cat-li mews, or stands erect on the perch performing slow Hula-like movemer and utters chuckling notes as it dips its tail and nods its head in rhythm unison, or ostentatiously jumps up and down the perch with much nois Ever spoiling for fight, it makes successive attempts to dash across the cag When excited, it moves restlessly or " freezes " into a posture as if me merized. A cock bird will also start a duet with another in sight, pourii out his song in an attempt to drown the voice of the other. If the bir are not removed in time, the song intensity may eventually frighten o bird into silence. It is therefore imperative that if two cock birds a kept, they must be kept out of sight but within earshot of one anothc This has the twofold effect of (i) stimulating the birds to sing by conta and response calls and (2) preventing the nerve fright. New birds of both sexes are imported into Singapore and at the first ne' of their arrival the birdshops are clustered with fanciers each eager bring home a good bird. The new birds are cheap and cost only Singapore dollars each. They are put in special cages designed to conti nervousness. These are hung in rows under bamboo poles for t inspection of prospective buyers who will whistle the female call to pi out the males. There is no doubt that a bird which responds in a she burst of song is a male. In the selection of a potential singer, so performance, tone quality and posture are the qualities to look for. T eyebrow or " spectacle " must be thick and well-defined. It is believ that the eyebrow serves as an indicator to the bird's singing capability, the expert care of the professional birdkeepers, the new birds which th brought home are put into an intensive course of nutritious food ai grasshopper diet to pull them out of the shock of transhipment. Aftei couple of months when the birds are more steady and are in full song, th are offered for sale. The taming process is a job usually undertaken by the professional a the more enterprising fanciers. The bird is confined in a small rectangu cage of deliberately low height, usually not more than eight in. high, wi three closed sides and one barred front. The idea here is to give the bi

try little room to make wild dashes. When the bird is less flighty (it kes about a month or so), it is transferred to a permanent cage described 1 the concluding paragraph. A piece of dark coloured cloth is stitched to t to the cage top. If the bird is still nervous, the perch should be fixed tar the top of the cage. The cage is hung high above head level, his is important because the bird should not be allowed to get unduly ervous or otherwise the undesirable " twirling of the neck " will occur, his is a condition very similar to that which afflicts the Green Singing inch and the Pekin Robin, but is unfortunately more pronounced, aking the birds out for regular walks in the parks on weekends or taking iem to coffee-shops where bird fanciers congregate are also part of the \0x25A0ocess of taming. Taming is completed when the cloth cover may be moved permanently with the bird showing no undue signs of nervous- [sss. I have no practical experience with regard to keeping this bird in a trden aviary. My experience is limited to an hour's observation of a lir kept in a school aviary in a mixed collection of birds consisting of me Spotted Doves, Red-Whiskered Bulbuls, Hanging Parrots, Java Darrows, Emerald Doves and pheasants. The aviary was spacious, some ) ft. long, 12 ft. wide and 8 ft. high, shielded from wind at one end. he inmate cock Spectacled Jay-Thrush was an exceptionally big speci- en and the hen was slightly bedraggled and her wing primaries showed int traces of white. They were active birds and hopped from branch to anch, frequently darting to the ground to forage for insects. While on e ground, they moved in a series of fast well executed Kangaroo-like )ps. Three or four times the cock covered the full length of the aviary Dm end to end in less than half a dozen hops. This was indeed an exhi- tion of fluid movement. The birds were not overtly aggressive though ey had a tendency to drive the smaller birds from the water trays. Even e larger sized doves fought shy of them. They did not appear to be raid of the pheasants with which they fed side by side at the food trough, hile on the ground, they would lift up their heads to look around. A ssing cat set up an alarm call from the cock, which sent the hen flying up a branch. Anting was indulged by both birds. At intervals the cock ould hop up to a top branch and burst into a short song. The birds dis- ayed a mixture of cockiness and curiosity reminiscent of Mynah birds, ^ery now and then, one bird would peep into a nest of mice outside the iary on the top wire-netting, chiding incessantly, to be joined by the 'her. To the Chinese fanciers, part of the fun of bird-keeping is in owning a rdcage. It is with this in mind that every Chinese birdcage is construc- I with meticulous care. It is a masterpiece of art in itself and comes incipally from China where cage-making has been refined to an exclusive ; l. Mainly made of a type of stout and flexible bamboo, the cage is light ; d easy to carry. Cylindrical in general outline, it comes in three

84 DR- E. M. LANG-SOME OBSERVATIONS ON THE CAPE PARROT standard sizes and is equipped with a detachable three-legged bottoi designed for easy cleaning. Highly decorative and fashioned to please th eye, it has elaborate patterns and exquisite carvings engraved on it. Th more expensive cages are of hardwoods complete with decorative jade an ivory pieces. Most of these are antique cages tracing their origin back 1 bygone eras. Crowned by a shiny chrome-plated dragon-headed hangc hook and complete with a pair of fanciful porcelain food cups and a sing] perch of bizarre contortions, sometimes sheathed in colourful snakeskii a Chinese birdcage certainly heightens the pleasure of birdkeeping.
algorithms.sectionHeader: SOME OBSERVATIONS ON THE CAPE PARRCT
algorithms.bodyText: (Poicephalus robustus robustus) By Dr. Ernst M. Lang (Basle, Switzerland) Members of the Poicephalus group have been represented in the Bas Zoo for many years, among them the Brown Parrot (P. meyeri ), the Browi headed Parrot (P. cryptoxanthus), the Orange-bellied Parrot (P. rujiventri and the Senegal Parrot (P. senegalus). As a boy I received a pet Seneg which I kept from 4th April 1924 to 26th October i960--more than 3 years. On nth June 1955, at the instigation of the director, Dr. D. Hey, v received from the Department of Nature Conservation, Stellenbos South Africa, a pair of Cape Parrots; which were determined from Aust Roberts' " The Birds of South Africa " (1948), as Poicephalus robust robustus. The range of this parrot extends from Knysna to the Eastei Transvaal, P. r. angolensis is found from the River Limpopo to Ango while P. r. suahelicus inhabits the eastern part of Southern Rhodesia ar the former Portuguese East Africa. The three subspecies differ in tl size of the beak and in minor colour features. The South African Natu Conservation Authorities estimate the Cape Parrot population to be in precarious position and, in recognition of the breeding achievements Basle Zoo, entrusted us with a pair, expressing the hope that the parrc could be induced to breed. On their arrival, the Cape Parrots were introduced into an aviary, 195 225 x 150 cm., shared by Brown Parrots, Senegals and, now and then, ev<
algorithms.reference: a Grey Parrot. The mixture did not exactly harmonize; at any rate, <\0x25A0 8th January 1956 an entry in the observation records mentions an atta on one of the Capes by a Brown Parrot; the antagonists were separated b only just in time. A note, two years later, refers to a serious quarrel witf Grey Parrot. In March 1964, when all the other species had been remov<
algorithms.bodyText: DR. E. M. LANG--SOME OBSERVATIONS ON THE CAPE PARROT 85 iOm the aviary, the Cape Parrots finally began to reproduce. Practice as shown us that, often enough, breeding activities do not occur until one air of birds has gained the sole ownership of an aviary. In the Cape Parrot the sexes are easily distinguishable. The female is haracterized by a bright red forehead while the head of the male shows ractically no red. The male possesses the more powerful beak of the two. On 16th April 1964 the first chick hatched in a hollow tree trunk. A est-box check on 12th May revealed a half-grown nestling and an addled yg. On 29th June the young bird left the breeding place, to be observed, few days later, climbing about in the aviary. The nestling period had *sted approximately 74 days. The youngster made good progress and as separated from its parents on 9th September. On 29th August 1966 was given, together with another juvenile from a later clutch, to the an Diego Zoo, U.S.A. On 26th October of the same year another chick hatched which lived for lly 10 days. Several times during the following year, 1965, eggs were laid, a number -ing deposited on the aviary floor beside the nesting hollow. The keeper ansferred them to the nest where they were incubated, somewhat iphazardly, by the adults but nevertheless failed to hatch. Four eggs ere removed in June as the birds had lost interest in brooding. In July ie nest was visited again. Apparently further layings took place for, on )th August, three chicks were present. The first fledged on 4th and the st on 16th October. The nestling period, in this case, lasted for 55-67 lys. Each youngster had badly damaged head feathers, in fact, a large irt of the crown was quite naked. Evidently the hen, in an over- gerness to preen the chicks, bites their head quills right off. As soon as e young birds can feed independently and are removed from the aviary, e feathers generally grow normally. The hen practises the same sconcerting habit on the cock with the result that his crown, too, is nost bald. In 1966 two clutches were laid, the first of which failed to hatch. Tw f o died eggs w^ere removed in March. In May, however, the nest contained 0 further chicks. They fledged and, on 14th June, were separated from e adults to allow their head feathers to recover as quickly as possible. The following year there were two successful clutches. On 1st March 67 and 3rd September 1967 respectively, three chicks hatched which re reared by the parents. The nestling period in the September clutch ted from 7 2 ~79 days. One of the birds moved clumsily, being unable use his left wing. I took him home and we fed him on a pre-chewed ish consisting mainly of rusk and banana. He adapted to his new roundings within a few days, allowed himself to be handled and supped > food out of a spoon. The wing obviously gave him some pain but the ury could not be exactly located. I suspected a torn muscle in the ist. The wing has never been folded close to the body nor has the

86 DR. E. M. LANG--SOME OBSERVATIONS ON THE CAPE PARROT power of flight improved, so he has stayed with us ever since as a pet, is perfectly tame, climbs eagerly onto a proferred hand and makes friends with everyone. The young parrot (hatched 3rd September 1967) afforded an excelleni opportunity to observe the change of plumage. At first he had a brick-rec forehead like the other members of the clutch but showed no red colouring elsewhere. The head and neck were a brownish olive-green, wings and tail dark green, rump and breast a lighter green. In February 1968, the tiny red forehead feathers began to fall out so that, by the middle of April the red border had completely disappeared. On 14th April I observed the appearance of red feathers above the ankle joint, the beginnings 0: the red breeches worn by the adults of both sexes. On 19th June tht first tiny red feathers under the front edge of the wing sprouted. Oui Cape Parrot must be a male because in the females, as was observed in tht tame bird's sisters, a bright red band on the forehead appears simul taneously with the red breeches. On 3rd April 1968 Keeper Marcus Ruf discovered a full clutch of thre< eggs which had probably just been completed. On 30th April two very small nestlings were present. The third egj contained a dead foetus. After 65-68 days the youngsters--again witl bald-bitten heads--left the nesting hollow. On 20th August they seemet sufficiently independent to be separated from the adults. Thus from seven clutches, 15 Cape Parrots have been reared in th. Basle Zoo since 1964. The nestling period was established at betweei 54 and 79 days. The juveniles show a brick-red colouring on the forehea( which disappears, at the age of about five months, to be replaced, in th< females, by a bright red band. #
algorithms.sectionHeader: D. GOODWIN OBSERVATIONS ON TWO JAMESON'S FIREFINCHES 87 OBSERVATIONS ON TWO JAMESON'S FIREFINCHES
algorithms.bodyText: By Derek Goodwin (London, England) Introduction I bought a male and female Lagonostica rhodopareia jamesoni on the 8th iptember 1963. The male was in beautiful condition but the female oked very ill and I doubted my ability to save her, only too justifiably, as e died the following day. Soon after this I obtained a female of the irk western race (L. r. virata). In this form, which must be well on the ay to becoming a good species, the sexes are nearly alike and the female, though darker, shows as much red as a male of the eastern forms. I ve described both forms elsewhere (Goodwin 1964) and explained how ese two firefinches apparently " mistook " each other's sex. They did 't respond sexually to one another and the female paired to a male Dark refinch [L. rubricata ) and later died egg-bound. All my attempts to obtain a female jamesoni failed (and have, indeed, ntinued to fail from that day to this, December 1968) but in May 1964 I maged to get hold of another female virata. At this time I had no irk Firefinches and, with no other congenors present, the jamesoni and ata eventually paired, after an initial period of " misunderstanding " lowed by several weeks in which they showed little sign of either stile or sexual reactions. They frequently nested but on only one ~asion am I certain that a young one was hatched and then it vanished thout trace on the second day.
algorithms.subsectionHeader: Social and Sexual Behaviour of the Male
algorithms.bodyText: On 20th February 1966 I put a Rosy-rumped Waxbill ( Estrilda >dopyga) with a damaged wing into the bird room. The male Firefinch once flew down to it and mounted it repeatedly for the next five or six nutes. He showed no overt aggression and I am far from convinced that *re is, as some think (Kunkel 1967), any aggressive motivation in this laviour which is shown, at least in captivity, by all male firefinches igonisticta ) to strange females of their own species. It seems to me to be 'urely sexual response, (the human moralist might term it impurely ual!) which, as the male has no feelings of affection or tenderness * ards the stranger (these being reserved for his mate), can be expressed ardless of her reactions. Ducks, as is well known, show comparable laviour. )n the 25th of February I put a new female Blue-headed Waxbill aeginthus cyanocephalus) into the room. She alighted on the floor (all se new birds were put through the " Judas hole " (see description in odwin 1959 an d *9^5) in the door so that the birds inside were not
algorithms.sectionHeader: 88 D. GOODWIN--OBSERVATIONS ON TWO JAMESON'S FIREFINCHES
algorithms.bodyText: otherwise disturbed and I could watch what happened) and a male Blue- head at once flew down and mounted her. As in the classic case of Thetis and Peleus this was " much against her will " but before she had time to do anything about it the Jameson's Firefinch dashed down, fiercely attacked the mounted cock Blue-head and, after he had dislodged him, spent the next five minutes or so enthusiastically but not successfully attempting tc follow his example. He behaved similarly to a female Cordon Lieu (L. bengalus) that I put in about ten minutes later but not to any of the three female Red-eared Waxbills {Estrilda troglodytes) that were let into the room about half an hour afterwards. I must add at this point that there had previously been other Blue-heads and Cordon Bleus of both sexes in the room but, for the period the Firefinches had been in it, the onl> Estrilda species had been a cock Rosy-rump (which had died some months previously) and his hybrid Rosy-rump x Red-eared daughter who more resembled a Rosy-rump (or, for that matter a firefinch) in the colour of her upper parts as she had a largely red rump and a rosy flush on the ings. The cock Jameson's Firefinch had not, to my knowledge, shown any sexual interest in any of these birds that had shared the room with him but his reaction to strange individuals showed that he was not now indifferent tc their species. After this episode with the new birds the Firefinch did not show an) sexual interest (so far as I observed) in any birds other than his mate (the hen virata) until after her death on 27th of May 1966. At this time ht was moulting and although by no means ill did not appear to be quit( his usual self ". On 26th of June I noticed with some surprise that he was showing a definite interest in one of the male Blue-heads It ellov Left. When this cock Blue-head gave his stem display, the male Firefincl at once flew and perched near him, approached him with tail twistec towards him in the usual estrildine manner, when sexually interested ir another individual, and gave his greeting display (see Goodwin 1964) When I first noticed this the association had evidently been going on some little time as further watching on that day showed that the two often sa together side by side, the Firefinch always going to the Blue-head no vice versa, and once I saw the Blue-head briefly preen him. The Firefincl was at this time still in full moult and had not sung or displayed since ^ few days after his mate had died. At this time the Blue-head was courting a female. The Firefinch's prompt responses to his stem display anc tendency to get between him and his beloved in a literal sense must hav< been frustrating but he showed no aggression towards him, nor did th< Firefinch and the hen Blue-head show any jealousy of each other. This lack of sexual jealousy is a usual feature of interspecific attachments ii waxbills and contrasts strongly with the vindictive jealousy of sexua rivals shown in normal pairings. On the tenth of July I noticed the Firefinch busily foraging about unde some twigs on the floor. The Blue-head Yellow Left, high up on a perch
algorithms.sectionHeader: D. GOODWIN--OBSERVATIONS ON TWO JAMESON'S FIREFINCHES 8cj
algorithms.bodyText: egan to display with a stem, breaking into song as the display got going, s soon as he began to sing the Firefinch at once stopped his fossicking )Out, looked up and flew to the Blue-head, giving intense greeting isplay as he came up to him. Later I saw this on many occasions; the irefinch took no notice whatsoever when other Blue-headed Waxbills isplayed but as soon as he heard Yellow Left start to sing (if he had not ready seen him begin to display) he flew at once to him. There can be 3 doubt that he recognized his mate's song just as a female Blue-head pes. Although remaining more or less faithful to the indifferent cock Blue- ;ad, as shown by frequently resting snuggled beside him and almost ways responding, as above described, to his stem display, the Firefinch d not restrict his sexual interest to him. By the middle of March 1967 he had come into full breeding condition id frequently gave the stem display himself. Often he did so very lortly after the Blue-head cock had displayed and he had gone to him id greeted him in the usual way. Sometimes both would display at the me moment (this, when seen, was always shortly after the Blue-head had splayed and been approached and greeted by the Firefinch) without *parently noticing each other. The Firefinch frequently entered nest uskets and gave his nest call, often after displaying, and he began to build sts, or rather the rough outer shells of nests, in one site after another, his behaviour has continued. By April 1967 it was evident that the Firefinch was now very willing to st the responsiveness of other individuals. From that time he frequently splayed to both Blue-heads and Cordon-Bleus, usually to females but metimes, in the case of Blue-heads, to males. Usually he would rsistently follow and display to one individual for a time, but no doubt dng to lack of response, he showed no consistent attraction for any one rd. On 19th April I saw him, for the first time so far as I know, display oeatedly to the Red-eared Waxbills. On the 22nd, ignoring both Red- red W^axbills and the Uraeginthus species, he persistently displayed to s hen Rosy-rumped Waxbill. This sort of behaviour has continued. The male Firefinch steadfastly nntained his responses to the male Blue-head Yellow Left, although 2se were, naturally, less evident when the latter was engaged in rearing ung or incubating. He also displayed towards other individuals (Stem splay) and nest-called and also showed other signs of both aggression and vual interest towards both Estrilda and Uraeginthus species, more often the latter. Although he built many unlined nests himself and showed Tie interest in the nesting of " his " male Blue-head and the latter's ite he did not, as I thought he might, show any inclination to incubate lir e gg s or feed their young. Although he often took the stem or feather m the displaying Blue-head's bill and might then display with it himself
algorithms.sectionHeader: 9 * D. GOODWIN-OBSERVATIONS ON TWO JAMESON'S FIREFINCHES
algorithms.bodyText: he did not, so far as I saw, direct the Stem Display at this male Blue-head if he (the Firefinch) had obtained the display symbol elsewhere. His be- haviour towards this male Blue-head suggested that he was behaving in a feminine or at any rate rather subordinate way towards him which ties up with his having been moulting and consequently in a subdued state when the attachment originally formed. Although the Firefinch showed no sexual jealousy of " his " cock Blue-head's mate, and never attempted to drive her away when both were, for example, competing for position closest to the male Blue-head when the latter displayed, I twice saw him show some aggression when the\ copulated. On April 27th 1967, I noticed the Blue-head pair were copulating; the male was dislodged prematurely and at this moment the Firefinch dashed up in what appeared to be the horizontal attacking posi- tion but then froze in this crouched position a few inches from the Blue heads. I had the impression that he would have attacked had the male still been mounted when he reached them. On July 18th I again noticec the Blue-head pair copulating when the cock was already mounted. Th< Firefinch flew to them and froze facing them in a crouched posture abou one foot away. He watched intently for a few seconds and then made 1 quick lunge forward but " stopped dead " about 6 in. from them. Thei he darted forward again and the two Blue-heads fell off their perch, think he had lunged at the female but not actually touched her and she ha< fled, or tried to, capsizing them both. I think this behaviour was homo logous with the interference with the copulation of conspecifics that i shown, inter alia, by all the blue waxbills, and was not motivated by an personal jealousy. He remained thus attached to the indifferent but tolerant male Blue-hea> Yellow Left until the latter died suddenly on 22nd April 1968. On Ma 7th, the Firefinch was seen responding eagerly (but fruitlessly) to th display of another male Blue-head (Red Left) and, a little later, to displaying male Cordon Bleu. Since then he has not shown any definite " pairing to a particuk individual. He clumps readily with Uraeginthus of either species an sex but also often rests alone. He responds by approaching and giviri his greeting display (or otherwise behaving as described in above accour of his behaviour towards Yellow Left) to male Blue-heads, male Cordo Bleus, female Blue-heads and female Cordon Bleus; apparently in the order of preference. He gives his Stem Display, however, to both sex< and, on the whole, I think rather more often to females than to males. I the case of Cordon Bleus I am fairly certain that females are now (wintt 1968) preferentially displayed to. I have also had the impression, whic may be wrong as I have done only short term watching of recent month that his former preference for Blue-heads over Cordon Bleus has no considerably waned. This may, however, be due to the fact that as, 1
algorithms.sectionHeader: D. GOODWIN--OBSERVATIONS ON TWO JAMESON'S FIREFINCHES 91
algorithms.bodyText: - cent years, the Cordon Bleus have bred much more successfully than the lue-heads they now outnumber them and also contain many more vigorous )ung individuals among their number. It has been v ery noticeable, however, that the Firefinch has become very )t to go from one bird to another when alas, (as, is ever the case) he gets d satisfactory response to his displays. For example: on 21st May 1968 j displayed very intensely to a female Cordon Bleu who let him come ght up to her in his sidling jumps but showed no sexual interest or sponse. He crouched lower and lower as he jumped, tilting his body wards her, looking up to her and raising and fluttering his wings. The ordon Bleu flew off; he followed her and began to display again, but hen she flew a second time he turned to the Rosy-rumped Waxbill (the me one that he had attempted to rape on her arrival over two years eviously when she had been unable to fly) and displayed to her. This Firefinch has shown himself in agreement with recent ornitho- ?ical opinion on the relationships of his family! Bereft of congenors he sponded first, and still most frequently, to blue waxbills (Uraeginthus), ^ondly to Estrilda species, but has never shown the slightest sexual terest in Avadavats or Gold-breasted Waxbills ( Amandava amandava d A. subflava). An interesting aspect of this cock Jameson's Firefinch's attachment to s male Blue-headed Waxbill Yellow Left was that, from the first, he owed a definite sexual reaction (the Greeting Display) when the Blue- ad gave his Stem Display. So far as is known (Harrison 1956 and 1957, )odwin 1964, Kunkel 1967a, p. 154) female firefinches, unlike females the blue waxbills and typical waxbills ( Uraeginthus and Estrilda ), do t give the Stem Display. Possibly, however, they may do so at times ter all, some aviculturists have supposed, incorrectly, that the female "rdon Bleu never gives this display) if the male is behaving inadequately, if the female is more forward sexually. As female firefinches are toriously more delicate in captivity than males (in strong contrast to 'rdon Bleus) it probably rather seldom happens that an observant culturist has a pair of any Lagonisticta species in which the female is er and/or more forward in breeding condition than the male. I am not refore, entirely convinced that female Lagonosticta never give the ' m Display, because one has not yet been seen doing it. [f they do not then we must assume that the cock Jameson's was showing eminine response to the Blue-head's display. If on the other hand lale firefinches do give the Stem Display in certain circumstances then nay well supply an extra strong sexual stimulus to the male. In either e the fact that this attachment formed when the Firefinch was moulting 1, probably, therefore in a rather sub-normal physical state is under- adable. Yhy this particular male Blue-head was the one the Firefinch fell in e with (no inverted commas, waxbills do fall in love!) I have no idea but
algorithms.sectionHeader: 92 D. GOODWIN--OBSERVATIONS ON TWO JAMESON'S FIREFINCHES
algorithms.bodyText: it is fairly certain that, in this context, its sex was irrelevant. All available observations suggest that male firefinches recognize another bird as < male primarily by its having extensive areas of red or wine-colourec plumage which, if worn by a firefinch, elicit aggression and sexual jealousy from other males. If, therefore, a bird does not show such red or wine- coloured plumage it will not usually (and probably not ever) elicit any o the specific responses that a cock firefinch normally shows to males of hit own (or allied and similarly coloured) species. I can add little to my former notes (Goodwin 1964) on display and voici of this species. As I then suspected " Stem Display " without the nes symbol turned out to be low intensity display; at high intensity the bin nearly always holds a piece of grass or feather in the usual way. Th< rather crouched posture during the Stem Display is, however, characteristi at all intensities, although I cannot say whether this is individual or specific As in L. rubric at a, intermittent wing-fluttering may accompany the Ster Display. A long, plaintive " feeeee " very like that of the female, ma be uttered, as well or instead of the other calls previously described, b the male during his Stem Display. It would be of interest to know if this a typical call of the female, is only given in display when a conspecifi female is not present. The " feeee " call of the second hen virata was less long-drawn tha that of the first. The nest-call of the male jamesoni is a soft, busk " tchu-tchu-tchu-tchu-tchu . . . On the Nesting of the jamesoni-virata pair The nesting behaviour of the jamesoni male and the virata fema seemed essentially similar to that of the Dark Firefinch (L. rubricate which I described previously (Goodwin 1964). I only saw building t the male and am not sure if the female even took in feathers for the nes lining. I cannot now remember seeing her do so and I have no record i my " Firefinch Notebook " of her doing so. The nests were like those " rubric at a, with a very thick pad of feathers as lining. The female wou readily lay, however, in a nest with few or no feathers, these were added j and when they became available during incubation. By day the male and female used to incubate for period of about / minutes to an hour and a half with the male doing, perhaps, rather mo than the female. I have several lists of times at which either was on tl nest if anyone is particularly interested but, as these may well have bet influenced by the rather artificial situation, it hardly seemed worth takii up space to give them here. The hen always went on the nest an hour more before dusk and stayed there until relieved by the male (or put off 1 me) next morning. The male always roosted well away from the nest. When about to relieve ist mate, or when " thinking about " so doir the bird would give the Alarm Call (" trrrrr, trrr-trr-trrt " by the mi
algorithms.sectionHeader: D. GOODWIN--OBSERVATIONS ON TWO JAMESON'S FIREFINCHES
algorithms.bodyText: #Soni, " churrr, churrr-rrr " by the female virata) obviously here an ression of conflict. Possibly the bird was often aware of my presence dng through the Judas hole and this probably, and certainly in the case he female, increased its hesitation to go to the nest. I never heard any from the bird inside the nest although the one about to enter would ;n give Contact Calls. On all the occasions on which I saw change-over relieving bird went into the nest before its mate came out. Often the e brought a feather to the nest. I never saw the female try to snatch om him as a hen blue waxbill often will in this situation, rom the many clutches of eggs which were laid and they incubated dfastly (there were also other clutches which were deserted because the ale had had slight egg-binding) only one egg hatched. All other eggs eared infertile when broken or possibly the embryos died at an emely early stage. The one young one hatched on December 25th 5, the other three eggs appearing (when later broken) infertile. I ized a young one had hatched at last when, first thing that morning, I that the male was searching desperately about the room. Ants as or any other really suitable natural food was out of the question at time of year. I hastily put in some whiteworm culture and several iefuls of earth and dead leaves from beneath the privet hedge in my London garden. he cock Firefinch began eagerly to search among all this debris but he id very little to liking and ignored the whiteworms. To my horror he I went to the millet tray and carefully selected the smallest grains he d find, swallowing them whole without de-husking them. Dark and eson's Firefinches and blue waxbills normally consume a lot of the II panicum millet without removing the husk. I also, of course, put gg food and milk sop without any hope that the Firefinches would h it; nor did they, except with their feet when they hopped over it. I k that if some seed like millet but much smaller were available this it be a great help in waxbill breeding. hen the hen came off she searched in a similar manner but took itities of whiteworms (although, obviously, only in default of what she really looking for) and then filled-up on soaked spray millet. At -day I ventured to shine a torch in the nest and look at the young one. ad lightish blue marks at the edges of its gape and its crop was full, mid not see with what although I feared the worst, that is to say the 1 dry millet grains that its father had so carefully sorted out! Next it was gone. It had, no doubt, died through unsuitable feeding and been thrown out of the nest but, astonishingly, I never found what me of it. he fact that only one egg, out of many dozens incubated, ever hatched, ests a reduced fertility that I think may indicate physiological incom- fility between virata and jamesoni. I had very similar results with a '* Rosy-rumped Waxbill paired to a female Red-eared Waxbill. Of all

algorithms.bodyText: the many clutches of eggs that they laid and incubated only one eve hatched. This young hybrid, a hen, was successfully reared and appeare in every way a healthy and viable bird. It was from a clutch of six egg and the other five all appeared infertile when broken, so that if they wei fertile the embryos must have died very early indeed. Summary A male Lagonisticta rhodoparaeia jamesoni paired to a female L. j. virati after some difficulties owing to the plumage characters (female of virat predominantly red, not predominantly brown like female of jameson causing the birds to " mistake " each others' sex. Between May 196 and May 1966 (when the hen died egg-bound) they incubated man clutches of eggs but only one egg ever hatched. While still living with his mate, but after having lived for nearly thn years in company with Uraeginthus and Estrilda species, the male Jameson Firefinch reacted to the introduction of new blue waxbills and a new Rost rumped Waxbill by at once attempting to copulate with them without ar previous display. This is the normal behaviour of paired male firefinch< when a strange female of their own species is introduced to their aviary After the death of his mate this male Jameson's Firefinch courted an " paired " to an indifferent but tolerant male Blue-headed Waxbil clumping with it and flying to it whenever it gave its Stem Displa' Neither the Blue-head's mate or the cock Firefinch showed any antagonist to each other. Since the male Blue-head's death (and to some extei before it) the cock Firefinch has directed its Stem Display at other Blu< heads and Cordon Bleus (of both sexes) but has not formed a stron attachment to any one individual.

algorithms.bodyText: (Coracias candata) By W. Collard and D. Collard (Natal Zoological Gardens, Amanzimtoti, Natal) 3 n the 20th August 1968 we acquired two Lilac-breasted Rollers racias candata , and as the sexes of these birds are alike we naturally did know whether they were a pair. It was with pleasure that some two nths later they were observed feeding each other, and we now knew that east they were of opposite sex. Eventually it was decided to hang up Dllow log in their aviary. We did not hold out much hope, but at least y would have the opportunity to nest. )n observing the writer's actions our head keeper ventured the opinion t they probably had eggs already, as he had noticed they were continually 1 nest put up for the Lorikeets sharing their aviary. This nest consisted a tin measuring 10 in. x 10 in. by 15 in. deep, and lined with wood h a round hole near the top. A ladder was immediately sent for and to profound delight, the nest contained two almost round white eggs, is was the 4th November and as we did not know the exact date on ich they were laid we were unable to ascertain the incubation period. )n the 17th, 13 days later, both eggs hatched and our task of finding ugh live food commenced. We would mention that from the outset hen was always very tame and ate from our hands. Both parents were ellent feeders, the hen taking the cockroaches, mealworms and crickets n our hand to the nest, whilst the cock was supplied by throwing these ; cts onto the top of the wire which he caught in flight as they fell rngh. \ T t always knew when the chicks had had enough, because the parents ild eat the insects themselves. bout a week after the hatching, a Blue-headed Parrot, also an inmate tiis aviary, chewed a hole through the wire, but the only bird to escape the Roller cock. While we were bemoaning our fate, he suddenly eared on top of the aviary with an insect in his beak and trying to find ay in. A trap cage was set with mealworms which he immediately red much to our relief. At this stage we were supplying food about or six times a day, no food could be left in the aviary for them to feed leir leisure, as it was shared with, amongst others, a Colombian Jay and e Cape Glossy Starlings, who would have made short work of the cts. n the 6th December, tragedy struck. It was noticed that the Rollers 2 eating the food themselves and not visiting the nest. On inspection ound that the box had been invaded by ants, one youngster being dead,

the other covered with these termites and still alive, but apparently weak. The area around the nest was fumigated and the box itself thoroughly cleaned out. The surviving chick was put back and the nest hung on the wall again. Whilst all this was happening, the hen viciously attacked the writer. We now started supplying the live food again, but neither parents were interested in feeding the baby. Regretfully it was decided aftei about an hour of endeavour to hand feed the youngster. The hen must have read my thoughts, for she suddenly made her usual chucking noise and looked up at the nest-box with an uneaten cockroach in her beak, and with a sigh of relief, we watched her commence feeding duties again. The cock bird eventually followed suit. On the 22nd December, the chick left the nest fully coloured except thai the lilac on the breast was duller, and the elongated outer tail feathers were absent. The parents continued to feed for about another ten days with the baby often joining the mother and feeding from the writer's hand. Ii is now completely independent and we are looking forward to the Rollen repeating their feat next breeding season. In conclusion we would likt to know whether there are any previous records of the Lilac-breastec

algorithms.bodyText: The pair of Little Owls in the Norfolk Wildlife Park were presentei originally by children who had found them as nestlings which had appar ently been abandoned. The female arrived in 1965 and the male in 1967 The aviary is in a sheltered corner of the Park and is of irregular shap 25 ft. in length, 9 ft. wide and 8 ft. high. A grass grown bank runs th full length and an artificial burrow has been constructed running two fee into the bank and ending in a chamber 12 in. by 9 in. in area. Thi chamber can be cleaned out by means of a steel lid covered by a sod of turf The entrance to the burrow is beneath an old tree stump close to an elde bush while other shrubs and an apple tree have been planted in the aviary The Owls are fed almost entirely on chopped up day old chicks and ea an average of five chicks between them per day. During May 1968 the female spent most of the time in the nest burro\ and was seldom seen. On the 20th of the month the chamber wa inspected and found to contain three eggs. No further inspections wer made at this time for fear of disturbing the birds, but by the middle 0 June food consumption had risen to eight chicks per day and so it wa
C. J. O. HARRISON--FURTHER RECORDS OF ALLOPREENING

turned that the young had hatched. On yth July the nest chamber was pened and had in it two fully fledged owlets. By the end of the month ley were both seen regularly in the evenings although they would dive awn the burrow the moment they noticed anyone approaching. How- er they gradually become more confident and one or both sometimes *mained sitting in the shrubs during the daytime. At the end of September the young were removed to a separate aviary, hey weighed 7J ozs. and 8J ozs. so are probably a pair. At the time-of riting (December 1968) both are thriving and it is hoped they will breed iring their first summer.

By C. J. O. Harrison (Perivale, Middlesex, England) For students of bird behaviour, collections of birds in aviaries are of nsiderable value, making it possible to study behaviour in greater detail birds which may be less affected by the presence of the observer than [Id ones, and to check for the occurrence of particular forms of behaviour a range of species that might otherwise never be encountered alive by ne person. A few years ago when studying allopreening (or mutual preening as it is metimes called) I found it necessary to rely heavily on observations of 1 iary birds in order to discover the extent to which it occurred in different : nilies. There was evidence of it in thirty-nine different families (Harrison 65). Since then Sparks (1965) has observed it in two more families ien watching birds at the London Zoo, and more recently I have recorded im yet another family, the observations being again based on aviary birds. 1 the information below I have summarized both my own observations d those of others in order to bring the original paper up to date.

FALCONIDAE. Sparks (1965) recorded allopreening by a pair of 1 d-thighed Falconets, Microhierax caerulescens , which performed this ivity when clumping close together on a perch. He also recorded it >m Forster's Milvago, Phalcoboenus australis , and from a pair of racaras, Polyborus plancus , in the London Zoo. He commented that irs of these species did not clump together; and that in the latter species i bird being preened sometimes faces away from the preener, fluffs the image, and withdraws the neck slightly. I recently observed allopreening from the last species, probably the ne birds, at the London Zoo. In this case the behaviour was reciprocal A the birds stood a little apart, each in turn bowing its head towards the

C. J. O. HARRISON--FURTHER RECORDS OF ALLOPREENING other which then preened the dark crown and the sparse feathers borderir the eye and bare skin around the base of the bill. TYTONIDAE. Information on this behaviour in owls as a whole rather scanty. I have only one previous record. I have now seen it an aviary in the London Zoo containing four Barn Owls, Tyto alb offspring of another zoo pair which had reared two young in each of ti two previous years. All four birds perched fairly close together, almost contact. Shortly after they began to preen themselves late one afternoo random allopreening occurred. The photograph (shows one of tl birds which had been preening its nestmate on the left turning its attentk to the bird on its right. The plumage was mostly allopreened around tl edges of the facial discs and around the base of the bill. PRIONOPIDAE. Sparks (op. cit.) records both clumping and all preening in the Plumed Helmet-shrike, Prionops plumata , a pair of whk were kept in a cage at the zoo. PLOCEIDAE. Allopreening does not normally occur among tl weavers, but Kunkel (1966) has recorded it in the two Sporopipes speck the Speckle-fronted Weaver, Sporopipes frontalis , and the Scaly-crowm Weaver, S. squamifrons. These birds may clump together when restii and also roost communally when not in breeding pairs, cramming ther selves into small domed nests. Among unpaired birds the allopreenii tended to be random, but in the pairs it was normally the dominant bi that did most of the preening, and at the nesting period this was norma! the female. The preening was restricted to the head feathers. The birds are often grouped with the sparrows, and thought to be nearer t simple, ancestral type of weaver, possibly forming a link between t weavers and the waxbill family.

It was found that allopreening was usually correlated with certa factors in the environment or in the birds' normal pattern of behavioi It was most frequently correlated with environmental factors whi caused the birds to remain in close physical proximity or contact with ea other, particularly when this occurred at the nest-site. Both the Re thighed Falconet and the Barn Owl are species which nest in hollow trt or cavities in which enforced close proximity could be a significant fact< In the case of the Milvago and Caracara this factor would not apply, b another which also appears to be a correlate of this behaviour and whi may be relevant here is that many birds which maintain a persistent pa bond over a long period also tend to show allopreening. In the case the Helmet-shrikes a third correlate seems to be involved. These bir resemble the babblers in their tendency to form close and highly social groups which move about together, clump together when resting, and n< as a sociable group; and such species, which experience physical proxim to each other similar to that of birds on a restricted nest-site although fit

Dtives other than physical necessity, also tend to allopreen. The allo- -eening factors of two weaver species would appear to show elements of )th the socialibility of the babblers and the enforced proximity factor of ie raptors. Information on another species which appears to show correlation of lopreening with a restricted nest-site, is given in a study of the Swallow- iied Gull, Creagrus furcatus (Snow and Snow 1968), though not from iptive birds. This species, which nests in the Galapagos, is peculiar, nong other reasons, in that it tends to choose small clilf-ledges for nests though other apparently usable and more extensive sites may appear to i available. Possibly as a result of this it shares with the Kittiwake, Rissa idactyla , many characters associated with adaptation to nesting on small dges, and the Swallow-tailed Gull and the Kittiwake appear to be the lly two gull species which allopreen.

In collecting observations I noted at times behaviour in species which id not allopreen which nevertheless bore a strong resemblance to it and )peared to be intermediate between pecking and preening behaviour, his was observed in captive dunnocks, Prunella species, among others iarrison 1966). More recently I have observed similar behaviour from pair of hand-reared Skylarks, Alauda arvensis. These were separated tiysically, but in sight of each other, for two weeks soon after they began > feed themselves. Subsequently, when they were put together again, ie bird already in possession of the enclosure approached the other in a ither aggressive manner. The other bird became quite motionless and ie first performed this very gentle pecking or touching, barely appearing " do more than touch with the bill, around the eyes and on the crown of ie motionless bird. The only record I have of apparent allopreening in cranes is a record by erek Goodwin (pers. comm.) of a captive Crowned Crane, Balearica gulorum, pecking gently among the crest feathers of the lowered head of lother individual; and I was able to observe precisely similar behaviour ore recently by a pair at the London Zoo. This again appears to be )rderline behaviour which does not clearly fall into one category or the her.

algorithms.figure: 100 R. W. GR0N0W--NOTES ON BREEDING THE RUFOUS-SIDED CRAKE NOTES ON BREEDING THE RUFOUS-SIDED CRAKE (Laterallus melanophaius ) By R. W. Gronow (Whitchurch, Cardiff, Glamorgan, Wales) My Rufous-sided Crakes, Laterallus melanophaius , had three nests in t
algorithms.bodyText: season of 1967. Each one was constructed in a different site. The fii was built in a privet bush about two feet from the ground, but this nest # waterlogged and they left it. The second was built in an old parakeet nest-box which I had la sideways on the ground. They hatched three young, which when th left the nest were all black in their down plumage. At the age of t days two of the chicks died but the other one survived and is now as big the parents. It took about four months to attain full adult plumage. After losing these two chicks I increased the live food supply (me; worms and maggots) not knowing much about these birds and having work by trial and error. I did not know they would take seed until I ss one taking seed from the hopper. The pair then built a third nest in another bush three feet from t ground about five feet from where they made the first; again the open ei of the aviary flight was used. Possibly remembering the fate of their ff nest with the rain they built a sort of canopy over this one. They laid U eggs and both hatched. Both chicks left the nest, again one dying at abc ten days, but the other survived. When these chicks left the nest th began nestling under the wings of the youngster from the first nest w began feeding them with no interference from the parents. The eggs of these birds are white and about one and a quarter inch long. I cannot give the incubation period as I did not want to disturb t nest. The birds seem to dip all the live food in the water before eating Mine have become quite tame and will take mealworms from the han I occasionally see them perched in the trees in the flight. Though th can fly they seldom do so. They are forever foraging along the groin and in the shallow pond, and when they see me entering the birdroom th come running into the indoor flight, although usually they are rather sic moving. They can, however, move very fast when they need to. I have heard that these crakes will take the young of other small bin from their nests, but I keep them in a large planted flight with about. other birds (weavers, whydahs, Zebra-finches, and Canaries) and I ha never experienced any fighting of any kind.

By W. R. Partridge (Evesham, Worcestershire, England) In case some of the Society's new or older members missed Mr. C. J. O. Harrison's article in Vol. 74, No. 1 Jan-Feb. 1968, on the reason why the Council of the Avicultural Society felt that a census of the Rothschild's Vlynah be taken among its Members, and a register of all known captive Leucopsar rothschildi be made, it is because of the doubts felt about the possible survival of this lovely bird in its limited natural habitat on the Northern part of the Island of Bali, Indonesia. Whilst the Council of the Avicultural Society realize that no-one has iucceeded in maintaining a viable population of any " softbill " under tviary conditions, and the difficulties are recognized, it is felt that taken in ime and on a wide enough basis, it may be possible to establish this bird. I have been greatly encouraged in this work, not only from the response )f private members in this country, but also from abroad, and I would ike to thank especially Mr. Kenton C. Lint, (Curator of Birds at San ffiego Zoo, California), Mr. C. R. Schmidt, (Associate Assistant at Zurich ffio) and Mrs. K. M. Scamell of Newdigate, Surrey, all consistent and uccessful breeders of this species for the detailed information they have, ent me. To Mr. Roger Van Oosten (Vice-President of Tacoma Zoologi- al Society, Washington), my thanks for his interest in our project, which e hopes the Society will make a permanent one, and that it may onsider setting up a Stud Book on these birds. I agree we should aim at starting a Stud Book at some future date, not, I ope, too far distant, but I would not recommend the Council to adopt this roject until it has been proved possible to maintain a breeding population of iis Mynah in captivity. So far as I can see from the records at my disposal, oung Rothschild's have yet to be bred from two aviary-bred parents. tS soon as we receive proof that this has been accomplished I think the me would have come to consider starting a Stud Book. In the meantime would like to hear of as many Rothschild's Mynahs as possible being ringed ith split rings, so they can be put on after leaving the nest, and so that lere is some means of identifying individual birds and their movements om one owner to another; also in preparation for the creating of a Stud 00k when thought fit, since then it will be necessary to be able to identify 1 individuals accurately. If Aviculturists can maintain and increase the number of this species in mfinement, then perhaps the improving climate of opinion for the role of ptivity-breeding in conservation will be further advanced.

102 W. R. PARTRIDGE--ROTHSCHILD'S MYNAH REGISTER & REPORT ON CENSUS The Zoological Society of London publishes annually The International Zoo Year Book, previously edited by Caroline Jarvis (Lady Medway) and now by Joseph Lucas. In this publication are listed those Zoos that keep Rothschild's Mynah (L. rothschildi ), together with numbers bred in captivity. In Vol. 8, for 1968 (census compiled between February and August 1967) 34 Zoos had between them a total of 129* of which 29 had been bred in confinement. In Vol. 9, for 1969 (census compiled between Feburary and June 1968), 36 Zoos had between them a total of 115" of which 39 were captive bred, making a total of 52 when added to those bred in private collections in this country. I am greatly indebted to Mr. Joseph Lucas, Editor of the Internationa! Zoo Year Book, for giving me permission to use information on the num- bers of L. rothschildi in world Zoos, contained in Vols. 8 and 9, in order tc make the following register, which locates the pairs and individual L. rothschildi in captivity in Zoological Gardens and in private collections as complete as possible. There are believed to be considerably more of these birds in captivity, particularly in private collections, that have not so fai been reported, and we shall be most grateful for any information about them that would help to make this register more complete, as would alsc any further information about the housing, breeding and feeding techniques used by successful breeders that could be included in the next report. Before finishing this article I must acknowledge the great amount 0; work done and assistance given me by our member, Mr. David Spilsbury in assembling the following register.

By C. J. O. Harrison (Perivale, Middlesex, England) ASPEBA, the Association for the Study and Propagation of European Birds in Aviaries, originated as an idea of Frank Meaden's. He had long wanted to form an organization to try to bring together those who were genuinely interested in keeping, breeding and studying our native birds in aviaries. I had had relatively little to do with British birds but became interested and helped to launch this association in 1965. At the prelimi- nary discussion it was decided that Europe formed a more obvious and lest parochial unit than Britain, and, in an attempt to define our aim, I must admit to being guilty of the mnemonic title. As a relative newcomer to this aspect of aviculture I was keen to know what species could be bred and perpetuated in aviaries. Unfortunate!) the desire to swell the list of birds allegedly bred and hence available for exhibition seemed to have led in the past to some dubious claims of success- ful breeding, and I had reached a stage of scepticism where I had come tc doubt if anything much could be, or was, actually bred under aviary conditions. I was therefore very interested to see what the breeding results would be among our members. Aviculturists are notoriously bad at putting pen to paper and we usually only had returns from some 16 to i#

C. J. O. HARRISON--BRITISH BIRD BREEDING AND ASPEBA 107 idividuals each year; but the four year period has produced what seems to le a rather impressive list of species which I am reasonably satisfied have sen bred under aviary conditions and constitute scientifically acceptable :cords. I have listed the species below and given the year or years in hich breeding occurred.

algorithms.bodyText: s think that, for a more complete picture, one might add to the above the )odlark, Lullula arborea, bred in 1962, and the Waxwing, Bombycilia nilus, bred in 1963, both achievements of present members prior to the ';ociation's foundation. t is particularly satisfying to find that most of the birds were bred under iditions of what I would call, with no disparagement, " Back-garden -ulture by people with limited time, space, and money available. I e naturally surveyed these records hoping to find some common factors t might emerge from them. There are only two that are immediately I'arent. One is that, as a general rule, few individuals succeed in eding from more than one insectivorous species pair in any particular

M. F. COUPE--NEWS FROM CHESTER ZOO season. This seems to be due mainly to the fact that a single brood of such young are likely to require all the small insect and fine food available at that period, and the breeder is also likely to concentrate on giving every advantage to the pair that have shown such promise. It is not, however, true that the pair on which most care is lavished will be the ones most likely to breed. The second interesting fact that emerges is that with the less frequently bred species most of the successes have been with birds which were either hand-reared as young, or at least reared under aviary conditions. This is the opposite view to that held by breeders of such birds at the turn of the century who held that success was most likely with freshly-trapped adults. I suspect, and hope, that this reflects our more effective rearing and subsequent care of birds in aviaries compared with earlier days.

[ When bringing together records of native species in captivity I found that then was little or no evidence of the breeding of the Woodpigeon, Columba palumbus Derek Goodwin informed me that they had been bred by the Hon. Miriam Roths child, to whom I wrote, and who has kindly supplied the following information Asst. Hon. Ed.] It is quite true that I have bred the woodpigeon in captivity, but to write it u] seems hardly necessary because there was no secret about it. The procedure was a I caught the woodpigeons as nestlings and hand reared them, feeding them 01 bread and milk and adding the usual extras such as codliver oil, premature bab; food and so forth. In those days we did not have antibiotics, but I suppose it was to hand-rear a bird today I would always add a little aureomycine to the bre\ in the early stages. When the birds were adult I released them in a large aviary Whether they bred or not depended on the number of birds to the square yard there was no breeding if they were so numerous that they formed a flock ; sooner 0 later under these circumstances one or two birds became aggressive and killed th others--then the remaining birds would breed quite successfully. I found that the woodpigeon does not only lay two eggs, as we are so olten told 11 the literature, but will lay up to 22 eggs if one of the pair is removed soon afte laying. Derek Goodwin may have told you that I found a tremendous differenc between the tamability of some woodpigeons and others, and I would strong! suggest that if anyone wishes to start breeding woodpigeons in captivity they choos a strain which is genetically suited to tamability,--that is to say woodpigeons fror one of the parks in London. Those you get from the fields in areas in the Midlands where we live and where they are shot at over decoys, appear to be tame in th early stages, but then become wild and very soon damage themselves in aviaries. Although my woodpigeons laid perfectly happily in small cages nearer the groun there is no doubt they are much happier in a tall aviary where they can nest near th wire roofing, and it is much better to give them a plank on which to nest than leav them in the branches because they are very poor nest builders in captivity. I am sure, however, that far the most important thing is to get your stock from London park, or somewhere where the genes for tameness have not been eliminate! As vou probably know, the same applies to starlings--there is an enormous vanet in tamebility among starlings and we always have to get rid of the wild ones. If any of your fellow aviculturists start breeding the woodpigeon 1 think the would be interested to note how diet affects the colour of their plumage. I he> changes may be rather subtle, but very definite once you are familiar with the bin Miriam Rothschild.

The hen came into ding condition long before the cock and laid four eggs, but resumed her old t of not being interested in sitting on them at night after having raised one d in normal fashion the previous year. Shortly after she started a second nest with three eggs, cock had now come into condition and was feeding her but she still showed no est in properly incubating them so again these eggs were placed under a Two of the three were fertile and developed about halfway before dying, not know why.

I had supposed this would be the end of the 1968 season but some weeks later thought the hen looked broody and in looking into the box found two eggs whic were warm. That night she was in the box, and subsequently sat tightly with onl one or two " forgetful " spells when I had to put her into the box after dark. Th cause of this, I believe, is that she gets so excited when flying back and forth wit the cock at dusk that she just reverts to her regular habit of going to roost instead c to the nest. When she is broody she will step onto a stick after dark, and by gentl holding her tail with one hand, holding the stick with the other, and with a flash light under my chin, I am able to put her head in the hole and she will then dim down and cover the eggs. In all she laid three eggs and hatched and raised thre chicks in normal fashion with the help of the cock. The elder Rudkin once wrot to me that he thought that it was the " extras " that many times made the differenc between success and failure in aviculture. I always thought of his observations a pertaining to food but I guess he meant it in a broader sense. In the summer of 1967 I had obtained three Crimson-wing parrots bred tha spring. In the fall of 1968 they moulted into one fully coloured male, one mal with about half of his black and red colour, and the third male showing about te black feathers in his mantle. I thought this rather unusual. C. Newton Caron.
