algorithms.author: By Jan Roger van Oosten
algorithms.bodyText: In December, 1966, I was fortunate enough to secure a male of each of he manakins shown on the accompanying plate. These two along with ix other manakins of two different species are presently housed in my ollection. These birds are very hard to obtain even today and those that 0 become available bring a high price. The main reason for this is that key, in the wild are very localized in their habitat, although their distribu- ion may cover a wide area. According to a belief held by Mr. Charles :ordier these birds are only maintainable during certain times of the year, he) can be trapped usually during most of the year, but are extremely ard to keep alive except during certain periods. While in Ecuador I mist- etted two female Blue-rumped Manakins (Pipra isidorei ) but even with )rce-feeding I was only able to keep them alive for a few days. The family Pipridae is exclusively tropical American and has some 52 lembers in it. There still may possibly be one or two species yet to iscover in the vast area of the Amazon drainage, as Dr. Helmut Sick iveral years ago discovered a new species in Brazil. They are, in most ises, small, brightly coloured birds which inhabit the thick under- 1 *wth of the forest or the lower canopy of the forest. They vary in size om that of a small wren to that of a sparrow. They feed mostly on fruit id especially berries and also insect life. The sexes are usually different 1 colour with the male sporting all the colour, while the females are mostly rab shades of green. Most have elaborate displays and display areas and e very often referred to as the " Birds of Paradise " of the new world, tales display for most of the year on their courts except when they are oulting. They likewise are polygynous in that they do not pair for life for a breeding season. Further they do not share in the duties of hiding a nest, incubating the eggs nor feeding or rearing of the young. > mentioned, they have and maintain display courts for years on end and ere hold court to attract the females, mating, in many cases w T ith more an one female. By the same token a female may visit more than one ale on his court. Their vocal sounds are unimpressive considering the N
algorithms.sectionHeader: Il8 JAN ROGER VAN OOSTEN--MANAKINS IN CAPTIVITY
algorithms.bodyText: whole family, but some do produce a loud snapping noise with their wings when going through their display, which sounds like a crack of a rifle. Manakins have a short and very rapid flight which is extremely hard to follow. Also many of the members of the family make a whirr sound when they fly, this sound being produced by the feathers of the wings. They are generally speaking very active birds constantly on the move. The Golden-headed Manakin (.Pipra erythrocephala berlepschi ) was trapped east of Banos in the Pastaza River valley in Ecuador. The species itself is very widespread from the Guianas, Brazil north of the Amazon through to Colombia and eastern Panama and then south and east of the Andes through Ecuador to northern Peru. Also a sub-species is found on the island of Trinidad. It lives in the tropical and lower subtropical zones in the undergrowth of the forest. The altitude of the zones runs from sea level up to 4500-5500 feet. The plate shows the general colour of the bird and hence only a few minor points should be mentioned. The bird is about four inches long and in this sub-species the head is yellow with a very faint scarlet border across the nape. The other noticeable colour is that of the thighs which also are scarlet. One other stand-out feature of this bird is the clear and sharp eye which gives it a very alert appearance, as if nothing can escape its notice. The female is generally olive green overall. Since I have had the male no display has been done by the bird. The only sound I have heard my male make is a sharp chee-weep. This either in a single call or a double one. However, none of the movements associated with the display have ever been seen. The Golden-winged Manakin (Masius chrysopterus chrysopterus) was collected in the same area as the preceding species. This species ranges from Venezuela in the northwest, throughout Colombia to north-eastern Peru. In Ecuador it is found on both the western and eastern sides of the Andes. They live in the forests of the upper tropical and subtropical zones, in altitude ranging from about 3500 feet to 7500-8500 feet. Here again the plate shows the bird off well as far as colour goes. However, a few very interesting points should be mentioned. The frontal feathers over the bill remain in that position and are not laid back, thus giving the appearance of a " horn ". The plate shows the bird in the excited attitude with his crest feathers raised. These feathers are rather long and the hind crown ones are red. On each side of the golden-yellow crown the black side crowm feathers rise giving the appearance of a set of oryx horns. When the bird is excited then the crown feathers assume the position as shown on the plate with either the yellow and red crown feathers lying flat on the head or raised as shown. Of course when normal then all crown feathers will lie flat against the head. It is further possible that these feathers are used during their display but thus far to the best of my know- ledge no one has observed its display either in the wild or in captivity. Also under the chin and on the breast as well as under wing-coverts and also the inner margins of the remiges and rectrices the bird sports additional

Ir 9 den-yellow plumage. When the bird is sitting on the perch in a ixed manner the black plumage surrounding the breast patch covers 1 patch so that no yellow shows. Further, at least this particular bird es to bathe every day regardless of the weather. As with the Golden- ded this bird has shown no display behaviour whatsoever while he has n here. Neither has he issued forth with either any song or call note. Doth cases this may be because I do not at the present time have either ther male or a female for either of these two species, only time will tell. tin the female is drab being mostly olive green with some yellowish te below. n captivity the critical times seem to be when the bird is trapped and 1 during the acclimatization period after arrival. However, once they established they seem to do very well and are easy to care for if one will the time to read about their habits. I feed my manakins the following ture daily and it is completely cleaned up. These birds eat a great, for their size. The mixture is as follows:
algorithms.table: |boxes of dried currants cans of blueberries tablespoons of Gevral cup of my meal mixture; which consists of the following: i part powdered spinach i part powdered alfalfa 6 parts Super Hydramin Protein Powder io parts Mynah Bird Meal io parts Purina Trout Chow . . .
algorithms.figure: apples pears papayas banana :o grapes carrots tomato cantaloupe (when in season)
algorithms.bodyText: he above ingredients are mixed in a large mixing bowl as follows, the currants for five minutes in water with molasses, then drain and ") a bowl - Then add the blueberries after they have been rinsed and led. Next add the Gevral and the Meal Mixture. Now cut up the na, carrots and the tomato and place in a blender and liquefy along the grapes. Then cut up the balance of the fruit and chop it up in ilender fairly fine. This is then added to the bowl and mixed well the other ingredients. This can then be placed in clean quart jars placed in the refrigerator for up to five days without spoilage. This ' standard mixture which I feed to all of my birds and which they all to enjoy. For the manakins, however, I mix in extra blueberries :urrants in each dish plus a little extra Meal Mixture. Other berries
algorithms.sectionHeader: 120 JAN ROGER VAN OOSTEN--MANAKINS IN CAPTIVITY
algorithms.bodyText: such as pyracantha and cotoneaster are also relished by manakins as v as cotingas, tanagers and honeycreepers. Newly imported birds are fed the above along with Terramycin in F; Formula (Chas. Pfizer & Co.) sprinkled over it. The terramycin is fed i one week and if the birds still feel or look a little bad then it is continii for several more days. This particular product seems to quiet them do after the trip and also bring them out of the state of shock which mi birds are in upon arrival. Another product that I feed to them is C i- thaxanthin (Hoffmann-LaRoche) and this is sprinkled on their food dur; the moulting season. This acts as a colour retainer during that per; and hence my birds do not fade as the majority of reds, yellows and oranji do in captivity. Thus the two manakins herewith discussed look today they did the day they were caught. It should also be noted that manak: like to bathe and in particular the Golden-winged which does so every c, as soon as I change the drinking water dish. In the summer when I r the stream then he dives right in and soaks himself until it is impossible :i him to fly. In the wild these birds consume a great many insects, but as yet I hi. been unable to get them to eat either mealworms, maggots or fruit fli I have even gone to the trouble of catching flies, moths and other inse: for them, but again no interest has been shown in them. The one exc< tion to this was the Golden-winged Manakin which upon arrival was sc to hawk a few fruit flies every now and then but no longer does it. Tb it would seem that apparently the above mixture coupled with n hummingbird formula, which is available to them, supplies all the noun: ment that they need. I say this because of the lack of interest shown all my manakins in any form of insect life. All in all they are wonderful birds and I can recommend them to anyc who may be fortunate enough to secure some. They are a star attract in any collection especially when they display. This article will be continued at a later date mentioning some of 1 other members of the family w hich I have in my collection. I am howe < including a partial reference list now for those who wish to read m< about the family--Pipridae.

(Sturnus pagodarum) By A. W. Bowden (Haverhill, Suffolk, England) had been keeping a number of birds--canaries, budgerigars, small "ign seedeaters and Pekin Robins--for some years, mainly for show poses; but began to find the small seedeaters a nuisance and got rid of m, buying instead a Pagoda Starling, Sturnus pagodarum. This was a d bird that did very well at shows, beating a pair of the same species led by a friend. I wanted a mate for it and bought a hen from a bird n. This bird was in rough condition when it arrived. It remained gh for as long as I had it. put both birds out in the spring of 1967 in an aviary 6 ft. x 6 ft. with a . x 3 ft. covered shed, nice and cosy and warm for nights. I also put with them a pair of Glossy Starlings that my wife had bought me for istmas, and they all appeared to get on well together. Shortly after this friend, who was moving, offered me his pair of Pagoda Starlings, iwing that they were good I snapped them up, brought them home and, "St July, put them into the aviary with the other birds, also putting in a -box in which my friend s pair used to sleep. This was an ordinary gerigar breeding box, with no concave in the bottom inside, but with a e hay which had been carried in by the birds from the flight. 'n 29th July there was a rare old scuffle in the aviary. I could not be 5 if this was mating or fighting; but shortly after I noticed that the cock ie pair that I had just bought from my friend was standing on its hen,

A. W. BOWDEN--BREEDING THE PAGODA STARLING which looked dead. I jumped into the aviary quickly and both birds i, up. I took out both my friend's hen and the scruffy hen; and fn subsequent evidence it would appear that my original " cock " was a i and had paired with the cock of my friend's pair. They had taken c: the nest-box and were nesting. My friend had tried to achieve this \ two years, and now it had happened in less than a month. The nest was completed with leaves from a blackcurrant bush that t planted in the aviary. Once breeding commenced the Pagoda Starli would not tolerate the Glossy Starlings in the flight but would attack thi and drive them back into the shed. On 7th August I could hear some squeaks from the box but dared " look in case I upset the birds. An egg-shell, which I saw when the cl pitched it out of the box, was about the size of a quail egg, and light blu<t colour. The weather was quite good, hot days and warm nights, I buying maggots for my quails, and put some down for the starlings. ']" latter started taking two or three at a time to feed whatever was the On nth August it poured with rain and the nest box became soaked fron leak in the aviary roof. This necessitated getting on top of the aviary 2: securing a piece of corrugated P.V.C. over the leak, which did the job, 2: mercifully the birds seemed all right. They were still feeding somethi I was putting in maggots three times a day now and this was gett i expensive, so I decided to try and breed my own from rotten meat, at 1; bottom of the garden. The starlings would not take the small ones thal was producing, only taking the larger ones. I had to keep on buying th"i in. I could not get enough, but after a time I noticed that thay we taking the pupae as food for the young. The droppings of the you; which were brought out were always lain on a sill in the aviary, never on t floor. At last, on 28th August, out came a young Pagoda Starling, onto t floor of the flight. It was just as with children, with dad showing what' do; the cock flying up onto the perch, the young one trying to folio falling down several times, but finally making it. Within twenty-fo hours the youngster was flying from one perch to another, and sleeping between times. It was fed by its parents for another week, apparent entirely on maggots, for I never saw anything else given. Then it becar more independent. The parents tried to feed it but it appeared not want them to. They would try, but it preferred to feed itself, witho being forced. On 12th September, the hen was sitting again I do not know when s) laid again for I had not missed her until then. As soon as the hen start* to settle to her second round of eggs the cock had started chasing the fir young one and would, I believe, have killed it if I had not removed it. C 18th September feeding with single maggots began. On 20th September t! cock brought out a dead young one in its bill which, from its shape, looke as though it had died before getting out of the shell. On 23rd Septernb 1

they were feeding young again on maggots, maggots and more maggots., On nth October a young one was out but did not look too good. Its feet were badly deformed and it could not stand and I had to destroy it. To my regret two further young, which emerged on 15th and 19th October respectively, were also badly affected in the same way. I think that their diet was less varied in October, unlike August when lies were available, more wasps on fruit, and caterpillars on cabbage leaves. 1 he main diet that I gave them was Sluis Universal Food and loads of ishing maggots; and in addition fruit--orange and apple, a few sultanas, md red currants and black currants. The first young one has turned out to be a fine cock. It has a brilliant -or.g and is quite tame, allowing anyone to coax its head if it is done slowly vithout frightening it; and it has won prizes at several shows.

algorithms.bodyText: To me, as a I hai, the accounts of aviculture in temperate countries are lways as fascinating as they are bewildering. The terrors of the winter - ason with its attendant maladies, need for radical changes in bird housing ad avian food shortages--particularly shortages of insects--are almost icomprehensible to those who live in the tropics. Thailand is particularly fortunate for its phlegmatic seasons. Some nglish folk here, I know, say " Oh for a cold wind and the sight of snow "! ut I doubt if the birds share their view. There are seasons here, of )urse, but just sufficient to trigger off the day-length, thermo-regulated id humidotrophic mechanisms upon which most of nature depends, ur mean minimum is 68'" F and our mean maximum 95 0 F, there is a x month wet season, but it does not rain every day nor does it ever rain 1 day; it does not rain but it pours "--and gets it over with, mean ind speed is 3 to 4 knots with little monthly variation, i.e. a more-or-less Tennial zephyr. In case you think this is subliminal tourist propaganda, t me hasten to draw the inferences in avian terms. If your birds are ly enough to stay out in the rain (as my Gouldians are) there is no follow- 1 icy blast to quick-freeze them. The constantly high humidity is surance enough, and most times the sun will come out, and so offset any aporative cooling (worse luck!). I hailand has other features as well, which favour aviculture. There is, r example, only a relative minimum of restriction on the external trade birds. Export is wisely controlled of the Great Argus Pheasant, the

Peacock Pheasant, the Black Stork, the Black-headed Stork, the White- necked Stork, the Sarus Crane, the Spotted-bill Pelican, the Comb Duck the White-winged Wood-duck and the Roul Roul. Moreover, Thailanc has, in its own right, many desirable indigenous species of cage-birds, furthermore, such is the economic structure of the country that most ol the appurtenances of aviculture are cheap and abundant. There are, of course, some drawbacks. First, the market is " thin " so that prices of individual species of birds tend to be anomalously high: a pair of Golden Pheasants here for example, costs about 2000 baht; in; Australia, I note they are quoted at about 350 baht. Yet they are freel) importable here but banned from import in Australia. There is also a dearth of cage-bird societies and of detailed literature on the hobby. The worst drawback, however, is the ant-based ecology of the place, in some ways this is a good thing, Australians, for example, who come here never cease to be amazed at the almost complete absence of flies; fresh meat can be hawked in the street without any danger of being " blown ", the main reason seems to be that whenever any organic matter falls to the ground, ants pounce upon it before any fly pupae can emerge. So far as bird-keeping is concerned, ants are an awful nuisance. Let a bird fall off its perch at night and unless you hear its cries for help and rescue it quickly it will be nothing but a pile of bones and feathers by morning, they are extremely vicious and attempts to succour a bird just newly-attacked means that you yourself will be covered in tiny stings, ants are insidious--none to-day; a whole swarm tomorrow--I find water dispersible dieldrin acts quickly and lasts long, but you must be constantly vigilant. Oddly enough, the very ubiquity of ants ensures an excellent supply of their egg-coccoons; you can buy them fresh, dried or quick- frozen or, for that matter, you can buy freshly killed ants themselves, a favourite food of the larger thrush-like birds. Apart from ants, you can buy other insects, there are dried " water- boatmen ", and a beetle like a German cockroach--the Rice-husk Beetle, which obligingly undergoes population explosions if you feed it rice-husks, banana skins and a little rice-water, its habitat is quite odd since rice-husks used to be used as an insecticide because of their abrasiveness. This pachydermatous beetle, however, evolved with great cunning in a medium which was lethal to its insect parasites and predators alike. As for other bird-foods, there is a never-ending supply of bananas, grapes and paw-paws, the latter, unless Ai in quality, being regarded as pig-food. Bird-seeds of all kinds are available but you can rarely buy millet sprays and I have to grow my own. The Market As I have already hinted, the Thai-market for individual bird species but this is offset by an absence of import restrictions and a is " thin proximity to sources e.g. Japan, Hong Kong, and Indonesia.

I2 5 Market conditions are however largely governed by the presence of the Week-end Market " which sells everything from kettles to cobras, from es to finches. Here dealers can set up stalls for nominal temporary rent About 40 stalls cater for bird-keepers, some selling seed only, some .cal birds only, some imported birds only and some a mixture. Pro- inquity tends to level prices, and you can go from stall to stall bargaining, at for rarer species bargaining is necessarily limited. There is no doubt, jwever, that the establishment of the " Week-end Market " some years ;o has helped not only to cheapen but helped also to popularize the ;epmg of birds.

Provided you are not in a hurry, you can buy most species illustrated in ch a book as Rutgerss A Handbook of Foreign Birds. You may have to ait a year, say, for Tanagers to turn up and I have almost despaired of iding a hen Pekin Robin or a Superb Spreo. Indigenous species are, of course, almost constantly available and some e so common that they appear in one part of the market as cage-birds d in another as birds for eating, birds which lead this double "life ", B the Ba ^ a Weaver and various of the water-rails. Birds which (happily) ' ^ 0t share thls dual fate include numerous species of international fame, ch as the King Vulture, the Greater Adjutant Stork with his pendulous )p of stinking food, the Green Peafowl, a great bevy of aquatic birds-- 'ebes, Pelicans, Gannets, Cormorants, Frigates, Herons, Bitterns, ises, and 15 duck species. A number of fierce-visaged Eagles, Hawks' izzards, Kites, Goshawks, Hobbies, Falcons, Harriers and Kestrels in iir entirety, suggest that there is no dearth of proteinaceous prey-on-the- of. J The Phasiamds are represented by the Francolin, a number of Partridges eluding the very popular Roul Roul, the Silver Pheasant, the Crested i Siamese Fireback and that " Daddy-of-them-all ", the Red Jungle vvl whence all domesticated " fowls " have sprung, needless to say, in mg Red Jungle Fowl, you need to be an expert systematist to avoid ng sold one of the many hybrids--the dorsal white spot being diagnostic no * an ex(d usive sign. There are five pea-fowl, including the Great 'Us Pheasant, which becomes aggressive in captivity. There is the Migratory and Painted Quail and three Button Quail operly Turmcids) I have found quail very difficult to keep on the floors aviaries, their accustomed place, again because of those aggressive sances, the ants. fhe Sarus Crane is the only representative of the Gruids but is now so 5 that its export has fortunately been stopped. There is a host of ,g birds--Rails, Crakes, Snipes, Lapwings, a Curlew, Godwits, \0x25A0nks, Sandpipers, a Taller and Turnstone, Knots, Stints, and that odd

sexually dimorphic pair, the Ruff and the Reeve, there is one Stilt, tw Thick-knees and two Pratincoles. There is, as one might expect, a " floating " population of skuas, gulls terns and the Common Noddy. Some are permanent residents and on or two species, e.g. the Brown-headed Gull, are on sale, a practice wit! which I cannot agree. There is a large number of Pigeons--quite a fe\ being variants of the Green Pigeon. There is a Rock Pigeon whici some claim to be autochthonous and thus not one of " the common herd ' (the ubiquitous " Double Bar "), but even the best of local ornithologist mournfully admit that " sometimes it is difficult to know whether it is true wild or a feral ". Doves are the darlings of Thai bird-fanciers and those which coo th most melodically fetch high prices--#100 for a single bird being th highest recorded price. A mystique surrounds the bird--the excellent of its dawn cooing setting a favourable augury for the day. At th Week-end Market there are stalls selling doves exclusively and one car see devotees just sitting and gazing for hours on end at either of the twc races --tigrina or vacillans --of the Spotted-necked Dove which, to mos foreigners, is just a mousy little bird, but here has an aura of magic am majesty. On the off-shore islands we also have the Nicobar Pigeon with its cape 0 long green hackles. A friend recently raised a brood in a very mixer aviary. We have seven rather greenish parrots, including the two cut< little Hanging Parrots. There are some owls, occasionally marketed, and a range of colourfu Trogons and Kingfishers. There is the highly-popular Hoopoe which fortunately, is very common throughout Thailand. Thirteen Hornbill: form a curiously interesting radiant group of which the Black and tht ever-raucous Pied Hornbill are frequently on sale. There are also r- species of Barbets including the extremely beautiful Coppersmith. A1 have distinctive calls and a friend who specializes in Barbets exclusively has them all and has taped all their calls. We have a large number 0 Woodpeckers, Wrynecks and Piculets, many of which have bright rec crests and are otherwise coloured attractively. Some say they are almos' impossible to keep for long, while the dealers claim that all one needs is ai incessant supply of insect infested tree-limbs. Perhaps both statements add up to the same thing! A family of which I am very fond are the Pittas and I have spent a lot 0: money building up a collection. I give them sloping logs on which tc perch and mushy dead grass on which to hop about. They live on the anl coccoons which are so easily obtainable here. The blue-winged Pitta is quite cheap--about 10 shillings per pair but others of the nine species bring around #4 or #5 per pair. Because of their low-roosting habits, you must be constantly on the watch for ants.

There are innumerable Shrikes, Bulbuls, Tits, Thrushes, Orioles, Starlings and Leaf-birds, representatives of all of which are frequently on Two of the most interesting amongst this galaxy are the incredibly fluent Grackle and that prince of songsters, the Shama. The Grackle talking Mynah, or Greater Indian Hill Mynah, occurs over much of south- eastern continental Asia and the sub-joined archipelago. I bought a young one for #2 and imported a whole library of books of the " How to tram your Grackle " type. " Koon Tong ", (" Mrs. Gold "), as we 1 hais call the bird, remained quite taciturn for several months and my usband used to joke and say " No need to buy any food today; we can have Koon Tong curry for tea ". And then within a fortnight, at the onset of his first moult, Koon Tong developed an astonishingly varied vocabulary, much of it conditioned, such as the tirade of abusive Thai whenever the dogs bark unduly. Rutgers ( loc. cit.) classes the Shama second only to the Nightingale as a songster. You can buy Shama here for 12 shillings each (pre-vocal) and up to 30 shillings for a guaranteed songster. Its close relative, the Magpie Robin, used to come every day to teach our Shama to sing and it was amusing to hear him warbling sotto voce to himself before he had the confidence to sing his wonderfully liquid song with all its contrapuntal improvizations. Of the smaller-cage birds, there are three which particularly take my ancy--the Advadavats, the White Eyes and the Pintail Nonpareils, the last named is a beautifully svelte little bird in which the cock is most colourful, many have rheumy noses but once you get a healthy pair they grace an aviary for years. Thailand has four White-eye species which are all too friendly, perching on your shoulder as you walk out of the aviaries like prisoners planning a bold escape. The Red Avadavats are the real pygmies of local bird-land, forever building nests which, in my experience, come to nought. There are lots of the 800 odd species of Thai birds which I have not mentioned. Literature on them was highly scientific, fragmentary and ^argely unillustrated until a month or two ago when our own Dr. Boonsong . e Thailand s outstanding Wild-Life Conservationist, published ns ully illustrated Bird Guide of Thailand. Copies are, I understand, ivaiJable from The Fauna Preservation Society, c/o Zoological Society \egents Park, London, N.W.i. If you come to Bangkok, be sure to visit the Dusit Zoo, which has a very me bird collection including a huge aviary, the central feature of which is a irge swamp surrounded by a natural habitat of littoral plants. A visit to Mrs. Y. Siak s Bangkok Reptile Grove " is also worthwhile, ot only because it must be one of the best reptile collections in the world' ut because it has some very fine specimens of carnivorous local birds and a 'nge of ducks.

algorithms.bodyText: By Rosemary Low (Sidcup, Kent, England) The Black-tailed Conure ( Pyrrhura melanura melanura ) has two sub- species--Chapman's ( P . m. pacified) and Souance's ( P . m. souancei). In the Natural History Museum there are skins of P. m. melanura and of souancei ; unfortunately these skins are very old and undoubtedly faded but it would appear that the main difference lies in the red feathers on the edge of the wing. All the specimens marked melanura show a little yellow in this area, whereas in souancei there is no trace of yellow in these red feathers which extend further down the wing. The scaly markings on the upper breast and neck on this sub-species are broadly edged with huffish white, but in melanura the scaling is mostly brownish or only faintly edged with buff. I have a pair of Souance's Conures and they are quite handsomely marked birds. In a consignment of about 20 of these conures which I saw last year, I noticed that three were slightly different from the others and bought them for this reason. They differ from P. m. souancei in the following respects:
algorithms.figure: Cheeks. Chest and Neck " Scaling." Skin Surrounding Eye. P. m. souancei dark green, very prominently edged with white, very wide, snowy P. m.} olive green, narrowly edged with huffish white,
algorithms.bodyText: barely noticeable. white. The most obvious difference at first glance is the very striking white eye ring, absent in the unidentified sub-species, which is a less brightly coloured bird and slightly smaller than souancei. It shows no yellow in the wing. Both sub-species have the upper side of the tail maroon and the underside of the tail black; the flights are bluish-black and the rest of the plumage is dark green. Presumably, the unidentified sub-species must be Chapman's. Can any member confirm this or refer me to any literature which may be helpful? I should add, that in all the Pyrrhura conures, there is no difference in the plumage of cock and hen or adult and immature birds.

algorithms.sectionHeader: THE KILLING OF NESTLINGS BY THE MALE PARENT
algorithms.bodyText: By C. J. O. Harrison (Perivale, Middlesex, England) 1 was recently congratulating myself on having persuaded two Robins Enthacus rubecula , to tolerate each other and to nest, when I rose one morning to find the eight-day-old young lay dead and cold outside the nest, in a condition suggesting a violent end. I contacted an acquaintance for sympathy, only to be told that he lost young Redstarts, Phoenicurus phoenicurus , in the same way at about the same age. Looking back through earlier volumes of the Avicultural Magazine I discovered that this seemed to have happened, at roughly the same period in the nesting cycle, with a number of attempted breedings of insect-eating species; and in discussing the matter wuth others I discovered that I had joined a band o. hopeful breeders of insectivorous birds for whom disaster strikes at just such a time. It therefore seemed an appropriate moment to consider the possible causes of these events. Steinbacher and Wolters (1964) when discussing failures to rear young Bearded Reedlings, Panurus biarmicus, in aviaries have suggested that where parents usually spend most of the daylight hours carrying loads ot small insects to begging young ones, the ready supply of food in the aviary causes the young to become sated and sleepy long before the parent's feeding impulses have been satisfied, and that when the young fail to respond to offers of food the adults react as they would to dead young in the nest, and throw them out. While this seems a reasonable hypothesis it would operate at any age and, assuming the food supply was available, the young would probably be ejected at an early stage and not halfwav through their period in the nest. The most likely cause of the death of the young would seem to be aggressiveness of the male. Nicolai, while studying the Shama, Copsychus malabancus , concluded that under aviary conditions the aggressive dominance of the male reasserted itself during the nesting period when the female was normally dominant and led to the killing of the young and disruption of nesting. It is, however, difficult to believe that this is just the normal aggressiveness of the male, usually inhibited by the female; and it seems probable that there is an increase in aggressiveness under aviary conditions possibly through a damming-up of aggressive behaviour that would find relief under natural conditions. Normally a great deal of the 11a e s energy must be dissipated, while the female is incubating and caring or small young, in patrolling the territory, fighting off rivals, and in \0x25A0rigorous assaults on a variety of small prey. Under aviary conditions e territory is very restricted, the rivals are usually absent, the food is nactive and readily accessible, and the only other living things present, owards which the male can react, may be the female and the young.'

130 C. J. O. HARRISON--KILLING OF NESTLINGS BY THE MALE PARENT This could create the potentially dangerous situation where the male might suddenly attack his mate or offspring. Where, as sometimes happens, the male destroys the young as soon as they emerge from the egg, it seems unlikely that he resents them as intruders, and I question whether he recognises them as birds. It seems more probable that the small squirming lumps of bare flesh release his impulse to kill small organisms. The larger insect-eating birds will at times take small fish, amphibians, and reptiles, and the sight of the young might release such a tendency which could be all the stronger for having had no other outlet. This might account for the killing of the young in the early stages, but it would not explain why the male might feed small young and then kill them when half grown. A suggestion often put forward by aviculturists is that the male destroys the young in order to " persuade the female to go to nest again While it is understandable that the male might be reacting strongly to the absence of any sexual response from the female, I think it argues a degree of reasoning that does not appear to be present in birds to suggest that the male recognises a nest of young as a distraction that is competing with him for the female's attention and decides to get rid of it. It would appear to be a direct extrapolation from probable (if a little uncivilized) human behaviour in similar circumstances to that of birds. I think that if aggression was aroused in the male by a lack of response in the female it would be likely to result in a direct attack on her, and to expect the bird to achieve its end by indirect methods would seem to be asking rather too much of it. I would add that I am equally dubious of that old and apparently widely accepted statement that in most species the male " drives the female to nest ". It again argues a degree of reasoning the existence of which I doubt. Such " driving to nest as I have seen appeared to be simply direct aggression on the part of the male, and if the female does finally take refuge on or at the nest, and if the male is inhibited from attacking his mate at the nest and therefore leaves her alone, this would appear to be a fortunate accident rather than the original intention. It is certainly an aspect of the behaviour of birds in aviaries which deserves more critical examination by students of bird behaviour. The nest may not necessarily save the female from violence since I know of one instance of a female Nuthatch, Sitta europaea , killed on her eggs by the male in an aviary. Assuming that there is a build-up of aggressive behaviour and hunting tendencies for which there is no natural outlet in the males of insectivorous birds in aviaries during the breeding season, one can therefore suggest reasons for the attacks on the hen and the killing of small young, but this does not explain the sudden killing of young birds, which the male has been helping to feed, at a point about halfway through their period in the nest. Unless one assumes that this is the length of time needed for the

C. J. O. HARRISON--KILLING OF NESTLINGS BY THE MALE PARENT 131 >ales frustrations to build up to a point of release, it is necessary to con- der what else might be critical at this stage. One thing apparent to me when observing the nestlings was that at about us period in growth a change seemed to occur, and what had previously een a blind, reptilian object with a constantly gaping mouth now began > appear for the first time as a bird which, although lacking proper iumage, started to resemble in size, shape and general appearance the ,ec,es to which it belonged. If such a change was apparent to me it is jssible that it might be equally apparent to the male parent and I think le could reasonably propose a hypothesis that at this stage in the develon- ent of the young the male may for the first time recognise them as dividuals of the same species rather than as a generalized mass of small ijects begging for food ,n a nest. If this were so, and if the male was ' reason of the aviary environment, in a state of hyper-aggression, then 'ack eC * S 10n m ' ght be the faet0r whkh tri SS ered off the final fatal K. E. On the days on which the feathers broke from the sheaths on th backs and necks of the young, the old birds stood on the edge of the nes often with food in their bills, screaming the enemy call, and while doin so they often made inhibited attacking movements towards the young one: Both parents of pair 3 behaved in this manner when I put among thei naked young a slightly older young one which was already a little featherec whereas they took not the slightest notice of a strange young one which wa also naked. algorithms.bodyText: Located some 15 miles or so out of the centre of Tokyo, but still in tl metropolitan limits is a new zoo called Tama Zoological Park. It is no 11 years old, and is now independent of Ueno. There are a number exhibits which follow geographic lines as much as possible. The birds fj the most part are kept in a series of cages which blend in with the trees ar shrubs which dot the hills of the zoo. For the Birds of Prey there are tv huge aviaries, in one are several Hooded Vultures ( Aegypius ), White-tail* Sea Eagle (Raliaeetus albicilla) that were busy nest building on the day my visit, hawks and kites. In the adjoining cage, which is also quite lar are two adult Stellar Sea Eagles. Scattered about the grounds are flights for Snowy Owls, Clark's Eag Owl, Formosan Blue Magpies, various pheasants, and one walk-throu^ cage with exotic waterfowl and shorebirds. The zoo is now building, ai will open this spring, a series of attractive runs for the wild Jungle-fowl the world, and already have for this exhibit trios of Gallus lafayetti (ti only ones in Japan) and Gallus soneratti. Off exhibit and for breeding a extensive runs of rare gallinaceous birds. The cock Satyr Tragopan w particularly fine. There are several cranes here including pairs of Ma churian, White-necked and Hooded. Osaka is a rather newer zoo, and in view of Expo. 70 is rapidly tearii down its old structures and replacing them with most attractive n( exhibits. There are many birds of prey here, including a large series those species native to Japan. There are fine runs for cranes, and t Sarus has hatched several young here in recent years, I saw the late: hatched in October 1968. The zoo also has set aside a very large avia solely for the use of European Storks. Some sixteen young have be hatched here in the past five years, now in the second generation. This a very good exhibit and since the cage is quite high they can fly about free I noted in my brief walk about this zoo a group of very reddish Scar Ibis, several young Cassowary and Ostriches, two groups of Argus Pheasai a pair of Concave-casqued Hornbill, Toco and Green-billed Touca several Hooded Cranes, a true pair of Indian Black-necked Storks, and ti rather rare psittacines which were not known to the zoo authorities found that really rare things were frequently misidentified or not identifi at all in several zoos), in a house, living in small cages. One was a fi Thick-billed Parrot, and the other a Racquet-tailed Parrot (Pnonitun with a very bright blue head, and perfectly formed tail racquets, rht also were several Rose-crested Cockatoos. Nagoya for many years was the largest collection in Japan and sti some very top quality stock. The zoo is large in size and borders botanical gardens. The Chilean Flamingo were in fine colour, and the were two Coscoroba Swans, a rarely seen species in Japan. I thought t pairs of Andean Condor and Hooded Vultures quite handsome, were four Hooded Cranes, two European, and single Manchurian a Stanleys. In the tropical bird house I noted four Citron-crested Cockatc

algorithms.bodyText: riel and Sulphur-breasted Toucan, and some nice Mynahs. There was a )od series of gallinaceous birds and birds of prey. However the main- ay of Nagoya is its extensive mammal collection. A rarity in Japan is the free zoo, and one of the most well known is ogevama Zoo in Yokohama, a short walk from the central railway station, id found in the midst of a well ordered park surrounded by the houses of is vast port city. The grounds are of necessity very small, but the limals and birds were in good condition. Mandarin Ducks do very well \0x25A0re and young are hatched each year, I thought all of the 16 seen were in cellent colour. Again a Coscoroba Swan (the first seen in Japan came Yokohama), and a fine Comb Duck. There were quite a few Vega erring Gulls and Japanese Kittiwakes, two colourful Rose Pelicans elecanus roseus), Woolly-necked Stork, a colony of Night Herons lycticorax) that have young every year, several Moluccan Ibis, four iropean Spoonbills, and a small pheasant exhibit which had wild imported ikados, very fine looking birds. The pheasants in general in Yokohama \0x25A0re better than anywhere else save Tama and Ueno. Of course the ize exhibit is a rather good sized flight cage containing four male and *ee female Andean Condors, the largest group on exhibit outside South nerica, and more are to be added this summer. One pair from this lection is on loan to the zoo at Seoul, Korea. All were in magnificent idition, but to date there has been no breeding, probably since the cage wercrowded, even though quite large.

By Rosemary Low (Sidcup, Kent, England) he study of abnormal colouring in parrots and parrotlike birds is remely interesting, examples of which are not particularly rare. Colour iations can be divided into two classes: (") those caused by mutation {b) those caused by constitutional disturbance or dietary deficiencv old age. I any British bird fanciers know that hand-reared birds which are ering from a deficiency in their diet often show partially or completely te feathers in their plumage; this is particularly evident on birds with k or brown plumage, where it is due to a lack of melanin pigment when feathers are growing. Green feathers usually possess a combination nelanin and a yellow pigment; if the melanin is lost the other may ain to produce a yellow feather. The yellow feathers of Amazon ots are of this type; but Grey Parrots are exceptional in that the feather ' be pink or red if the grey colour is lost.
algorithms.sectionHeader: 138 ROSEMARY LOW--ABNORMAL COLOURING IN SOME PARROTS
algorithms.bodyText: I have had two cases of yellow feathering among my own birds. Tw( years ago I purchased a female Salvin's Amazon--on the day she arriver in this country. There was quite a lot of yellow scattered irregularly ove her plumage, but mainly on the back and flights. The feathers affectec were partially, not wholly, yellow. She gradually lost all these yellov feathers. She appeared quite healthy but later contracted sinus trouble which ha left her with a permanent, though not serious, wheeze. This woulc indicate a constitutional weakness. The second case relates to a male Purple-bellied Parrot ( Triclaru malachitacea). This bird, when imported about four years ago by Mr. H Murray of Brentwood, was perfectly normal in colour. Golden-yellov feathers gradually appeared in his plumage, which have really adde< considerably to his beauty. Some of the flight feathers are marked witl yellow and the lower tail feathers are all almost completely yellow. / large number of feathers on the back and rump and a few on the breast am wings are also yellow. This bird appears very fit and wintered outside with only an open fronted shelter. The pair have apparently always refused fruit and greei food, unlike Mr. Murray's other pair of Purple-bellieds, and feed only 01 seed and nectar and any winged insects that they can hawk for themselves I can only persuade them to take sunflower seed, a little hemp, a dail handful of peanuts in the shell, spray millet and nectar consisting of hone and rose-hip syrup. They also like twigs from fruit trees with buds oi them. The cause of the yellow feathering in this bird is therefore almos certainly a deficient diet. Frank Finn, in his book Pets and How to Keep Them wrote of a so-calle* " King Grey Parrot ", i.e. one with irregular red feathering on the bod\ He stated that " The best specimen of the variety I ever saw, a bird whicl was really more red than grey, showed the plumage of a thin and sickl character, and I have heard since that it moulted out much greyer, thu showing the red to have been a sign of constitutional disturbance ". Another interesting case of the appearance of yellow feathers can be seei in the Double-eyed Dwarf or Fig Parrot ( Opopsitta diophthalm< diophthalma) in the Bird House at the London Zoo. This bird wa collected by David Attenborough in New Guinea in 1957. Twelve year in confinement is a remarkable length of time for a species which few hav even succeeded in keeping alive. For the last two years this little bird ha been showing definite signs of age and spends most of the day sleeping During the last twelve months, it has acquired a large number of yello\ feathers and now all its plumage is evenly mottled with yellow. I recently saw a Spectacled Amazon Parrot ( Amazona albifrons albifrons known to be very old, marked in exactly the same way.
algorithms.figure: KARL PLATH--THE SPIX MACAW, OR LITTLE BLUE MACAW *39 'HE SPIX MACAW, OR LITTLE BLUE MACAW (Ara spixii) By Karl Plath (Curator of Birds Emeritus, Brookfield Zoo, Illinois U.S.A.)
algorithms.bodyText: This lovely little Macaw, the smallest and perhaps the rarest of the ue Macaws, is a native of Eastern Brazil, chiefly in the Province of lhia. It owes its name to Dr. J. B. Spix who discovered it on the Rio in Francisco, Bahia, during his trip to Brazil, 1817-1820. Rare, not il} in Museums but also in zoological collections, there are no authentic cords that show its importation into America prior to 1927 and very few, am, since that date. Of the very few imported in the United States, I ceived one from the firm of Louis Ruhe, Inc. of New York, in exchange r a Thick-billed Parrot, equally rare at that time. A dwarf compared to the giant Hyacinthine Macaw, it is but twenty-two dies in total length. It differs noticeably also in the paler and softer ade of cobalt blue, according to the light or the position it assumes, ost of the feathers being edged with light grey the plumage has a silvery ect which is very pleasing. The feathers of the head and neck are eyish and elongated and often erected which gives the head a puffy pearance. The upper part of the chest is tinged with brownish-grey d the under parts are dull greenish-blue. Its comparatively small beak, lg tail, and general elegance of form make it one of the most perfectly portioned in this family of usually ungainly birds. Talking parrots have been rare in my collection but " Mac " our Spix icaw, while not as proficient as a good talking Amazon Parrot, has quite ew sentences. When any attention is paid to him, particularly by a anger who takes his fancy, the conversation carried on gives an impres- n of a very intelligent and educated bird. All people do not make good pressions evidently for unless he senses a sympathetic nature he sits smn and dumb on his perch. He is not kept in a cage but his stand has a ee foot high natural branch on which he gyrates and flaps his wings with at abandon. Having one wing clipped soon taught him not to attempt ring his territory and we could trust him not to, voluntarily, dis period of greatest loquacity is in the morning before breakfast when can hear him chattering " Mac wants his breakfast " Mac wants ie water "--or apple--or bread--or " Mac wants a drink " usually in id succession and quite distinctly, in a feminine voice. WTien we ue down he says " Good-morning " quite briskly. ) stranger is apt to be disconcerted when suddenly asked " Want a A " by this feathered imp. We have taught him " Way down on the anee River far, far away " which he sings in a funny quaver, and ock abye baby, in the tree top ", gulping and swallowing a word asionally and, I am sorry to say, missing the tune completely. He is

quite lovable and tame, rarely nips, and though he does squawk sometim this does not compare in volume to the harsh, strident screech of tl larger Macaws or Cockatoos. Sometimes after indulging in his wild twirlings on his perch he w become quite noisy for a spell, then suddenly say " What's the matte huh? " and if reproved for anything says quietly " Mac's a bad boy He is always ready to have his head rubbed, purring the while and is qui amusing when he whispers the sentences he knows. His monkey-lil antics are quite amusing when he is climbing up and down his branch ar he derives much amusement from a small bell which dangles from a cha fastened to the branch. For food my Macaw had a great preference for sunflower seed thou# canary, millet and hemp seed were offered and included in the set mixture. In addition, each morning he would get the core of an app and a piece of drv bread or cracker which invariably he would drop in tl water before eating. In summer a bit of grass sod would be enjoye He liked a bath in the warm summer rain, drooping his wings and fluffir out, but during the winter he tolerated a bath in the tub with about tw inches of water and would be gently sprayed with a small sprinkler. I this time his feathers would be held tight and close to his body. " Mac " was received 9th February 1928. I can still visualize hii crawling out of the shipping crate and shyly climbing on my hand, h was a young bird and met an untimely end. I had been out of town at convention and " Mac " was being temporarily boarded at the Zoo. h had been placed with two Amazons supposedly safe but one morning tl parrot keeper found him dead from attacks by the Amazons. His li ended on nth March 1946.

Males an females are coloured alike in shades of brown varying from dark fuscou almost black, on the upper tail coverts and retrices to buffy white on tb abdomen. The beak is a dull metallic grey, and exposed skin of the tars feet and eyelids is greyish. Newly hatched nestlings have darkly pigmer ted skin. On 21 st July, 1967, an albino of this species was hatched in my aviary lere m Long Beach, California. It was noted on the morning of hatching s its skin was a uniform pink in marked contrast to the dusky skins of its :estmates. The bird was observed daily during the nestling stage, photo- graphed from time to time, and conditioned to hand feeding as a part of ne observational procedure. The lining of the mouth was pink with no race of the black band across the palate. The eyes, which opened on the eventh day, were red. The juvenile plumage was white, with a faint nge of pink on the upper tail coverts and the upper surface of the retrices Although the normally coloured siblings of this bird departed from the est on the 17th day, the albino stayed in the nest box for two additional ays. After departure, it demonstrated a visual difficulty in bright miight, being unable to fly to the perches with the precision usually emonstrated by fledglings of this species. For its protection, it was moved to an indoor cage with one of its parents. At the postjuvenal moult in October, the pinfeathers of the rump region ere an intense pink and the resulting feathers formed an attractive rose floured spot. The amount of this colour has varied with succeeding oults in a manner which suggests it is influenced by diet. Presumably, it due to a carotenoid pigment which is genetically independent of, and ?mally masked by, the melanin pigments in birds of standard colour, he tarsi, feet, and eyelids of the albino are flesh coloured. The albino, a male, did not breed during its second summer. It was \0x25A0nfined during that summer in an outdoor aviary with several prospective ates. algorithms.bodyText: A. A. PRESTWICH--SOME ORKNEY NAMES FOR BIRDS

By A. A. Prestwich (Edenbridge, Kent, England) Thirty years ago I spent six months in Orkney--the Magnetic North During that time I collected the names of birds, both dialect and ir literature. There are between 65 and 70 islands in the group--a couple with thriving townships, some sparsely populated, but well over half uninhabited--with a population of about 25,000. Some of the more elderly Orcadians probably with justification, boast of viking ancestry and undoubtedly mam of the names used for birds are of Scandinavian origin. During the war many thousands of servicemen were stationed through- out the Islands, and since then Orkney has become a centre of tourism. A number of the bird names listed had long fallen into disuse and it is ven probable that the great influx of visitors of all kinds has now rendered the great majoritv of the remainder obsolete. Most will have been replacec bv those generally accepted in current check-lists and handbooks, and so apart from being of interest only to the philologist, they will soon be forgotten. Some of the names are common to Shetland or the north of Scotland, 01 all three. The list does not pretend to be complete but it is believed tc include all but the most obscure.

algorithms.bodyText: The most welcome additions were three species of Manakins--the Blue-backed, Red-headed, and White-bearded. We had been trying for a long time to acquire specimens of the latter two species, and it is such a pity that they are not better travellers, as they enhance any collection of birds. Also received were a pair of Black-gorgetted Thrushes, three Roulrouls, a Ross' Touraco, several Ferruginous Wood Partridges, Lesser and Rufous-bellied Niltavas, Klaas Cuckoo, Rufous Chatterers, Streaked Spiderhunter and Yellow-crowned and Red-headed Bulbuls. Two more clutches of Green Wood-hoopoes have been reared and the hen is sitting again. A pair retained from their first clutch last year are also beginning to show an interest in the nest-box. The Red-billed Horn- bills are also nesting again after a lapse of almost twelve months, and a pair of Spotted Morning Warblers purchased only in January have built small cup-shaped mud nests in several places, directly onto thick boughs. On three occasions they laid eggs and commenced incubation, only to desert them after a few days. The Hoopoes were again thwarted in their nesting attempts when the hen suffered a blocked preen gland whilst incubating. The expelled contents had the most vile smell. The problems of breeding birds in communal aviaries are still with us, and both the Andaman Grackles and Yellow-breasted Fruit Pigeons have recently lost chicks that were several days old. Abyssinian Ground Thrushes are also sitting again after losing their first clutch of eggs. Our Southern Tree Pies, the

A. A. PRESTWICH--SOME BREEDERS OF ECLECTUS PARROTS H 5 nost attractive of the Tree Pies, have just reared two young and a pair of Little Bee-eaters, have tunnelled, and we assume nested, as they are busy ;aking live food in at present.

By A. A. Prestwich (Edenbridge, Kent, England) There appears to be a deal of confusion regarding the English names of ome of the Eclectus Parrots that have been bred in this country. In 1912, Miss M. Drummond, Errol, Scotland, bred two Eclectus 'arrots. In two Editorial notes in " Bird Notes " Wesley T. Page eferred to them as Red Sided Eclectus Parrots and Grand Eclectus parrots. In her breeding account Miss Drummond called them Red- ided Eclectus pectoralis and the Foreign Bird Club Medal was awarded nder that name. But when another young one was reared the following ear the Editor referred to it as the Grand Eclectus Eclectus roratus and diss Drummond too, called it the Grand. The situation was eventually larified by an errata slip which states that by an unfortunate misunder- tanding the birds referred to as " Red-sided Eclectus (E. pectoralis) " /ere in fact Grand ( E. roratus). Miss Drummond gave another breeding ccount in the Avicultural Magazine, using the name Grand Eclectus oratus , and the Society's Medal was awarded for this success. Mrs. E. H. Hartley, Hastings, reported the rearing of a Grand Eclectus iratus in 1913. The next succesful breeder was H. J. Indge, in 1952 . He describes is birds as Red-sided Lorius roratus pectoralis and the Society's Medal as awarded accordingly. The most recent success is that of Mrs. N. Howard in 1968. The lbspecies bred she names as the Ceram Eclectus Lorius roratus roratus. Now the question is who has bred which species or subspecies? Authorities are agreed that there is only one species of the genus Lorius oddaert, 1783 (replaces Eclectus Wagler, 1832), namely roratus Muller, 776. Peters, with slight reservations, recognizes eleven subspecies or geo-
algorithms.reference: aphical variants: Cornelia , Cornelia's Eclectus Parrot. rtedeliy Riedel's Eclectus Parrot. westermaniy Westerman's Eclectus Parrot. roratus. Grand Eclectus Parrot. vosmaeriy Vosmaer's Eclectus Parrot. pectoraliSy Red-sided Eclectus Parrot.
algorithms.bodyText: A. A. PRESTWICH--SOME BREEDERS OF ECLECTUS PARROTS maforensis , Mafor or Numfor Eclectus Parrot. biaki , Biak Eclectus Parrot. aruensis , Aru Eclectus Parrot. macgillwrayi, Pascoe River Eclectus Parrot. goodsoni, Goodson's Eclectus Parrot. solomonensis , Solomon Islands Eclectus Parrot. Possibly there are now others. There is, of course, no gainsaying that Miss Drummond bred an Eclectus Parrot. But in view of the duplication of names by Wesley Page and Miss Drummond herself, and a complete absence of any description it is impossible to say exactly which Eclectus Parrot she did breed. It is, however, accepted that it was the Grand. Mrs. Hartley's bald report: " One Grand Eclectus ( Eclectus roratus)-- only the second time reared in captivity I believe ", could mean much or little. That the Eclectus Parrot bred by Indge was the Red-sided pectoralis is quite certain, as he showed the parents with their young one at the B.A.C. Meeting, 14th January, 1953. Mrs. Howard calls her Eclectus Parrots the Ceram Lorius roratus roratus , which is properly the Grand. As this Eclectus Parrot does indeed come from Ceram amongst other islands it could quite reasonably be given this as an alternative name. But Mrs. Howard has imported some twenty to twenty-five pairs of Eclectus Parrots and never before or since has she received a pair like her " Ceram "--all have been either Grand or Red- sided. Without being certain of their origin it is very difficult to decide to which race they belong. Colin Harrison has kindly compared colour photographs with the skins in the Natural History Museum. He is unable to come to any definite conclusion but thinks they might possibly be aruensis , from the Aru Islands. In any case they are sufficiently distinct for the Council to regard this event as a first success and to award the Society's Medal. Besides the Red-sided and Grand, Westerman's, Riedel's and Cornelia's Eclectus Parrots are believed to have been imported; and a smaller, purer and darker green race used to arrive from time to time. It was recognized as the Ceram or Cardinal Eclectus cardinalis , but cardinalis is now con- sidered to be a synonym of L. r. roratus. And so? It is believed that another aviculturist has bred Eclectus Parrots during the past two or three years, but no such success has been reported to the Society by the breeder. Only birds bred by Members of the Society have been reviewed.

The book deals with the Grass Parakeets and Broad-tailed Parakeets ad also includes the Polytelis species and the Cockatiel, omitting the King nd Crimson-wings, and the Cockatoos, and nectar-feeders with the xception of the Swift Parakeet. It opens with a general discussion of the .ustrahan parakeets in their natural habitat, and on keeping them in varies in Europe. algorithms.construct: i 5 * I LIVE WITH BIRDS. By Roy Ivor. London: Souvenir Press, 1968. Price 375. 6 d.
algorithms.bodyText: The author is well known for his observations, over forty years, of hand-reared birds, often at partial liberty, at his home near Toronto, Canada. Now 89, he has recently written this account of some of his observations on the birds that he has kept. One is aware throughout the book of the deep affection that the author obviously feels for his birds. He is anxious at all times to emphasize the individuality and personal peculiarities of each bird as a separate being, varying to some degree in its behaviour and activities from others of the same species. It is obvious that he has been engaged in a prolonged battle with those who insist on a more mechanistic interpretation of a bird's life and behaviour, and who have regarded the individual bird as an automaton which, in response to a certain stimulus, would invariably provide the expected response. To some extent this has driven the author to the opposite extreme, and although he advances his defence of anthropo- morphism (which has some justification, despite its use as a term of abuse) it nevertheless makes it difficult to evaluate the claims and comments on such difficult subjects as intelligence and the ability to learn and remember. Although one wishes at times for a little more critical appraisal and factual detail, the book does show the extent to which the hand-rearing of birds and constant living with known individuals can lead to a greater apprecia- tion and understanding of their lives and behaviour. Those of us in Britain who have had similar experience in raising birds tend to take our good fortune for granted, and it is therefore a little saddening to discover that Roy Ivor's opportunity to keep and study these birds was a wholly exceptional one maintained by virtue of special permits. The story that he quotes of the tame nestling Bluebird, left behind by its parents and hand-reared, which was to be confiscated and released elsewhere because those who failed to leave it to die had broken the law by being in possession of it, underlines the need for saner legisla- tion, flexible enough to cope with such exceptions. Criticism apart, Ivor's book does show the enhanced and sympathetic understanding that can be gained by a closer association with birds through keeping them, which I believe to be one of the great justifications for the continued existence of aviculture; and I would recommend it to every aviculturist who cares for birds as individuals. The book is illus- trated with many photographs of Ivor's own birds, 63 in the text and four pages of colour photographs.

algorithms.bodyText: I first noticed the illness of our Sawwhet Owl on the 6th of May, while he was ving his bath. The Owl has complete freedom within our house and free :ess to the outside world, which he never takes advantage of. We have had him
algorithms.listItem: * four years. While he was bathing I noticed that his right foot was very swollen and that ire was a small cut above the first joint of his toe. I picked him up to make a ser examination and at once noticed the foul smell that accompanies gangrene * ; f r oot and were green from just above the cut to the first joint. i\ e removed him at once to a large airy cage with clean sawdust on the floor we were unable to obtain peat moss, a low wooden perch and a stone for stropping beak on As he normally drinks a lot of water we gave him a bowl of water xed with Terramycine, and a freshly killed mouse. The Vet came round and mrmed our diagnosis; he also gave us a spray to use three times a day, more in nature of experiment, than any hope that it would work. The spray is called osan-Spray and contains Cloranfenicol and Gentian Violet. Vfter one week of treatment with the Spray and Terramycine, the colour and the , . Sone completely, the flesh of both leg and toe were a normal pink and swelling almost gone. ' -ugo, Spain. C. Matheson.

This folio volume lists all )irds and ammals kept at Lilford during the period August, 1878--June, 1893. ie Eiltord aviaries were, of course, renowned for the birds of prey. Amongst oany hundreds of entries probably the most interesting are those relating to the e-tailed Eagle Aquila albicilla --formerly resident in the British Isles and now a rare migrant: and the Little Owl Athene noctua --now resident as an intro- a bird. Donald Mack; had a shot at it a day or two before its capture as it flew over Lilford Wood, had a leg broken in the capture, and had I think a shot in or near the brain as it occasionally affected by a curious convulsive movement of the head, but it fee< well and seems healthy--Now in full moult, Aug. ' 78 It died the followir year. Towards the end of the last century Mr. E. G. B. Meade-Waldo, in Kent, ar Lord Lilford attempted to introduce the Little Owl. The efforts of the form met with some success but it was due mainly to the perseverance of Lord Lilfoi that this Owl became established and subsequently spread with considerab rapidity throughout the greater part of England. Has laid many eggs and hatched some young here." There no further entry concerning this species until April, 1881, when the additions ii elude two " Bred in Lilford aviary." {Aplonis panayensis) By Robin L. Restall (Copenhagen, Denmark) In the first volume of Aviculture (1925), M. Delacour had this to say of the subject of this paper: " . . . The Aplonis are a little smaller than Starlings; males are generally glossy black, females less dark; the differ- ent species are found in numerous islands, and are of little interest to avi- culture and seldom introduced. " Mr. Allen Silver, on the other hand, began an article on Glossy Star- hngs (1955) with " one cannot really think of Glossy Starlings without remembering Calornis {Aplonis) ". Admittedly, 80% of Mr. Silver's art- icle dealt with African Starlings, but it is nice to find a not unfavourable mention of them. The references to these birds in avicultural literature are rare, but a serious searcher can find mention elsewhere. My introduction to the species was when I discovered Robinson's Birds of the Malay Peninsula many years ago. Although I did not read the text on Aplonis panayensis , or even the caption to the picture, the illustration struck firmly in my mind. Later, when I became interested in the African Amethyst Starling, Cinnyricinclus leucogaster , the plumage of the thrush- like female Amethyst recalled the picture of the Aplonis in Robinson. I resolved that when the opportunity arose I would obtain the latter. The ambition became reality when, in September 1967, I saw an ad- vertisement by Avon Aviaries at Evesham for some Thailand Green Star- lings. Without waiting for an opportunity to refer to Robinson, I tele- phoned the proprietor, Mr. Burton, and ascertained that the males were green and the females thrush-like, and that both had the distinctive red eye I remembered. Because of other commitments at the time I restric- ted my purchase to only one pair, and eagerly awaited their arrival. The birds duly arrived. In subsequent conversation with my friend Mr. Derek Goodwin, he informed me that, to the best of his knowledge, the sexes of nearly all Aplonis species were pretty much alike and that my birds were almost certainly an adult and an immature A. panayensis , probably of the race strigata. Much later, when Mr. John Yealland was kindly showing me the single A. panayensis at the Zoo and telling me of their breeding at

RESTALL--THE ASIAN GREEN STARLING slight wing raising noticed at one point hackles more pronounced pupils dilating slightly tail cocked slightly, or slightly fanned still has bottom- heavy aspect to posture this is the pose struck by at zoo. Bill also raised higher Male A. panayensis strigata
algorithms.sectionHeader: ROBIN L. RESTALL--THE ASIAN GREEN STARLING 155
algorithms.bodyText: the Zoo some years earlier, I mentioned my confusion over the sexing. We then referred to the plate in Robinson and, sure enough, the caption made it quite clear that the thrush-like figure was indeed an immature. The young bird did not survive the winter, but to my delight Mr. Burton still had one bird left from his consignment which he sent to me. This bird lasted until the spring but was accidentally killed by a heavy frost. The remaining bird, the original adult which was undoubtedly a hen, went to the Zoo on my remove to Denmark, to pair up with the cock bird there. My experience with the species is thus limited to three birds over a period of ten months. None the less, I hope the following notes prove to be of interest to members. I would be grateful if anyone with further experience felt moved to contribute further to the subject. I have used the common name, Asian Green Starling, for Aplonis pan- 2 yensis, but it is possible--even likely--that any specimens being adver- ised would be described as Malay, Thailand, Java, Sumatra (or wherever .he consignment was shipped from, not necessarily the same as country of origin), and then either Green Starling, Glossy Starling or Tree-starling; Robinson calls A. p. stvigatus the Malay Tree-Starling. It is widely dis- puted in Asia, ranging from East India and the Assam through south- east Asia to the Far East, Celebes and the Philippines.
algorithms.sectionHeader: ROBIN L. RESTALL--THE ASIAN GREEN STARLING Description
algorithms.bodyText: The adult birds are alike to look at. From a close examination of dozens of adult skins of nearly all the races there appears to be no diag- nostic aids towards sexing the birds at all. Quite possibly males are bolder, and the male I studied at the Zoo was certainly much bolder in posture than my own female. Total length about 8 |in. Basically, the plumage is black, or blackish, with a green gloss in many places. The feathers of the neck are lanceolated, but not to the extent of that of the Asian mynahs. An outstanding feature is the bright vermilion eye. The amount of green colouring and the extent of the glossiness is much less than on the African Glossy Starlings. The bill and feet are black, the soles of the latter grey. fir ? e . n ^ loss on very clearly deep emerald
algorithms.figure: defined ear cove scales on foot dark horny brown nearly black hackles very short v outer 5 % toe yellowish tinge around -- bright scarlet rows of fine black \0x2666 pads under toes finely dotted
algorithms.figureCaption: and grey tiny feathers skin around eye is grey
algorithms.bodyText: The immature bird is greyer and not anywhere near as glossy above as the adult; on the face it is lighter, and below it is a dirty white with black streaks. There are many races of A. panayensis , all fairly similar to each other but, in general, the most isolated oceanic island forms (Samoa, etc.) are the dullest and the largest, as with other groups of birds. My illustra- tion and sketches show A. p. strigata , the most widely distributed race. Voice I never noted any of my three birds making a sound. The adult, even when on a favourite perch basking in the sun, was silent. That this was not necessarily a function of being single is evidenced by the lone male at the Zoo who perched in front of me on two occasions and obligingly burst into song. It was on these two occasions that I made sketches for the male in the colour plate. The song was a typical squeaky whistling affair
