Hence foot softer poorly defined scales browner striations ^ pads under foot much fawner than on adult dark browny grey, not black 7 to 8 rows of striations on each side of breast creamy off w'hite under tail coverts off white black quill very long only \ inch short of end of tail Immature
algorithms.construct: ROBIN L. RESTALL--THE ASIAN GREEN STARLING and nothing to write home about. In the literature, the note is described as " A loud clear metallic note frequently uttered on the wing " (Smythies) and " A sharp, metallic, single note " (Robinson).
algorithms.bodyText: It appears to be a social, noisy creature, highly gregarious and arboreal. Large numbers live in towns where, presumably, their noisy chattering until well after dark either causes annoyance or creates charming atmos- phere, according to the disposition of the listener. Robinson says of its flight " . . . swift and direct, though the bird often seems to have diffi- culty in steering itself ". The flight my birds were in was over 17 ft. long (plus 10 ft. of house) with a width of 11 ft., and yet they invariably appeared to be aeronautically inept. The flight posture appears to be an inefficient one, with the body slung low and the head slightly raised as if the bird is straining for another few inches of altitude. usually stand like this on shelves in shelter or tops of walls, window sills, etc., also on floor All three specimens had the habit of hopping or running (very quick!) indeed through thick undergrowth) and they would quickly hide in an) hole or cranny. They would also cling to the brick wall, in the corne and scrabble upwards. Most noticeable of all the slightly eccentric post ures of the species, however, is the standing stance shown in the plate an( the sketches. In my aviary it was totally inoffensive and docile, almost to the point 0 retiring timidity. It appeared to take no notice at all of other companions Mr. Burton told me that the specimens in his stock flights were quit'
algorithms.sectionHeader: ROBIN L. RESTALL--THE ASIAN GREEN STARLING
algorithms.bodyText: peaceful too. When it bred at the Zoo it was in a community flight, ad- mittedly a large one with medium to large companions, but apparently no trouble was experienced. Comments regarding posture, etc., are left to my sketches. Food No one should ever have any difficulty in feeding a starling, certainly not a widespread typical bird like A. panayensis. However, I will list my collected notes in the hope that they will be of interest. Smythies (i960) says it eats mainly fruit, and that at Tarat near Serian it is a major pest of pepper. Robinson lists food as various kinds of ber- ries, the ground at the foot of the roosting places being littered with re- jected seeds. " The fruit of various figs is an especial favourite, and a fruiting tree of this species is crowded with this bird, fruit pigeons and fairy bluebirds (Irena) " (Robinson, 1927). Mr. Burton kindly filled in my standard questionnaire on feeding, etc., which I attempt to get completed before any purchase. From this, I learned that the 24 birds in the consignment from Thailand (12 "hens ", i.e. immatures, and 12 " cocks ", i.e. adults) were imported on Soya bean flour and water melon. Mr. Burton weaned all 24 rapidly on to a diet of live maggots, 'Sluis' brand universal food, soaked puppy meal, raw minced meat and various fruit. They showed preference then for the live food and the 'Sluis.' I kept them with a mixed collection of birds, mostly softbills and supplied most fruits in season, various softbill mixtures, including'Sluis' Mynah food mixed with fresh meat finely minced, and soaked dried fruit (e.g. California Raisins). The latter they certainly took. Mealworms were supplied, and a handful was thrown around in the flight to stim- ulate food-seeking behavior. In the case of Aplonis it was months before they would drop to the ground to claim their share of the spoils, and even then they were usually late. Remembering how arboreal they are reported to be in the wild, I think the only reason they went to the ground in the aviary is because that is where the cover was densest. Nest and Eggs The nest is usually in a cavity or crevice of some kind. It is a rough cup of roots, grass and leaves (Smythies, 1940), and may be placed in a hole in a tree, the cranny junction between the leaf and trunk on a toddy palm, crevices in cliffs or under the eaves of roofs. It breeds socially (Robinson) and in colonies (Smythies, i960). These two adjectives may indicate vary- ing levels of nest density. The eggs are like small mynahs' eggs--glossy blue with a greenish cast, speckled with brown mainly at the fat end. Since breeding accounts are rare in avicultural literature, I hope I will be forgiven for quoting in full the only accounts that I am aware of.

l6o ROBIN L. RESTALL--THE ASIAN GREEN STARLING In the Aviculture Magazine, 1957, Mr. John Yealland wrote in his London Zoo Notes: " The Malayan Glossy Starlings sent by Dr. Searle several years ago have reared two young, one in each nest. This Starling was bred in 1931 by Mr. A. H. Isenberg in California (A.M., 1931, p. 23) but has not, so far as I know, ever before been bred in this country . . . The nests were built in a crevice of the rock-work." Mr. Yealland subsequently wrote (Personal communication, 1967) " In January, 1955, Dr. Searle sent us four from Singapore and we kept them in a large central aviary inside the Bird House. In 1957 two were bred in this aviary, one in 1958, one in 1959 an( ^ one m *9^7 * * * Mr. Yealland told me in conversation last year that the Starlings were later transferred to one of the outside aviaries where they all did well, but they never bred again. With the help of Mr. Prestwich I traced the reference to the magazine for 1931, but this turned out to be, in turn, only a ref- erence to Mr. Isenberg's report in Aviculture (1930) which I repeat below. " Early in May, my Malay Glossy Starlings {Aplonis panayensis strigatus) started carrying material into a log nest-box. I, unfortunately, avoided looking into the nest, hence did not see the eggs, but according to Robinson (The Birds of the Malay Peninsula) they are glossy blue with greenish cast mottled with brownish blotches, three to five in number. The young seemed to remain in the nest a very long time. They retain the striped plumage until they molt when they start turning the glossy colour of the adults. Due to a very late summer only one young survived. The other one began breathing heavily, almost gasping for breath with its bill wide open. This sickness, however, lasted several weeks before it proved fatal. I have noticed this trouble with a few other species but most of them get over it. The adults were fond of hardboiled egg yolk which they ate greed- ily and then flew to the nest. They also took mealworms and other bugs which they found on the lawn. They nested several times during the summer and although they hatched young each time only one survived. This bird has quite a pleasing song and also some power of mimicry; it is well worth keeping and is quite harmless in disposition although cap- able of protecting its nest from much stronger birds." Conclusions There are many races of the Asian Glossy Green Starling, but it is prob- able that the only one imported is Aplonis panayensis strigata. After an absence from the market of over 30 years (apart from a small trickle) the species is now making more frequent appearances on the market. It is smaller than the better known African Starlings or the Asian mynahs, and is less colourful that the former. However, its peaceful nature and unde- manding needs make it a suitable bird for mixed collections. The lack of detailed knowledge about its behaviour also make it an interesting species for the serious aviculturist to study. Breeding records are rare and it

algorithms.bodyText: seems likely that the social interactions of several being kept together would encourage breeding.

algorithms.table: * # # SHORT NOTES ON SOME OF MY BIRDS By Reinhard Hoppe (Berlin, Germany) For 15 years I have kept native and exotic birds, chiefly insectivorous
algorithms.bodyText: pecies. I am particularly fond of the European warblers such as the cterine Warbler, Hippolais icterina, Great Reed Warbler, Acrocephalus rundinaceus, Marsh Warbler, A. palustris , and Sedge Warbler, A. zhoenobaenus, as well as the Blackcap, Sylvia atricapilla, Garden Warbler, bonn , Rufous Warbler, Cercotrichesgalactotes, Whitethroat, S. communis , nd Lesser Whitethroat, S. currucea. But my special favourites are irikes and owls. Of the warblers I have kept an Orphean Warbler and *\o pairs of Sardinian Warblers, S. melanocephala, for five years. The Orphean Warbler S. hortensis, which, after the Barred Warbler S. nisoria , 1 the lar g est of the European Sylviidae, is a good singer whose soft )ng is midway between that of the Black-throated Thrush and the rarden Warbler. This bird moults in winter and is therefore very elicate during the first year in captivity and often does not undergo a )mplete moult. A bird which has only moulted slightly or not at all )0n becomes sickly and delicate as a result of the hormone control of ie endocrine system being upset. I have had good success in keeping these and other fruit-loving warblers, * for example the Garden Warbler, which also moults in winter and can iuse much anxiety, and with Blackcaps, Barred Warblers, Common and esser Whitethroat and Sardinian Warbler when I give them a special et. I mixed 50% curds with 30% fruit (apple, banana, pears, currants 1 figs) 10 / 0 glucose, 10% dried yeast to a mash of the consistency of e dough of a cake and all the ingredients are finely cut into small pieces.
algorithms.sectionHeader: REINHARD HOPPE--SHORT NOTES ON SOME OF MY BIRDS
algorithms.bodyText: In place of the 30% fruit I also give a mixture of 15% fruit and 15% spinach pulp (Baby food). To this mixture I add a few drops of the multi-vitamin preparation prescribed for humans. My birds have been fed entirely on this mixture for 18 months with only the addition of a few mealworms each day. They are tempera- mental birds which one would not expect to live for six years in captivity. The mixture can be prepared in bulk and can be kept for weeks in a refrigerator. With the exception of the Great Reed-warbler, Reed, Marsh and Sedge warblers are very delicate birds which at the time of the winter moult can cause much anxiety. The majority of these species seldom survive the first winter in good health and new plumage. They can only be brought through the winter successfully if you can provide a great deal of live food such as deep frozen fresh ant-eggs, wax-moths, crickets and maggots. In addition it is very important for them to have good light during the dull autumn and winter days otherwise the birds become listless and refuse to eat. It is a good thing to keep several species in a group in one small aviary. It is very helpful at the onset of the moult if a day temperature with a maximum of over 28* C at midday is main- tained; the minimum temperature at night can be 18 0 C. The daily high temperature induces the moult and this can easily be achieved by putting infra-red lamps near the cage. Also small quantities of the hormone Testerone will produce good results. The Great Reed Warbler is easy to keep if it is given the same food as I give my shrikes. My shrikes--Lesser Grey, Lanius minor , Woodchat, L. senator, Red-backed, L. collurio, Bay-backed L. vittatus and Rufous- Backed L. schach erythropnotus are fed exclusively on living mealworms. Once a week only they are given little strips of heart. In this diet it is of the greatest importance that the mealworms should be regularly moistened with a few drops of multiple vitamin preparation! If this important requirement is not carried out the birds suffer from severe vitamin B deficiency (polyneuritis, fits, epilepsy) or Vitamin A deficiency (Owl-face, abcesses on the bill and feet). If large numbers of mealworms are given without the addition of vitamins to shrikes, after six months in all prob- ability it will be observed, by the evident discomfort of the birds, that they have ailments of the feet; and they may fall from the perches. Othei birds certainly develop thickening of the toe joint and considerable swell- ing of the foot joints, as a result of being given too many mealworms. Ir others abscesses develop at the base of the beak, on the head and so ovei the eyes. These symptoms are all signs of severe vitamin A deficiency and can be cured by prompt treatment with a vitamin preparation. They never occur if regular vitamin treatment is given. The Reed Warbler which I kept on this diet has remained in perfec condition for six years, and the Shrikes for between three and four years For four years I have kept Scops Owls, Otus scops, which I got fron
algorithms.sectionHeader: REINHARD HOPPE--SHORT NOTES ON SOME OF MY BIRDS
algorithms.bodyText: Yugoslavia. In the last few years they have bred regularly so I now have six specimens; it is a delightful owl about the size of one's hand. The sex can only be determined by the display call; from the beginning of March to the end of May the male utters a melodious " Fhut-fhut " of the tone of an Okarina, but the female's call is a much louder harsh " koerk-koerk " with a loud trill. For the rearing of the young a great deal of insect food (cockroaches, mealworms) must be provided or other- wise the young birds eyes remain light grey for a long time and do not change to the golden-yellow of the adult birds for several years. In the wild their eyes become golden-yellow as soon as they are fledged. By chance I own a South American Owl, a species which had never before been brought alive to Europe. It is a species whose native name is Lechuza cola larga ", Ciccaba virgata, and is a very nice owl which appears to have been hand-reared as it was completely tame from the start. He has regular conversations with my wife in which he answers with a soft " muu " ora tittering " rikekekek ". From the Berlin collector Bregulla, who has travelled in the Philippines, I obtained a Shama, which had certainly never been brought alive to Europe before. It is a small whitish-brown Shama, Copsychus lucionensis , with a compaiatively short black and white tail, orange rump and reddish flanks. Two living specimens of this species were brought to Germany, an old male which Dr Raethal of Berlin has and a young male, which has a light grey sheen on the throat and which is in my collection. The bird is easy to keep and has an extremely melodious low full-throated, flute-like song of great purity without any disturbing harsh notes. Some stanzas are an ascending scale dueli-dueli-dueli " followed by soft melodious notes. The alarm call is a low panting " raaf-raaf-raaf ". Since 1964 several European importers in Holland and Germany have offered a Pygmy Falconet from the valleys of the Himalayas which pre- viously had only rarely been imported--the Red-thighed or Himalayan Falconet, or, according to the latest literature the Red-breasted Falconet Microherax caerulescens. It is a very small falcon of about 18 cm. in length of which 6--8 cm. consists of the tail. It has a black crown, white neck-band, black shoulder feathers and white spotted patterns on the expanded wings and tail. The anterior is white more or less mixed with rust-red and it has a rust-red spot on the throat and deep rust-red legs and belly. There were three young birds among my six specimens, which are distinguished from the adult birds by a rust-red frontal patch which in the adults is white. The bill is horn-coloured instead of black, and the legs and belly are only light red. These falcons are outstandingly >ocial; they carry out mutual preening, sleep close together in a sleeping hole in a balanced body position like young budgerigars after they have made a depression in the shavings in the sleeping-box by scraping and turning round. Their notes are very varied--a loud " gia-gia-gig-gig ", a hurried, angry " viss-viss ", a " hig-hig ", a grumbling " waed-waed-

G. R. PRYOR--BREEDING THE BLACKISH RAIL datdatdatdat-hik " with a trill at the end, or a loud warning call " gigigigig " which immediately drives them all into a panic in the sleeping-box. This falcon is a plucky fighter which on being taken hold of pecks hard and strikes with its claws, or when greatly disturbed lies on its back and from this position attacks the aggressor with beak and claws. If you take hold of these falcons they immediately peck hard, but if you take one out of the sleeping box it lies quite quietly in the hand, eventually calls, but only starts pecking when it recognises the hand in the light. This behaviour evidently emanates from the social behaviour as they never peck each other. A species seldom kept in captivity is the large nectar-feeding bird the Indian Streaked Spider-hunter Arachnothera m. magna. I obtained this bird by chance from an importation by a German firm from the Himalayas. This bird is a restless soul and is always on the move. It frequently utters its loud call 4 4 kieuk-kieuk " and in addition has a soft, scarcely audible song that always begins with a " wij-witte-wij " and then changes to a rapidly uttered " wijwittewittewijwij ". Also there is a less frequent throaty, very soft, noise heard when the bird is disturbed. I have had it for two years and it is in perfect condition. Its food consists exclu- sively of a fluid mixture consisting of 40% powdered milk, 30% soya flour, 10% dried yeast, 10% powdered egg and 10% peptone from meat. I mix a heaped teaspoonful of this with 50 ccs. water and add a teaspoonful of honey, and once a week several drops of multivitamin. Peptone from meat is a yellow, bitter powder and consists of tryptic decomposed meat and therefore consists of simple protein cells. I purchase it from the chemical firm Merck/Darmstatt.

(Rallus nigricans) By G. R. Pryor (Calver, Derbyshire, England) A pair of " Venezuelan Rails " were advertised in Cage Birds in June 1967. They arrived on the 13th and corresponded exactly to De Schauensee's description in Birds of Columbia of the Blackish Rail, Rallus nigricans. His description was:-- size 9--11 ins. Head and under- parts ashy-grey with the exception of a white throat. Upper parts olive, tail black. Bill yellowish-green, legs red. They were placed in a heavily planted tropical house 44 ft. x 15 ft. containing a mixed collection averaging 24 species and 36 specimens. This house is kept at a minimum of 6o* F by gas-heated hot air blowr through a waterfall to maintain humidity. A shallow stream runs frorr the small pond at the foot of the waterfall the full length of the house

The only other ground birds in the main flight are a White-Winged Trumpeter (P sophia leucoptera), a White-Breasted Waterhen (. Amaurornis phoenicurus ), several Southern White-Breasted Crakes ( Later alius leuco- pyrrhus). The last two of the Crakes were killed by the Trumpeter in March of this year. Extensions at each end of the house are wired off as separate aviaries for Humming Birds, Aracaris, Toucanets etc., Since they were received, the Rails have remained nervous and shy although if one remained seated and still they resumed normal habits and could be observed. They made no attempt to nest in 1967 or 1968. In June 1969 they built a shallow cup-shaped nest on the ground, well covered overhead by ivy. The nest was made of ivy leaves, pieces of iris leaves and so on. The first egg was laid on 28th May and a second on 30th May. No more were laid. The hen began to sit hard on 3rd June although some incubation may have started before this. Two chicks hatched between 8 a.m. and 12 noon on 20th June. They left the nest before 8 a.m. on 21st June but return quite early each evening about 5 p.m. and were then brooded by (presumably) the hen. On two occasions between hatching and first leaving the nest they were being brooded by both cock and hen on the nest together. The foods normally available in the house include wheat, millet, coarse soft-bill mixture, various fruits, meat, maggots and, of course, nectar substitute and fruit flies for the nectar feeders. The Rail chicks are fed by their parents with maggots which are put in the stream so that the other birds will not get them. As soon as the eggs hatched the Trumpeter was removed to an outside aviary as he was considered to be a bad risk.
algorithms.table: * * * THE BREEDING OF SCARLET IBIS (Eudocimus ruber )
algorithms.bodyText: By D. H. S. Risdon (Tropical Bird Gardens, Rode, Somerset, England) Me purchased the first two of these birds in 1965 and received four nore in 1967. The first two were already in full colour. The later four vere in intermediate brown plumage interspersed with pink feathers. From the start all six birds have been kept in a large planted outdoor viary of irregular shape but the floor space must be somewhere in the egion of 2,000 sq. ft. The bushes are mainly elm suckers from an old ree which was cut down many years ago and the ground is grassed. There

D. H. S. RISDON--BREEDING OF SCARLET IBIS is a circular concrete pool some four feet across. Two wooden shelter sheds are available in this aviary but the birds never roost in them even in frost and snow, preferring the most exposed and highest perches at night--rather like pheasants. Scarlet Ibis are hardy, at any rate in north Somerset, where, although the climate is perhaps milder than further north, we get our quota of snow and hard frosts. Elsewhere in Zoos generally they seem to be treated as hothouse birds and I cannot understand why. At first they shared this aviary with various jays and pies and our breeding colony of Sacred Ibis, but last year when they began to show signs of nest building, the former were removed for obvious reasons! Last year (1968) the Sacred Ibis nested for the first time and reared two nice young ones and this triggered off nesting activities among the Scarlets which squatted in the tops of the bushes and carried a few twigs about, but went no further. This year (1969) the Sacreds went to nest early and reared two more young and then promptly laid again in the same nest and now (July) have yet another two half grown. In April the beaks of the Scarlets turned from brown to black and they developed small ' wattles ' like those of a chicken at the base of the lower mandible. In May two birds started carrying twigs into the tops of one of the bushes so we made shallow baskets of \ in. mesh wire netting and fastened these in similar situations. A very sketchy nest was made in one of these and on the 14th May the first of two eggs were laid--rather elongated in shape and coloured green with brown spots at the larger end. One of my reference books states that both sexes incubate. This I can neither confirm nor deny as the birds are difficult to distinguish. In fact I am not sure which of the six birds are the breeding pair. Due to the breeding we let the aviary become rather overgrown and left the birds as much as possible to themselves with the result that events were not all that easy to watch without disturbing them. The nestling-down is black. The legs are pink and the beak is pink with a black tip. The beak of the chick is short to start with but it lengthens as the bird grows, and turns black. The legs also darken with age and at the same time the nestling-down is replaced with feathers. Two chicks hatched on or about the 5th June and left the actual nest on the 15th July. However, their flight feathers were not fully developed and they stayed in the surrounding branches for a further 14 days before beginning to move about the aviary. This early leaving of the nest may have been due to the fact that the parents or another pair laid again in the old nest and may have pushed them out prematurely on to the surrounding bushes.
D. H. S. RISDON--BREEDING OF SCARLET IBIS

The nest feathering at this stage is charcoal grey above including the lead, neck and beak, and dirty white below. The legs and feet have urned black. They evidently have an intermediate phase between this nd maturity as the birds we imported were brown and pink as already [escribed. The rearing was uneventful. Food supplied consisted entirely of fish nd cut-up, day-old chicks and the young are fed by regurgitation--the oung thrusting their bills down the parents' gullets. In addition the *irds obviously find insect life and worms in the soft ground of their viary judging by the multitude of small holes made by their probing \0x25A0eaks. Whilst writing this (July) two more eggs are being incubated and a econd pair have laid. So it would seem that both Sacred and Scarlet bis can be double brooded. ^ Now I would like to write a bit about the colouring of these birds, he first two we had were in red importation plumage but moulted out ink as was expected. The next lot of four were brown and moulted ut pink. At the same time the older pair (second moult with us) became onsiderably deeper in colour and since then, with every subsequent moult, ley have all become brighter until last year and this year the two oldest irds have been a deep orange-red, almost as brilliant as freshly imported Decimens. The only addition to their diet has been grass meal scattered on the sh and meat. This was on the advice of Reginald Greed, the Director f Bristol Zoo, who has a fine brightly-coloured colony of these birds id swears by grass meal. It seems strange that a fish and meat eating ird like the Ibis should benefit from a vegetable ingredient but there is 0 doubt about the brilliance of the Bristol Zoo birds which are kept nder more artificial conditions than ours. It is difficult to be absolutely certain about the effects of grass meal as ir birds were becoming progressively brighter before we started using it. loreover, some of ours are much brighter than others. One thing is rtam, whether it is the grass meal or not, our birds are the natural cranium red and not rose red which seems to be the effect of other >louring agents. As described by D. H. S. Risdon, the Scarlet Ibis (Eudocimus ruber) has en bred at the Tropical Bird Gardens, Rode. It is believed this may - a first success. Any member or reader knowing of a previous breeding of this species in reat Britain or Northern Ireland is requested to communicate at once th the Hon. Secretary.
168 C. J. O. HARRISON--PARTIAL SUCCESS WITH BREEDING THE ROBIN
algorithms.sectionHeader: PARTIAL SUCCESS WITH BREEDING THE ROBIN
algorithms.bodyText: (Erithacus rubecula) By C. J. O. Harrison (Perivale, Middlesex, England) The Robin, Erithacus rubecula , in spite of its tameness under natun conditions in the British Isles, has always been regarded as a difficult bir to breed under aviary conditions. The birds are very aggressive towarc one another. In winter the hen holds her own separate territory singing and warning off other birds of either sex. Pairing tends to be cautious affair; and the experience of most aviculturists who have trie to breed the species has been that one bird would invariably turn on th other and kill it, although from the information which we now have would seem that among insectivorous birds such behaviour is by no mear confined to Robins. Although I am not able to record a complete succes in breeding this species I feel that the information gained might be ( help to those who may try it in the future, and I have therefore kept sorr notes of what occurred. There are two claims for breeding this species in Britain. The firs in 1869 (Smith) is very brief, with no details, merely claiming--" Unt this year I have never been able to keep a pair of Robins in my aviary ; one always killed the other. Now, however, I have not only succeeded i doing so but they have actually made a nesit and succeeded in rearing brood of three young ones ". The second is that of David Lack (Lac 1943) who during his study of this species bred these birds, two pai being placed in each of two aviaries, one 30 ft. x 12 ft. x 6 ft. the otb 30 ft. x 20 ft. x 6 ft., both aviaries extensively planted and containir shelters with brushwood in them. In each aviary a dominant pair succes fully reared five young, mostly on mealworms. The birds were release as soon as the young could fend for themselves. In reply to my enqui Professor Lack informed me that the birds were obtained for him Spring after they had paired, and he would therefore have avoided t difficulty of reconciling the members of the pair to each other. During the summer of 1968 I took over from two aviculturist acquaii tances three young Robins which had been hand-reared after nests hi come to grief in the wild. One, a female I believe, had been hand-rear< in isolation from any other Robin and although it appeared to recogni other Robins for what they were it also regarded humans in the same lig and if allowed the freedom of an enclosure for an hour or so would take over as a territory and vigorously attack anyone who entered it. appeared to regard the person who fed it as a super-robin " unjusl monopolizing a large food supply. Although it provided interesti opportunities for study it was obviously unlikely to settle to breed wi its own kind. The other two were from the same nest and were rath

C. J. O. HARRISON--PARTIAL SUCCESS WITH BREEDING THE ROBIN 169 iorc timid. Frank ]\leaden, when he saw them in partial juvenile lumage, correctly sexed them as a pair. W hen they passed into my care during August they were in juvenile lumage but partially moulted, with some red feathering. I put them imporarily into a cage, 4 ft. x 1 ft. 6 in. x 1 ft. and then, later in the loult, transferred them to a compartment in a greenhouse about 3 ft. 6 in. (3 ft. 6 in. x about 8 ft. in height. Its longest horizontal dimension was lerefore a little less than that of the cage, but although the two birds had greed together in the confined space of the cage they began to disagree ithin about half-an-hour of having been transferred to the compartment, his agreement in close cage confinement followed by fighting when a ttle more space is allowed seems to occur frequently in insectivorous irds, and the apparent concord between a pair in a cage seems to fool lany aviculturists who are surprised when the birds are turned out into a ood-sized aviary and one immediately turns on the other and frequently ills it. In this case the hen had a slightly short upper mandible which made it lore difficult for her to seize and manipulate insects. She also had a aler red breast. She was suffering from constant supplanting attacks y the male which, while not directly harming her, were preventing her om feeding or resting properly. I therefore transferred her to another 3mpartment 6 ft. x 3 ft. containing two young hand-reared Skylarks luudci arvensis. She remained there for seven or eight weeks, agreeing lirly well with the larks but attempting to snatch mealworms from under leir very bills, only stopping short when they threatened her by crouching ith bill open and head extended a little in forward threat. One day awever I came in to find her perching on something and found that she id rolled a lark over and was standing on it, digging her bill into its reast feathers. I shooed her off and a rather dazed lark sat up. Since xommodation was limited I had to put the female Robin back into a ige a few feet from, and facing, the compartment in which the male obin was now living with a pair of Painted Quails, Excalfactoria 'inensis. d he latter were better able to cope with a Robin than were the kylarks. The Robins were fed on "Avivite " softfood, maggots, grated cheese, id one or two mealworms daily. Once or twice a week a drop of multi- tamin was given on a mealworm, d he birds also ate sprouted seed at e " mustard and cress " stage with the first pair or two of young leaves 'Owing, and small pieces of cuttlefish broken up for them. I also threw grassroots and weeds with earth adhering when I pulled them up while rdening. In the autumn song began. The male soon started to whistle subdued irases of increasing complexity, but the female and the other aggressive male only achieved a few harsh squeaky notes at times. If any of the ^bins slipped out of its compartment it would fly to one of the others

170 C. J. O. HARRISON--PARTIAL SUCCESS WITH BREEDING THE ROBIN and squabble through the wires. The nearest outside Robin territories are about a quarter of a mile in each direction, but an overgrown bad garden, 22 ft. x 100 ft., among the rows of neatly cultivated garden provides a miniature woodland habitat which supports a single Robii each winter but never retains a bird during the spring, and would appea to lack some factor that would make it suitable for nesting. In th winter of 1968-69 this territory was held by the usual Robin whicl immediately began to visit the greenhouse in which the other Robin were kept and spent a long time in mutual posturing through the glas with the aggressive female. These bouts produced very little song an* were marked by periods of excited " ticking " calls from the birds. A in other years the intruder disappeared in spring, and this bird and th aggressive female were the only other Robins that the pair saw or hearc The male would begin to sing as soon as I entered the greenhouse, an for as long as I stayed there. The song was vigorous but seemed nc quite as loud as that of wild Robins, possibly because he never needed t communicate to a trespasser at a distance. He would also sing when h saw activity outside the greenhouse. The building is within a few fee of the house and the light from the windows often shines into it at nigh' The Robin would sing vigorously while there was any kind of light an activity in the house, well into the night; and if a light was put on at an time of night it would be acknowledged by a sudden ripple of Robin son out of the darkness. He appeared to prolong his evening activities by th scanty light which shone in from the windows of the house, and on would see him moving and feeding in semi-darkness. During the winter the greenhouse was heated by an electric bar heatc via a thermostat set for 54 0 F.; but with the heat loss through the glass 0 cold mornings the temperature might drop to the upper 30's producin ice on the water in some compartments. The volume of song suggeste very strongly that the male Robin, at this period, sang more frequently ; lower temperatures. During colder weather song was prolonged but i warmer spells it was less in evidence. One fine bout of song marked failure of the heater, and dropped off rapidly when the greenhouse warme up again. In February 1969 the female was tearing the paper on the bottom < her cage and dropping it in the drinking bowl, and I suspected that th represented the commencement of investigation of nesting material. /\0x25A0 the beginning of March I transferred the birds to a compartmei 6 ft. x 3 ft. x 4 ft. on a base raised to table-top level, divided into two by wire-netting division in the middle. I used twigs of variable thicknes saved from shrub pruning, for perches in the compartments, and some j these passed through the central division. I put one of the two siblir Robins on each side. After about a fortnight I observed that the bir< would occasionally perch on the same twig on their respective sides of tl partition, only a few inches apart, with little reaction save for a slig

C. J. O. HARRISON--PARTIAL SUCCESS WITH BREEDING THE ROBIN 171 raising of the bill by the male. The hen was by now definitely carrying about small pieces of grass and in a burst of fine weather the tem- perature in the greenhouse in spite of a double roof and open windows was rising into the 70's and 8o's. I decided that it was time for action and on the evening of Friday, 22nd March, I bent down a corner of the partition and allowed the birds to meet, relying on the week-end to allow aie the chance of noticing if violence occurred. In spite of my fears it did not occur. The birds invaded each compart- ment in turn. When the male found itself near the female it displayed 3y raising its bill to show the breast not in the sleeked threat posture preceding attack, but in what appears to be a more ambivalent posture vith rather fluffed head feathers, and the central throat feathers raised to ippear as a dark ruffled patch. It sang very subdued squeaky phrases. The female's reaction was to gape towards the male when he approached 00 close, but gradually over a period of days this changed to food-begging behaviour. I continued to put food and water in both compartments, seeping the middle division in place with a gap at one corner allowing he birds to pass. For the first few days the two birds returned to their own lsual corners to roost. Otherwise nothing untowards happened. The inapping out of territories by Lack in his study of the Robin revealed that he female, after holding her own territory during the winter, often amalgamated it with that of an adjacent male in the springs and I hoped hat I had duplicated this situation in miniature The hen was eager to build and on 24th March I offered a nest-site. The first was a large flowerpot laid on its side in a corner; this she inspected )Ut did not use. I then wedged a flowerpot up behind a diagonal support t the back of the compartment, and she carried material to this but could tot fix it in place. I substituted a narrow cardboard box c. 4 in. x 8 in. x 8 in. agh. The female again found it hard to start a nest so I wedged in the im of an old blackbirds' nest. The nest started with a few dead leaves, tien the female changed to dried grass and within two days had wedged ito the box a miniature haystack with a round cup in a cavity towards ie back of it. The female was now actively begging for food from the male, crouching lightly with bill open and wings fluttering a little and uttering a squeaky all. The male would hesitate beside her with a mealworm in his bill, ppear to be about to feed her, then swallow it himself; and once he latched a mealworm from her bill and ate it. Several days after this the female was in the box long enough for me to egin to worry that something might have happened to her. On Sunday, tn April, I hastily inspected the box with a small mirror and found there ere about four eggs. On the morning of 7th April she started to leubate. It was not until the ninth day of incubation that I was able to >tablish that the male was feeding her, when I saw him carry mealworms ito the nestbox for her and later feed her when she left the nest.

IJ 2 C. J. O. HARRISON--PARTIAL SUCCESS WITH BREEDING THE ROBIN The box had been wedged into position and the constant movement; of the birds caused it to tilt. One evening the tilt was enough for me t( decide I must remedy it in the morning when the birds could more safely be disturbed, but needless to say an alarm in the night brought me out of; bath to discover the nest tipped up, mercifully with entrance uppermost and the two birds dashing about. I hurriedly wired the nest back in place withdrew a little, and within two minutes the hen was back on the eggs I have copied the lighting system used by Frank Meaden and can put ou the main lights in the greenhouse and leave two dark red bulbs alight The latter give enough light for a bird to find a perch or, if necessary feed by; but are dim enough to persuade most birds to roost. I cai switch these lights off from the house and can therefore use them fo settling birds down before switching off the lights completely. By the 12th day I started checking for possible hatching by putting m hand into the nest when the hen was off. The female did not react bu the male would dash past, striking my hand momentarily in passing, an< perching with plumage aggressively streaked. By the evening of th 14th day nothing had happened but on the 15th (20th April) in the mornin I thought I could feel a young one in the nest. I had a mealworm cultur in a wooden box and I put this right into the compartment, stirring aroun handfuls of the contents, in which were small mealworms in variou stages and some meal moths. That afternoon I gratefully received fror Alan Hayes, a fellow aviculturist, the welcome gift of a good culture c the Greater Waxmoth in an insect cage. I offered these to the birds ths evening and they avidly snatched up the moths. Next morning noticed an eggshell and could now hear the young birds. For the ne> few days I regularly stirred up the mealworm and moth cultures and fe the normal food and hoped for the best. On the fourth day after hatching a young one, about two days old, w; found dead near the nest. Subsequent examination revealed an incoir pletely absorbed yolk sac. On the fifth day additional maggots wei offered. These were treated with Paladec multivitamin and heavil powdered with scraped cuttlefish to provide some of the minerals an vitamins needed by birds getting mainly maggots and mealworms. 0 the sixth day I removed from the nest two infertile eggs, and confirme that there were two young in the nest, making a clutch of five. T 1 adults no longer showed much anxiety when the nest was examinei On the evening of 27th April, the seventh day after hatching, the adul were feeding and brooding the young normally. The next morning found the two young dead and cold, with signs of violence, on the con partment floor. I have commented on the possible causes of th elsewhere (Harrison 1969). By the evening of that day the nest was disarranged and the ma displaying a little, and on the 29th a new nest-cup had been made in tl box. On 2nd May the first egg of the second clutch was laid. The hi

was on the nest, presumably laying about 8 a.m. each morning. She 3egan to sit with the laying of a fifth egg on the morning of 7th May, but he clutch was subsequently found to consist of six eggs. The female was jsually off the eggs for a while at mid-morning and late afternoon. 3 n 12th May one egg had somehow been knocked out of the nest. When [ investigated it was the hen that flew and struck my hand. On 14th May, vith the eggs half-incubated, I returned home on a hot and thundery ifternoon to find the female dead on the floor of the compartment, with 10 signs of violence or indication of the cause of death. The single iggressive female Robin was being cared for by a friend and I passed the nale over to him to see if they would go to nest, but by the time they lad been successfully introduced to each other they had began their ummer moult and were disinclined to nest.

algorithms.figure: I * # * j FIRST BREEDING OF THE SOUTH INDIAN (LESSER) HILL MYNAH (Gracula religiosa indie a ) By Brian Bertram (Sub-Department of Animal Behaviour, Madingley, Cambridge)
algorithms.bodyText: In 1968 a pair of South Indian (Lesser) Hill Mynahs successfully iared two broods at this Sub-Department, apparently the first time that fis race has been bred in captivity. The nomenclature of races of [ill Mynahs will be discussed in another article. In the Avicultural Iagazine in 1957 E. J. Boosey reported the breeding of a Northern greater) Hill Mynah, Gracula religiosa intermedia , at Keston. In view f the great differences in appearance, behaviour, and calls between these ices, I feel that an account of the breeding of the Lesser Hill Mynah 7 . r. indica) would be of interest. To supplement my field observations in India on the social and vocal ehaviour of Hill Mynahs, a number of wild-caught adult indica were nported in February 1967) selected from among the unfortunate birds 1 the Calcutta bird market. The birds were released into an outdoor ;iar y> 3* ft. x 10 ft. x 10 ft., screened with polythene and warmed inside ntil the summer. Thereafter, the only heat available has been from

two small heater lamps suspended above the perches inside the shelter, The shelter consists of an enclosed 3 ft. portion of the end of the aviary The birds have access to this through a single small high entrance hole; they always retreat thus when humans enter their aviary at the other end and remain there invisible and undisturbed by the observer's actione (e.g. inspection of nests) in the aviary until he leaves, whereupon the} emerge at once. The shelter is accessible to humans from the back, anc standing inside the dark shelter an observer can see and note the birds behaviour through a darkened perspex screen, while being totally invisibh to and undetected by the birds in the flight outside. This seems to b< an excellent arrangement for observing and breeding timid birds. Rougl nesting boxes are provided in the flight, and some of the birds roost ir these. Water is always available in quantities sufficient for bathing The basic diet supplied daily is Sluis' Mynah food, supplemented with ; mixture of chopped-up apples, pears, carrots, hard-boiled eggs, meat am maggots. In the winter of 1967-68 there was a considerable amount of disturbano through the construction of a large building beside the aviary. Whei this was over, the aviary was prepared for breeding, more of the polythen screening on the roof was removed, the birds were disturbed less, grass am twigs were supplied, and new nest boxes with small entrance hole surrounded with bark were put into the flight. The five birds in thi aviary, all colour-ringed, were observed to consist of two pairs and ai unpaired bird, with no signs of hostility towards one another. First clutch At the end of April 1968, two eggs, pale blue with small speckles c pale brown were found in a hollow of twigs and grass in one of the nes: boxes. The two birds of the breeding pair were easily distinguishabl from one another by ring colour and wattle length; in this case the mal had wattles considerably longer than the female's, but this is not a genen distinguishing feature between the sexes. The breeding pair wei chasing the other pair considerably and driving them down to the lowe perches, but ignored the single bird. Hill Mynahs are nervous nester: and this pair left the nest at the slightest disturbance, so little observatio was consideied possible. Two young hatched, but died at five days ole dissection showed them to have in their gizzards a tangle of coarse grai and raw carrot, probably causing a fatal blockage. The lesson was learn Subsequent nesting attempts were observed much more closely, and moi effort taken to ensure their success. Second clutch Ten days later, the pair laid again, having added more grass to t! nest since the last brood. Both sexes gathered and took in nest materk approximately equally. The birds incubated sporadically and amazing

ittle, emerging from the nest usually after spells of only five to 15 minutes, >r sooner if disturbed at all. Both sexes incubated, approximately equally, although the female sat for somewhat more and longer spells. The two birds of the pair were never both in the nest at the same time, :xcept at night. The eggs hatched at 14 days, the young being naked vith whitish hairy feather strands, a yellow edge to the gape, and with yes closed. To avoid the earlier misfortune, all the grass supplied as lesting material was removed from the flight, to prevent the adults eeding their young on this inappropriate food, and carrot was dropped rom the menu. A large amount of live insect food was also provided, tarticularly chopped-up cockroaches, mealworms, maggots, and moths, loth adults fed the young, one of which disappeared at three days old; he male visited the nest less often than the female during the first eight lays after hatching, but more often than the female thereafter. On such isits, a portion of food is held in the beak, and more is regurgitated when he parent bird is inside the nest. At nine days old, the chick was first teard calling loudly while being fed; at this stage it was large with pin- eathers appearing on its back. At 14 days, black feathers were beginning 0 emerge from the tips of the long pinfeathers. The head was somewhat ;reenish and still bald, with smooth bare yellow patches showing where he wattles would later grow. The parent birds were feeding it almost ntirely on insect food, causing considerable difficulties since they kept hanging their tastes. Finely chopped cockroach was favoured at first, hen rejected, and maggots freely taken; some days later they tired of hese and insisted on moths, and later house-fly pupae. Young locusts hey consistently scorned; mealworms and crickets they always took. )bservation of them taking food to their nest was invaluable in detecting vfien they were beginning to tire of a particular food type. If unable to ind the preferred food, they did not take a less favoured food to the nest, he parents were now chasing the other birds in their aviary so ferociously hat these had to be removed, whereupon the breeding pair became much ~ss active. On the 27th day after hatching, the young bird left the nest, to which it .ever returned. Compared with the adults it was somewhat smaller, vith pale yellow wattle patches rather than with pendant mustard yellow aps, and with plumage sooty rather than glossy black. It flew strongly rom the first. Within two days it was eating from the food trough, lthough the adults occasionally also fed it thereafter. liird clutch On the day after the young bird left the nest, the first egg of a new lutch of three was laid. Incubation as before took 14 days, with both dult birds sitting usually alternately. Three young hatched, and one ad disappeared after four days. The parents fed the remaining young s before. The young bird already fledged was fully self-supporting by
algorithms.page: 176 H. FRAUCA--OBSERVATIONS ON THE LAUGHING JACKASS OR KOOKABURRA
algorithms.bodyText: this time, but seeing its parents carrying food in their beaks it started food-begging again much more than before, and thus successfully inter- cepted a quantity of food intended for the next brood in the nest. Despiti this competition, the two young birds of this later brood also fledgec successfully in the middle of August 1968. The female parent diec inexplicably a fortnight afterwards; the two later-fledged young lived fo: three and eight months, being then killed by an accident and by an aduli Hill Mynah respectively. The first fledged young bird still thrives, and at the time of writing (June 1969) is fully adult in voice and appearance, and seems to be abou to breed with its father.
algorithms.table: # # * SOME OBSERVATIONS ON THE LAUGHING JACKASS OR KOOKABURRA (Dacelo novaeguineae). By Harry Frauca (Queensland, Australia) Australia's famous Laughing Jackass, or kookaburra, is the world':
algorithms.bodyText: largest kingfisher. Its diet consists of small snakes, lizards, insects crabs, mice, small rats and baby birds. This bird, known by the scientific names of Dacelo novaeguineae stands about 15-16 in. and has a 5 in. long tail. Its enormous bill is : formidable cutting implement, and the muscles that power the mandible: are as formidable, for the kookaburra can dig a nest in the almost-concret< hard texture of a termite mound on a tree. There are, in actual fact, two kookaburras in Australia; the blue winged, or Leach's kookaburra (Dacelo leachii ), which ranges throughou parts of Queensland, Northern Territory, north-west Australia an( New Guinea and which doesn't laugh, and the laughing jackass, referrec to above, which ranges throughout eastern and southern Australia. Th< latter species was introduced into Western Australia in 1898, and int< Tasmania in 1905, and appears to be thriving in both States, beinj particularly common in certain parts of Tasmania where it is not evei protected because of the damage it causes to bird life, attacking or robbing the baby birds from nests. The kookaburra is sedentary and lives either in pairs or in small groups In the Queensland districts the species is found in all types of environ ments: dry eucalyptus forests, margins of mangroves, seaside casuarin; bush, margins of rainforest, tea-tree swamplands both at sea level am

H. FRAUCA OBSERVATIONS ON THE LAUGHING JACKASS OR KOOKABURRA 177 high up in the ranges. It is found in almost all the suburbs of Queensland country towns where it may breed in tree holes in suburban gardens as a pair has done these past three years in a garden in my street. They breed in the hollow limb of a gum tree. The breeding season lies between early summer, November and January, but I have known kookaburras that have bred before and after that. All kingfishers nest in holes, and the kookaburra is no exception. It will select the hollow limb of a tree or a tree hole, or will excavate a nesting burrow r in termite mounds or trees, which are extremely common in these parts of Queensland. Some of these mounds are so hard that I have required a hammer to break through the clayey material, but the kookaburra's bill and mandibles are sufficiently strong for the job. After selecting a termite-mound, the kookaburra lands on it and clinging to it with its claws, proceeds to peck away at the clay with its powerful bill. Apparently, both hen and cock birds take part in burrow-digging and the resulting burrow is about 14--16 in. deep with the entrance about 4--6 in. across. In some cases the same pair of kookaburras may re-use last year's burrow^ so that I know of some termite mounds that have had as many as four kookaburra nesting burrows apiece. In this case the mound becomes so badly riddled with holes that the birds have to look for a new one come the next breeding season. In some areas, however, kookaburras breed in hollow limbs or tree holes and some birds have been known to excavate burrows on river banks, but I have not yet seen one in my districts. The hen lays between two and four eggs, each of which is white and aiore or less round. While one bird incubates, the other hangs around fie breeding area and will call loudly if a trespasser is seen. Should the respasser be a human and should he get near the breeding tree, the ncubating bird will usually poke its head out of the burrow and suddenly ake off into the timber. Incubation lasts between 27-29 days, and the 'oung at hatching are naked and blind and look nothing like the adult. The eyes open when about 10--12 days old, and it takes the young about 1 month to leave the nest. Thereafter they stay with the parent birds or about two months more. On many occasions when spotlighting in the bush at night during late ummer I have caught four or five kookaburras perching completely still nd close to each other on a tree branch, probably a young brood and he parents passing the night away under the bush sky. Kookaburras pounce regularly on lizards of various sizes, small snakes, isects, baby birds and field mice and rats. One nest investigated in ^ew South Wales, for instance, was found to contain the remains of 16 ats, and an observer in New South Wales recorded seeing a pair of ookaburras bringing to their nest 19 baby wood-swallows in about two ours. Kookaburras will often tackle large snakes, about 4 ft. long or so, ut they are not always successful in killing these serpents. Australian

178 H. FRAUCA--OBSERVATIONS ON THE LAUGHING JACKASS OR KOOKABURRA naturalist A. H. Chisholm, for instance, reported: " I have records of two cases in which enterprising kookaburras were in a bad way . . . while they were choking the snake, the snakes were choking them. " The killing behaviour of this bird is like this: it will pounce on, say, a lizard, of any size, and seizing it in its bill by the neck, it will kill it by bashing it against the ground or, taking it up a tree limb, it will bash it against a tree limb. Apparently, kookaburras are stimulated to attack and to kill long things at once. We had one in our aviary that would pounce on string beans and spagetti; seizing each in its bill, it would bash it against the ground until it was " dead ", whereupon, the bird would swallow it. Kookaburras are very conscious of hawks and eagles and when one of these predators flies overhead, the laughing jackasses will almost always assume a cryptic attitude, remaining completely still and, often, pointing the bill skywards to cut down their true configuration. Recently, while taking pictures of a young kookaburra near the local aerodrome, I noticed with amusement, that every time an aircraft passed low overhead, the bird would immediately assume a cryptic attitude. Apparently, the shadow of the aircraft suggested a predatory bird to my kookaburra. Its laughter is, of course, a part of the various calls and sounds it has evolved. It is in fact its language. But during a certain time of the year usually between breeding seasons, groups of these birds tend to gather on tree limbs, house roofs, television aerials, basketball posts and whatevei heights are available, and break into concerts during which their mac laughter reaches an almost deafening intensity. It is then when one car understand Sturt's reference to " a chorus of wild spirits. To man the kookaburra is a completely harmless bird, but I sav, something once that is worth relating. My friend Paul Farmer is one 0. the most expert tree-climbers I have known, and because of this ability I asked him to climb to a kookaburra nest in the hollow limb of a loft) gum and inspect it for me. Paul climbed up there and was peering int( the hollow limb when suddenly one of the parent birds flew from 1 nearby tree and swooping down, struck a blow with its bill on Paul! head. Paul howled with pain as blood streamed down from a cut 01 his scalp. But the kookaburra was feeling no better. After hitting nr friend, it literally collapsed to the ground, stunned by the impact 0 the crash. I was going to pounce on it when it came round again, an( staggered away into a patch of grass from where it eventually took of in a clumsy flight. I don't think that kookaburras usually attack man. think that in our case, the bird wanted to frighten Paul, but it miscalculate! its dive and accidentally, hit the human with the bill. If kookaburra were in the habit of crashing against intruders, many birds, I think would be seriously hurt in the process.
algorithms.reference: D. G. HANOVER--FIRST BREEDING OF BUCKLEY'S GROUND DOVE
algorithms.sectionHeader: FIRST IMPORTATION INTO THE U.S.A., AND FIRST BREEDING OF BUCKLEY'S GROUND DOVE
algorithms.bodyText: (Columbina buckleyi) By Donald G. Hanover (Tarzana, California, U.S.A.) It is always a great satisfaction when a fancier of foreign doves can add a brand new species to his collection. This satisfaction was mine when I was able to import a number of Buckley's Ground Doves Columbina buckleyi into this country; so far as I am able to ascertain a first importation. Since that time, it has been my good fortune to see these lively little doves breed successfully in my aviaries and to raise a number of youngsters, which have left their nests and are now independent. In view of the foregoing, I am pleased and proud to be able to submit the following report on the first breeding of Buckley's Ground Dove in the United States. Description I think I can best quote that given by Derek Goodwin in his Pigeons 2nd Doves of the World :-- Approximately the same size as the Ruddy Ground Dove, and of similar proportions. Forehead and face pale greyish-pink shading to slightly deeper mauve-pink, suffused with grey, on breast and underparts. Crown and nape bluish-grey. Upperparts pale brownish-grey, wing-coverts pinkish-grey spotted and barred with black. Primaries and outer secondaries mainly black. Central tail feathers greyish; remainder black with some grey at base, outermost ones tipped white. Axillaries and underwing coverts black. Female rather browner and less pinkish, especially on breast. Juvenile brown with pale or rusty edges and/or centres of feathers in areas where adults ire pinkish or greyish. Distribution and habitat North-western Ecuador south to north-western Peru. Confined to the irid tropical zone.

\\ ill eat most small seeds and grains from the size of grass seed up to Vlilo. Actions are typically dove-like, but swift and precise. These ively little doves enjoy being in groups, both on and off the ground: hey are sociable. Being rather recently imported, they are still flighty ind nervous. However, they undoubtedly will settle down after becoming iccustomed to their captive surroundings.

i8o J. J. YEALLAND--SOME BIRDS OF THE ARCTIC Nesting The nest of the Buckley Ground Dove is not a typical pigeon or dove nest, it being much more compact, much deeper, and more birdlike in construction. Pine needles were the principal materials used. Two white eggs were laid on 15th and 16th April 1969. The first egg hatched on 28th April, the second 29th April, thus totalling 14 days for incubation. The young fledged at the age of 12 days. As of this writing, 24th June 1969, I can as yet discover no change-over to adult plumage. In my experience, the parents have proved the most protective of any species of foreign doves it has been my privilege to raise. Whenever I approached their nest, they would immediately stage the " broken-wing ' act on the ground. When the young left the nest, their parents would drive off all other doves that ventured near them. I had three pairs nesting within four days of each other, and as the young fledged I noticed this protective aggression on the ground and on perches for a period of approximately two days and up to a distance of 3* feet from the nest. All three pairs nested again at their original sites. I have, in the past, noticed similar protective aggression from Green Imperial Fruit Pigeons and Wonga Wonga Pigeons with newly-fledged young, but to a much lesser degree. When the young Ground Doves reached the age of three weeks the adults nested again, which suggests that they are a very prolific species.

By J. J. Yealland (Binstead, Isle of Wight, England) Svalbard is a group of islands covering some 25,000 square miles and situated approximately 400-500 miles to the north of Norway. By far the largest island is known as Vest Spitsbergen and the area with which we are here concerned, Kapp Linne, is situated on the western coast at Isfjord. The ornithology of the group has been well studied, particularly in recent years by Lovenskiold and others. An account of the birds seen during a stay of six weeks in the summer of 1964 was written by M. A. Ogilvie and R. J. F. Taylor (1967, Ibis , 109 , 3,299-309.) who traversed the area from Isfjord south to beyond Bellsund. It was on 24th June 1968 that Jack D'eath and I set off for Isfjord, and early in the morning of the 25th we arrived at Tromso where we were to embark on a ship that was cruising between Bergen and about 8o* N. on the western side of Spitsbergen. In Tromso Common Gulls were about the streets near the quay and a tame Magpie was investigating refuse bins n the streets. At about 7.0. a.m. we left and proceeded in bright sunlight
algorithms.reference: J. J. YEALLAND--SOME BIRDS OF THE ARCTIC
algorithms.bodyText: through the beautiful Tromso Fjord, calling at Hammerfest and Honnigsvag. Some Shags, a Black Guillemot, Guillemots, Kittiwakes, Common Herring, Great and Lesser Black-backed Gulls and a few Arctic 'ferns were seen. The Lesser Black-backed Gulls in this area are not easily distinguished from the Great at a distance, for the back and wings are quite black and not dark grey as in more southerly birds. The next day was dull and wet, the ship stopped off Bear Island for the unloading of some supplies. Some Fulmars were met with during the day and next morning a few Little Auks, Black Guillemots, a Puffin and some Eider Ducks were seen. Early in the afternoon we landed at Kapp Linne and were soon installed in the old radio station, a wooden building where we lived in unexpected comfort, for there was a fireplace, plenty of wood and coal and even a fully operational electric cooking stove, while, since the food supplies had been organized by Jack D'eath, with no item'forgotten, we lived at a standard not usually associated with Arctic expeditions. On arrival we met Dr. Norderhaug and two colleagues who had been staying in this building and making a study of the breeding birds, collecting insects and doing other research on behalf of the Norsk Polarinstitutt. They left that night for Prins Karls Forland, a large island to the north- ward, but before they went Dr. Norderhaug took us to see the very many nests, particularly of Eider Ducks, around the station. There were then a few nests of Arctic Tern; he also showed us a nest of Grey Phalarope and one of Snow Bunting which was very neatly constructed in a rock crevice and lined with white hairs of Reindeer. This nest contained six eggs and another that we found later, an untidy structure situated in a crevice on the face of the low cliff at the entrance to the fjord, contained young.^ While we were out with Dr. Norderhaug two of what we thought were Common Scoter flew over, but we did not see them again. Of the Grey Phalaropes that were about the shallow lakes and pools near the radio station we saw only the one male, so perhaps any others were also incubating eggs, though we did not see any other nests and would probably not have known of the one had not Dr. Norderhaug showed it to us. There was some variation among the female Eiders, some of them ^eing quite grey with the darker markings more conspicuously con- :rasting; we did not, of course, get so close a view of the drakes, many of *vhich, when we arrived, were sitting about among the nests, but they appeared to be exactly like the nominate race, not having the more yellow- sh hill of borealis. There were several pairs of King Eiders nesting among he others near the station and a few Long-tailed Duck. We did not ever iee any of the ducks feeding with the exception of a drake Long-tailed vhich was sometimes diving just off the shore. The female Eiders, so ar as we knew, never left their nests except when approached quite near in .d then they would not go far and quickly returned. It is stated in hrds of the Soviet Union , vol. iv, that " Female almost never leaves nest

jg 2 j. j. YEALLAND--SOME BIRDS OF THE ARCTIC after conclusion of clutch, towards end of incubation sitting so attentively that she may sometimes be picked up, and, probably refraining entirely from food at such times, subsists chiefly on fat deposits. Weights during incubation consequently drop by some 39% * * * * O ne of the sitting birds was quite unafraid of us and I was able to insert a thermometer between her and the eggs on several occasions and found that the temper- ature there ranged between 103* and 103.7 F. The nests had little down in them and the birds seemed to prefer nesting either in a depression in the ground or among scattered small heaps of pieces of wood left about when the new radio station was built. One nest was among a lot of empty bottles and there were others among heaps of scrap metal: there was one quite near our hut at the foot of a wire stay supporting the flag- pole and surrounded by tethered husky dogs at a distance of no more than 30 to 60 yards. Except for the area of four or five acres around the radic station we saw few birds and no nests and it would be very interesting tc know how long it took the birds or their ancestors to discover that the} could more safely nest near the station than further off from it. There was one Eider's nest close up against the wall of the new station and we noticed that the nests furthest from the buildings were the first to have the eggs taken by the Glaucous Gulls and presumably by the Arctic Skuas of which there was at least a pair about the area, but on the 6th of Jul) there came a greater menace--an Arctic Fox which we immediatel) noticed because of the great clamour made by the Arctic Terns mobbing it. It was running from one to another of the furthest nests and as soor as it came in the vicinity nearly all the male Eiders left the nesting are. and no longer sat about among the nests, but we continued to see som< on the sea and on the rocky islets. A day or two later a second fox came one was much bolder than the other and by concealing himself by a rock Jack D'eath obtained excellent film sequences of this animal. They die not come every day, nor, so far as we knew, did they come before 6th. Jul; The day before this the first of the Eider ducklings hatched in a nes near the cliff; there were three eggs from which two normal health; birds emerged, but the third egg contained a laggard which, when tw< days later the mother and two chicks had gone, lay dead in the nest. Wi did not see the going of this family, but in the ensuing days others hatche< and went off into the fjord and presumably they went up the fjord wher it would certainly have been more sheltered from a persistent cold wester! wind. Generally the families were accompanied by what the radi station men called " aunties " and these were presumably females tha had lost their eggs to the predators. The " aunties " that we saw wit one family numbered seven, the eighth bird being the mother, but whic she was there was no telling and whoever she was she had no objection t the rest of the company. Presumably this habit is of benefit to th mother and young, for it would certainly help to protect them and migf give the mother opportunity to find food for herself. Where the familit
algorithms.reference: J. J. YEALLAND--SOME BIRDS OF THE ARCTIC
algorithms.bodyText: went or for how long the " aunties " stay with them we did not discover. One morning I saw a mother with two ducklings in the sea at the foot of the cliff where it was about 20 feet high and while I watched a third duckling scrambled out from among the rocks close in under the cliff, and evidently these had come from a nest near the edge and had jumped over. There were no " aunties " with them so they apparently had not tra\elled overland for very far or they would have collected some. Some nests contained as many as eight eggs, but whether all were laid by the one bird there was no telling; it seems unlikely that the birds would leave their nests for long, if at all, after the laying of the first egg, for if they did the gulls would soon take the eggs. In that tundra type of country there is little cover and not much vegetation suitable for the covering of such large eggs, so even when eggs are covered with down, the nest is still fairly conspicuous. Close by a track that we took whenever we or the radio station staff went towards the sea there was a nest of King Eider, but the bird was more nervous than the others and would fly off as soon as anyone approached within about 30 yards. The down is, of course, much darker than that of the Common Eider, so the nest is easily indenti- fied even if the owner is not seen. The males were very spectacular in their full breeding plumage; they seemed to spend most of their time on the shallow lakes, but were sometimes to be seen on the sea. I once saw a pair at some distance from the station on a recently thawed lake, but whether they had a nest close by is doubtful and I did not see them there *?ain. The orange of the male s facial area looked much brighter than that of any of the captive ones that I have seen. None of the King Eiders oad hatched their eggs by the time we left and whether they also go with heir ducklings to the fjord or whether they go to the fresh water lakes s not known. There were at least two nests of Long-tailed Duck near the station and )n ra re occasions we saw one or two Pink-footed Geese flying over. At one place along the shore, where a quantity of seaweed had been vashed up, one could be sure of seeing Turnstones and Purple Sandpipers vhich were quite approachable, the latter often performing the character- stic wing-raising action as one drew near. It is difficult to explain this ction, for it appears neither a concealment nor an aggressive posture. )n the seaward side of Kapp Linne, close by the low cliffs, the Fulmars vere often passing up and down; I thought one or two rather paler than thers, but it may have been the effect of the light and we did not see any f the light phase birds there. Occasionally a few Little Auks were seen ver the fjord and once or twice a Black Guillemot: a Great Black-backed juII appeared one day and a Ringed Plover was about the station for a 2w hours. The Kittiwakes often passed over, but did not stay about the tation as the Glaucous Gulls did, the attractions being presumably the efuse tip at a cleft in the cliff, the eggs, of course, and the occasional -a left at the jetty by a patrol boat, the carcasses being used as dog food

j8 4 J. j. yealland--some birds of THE ARCTIC and the skins preserved. We found several dead birds that were plump and in good plumage, so did not look as if they had suffered any long illness, nor was there any obvious sign of injury. There was a female Eider, a Black Guillemot, a Grey Phalarope, a Purple sandpiper and a Little Auk, the last being underneath an overhead cable that led to a light beacon, so may have flown into it, though, of course, at that time of year there is no darkness, but there is sometimes mist. It was difficult to detect what the Snow Buntings were feeding on, so rapid were their movements, but it must have been the tips of moss. One bird came sometimes and picked about under the kitchen window of the radio station where no moss grew and it must have found some scraps of human food there. I put some rolled oats on the ground in front of our windows and this was soon found, the bird eating some and flying off with a beakful. There was very little in the way of insect life on the land and all we ever saw was a very few black flies, and even under pieces of wood that had lain for a long time on the ground there was no visible sign of life. There must have been something in the decaying seaweed and something in the shallow pools and lakes that provided food for the waders, though we never saw them feeding. On the stony beach there were few shells of small molluscs washed up; there was food thai the Arctic Terns, which appeared to increase in number while we wert there, were finding just off the shore, but they had to work hard for r and by no means every dive was successful. The Grey Phalarope's eggs disappeared one night, but whether hatched or taken we never knew The nest was rather far from the station, so, like others on the perimete: of the nesting area, it was probably robbed. We wondered how many o the Eider ducklings from this area could survive the predators and th< rigours of their early lives; even ducklings that got safely to the se. would have a long journey in cold and choppy water before reaching < sheltered place further up the fjord. The men at the station never moles the birds except for the Glaucous Gulls of which they shot several whil we were there, and do so every summer, but this is done to protect th Eiders for which the men have a friendly regard. One of the men sau he had heard a Red-throated Diver, but we did not ever hear or see on and when we arrived the fresh water was mostly frozen over, so, thoug this species is in the area, it is perhaps not usually so far to the north o comes later. One morning we were awakened at about four o'clock by some of tn station staff who were about to set off with tractor and trailer with co; and other supplies for a hut some four miles to the south. These hut are used by trappers and are kept provisioned for their use. We were t have spent the day there, but the tractor became stuck fast in the sno' when we were crossing the bed of a stream, so we proceeded on fo( with enough food for breakfast. On an islet just off the coast we saw Barnacle Goose and two Pink-feet flew over, but apart from them an some Kittiwakes, we saw no birds.
