algorithms.bodyText: Here and there along the shore there were stoutly built wooden traps in he form of a raised narrow open-fronted box of two compartments. At he front is the bait, a piece of fat attached to a wire which, when pulled, ires a shot from a pistol in the inner compartment. These traps are for ) olar Bears, but are to be discontinued because, of course, they sometimes ill a mother bear which may have one or two dependent cubs. The tears had gone north, presumably following the seals, and the only nammals we saw apart from the foxes were the local population of four teindeer, one of which at intervals of several days worked its way round a the front of the station to graze on the mosses and lichens. There are -lusk Oxen in an area further up the fjord inland from Longyearbyen, ut how many and when they and the Reindeer were introduced we did ot discover. There are no small mammals and so foxes must live mainly n the birds and must store them in considerable numbers for winter food. For some miles to the south of Isfjord there is an area of flat tundra rom one to two miles wide and this appears as if it must be made p of stones, sand, etc. thrown up by the sea and also deposited over the ears by erosion of the mountains to the eastward. The reason for thinking us is that here and there, as much as half a mile from the existing coast- ne, there are vertebrae and ribs of whales, some partly buried and pparently of considerable age, that must have been, presumably, washed p on what was then the shore line. I found a piece of walrus tusk, but appose that it is many years since this species lived in those islands. W hen, two weeks later, the next ship called on its northward way, I ubarked because of wanting to see more of the fjord and the small coal- lining towns of Longyearbyen and Ny Alesund. At Longyearbyen it as much warmer than at Kapp Linne, for it was sheltered from the esterly winds. Here the plant life was more advanced and Dryas topetala already in bloom, while a species of poppy grew much larger ere than it was at Kapp Linne. Above the straggling town was an entrance to a coal mine in the hillside id much higher still could be seen Little Auks flying about and presumably ey were nesting there. A mining official who was feeding some quite me Kittiwakes outside his hut told me that he had seen six Arctic Foxes 1 the hillside that morning. One of the Glaucous Gulls about the town id a bright red head and had evidently been feeding inside a carcass, r it did not look like a bird that had suffered in a fight. A little further wond the entrance to the mine was a favourite place for visitors to search r fossils brought there by a glacier; I brought back an almost complete if that resembles some of the Miocene period. At Ny Alesund, further to the northward, I saw a Ringed Plover, rhaps our visitor of a few days before; also a Dunlin, Grey Phalarope, arnstones, a few Eiders and Snow Buntings. The ship proceeded *rthward, but not quite to 8o* N. because of mist and the presence of -bergs. Back in Isfjord and after a second call at Longyearbyen, we

1 86 G. A. SMITH--SOME OBSERVATIONS ON NEW ZEALAND PARAKEETS were taken to see a glacier, the ship sailing quite close in towards the fac< which towered above the sea. Late that night, in gathering mist, w* arrived off Kapp Linne, Jack D'eath embarked and we took leave of ou kind friends of the radio station which, together with oui erstwhil* desirable residence, soon faded from sight. We arrived back in Tromso on July 15th and flew to Oslo where w stayed the night. On a large lawn in the city we saw a Redwing and som Fieldfares, while about the harbour were many Black-headed Gulls, species which does not normally venture as far north as Spitsbergen there are only two records for the area. In spite of much dull and cold weather, not conducive to outdoo photography Jack D'eath has made an excellent colour film of our visi to Spitsbergen, which is also a record of an extremely interesting an< perhaps unique concentration of breeding birds.

algorithms.bodyText: By G. A. Smith (Peterborough, England) My interest in these parakeets started when, as a child, I used to re< the only two available bird books in the local public library. The author, the Rev. C. D. Farrar, was a very successful aviculturalist half a century back, and wrote most entertainingly about his stock. H enthusiasm for keeping New Zealand Parakeets must have overflowed in myself and has stayed with me since. The books, since those war da) have long ago been pulped in some improvement scheme; so that I cann verify as to what he actually wrote concerning them. However, I < remember that they seemed to possess all the possible psittacine virtues- low voiced, beautiful, tractable, of extreme fecundity and had no sexii problems. And yet to counterbalance these perfections they, unfortunate just when things seemed to be going along most swimmingly, died li flies--of no apparently known malady. Other and later authors seem substantiate him fully on these points. Inexplicable and it seems inevital early demise is the worst of possible faults for an aviary bird to possess a; they consequently were often given up as worse than useless . Even in the wild they do not seem to be able to maintain their numbe Buller, 100 years ago, writes of seven-year cycles of superabundance wh flocks of thousands of the birds settled like locusts on the farmers' fiel< Today they are decidely rare on the mainland. With such a nc

G. A. SMITH--SOME OBSERVATIONS ON NEW ZEALAND PARAKEETS 187 specialized species the clearance of the forests and the introduction of modern agriculture should have benefited them as much as it has the closely related Australian Platycercines. Only on the outlying islands do they seem to hold their own. W hen I eventually had receipt of my birds they were even more delightful than I had thought possible. From the illustrations in Buller, and fiom examining skins at South Kensington I was prepared for their appearance; but no description, not even the eulogizing of Farrar, had done them justice. Both the Red-fronted and the Yellow-fronted were turned out provisionally into flight cages. W ithout any more ado they immediatel} started cracking seed and sampling the various greenstuffs provided as if they had lived in these cages all their lives. They didn't, to my ears, " bleat like sheep heard in the distance ", nor did the call even caguely sound like Buller's "twenty-eight"; but they staccatoed away like miniature magpies. A sort of low-sounding polysyllabic call. Presumably like that used by titmice, serving to keep the community together when travelling through dense vegetation. The Red-fronted were quite beautiful--of a Stanley Rosella size with a body of purest parrot green, shading into a lighter yellowish green on the abdomen and Test, a contrasting red head, and a bluish margin to the primary feathers. The legs look incongruous, as if they had been designed for a somewhat arger bird. The Yellow-fronted was different altogether, being a smaller bird, with i proportionately longer tail. 1 he green of its plumage was not quite so Jure in tone, the red somewhat muddy and the yellow of the head quite Jingy. The legs were even more ungracefully long. Both species of birds lave the irises blood red in the male, slightly more orange-toned in the emale. Whereas in larger Red-fronted they look quite appropriate, in he Yellow-fronted they give it a wild-eyed look suggestive of incipient nadness. It et how charming they are. So very confident and with all he " cheek " of a London sparrow. They scratch with a lateral sidewards notion when they are feeding. Their general pert manner is reminiscent, nore especially so in the Yellow-fronted, of a blackbird, or perhaps an iwkwardly large titmouse handicapped with big awkward feet and rather hin long toes. Their appetites seem insatiable--not as regards seed, nost of which is wastefully scattered with their hen-like scratchings unless fed from a bevel-sided dog's drinker bowl)--but of vegetation and ruit. Leaves of groundsel and chickweed are chewed off the plant and wisted and turned in the beak, ever diminishing in size, until it disappears Ten another portion is immediately bitten off. Occasionally a foot is ised to hold some item down or to lift it up to the head. With regard to eed they seem to be most fond of hemp although all the commonly-fed eeds are also eaten. When walking on the grass, or hanging from a suspended bunch of reen food, the birds become almost invisible. Indeed it is only the red,

188 G. A. SMITH--SOME OBSERVATIONS ON NEW ZEALAND PARAKEETS on the heads of both, and the yellow on the smaller species, that enabh one to see the birds at all. Red and yellow are common " signal colours ' in many species. Presumably the coloured foreheads are of value to thf parakeets themselves in distinguishing one another when they are so wel camouflaged. In another parakeet, the budgerigar in its wild greer coloration, I have similarly noticed that it is only the yellow foreheac again that can be made out, and this with some difficulty, when they an grazing green grass. Cyanoramphine parakeets must be as hard as nails. Subspecies o the Red-fronted used to live on the almost Antarctic, extremely mhospit able, Macquarie Islands whose climate must be akin to the Falklands where, like the same subspecies still found on the equally drear anc treeless Antipodes Island, they must have derived a considerable propor tion of their diet from the skins and carcasses of dead penguins. Phe relationship of size of bill to size of bird is quite interesting in thi. genus. The larger the bird the more geometrically disproportionate th< size of the beak becomes. This relative growth applies not only betweei male and female, the hens being slightly smaller than their mates anc having beaks of, relatively, extreme difference in size; but also withir species where the largest of all the Antipodes Island Parakeet (Cycmoramphu unicolor ) though only 12 in-13 l*ng, ^ as a beak that would not dis credit a macaw, and the smallest the Alpine, or Orange-fronted Parakee (C. malherbi ), 8 im-9 in. long, has a beak of most modest proportions like that of a grass parakeet. Phe Red-fronted ( C. novaezelandiae ), iOo in. 12 in., and the Yellow-fronted (C. aunceps), 9 in.-ioj in., take up ; relative intermediate position. Courtship and nesting behaviour are rather like a benignly reformat version of Rosella behaviour. The cock feeds the hen (I have seen th< hen in her turn feed a rather puzzled-looking cock). No driving of th< hen takes place. Pie runs along the branch on which she is standing alternating the direction in which he faces with each step, while she coyl; retreats ever more slowly away from him. While so advancing the pupil of his eyes contract and expand and he utters an excited feeding call note Suitable nest sites are investigated by the cock who enters first and ty " encouragement noises " actively entices the hen to enter. Sometime both birds remain in the box together: more usually the male would sta outside sitting by the entry hole whilst the hen was within. Having once selected a suitable box, an ever-increasing large amount of the hen' time will be spent within, chewing up the rotton wood on the floor 0 the box and divesting herself of abdominal feathers with which the bo: is lined. When the decision over the acceptability of the box has beei made the hen always roosted at night within it. Initially this loosing th< company of their wives used to unnerve both cocks, and as the evening drew darker, much time was spent by the cock birds in trying to persuade the hens to forsake their boxes and roost with them in the safety of th

G. A. SMITH SOME OBSERVATIONS ON NEW ZEALAND PARAKEETS 189 shelter. ^ On one occasion the Yellow-fronted cock, quite exasperated by his hen s refusal to come out in response to his blandishments, went in and drew her out forcibly by the wing feathers. This roosting and otherwise spending long periods of time in the nesting cavity long before the eggs are actually laid must serve to dry the bedding. Eggs were not laid until exactly ten days after the first observable copulation, and a fortnight or three weeks after deciding on the site. Treading of the hen, as with cockatiels, seems to be part of the " pair bond " and may take place daily, or more frequently, irrespective of whatever stage of nesting, though probably the incidence drops off as the chicks start to grow. As is usual in parrots the eggs are laid on alternate days. Incubation takes 19 days for both species--excluding, of course, the first one or two eggs laid. The total clutch size was 5-9 eggs. They are excellent parents, the hens especially so. Several times a day the cock bird having fed, would call, in very respectful and subdued tones outside the nest hole. He might then go inside, presumably on her invitation, or go about his business. After 10 or 12 seconds inside the next box the two would emerge. He would then feed her, she would preen herself, perhaps have 1 bath, eat a little seed and greenstuff and then go back to the nest. The Dald abdomen and lower chest of a hen, where she had plucked out her eathers to extend her brood patch, looked particularly noticeable when hey clung to the wire to plead for tit-bits. The youngsters are clothed with a grey down, and seem after a poor itart to grow surprisingly rapidly. The eyes open on about the eighth >r ninth day, and about this time they start quilling-up. By the third veek the head feathers have emerged sufficiently for one to be able to liscern whether they are indeed Red or Yellow-fronted (a lot of hybridiza- ion has taken place and perhaps very few " pure " birds exist in captivity t the moment--however this miscegenation, in most cases, is barely vident). One interesting thing is that on the nape of the neck, in both pecies, a faded-yellow coloured area is discernable from about the tenth ay, disappearing, or rather becoming hidden by the green neck feathers t the time of fledging. The young of both species seem to spend longer in the nest than would ?em to be essential. How such active tightly spring-wound parakeets an bide their time cooped in a box is a little perplexing, and when after x weeks they do emerge they look as large as the parents with their ell-grown wing and tail feathers. The bill is horn-coloured at first, fter a w r eek it has already darkened, the bluing takes a few months longer, exing is immediately obvious from the discrepancy in body and beak size, he feathering over the cere is not developed until a fortnight or three eeks after leaving the box, which makes the YYllow-fronted live up to ^ name until the red feathers emerge around the cere. Invariably before they fledge the hen is already incubating another utch in a second nest box. Investigations of this other site having

G. A. SMITH--SOME OBSERVATIONS ON NEW ZEALAND PARAKEETS persisted at a low level all through sitting and brooding and feeding the first nest, as if a daily visit marked the second box as being theirs. 1 his philoprogenative propensity of theirs becomes a little upsetting as the season progresses. To stop the breeding cycle one must at some point destroy a clutch of eggs. Before keeping New Zealand Parakeets my opinion concerning other people's losses was that it would almost certainly turn out to be ascari- diiasis--worms--or that such a high reproductive rate cou d lead to a hypoproteinaemia unless a rich source of protein was made available. I had not had the Yellow-fronted a fortnight before the hen had been treated for concussion from having flown into the wire, and the cock bird for an (at the time) undiagnosed severe illness which, to my surprise, responded so well to "Aureomycin " that within a couple of days he was his normal sprightly self. To cut a long story short, after several months I lost the Yellow-fronted hen after a one-day illness. Autopsy showed psittacosis, which was eventually confirmed by laboratory examination. The very next day the Red-fronted pair became seriously ill. Fortunately I had, immediately after diagnosing the disease, started to medicate a drinking and bathing water with tetracycline antibiotics, which saved the day and the birds. The psittacosis however killed several New Zealand chicks in the nest and left the Red-fronted parents so weak that they could not fly for a week following the inception of the disease Psittacosis is not an uncommon disease in many widely differing croups of birds. It is, for example, endemic in feral and domesticated pigeons, and in most, probably all, Australian psittacines Usually the birds live in some sort of harmony with the disease. Occasionally 1 causes the loss of young fledglings, exceptionally, unless in a virulent form, losses in adult birds. Mostly it exists unobtrusively and totally unsuspected. Recovered birds may become carriers. It is my opinion that the cock Yellow-fronted contracted psittacosis from Budgerigars. (The New Zealand Parakeets shared a shed with them for a month or so while their aviary was made ready.) Following his treated illness he must have become a carrier. The stress caused by simultaneously moulting and rearing a family of very large chicks lowering his resistance and causing him to shed the virus. While all the other New Zealands became ill following the death of the hen he remained, apparently, perfectly unaffected. No other of the varied species of parakeets kept in the same block of flights showed any form of illness or sickness whatsoever, con- tagion having jumped two flights to get to the Red-fronted, the intervening cockatiels, rearing chicks at the time, outwardly seemingly completely unaffected. Conversation with other keepers of these birds who have suffered loss leads me to believe that their losses were also probably psittacosis, ant that at the time of their demise no other parrots seemed to be affected
algorithms.reference: P. J. OLNEY--LONDON ZOO NOTES
algorithms.bodyText: If so it may be that these New Zealand parakeets have an unusual sensi- tivity to the virus of ornithosis (psittacosis). So much so that the many otherwise mild strains extant in several other species of birds prove fatal when contracted by New Zealand parakeets. This idea, in the absence of any substantial evidence, must be of course only conjectural; but as most host species live in a delicate balance with their parasites, when a parasite or a disease meets a new host, then its effect is likely to prove catastrophic (myxomatosis in the rabbit, compared with its natural host the cotton-tail rabbit, where it is a very mild disease, is an especially good example of this). New Zealand was a particularly isolated archipelago--very few species of birds and no mammals, save the bats, found their way there before the Maori and then the European invasion. It is certainly feasible that ornithosis was unknown until introduced some time within the last 100 years, probably brought in with one of the many alien species of birds brought over at various times to add variety to the otherwise rather poor fauna. If so this might also explain the remarkable decline in most native species of birds, some of which, like the New Zealand parakeets would, on the face of it, seemed to have benefited because of the opening up of the country.

By P. J. Olney Since the last London Zoo Notes were written John Yealland has retired to the comparative solitude of the Isle of Wight, where we all wish him much happiness. Possibly the most important event at the Zoo has been the repainting and refurbishing of the Tropical House, which was re-opened to the public at the end of July. Three small waterfalls have been added and provide a pleasant background of running water. There are now 16 different species in the house and the opportunity was taken when the previous occupants were reintroduced to include four new species of Hummingbird, including two Black-throated Mangos Anthracothorax nigricollis which have not been in the collection for many years. A species new to the collection is the Carmine Bee-eater Merops nubicus and a group of five are now in the Bird House. They have settled down

extremely well, and it is proposed to build them suitable nesting sites over the winter. Four King Penguins purchased in the spring joined the single female which has been here since 1956. Three Alpine Choughs were released into the Snowdon Aviary and appear to be enjoying their extra freedom of flight. The new male Cock-of-the-Rock which now sits in solitary splendour in the Bird House is the nominate race Rupicola peruviana , and is a subspecies not seen in the collection before. Almost a must for this tvpe of collection are the Crowned Pigeons and we have just acquired two Victoria Crowned Pigeons, which we hope will bring joy to our demanding public. It is too earlv to say how good or bad the rearing season has been, but certainly the Owls have done well. The most exciting event has been the successful rearing of a single Spectacled Owl Pulsatrix p. perspicillata which is certainly new for London, and possibly is the first time in captivity. Ornamental waterfowl are amongst the most beautiful birds and many f their admirers must have envied the spacious parks with lakes or ponds, sually associated with their maintenance. The first part of the book deals with starting a collection, with a list f the more attractive and less expensive ducks recommended for the eginner. Then follows useful chapter on nests and eggs and an account of the plumage and lOults, including details of the operation of pinioning a bird which is by r the most satisfactory method of preventing waterfowl from straying, ilments and diseases are briefly considered but when in doubt the amateur advised to consult a veterinary surgeon. algorithms.bodyText: The Editorial, "Aviculture and the Introduction of Non-native Species ' overlooks the breeding of birds by the controlled liberty system. This systenr with its many variations, has been practiced for over 20 years and has greatl contributed to the successful breeding of both foreign and British species. 1 fundamental knowledge of a species together with a proper system of release an. control, is sufficient to safeguard the interests of Man and Nature. Liberty Zebr finches have now been established here on the six months open aviary systerr There is more probability of the white garden fantail having a serious effect o the wild native woodpigeon chances of survival than the liberating of Zebra iinche and many other species have in upsetting the balance of Nature. P.H. Glossy Starlings were bred at liberty last season, the liberty system playm major part in the production of robust healthy young. While mass liberation and indiscriminate releases of non-native species must be discouraged, the keepin of various species at liberty under the conditions practiced here, is in the interest of aviculture. There are many more possibilities of beneficial extensions, rehabili tations and additions to the territorial ranges of birds, than the risk of native specie being exposed to adverse competition with new invaders. The danger of Hous sparrow and Starling type evolutions " do exist. The introduction of certai species could upset both Mian and Nature. M^ore than one species could b established in the Californian fruit-growing areas, with possible disastrous result all round. Several Asiatic and Eurasian species non-native to this country coul be established here in the wild. However to suggest discouraging controlle liberty breeding of selected species would be against the interests of the bird: On the contrary, having considerations for the worldwide traffic in wild trappe birds, every encouragement should be given to the breeding of the birds. Tab the case of the Lavender finch, a species imported in large numbers but very rare* bred. Research indicates aviary-bred strains of the species are likely to t established by the controlled liberty system. Many other species could benef from this form of culture. Great Tits were bred for several generations under various conditions and line reared in total confinement deteriorated rapidly while others reared by tf liberty system maintained their stamina. Last season Blue Tits reared health young by the liberty method. What can be done with native species applies t foreign. At present observations are being made daily on Mistle Thrushes, Sor. Thrushes, Blackbirds and Fieldfares all nesting under various aviary condition (It is hoped to submit an article at the end of the season.) If a small colony < Fieldfares is established, consideration will be given to liberating breeding pai at the appropriate time. Does such action constitute a threat to the native bn population? Not that there is any likelihood of establishing a wild breedir stock in this country. With the Mistle Thrushes a project is under way whe one dozen young may be bred from one pair; again the liberty system has a pa to play. j So many breeding successes can be attributed to the use of prolific wild stoc and the establishing of true aviary bred strains of many species is remote und normal aviary conditions without having to continually resort to the use wildlings. Avicultural societies should get their priorities right and introduce policy which encourages the establishing of aviary-bred strains of various specie rather than only reward effort for first breedings of a species which is frequent subsequently neglected by the breeders. In recent times Zoos without bars developed. A system of maintaining birds in "Aviaries without netting cou be adopted by the hobby. Visitors to the writer's garden and other establishmeri where non-native birds are kept at controlled liberty must agree that such additio are a desirable increase to the bird life of the area. . ' So much remains to be done to establish bird protection which is truly in t interests of the birds.
algorithms.reference: T. S. Thomson. 16 Long Lane, Hoole, Chester.
algorithms.bodyText: As an individual with a major responsibility for the production of the editorial *n the liberation of non-native species I feel that it should be pointed out that the *reeding of birds at semi-liberty or complete liberty was not overlooked and that he comments must apply equally to this. I am not satisfied that such a system can be adequately " controlled " and I hink that, if widely practised, it is likely to lead to loss and release of a variety if birds. Unless liberty-breeding occurs in an area of complete devastation it must have ome effect on local birds. The analogy of hantails and Woodpigeons is not a alid one since their ecological niches differ, but when it comes to releasing smaller irds then the only truthful answer is that we have not the slightest idea what effect tiey are having on other species. If we release native species at semi-liberty for reeding purposes in areas where there are wild birds of the same species we are kel> to upset teriitorial boundaries and distribution and may jeopardize the lirvival of wild broods. In addition the authorities may be a little sceptical of le method by which an aviculturist who catches up his birds at the end of a esting season discriminates between " his " birds and wild birds of the same age 1 the local population. If, as is suggested, one can only breed successive generations of Great Tits under anditions of partial liberty then this is really a statement that one cannot breed lem as a\iary birds. It may be useful to know that a controlled liberty system light be possible if it were vital to try it in order to ensure the survival of a species 1 danger of being lost elsewhere, but I do not think such a system should be dvocated as an alternative to discovering how to breed birds under fully controlled v'iary conditions. I am personally of the opinion that a breeding achieved by allowing birds berty at the point where they begin to require food for the young should not be igarded as a successful aviary breeding, in the full sense of the wmrd, and that, here awards are made, there should be some distinction between the two methods f achieving a breeding. I also feel that if one is going to make awards for breeding, len where a species has been first bred at semi-liberty there should be some ibsequent recognition of the first breeding under normal aviary conditions. As members of a society interested in birds through aviculture w r e have the .rne responsibilities tow r ards our environment as have others whose similar terests are expressed in other ways, and we have therefore asked a representative the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds to give his comment on Mr. homson's letter. C. J. O. Harrison. j. Dawlish Avenue, Perivale, Middlesex. Mr. Thomson s interesting letter in the present issue of The Avicultural magazine raises a number of somewTat controversial points. Recently in biological and conservation circles the subject of introductions of >n-nati\e species has been much discussed. There is a large measure of agree- ent that non-native species should not be introduced whether they are plant or iimal, and that reintroductions of (extinct) native species should only be under- en where it can be shown that the experiment would be of scientific interest d that the ecological conditions were suitable for the organisms' survival. I feel most strongly so far as Britain's avifauna is concerned that it would be plorable if it were to be contaminated by the introduction of non-native species liberty breeding. One cannot see with any certainty that a species which is ing liberty bred will not disperse, begin to breed freely and ultimately spread er the country. The whole history of the appearance of new species of birds the faunas of various continents sprinkles with examples to show that -scaped birds or animals have spread to become a menace or at least a nuisance the native fauna, or to the various aspects of human interests. I would maintain ^strongly that the utmost care must be taken to ensure that foreign birds do not abash themselves outside an aviary. Those of us who are concerned about the native fauna of this country do not find roduced species a pleasure and most of the organizations concerned w'ould, ink, deplore the reintroduction of such species as the Fieldfare, particularly ien there are signs of this species beginning to recolonize Shetland by natural

means. Mr. Thomson asks whether the introduction of the Fieldfare would create a threat to the native fauna. The Fieldfare might not, but many other species could, and each individual case must be considered on its own merits. In addition, introductions of the kind mentioned by Mr. Thomson would vitiate years of study by students of the movement of bird populations; if every aviculturist took it into his head to release or establish colonies outside their normal breeding range, chaos would ensue. Mr. Thomson confuses the issues when talking about zoos without bars. It is true that some zoos have no iron bars, but inmates are still confined. If one could confine birds to an area, thus preventing them spreading, without the use of netting, there might be no objection. Peter Conder, Director. Royal Society for the Protection of Birds, The Lodge, Sandy, Bedfordshire.

Parrots are popularly supposed to live for a hundred years or more--a suppo- sition fostered by grossly exaggerated claims made in regard to unfortunate birds exhibited at fairs and seaside shows. Pet dealers extolling their stock frequently tell prospective customers that the life expectancy of a parrot or cockatoo may reasonably be regarded as similar to their own. There are, of course, records of such birds living to a great age, but they have necessarily had several owners and it is this handing down that is responsible for many inaccuracies. In addition, none has been bred in captivity and here again a certain amount of guesswork is involved. Ages of 30 or 40 years are quite exceptional and very few indeed die of genuine old age. There are accounts of birds such as the Macaw (? species) living in Venice in 1900, suoposed to be 136 years old. It is said to have originally been the property of Charles IV of Spain who died in the early 1800's. It was then in the ownership of the King's grandson--the so-called Duke of Madrid. Then there was " Cocky Bennett ", a Sulphur-crested Cockatoo, that died in Canterbury, near Sydney, in May, 1916, at the reputed age of 119 years. " Cocky " was for many years in the possession of Mrs. Sarah Bennett, licensee of the Sea Breeze Hotel, at Tom Ugly's Point. Judging by a photograph of the stuffed remains " Cocky " was indeed a Methuselah amongst cockatoos. It was prac- tically featherless for the last 20 years of its life, with the upper mandible overgrown to such an extent that it almost touched its breast. Dr. W. C. Osman Hill has recorded three cases of longevity of Blue-fronted Amazons, presumably based on birds sent to the Zoological Society of London foi

algorithms.bodyText: her possession for 49 years and was said to be eighteen months old on receipt It died on 21st October, 1950, presumably over 50 years old. 2. A male kept by its last owner for 14 years and by the previous ownei for 42 years; before that it had been in the same family for 37 years. Ir. 1944 the owner had published a note in The Star giving its age at that datf as 87. It died in April, 1954, at the reputed age of 97 years. 3. A female that had been in the possession of three owners, 9# years, 19 years and 70 years. When it died in July, i 954 > if the history is reliable, it musi have been a centenarian. Dr. Osman Hill also mentions a Greater Sulphur-crested Cockatoo of 51 years and another of the same species as being accidentally killed after 109 years ir captivity. And a traditional record of 137 years and 10 months for the samt species (Avicultural Magazine, 1951, 36; 1954, 165). And in 1954 there was a Red and Yellow Macaw in the Adelaide Zoo, believed tc have been in the possession of the Royal Zoological Society of Australia for at leas' 75 years. . . , It would be of interest if readers were to record any cases of longevity with whicr they are personally acquainted. algorithms.bodyText: Three score, ten and five years, three-quarters of a century, seventy-five years describe the period how you will--it is quite long by any standard. Despite many forebodings the Society has managed to thrive and today it may truly be said to be in a stronger position than at any time in its history, and the Avicultural Magazine has a world-wide circulation. But this satisfactory state of affairs is undoubtedly due to those early pioneers in aviculture at the turn of the century, who placed the Society on such solid foundations and who from the first established a high standard for its journal--the Avicultural Magazine. In the following pages an exact reproduction of parts of the first lumber of the Magazine, published in November 1894, are given, including :he statement of aims and objects, rules, list of officers, committee, and nembers together with a specimen of the advertisements which appeared n this number. Notes by the Secretary and Treasurer, with slight iterations, are as applicable today as they were 75 years ago! An article " On Aviculture in Aviaries " by Arthur G. Butler and he first of a series of articles on " Our Bird-Rooms and Aviaries " which :ommenced in this number, contributed by Reginald Phillipps and entitled My Bird-Room ", are also included. The first colour-plate, reproduced as the frontispiece of this special upplement was not attained till the third volume, published in 1896. rhe accompanying article by A. G. Butler on the Pine Grosbeak was the rst of a series on the Fringillinae.

On its foundation it was expected that the Society would be " kept together by the penny post ". But that lowly charge has long since vanished and while the Society is, of course, still reliant on the Magazine it does now have an advantage in the British Aviculturists' Club. The Society has had a very great past and it is to be fervently hoped that Members will never lose their sense of gratitude. The Society prides itself on being international in character, and reference to the List of Members shows that there are in fact Members throughout the world. Scattered though they are it is perhaps difficult for some to remember they are members of a society , and not just subscribers to a publication; and as such they are asked to do everything possible to further its interests. It has been said that a society is only as good as its members. If true,, our Society is paramount. With your co-operation we can keep it that way.

One of our chief objects will be to endeavour;to bridge over the gulf which exists between the lover of live birds and the v scientific ornithologist --we believe that each has much to learn from the other. We want to infuse a little science into the bird-keeper, and to interest the cabinet ornithologist in the habits of birds. A word as to our name. It seems desirable and even necessary, to invent or acclimatize a word which shall denote " a person interested in the keeping, and breeding of birds," and Aviculturist (being analogous to Horticulturist) will do perhaps as well as another. If any one will suggest a better, we shall be glad to adopt it--till then, we beg to subscribe our- selves Avicui/turists. We relv for the success of the Society upon the energy of the members in inducing others to join, and in contributing to the Maga- zine. Those who are not prepared to write a formal article have generally met with some little facts or fancies in their avicultural experience, which will be of interest to others, and if they will note these down and send them to the Secretary, thev will place the rest of the Society under an obligation. We want the benefit of the practical' experience of all--we neither expedt nor want literary skill. In order that the Society may be of real assistance to beginners, we have arranged to give advice to members upon all matters relating to aviculture bv Post. The vexatious delay which arises when correspondents are only answered in the columns of a magazine or newspaper will thus be avoided. All letters and questions must be sent to the Secretary, and contain a stanipea envelope for reply. The Secretary will forward the letters to those Members of the Committee who are best qualified to deal with the subjects to which they relate, and who are willing to undertake the task of replying to questions. For the present, questions relating to Parrots will generally be replied to by Mr. Camps or Dr. Simpson ; Insectivorous Foreign Birds will be undertaken by Mr. Phillipps or Dr. Simpson ; Foreign Finches, by Dr. Butler or Mr. Fillmer; and British Birds by Mr. Frostick or Mr. Swaysland. fhose questions and answers which appear to be of general interest, will be published in the Magazine. Dr. Simpson regrets that he cannot undertake post mortem examina- tions of birds, audit is particularly requested that'.bodies of birds be not sent either to him or to any of the other officers of the Society. We should be glad to hear from any member willing to undertake post mortems. It has been suggested that a sale and exchange column should be opened, and we are prepared to admit advertisements of birds at the rate of* 3d. for each insertion, of not more than two lines. Longer advertisements will be charged in proportion. Advertisements of " wants will be inserted free of charge. It is hoped that this'arrangement will prove of mutual advantage to our members, who will thus know with whom they are dealing. We do not.pretend to be exclusive; but we believe that under our rules (which have been very carefully thought out, and will be vigilantly administered), it will not be possible for any but honourable and straight- forward men and women to become members of the Avicultural Society. Signed on behalf of the Committee,

algorithms.bodyText: i--- The name of the Society shall be "The AvicueTurai, Society." Ami its object shall be the study of Foreign and British Birds. Poultry, Pigeons and Canaries shall be outside the scope of the Society. , 2.--The officers of the Society shall'be elected annually by the mem- bers in manner hereinafter provided, and shall- consist of a President, a Vice-President, a Treasurer, a. Secretary, an Auditor, a Scrutineer, and a Committee of 12 members. All officers shall be ex officio members of the Committee.
algorithms.sectionHeader: 3 ---Each member shall pay an annual subscription of 5/- to be due
algorithms.bodyText: and payable in advance on the 1st of November in each year. New mem- bers shall pay an entrance' fee of 2/6. Any member whose subscription or entrance fee shall be four months overdue shall cease to be a member of the Society, and notice of his having ceased to be a member and of the c?iuse, shall be inserted in the Magazine. 4.--New members shall be proposed in writing; and the' name and address of every person thus proposed, with the name of the member pro- posing him, shall be published in the next issue'of the Magazine. And unless the candidate shall, within two weeks after the publication of his name in the Magazine, be objected to by at least two members, he shall be deemed to be duly elected. If five members shall objeCl to the candidate he shall not be elected. If two or more meijibers (but less - than five) shall lodge with the Secretary objections to any candidate, the Secretary shall announce in the next number of the Magazine that such objections have
algorithms.listItem: * been lodged (but shall not publish the names of the objectors), and ; shall
algorithms.bodyText: request the members to vote upon the question of the election of"such candidate. Members shall record their votes in sealed letters addressed to the Scrutineer, and a candidate shall not be elected unless two-thirds of the votes recorded are in his favour ; nor shall a candidate be eleCted if five or more votes are recorded against his election.
algorithms.sectionHeader: 5 - --The Magazine of the Society shall be issued on the first day of
algorithms.bodyText: every month, and forwarded, post free, to each member. The Secretary shall have an absolute discretion as to what matter shall be published in the Magazine (subjecT to the control of the Committee). The Secretary shall refer all matters of doubt or difficulty to the Committee, The decision * of the majority of the Committee shall be final and conclusive in all matters.
algorithms.footnote: 6- --The election of officers shall take place every year between the 1st and 14th of October. All candidates must be proposed by one.member
algorithms.bodyText: and seconded by another member (in writing), before they are eligible for election ; but this; shall not apply to officers willing to stand for re-eleCtion to the same office. All such proposals which have been duly seconded must be sent to the Secretary before the 14th of September. The Secretary shall prepare a voting paper containing a list of candidates, showing the offices for which they.are respectively seeking election or re-eleCtion, and shall send a copy of such voting paper to each member of the Society, with the OCtober number of the Magazine. Each member shall make a cross (X) opposite the names of those for whom he desires to vote, and shall sign the voting paper at the foot, and. send it to the Scrutineer in a sealed envelope before the 14th of OCtober. The Scrutineer shall prepare a written return of the officers elected, showing the number of the votes recorded for each candidate, and send it to the Secretary before the 21st of October, for publication in the November number of the Magazine.
algorithms.sectionHeader: 7 - --It shall be lawful for the Committee to delegate any of' their
algorithms.reference: powers to a Sub-Committee of not less than three. 8.--The Committee (but not a Sub-Committee) shall have power to alter and add to the Rules, from time to time, in any manner they may think fit. 9 ---The Committee shall have power to expel any member from the Society at any time, without assigning any reason.

algorithms.bodyText: The Secretary hopes that every member will assist him in making the Magazine a success by sending notes or short articles on Aviculture from time to time. It is intended to publish an account of the various bird- rooms and aviaries belonging to the members, under the title of " Our Bird Rooms and Aviaries.'' Mr. Pliillipps has earned the thanks of the Society by his most valuable contribution to this series. Will each member follow his example ? Another series on " Rare Foreign Birds," to which Mr. Fillmer this month contributes "The Parrot Finch," and " The Black- tailed Hawfinch," it is believed will be of great interest, if all will help by sending notes on the rare species they have kept. Will those who live in the country communicate their observations on wild bird life ? And will our more scientific friends enlighten us on those points of ornithology which bear upon practical Aviculture. Lastly, will those who do not feel able to do anything else ask questions ?

I shall be much obliged if those members who have not yet paid their subscriptions, will kindly remit them to me in the course of the next few weeks. I have promised that the necessary funds shall be forthcoming for the printing and circulating of our Magazine for one year, and that the Society shall start upon its second year free from debt; after October, 1895, the Society must be self-supporting if it is to continue to exist. I calculate that if we can secure a membership of from 140 to 150, the success of the Society is assured, and there will be 110 deficit for me to make up at the end of the year. It will be seen that we start with 52 members ; we want therefore 100 new ones, and I appeal to all to do their utmost to increase our numbers. If we have a large membership we shall be able to have a large Magazine, and .shall be in a position to extend our cause in various other ways. But if our list of members remains small, we cannot afford to print more than eight pages per month, and shall be prevented from extending the usefulness of the Society by other means. I shall not be satisfied until we number 200. Members who wish for extra copies of this first number for distri- bution amongst their friends, can have them on application, at one penny per copy. This charge is merely made to cover postage. Horatio R. Firmer, Hon. Treasurer.

A. G. BUTLER--ON AVICULTURE IN AVIARIES
algorithms.bodyText: Reproduced from Vol. 1, No. 1, p. 4.

By Arthur G. Butler, Ph.D., F.L.S., etc. The study of birds in aviaries (I am not speaking of flight cages, but such as are large enough for the owners to walk about in) is in many respects far more satisfactory than when they are confined even in large cages. Of this fact I can speak from experience; because, when I com- menced to keep birds, my space was limited; so that my largest " aviary " was then actually little more than a long flight cage, only two feet six in height and one foot four inches from front to back: in length, this cage was not so bad about ten feet; but nevertheless, for breeding purposes, it was of little practical use, on account of its narrowness, which brought the birds too close to the observer. When my present house was built, I had seven aviaries constructed, all of them under cover: of these, four are kept at a moderately warm temperature during the winter; the other three are unheated. I have now added two open garden aviaries, with a door of communication from one to the other, and each of them measuring eleven feet six inches in length, four feet six inches from front to back, and from about seven to eight feet in height (the roof sloping forwards). At first, my unheated aviaries were permanently open on one side to the air, throughout the year; but the through draught caused, when the door in my garden was opened, proved very prejudicial to the health of some of the birds, more especially to British species, such as Linnets, Goldfinches and Siskins; therefore, I eventually had sashes made (which could at any time be removed) so as to exclude draught. To attain much success in breeding, each aviary should be plentifully supplied with various forms of receptacles for nests, and when possible these should be more or less concealed by thick bushes: dead furze-bushes perhaps make the best cover; but if these are not procurable, branches of fir answer the purpose fairly well. Pea sticks nailed against the walls make convenient elastic perches, and when used in quantity, help a little to conceal the roughness of nest-boxes. In the case of the well-known receptacle described by Herr Wiener, as of the cigar-box pattern, it is always best to give the builders a start by ramming two or three handfuls of hay into the bottom before hanging it up: the actual nest is then much more easily and rapidly completed, than when the architects have first to form their own foundation; while the appearance of nesting-material in the box gives the birds a hint as to what is expected of them. From a study of the works of Dr. Russ, I am convinced that when many birds of different species are kept in the same aviary, it is necessary

2 o8 a. G. BUTLER--ON AVICULTURE IN AVIARIES to supply a considerable amount of cover in order to ensure the production of many broods. My own experience has shown me that where it is impossible to do this, the different architects are constantly at warfare, consequently, though many and varying nests are built throughout the year, few, if any, broods come to perfection. This, I believe, is the reason why my Ornamental-finch aviary, which only has one short wall available for nesting-purposes, so rarely proves productive; whereas the adjoining Weaver aviary, having a twelve-foot length of additional wall, gives fairly satisfactory results. The amateur who has only observed Ornamental-finches in store or flight-cages would be apt to imagine that they were, as a class, the most amiable and peaceable of birds; there they sit in rows close together, preening each others feathers and lovingly caressing one another: but in the aviary all this is changed, and especially when more than a pair of each species is turned loose. Now disputes are frequent, more particularly when nesting is commenced, and in the case of some of the species, not infrequently with fatal effect. An Ornamental-finch aviary should not only be restricted to small Fringilloid birds, but it should exclude Aurora, Diamond, Parson, and Ribbon-finches, more particularly the two last-mentioned, which are both meddlesome and murderous towards smaller or weaker birds. Then again, (but here I am preaching that which, at present, I do not practice), a Weaver-aviary ought not to include Bayas or soft-billed birds, some of which are very destructive both to eggs and newly-hatched youngsters. During the present year my two Bayas and a Yellow-bellied Leiothrix (Pekin Nightingale) have, I know, greatly reduced the numbers of my additions: but when I kept Blue-birds with Ornamental-finches, every egg was stolen, almost as soon as it made its appearance in a nest. Next year I hope to try an interesting experiment with my garden aviaries: it is my intention, as soon as the warm weather commences, to turn out pairs of two species into each aviary, with ample nesting accom- modation and plenty of cover. I believe that, under these favourable conditions, far better results may be anticipated, than when thirty or forty examples of different species are associated together. If supplied with plenty of suitable food, I think that many birds which are usually considered unable to stand cold, become perfectly hardy under this apparently adverse state of things. As an instance, I may mention that, in about August or September of 1893, I turned loose a Redstart into one of my unheated aviaries. Now, in the article on British birds in Cassell's " Cage-birds ", Mr. Swaysland mentions one that was kept from April to December, but which always felt the cold when the thermometer fell to 40*, and in November the cold weather sent it into a decline, of which it died. This bird, however, was fed partly on raw meat, and meal-worms appear to have constituted its insect-food. Fortunately for my birds I have a goodly number of Cockroaches in my bird-room and
algorithms.reference: A. G. BUTLER--ON AVICULTURE IN AVIARIES
algorithms.bodyText: stoke-hole: every night three " demon beetle-traps " are put down; and each morning, summer and winter, these are transferred to my aviaries' where they are soon cleared out by the birds. Last winter, on a diet of bread, potato, grocer's currants, egg, ants' e gg s > Abrahams food and cockroaches (with an occasional spider) my Redstart, a Blackcap, a Whinchat, a Yellow and a Grey Wagtail, together with several foreign seed-eating birds, were quite indifferent to twelve degrees of frost. All these birds, excepting the Blackcap, which was killed by a Blossom-headed Parrakeet, are in perfect condition at the present time; and, so far as I can see, likely to live through the coming winter equally well. Perhaps I may be prejudiced, if so, my prejudice is based upon very unpleasant experience; but I believe that raw meat is extremely unsuitable food for any but predacious birds. I have kept Thrushes and Blackbirds in perfect health for years without a particle of raw meat, and it is absolutely certain that a Missel-Thrush brought up and always fed upon farinaceous food, was killed at the Crystal Palace through having scraped raw meat and bread supplied to it; previous to that time it had never had a day's illness, but was a marvel of vivacity, tameness and cleanliness. In. the breeding-season two cock Wagtails, of different species, invariably fight in an aviary; and unless separated, the stronger (not always the larger) will infallibly starve the weaker to death, by incessantly driving him from the food-dishes. I even lost a favourite hen Grey Wagtail two or three years ago, owing to the persecutions of a male Pied Wagtail. This summer again, I was obliged to remove my Yellow Wagtail to a cage to prevent his destroying a very beautiful cock Grey Wagtail. At the Zoological Gardens the Grey and Pied Wagtails have been successfully crossed: probably the hen bird was the Pied; if not, the male bird must have been an especially amiable individual. My experience of British birds as aviary pets leads me to the following conclusions:--All finches must either be kept in a large open garden aviary, as nearly as possible under the same conditions to which they would be subject when at large; or, they must be kept during the winter at a high temperature, indoors. They are far more susceptible to changes of temperature when in captivity than the majority of foreign finches. It is rare for Goldfinches, Bullfinches, Linnets, and especially Siskins, to live in a limited, unheated, though enclosed, aviary for more than eighteen months. Indeed I have found some of the small Indian, Austra- lian, and even African and South American Ornamental-finches, decidedly more hardy under these conditions. On the other hand, many Insectivorous British birds appear to be ndifferent to temperature provided that they can be supplied with a fair quantity of insect-food throughout the year. Budgerigars seem to be subject to the same influences as British inches, they will stand cold well, but not in a covered-in aviary: yet in a

A. G. BUTLER--ON AVICULTURE IN AVIARIES flight-cage open only in front, and kept at a moderate temperature, they live for years. Blossom-headed Parrakeets, on the other hand, have so far done well in the same aviary which killed the majority of my Budgerigars: indeed, whereas twelve out of thirteen young birds of the latter species died within two or three months after leaving the nest, a young male Blossom-head, born this year in the same log-nest, is larger and apparently more vigorous than its parents. The preceding observations must, nevertheless, be understood generally; not as applying to every individual of a species: thus, for several years I repeatedly tried to keep the Cordon Bleu in my Ornamental-finch aviary; but always lost every individual, either within a few weeks or at best in two or three months. At length, I purchased two pairs, in 1892, and turned one pair into the same aviary, the other into a flight-cage; the hen of the first pair lived about three months, that in the cage a little over a year; but both cock-birds are in perfect health as I write, having passed through two winters, at a temperature never lower than 46 degrees Fahr., but rarely exceeding 50 degrees. It has been frequently stated that, in flight-cages, the Amaduvade Waxbills, as well as Cordon Bleus, are liable to baldness. This is, without question, due to the fact that the birds pull out one another's feathers; a trick to which the Green Amaduvade is much addicted. In a large aviary, on the contrary, all these birds are usually in magnificent feather; though in the case of Stictospiza formosa , a spiteful unpaired hen will sometimes make herself objectionable by pulling out her companions' feathers; or specimens which have long been naturalized in the aviary will simul- taneously surround and pluck a new-comer, more especially when the latter is somewhat rough in plumage. For this reason, as well as from the inexplicable fact that, after several years of uninterrupted health, these lovely little birds will suddenly and unaccountably be found dead (though subsequent dissection shows all their organs apparently healthy) the Green Avadavats, or Amaduvades, are somewhat aggravating aviary pets. Mr. Abrahams considers them delicate; but I think this is not the real cause of their death: a bird which can stand twelve degrees of frost and be none the worse, can hardly be strictly called delicate. My own opinion is that these birds usually die of apoplexy, or heart disease, suddenly; that a scare, caused by the hasty entry of any person into the bird-room, or the abrupt turning on of artificial light, may be accountable. If these few rough notes should prove useful to any of our members, they will have served their purpose; and such matters as I may have over- looked, will, I hope, be supplemented by others who have had experience of this form of Aviculture. On the other hand, should anyone wish for further information on any of the points which I have mentioned, it will be a pleasure to me to attempt to answer such questions as he may put. What all aviarists desire is, to render their feathered pets as nearly as

possible immortal; but perhaps when I say all , I should exclude bird- dealers, who doubtless would be content with a more moderate span of life for them. At present, aviculture is still in its infancy, and every crumb of information based upon fact is important. A Society such as ours, which affords its members the opportunity of freely exchanging experiences, is therefore likely to prove extremely useful, in reducing the death-rate of birds in captivity.
algorithms.equation: * * * Reproduced from Vol. i, No. i, p. 8. OUR BIRD-ROOM AND AVIARIES I MY BIRD-ROOM By Reginald Phillipps
algorithms.bodyText: Most of us are the victims of circumstances; and most of those who, like myself, love their birds, would like to provide better accommodation for them than circumstances will usually permit. Besides, we all have our own peculiar idea of what is right and what is best; and some of us keep one class of bird, some another. It follows of necessity, therefore, that bird- rooms are of all sorts and sizes, and arranged in many different ways; and doubtless we may all pick up a wrinkle or two by reading accounts of the homes in which our fellow aviarists keep their feathered pets. Some people seem to consider that a bird-room is a room in which to place cages containing birds; and there are some who--the victims of circumstances, you know--find it difficult to keep their birds except in cages. The room is fitted up with shelves, and on the shelves are placed :he cages, and in the cages are placed the birds, all much like a bird-shop, 3r, to put it more prettily, like the Parrot House at the London Zoological wardens. The habits of caged birds may be studied in such a room, but lot the habits of birds. If you desire to study the habits of your favourites, md to find out what are their respective natures, why birds have been con- structed by the Master Builder some in one way, some in another, and all 10 marvellously according to their several requirements, you must let them lave as much liberty as possible. If you have not an out-door aviary, have me made; if you are likewise a victim, and cannot do so, at any rate let mur birds fly loose in your bird-room, as far as practicable. When selecting a room for your birds, choose, if you can, a lofty room, acing south or thereabouts, on the ground floor, with the window opening m to the private garden. There are several advantages in having the bird- oom on the ground floor. The temperature is more equable than if it be

somewhere among the garrets; the birds are more handy during your waking hours; you are less likely to stir up the ire (always latent, if not always expressed) of the petticoated members of the household, as you will avoid making a mess about the house, and being accused of wearing out the stair-carpet by your " perpetual tramping up and down after those nasty things "; and above all you may be tempted to do what I have done --to build an aviary in the garden coming up to and against the house, and so arranged that you can let your birds fly backwards and forwards between the bird-room and the aviary, just as you may deem prudent or find convenient. Your bird-room must (I prefer must to ought) have a fire-place, to assist the ventilation; and, in my room, at the very top of the wall, I have had a good-sized hole knocked through into the chimney, protected by a grating. A wire-guard protects the fire-place, and prevents any bird going up the chimney, or sitting on the cold bars in a very draughty place. The window is protected by wire-netting: I have two light wooden frames covered with netting, the one fitted over the upper half of the window, the other over the lower; either of these can be easily removed, to allow the birds egress and ingress; or, when left in position, the window can be opened without allow- ing the escape of the inmates. The window, moreover, can be opened and closed from the outside, without entering the bird-room. The room should be as light as possible, but should be provided with a dark blind; this latter is of great value when you desire to catch a bird, one person trimming the blind, while you catch your bird without any bustle. I still have a blind; but, since I have introduced some of the larger parra- keets into the family, it has fared rather badly. The walls are washed, not papered; and, if you may (I may not), you will do well to cut a panel or two out of the door, and cover the apertures with netting; the apertures serve not only as peep-holes, but also as aids to ventilation. If too draughty or cold, a piece of green baize, or other covering, can be arranged to fall down over them as required. The question of the floor and its covering is a very serious one. If you have tiny finches, waxbills, and the like, I suppose there is nothing better than a good layer of sand. This has the disadvantage, however, of clinging to one's feet as one leaves the room, with the unavoidable conse- quences that more is carried away and deposited elsewhere than the ruling powers usually approve of. Not long since I met a gentleman who is very warm on the canary. I have never seen his bird-room, but, like that of most fancy canary breeders, doubtless it contains only caged birds. As he piteously remarked, it is impossible to help a little seed-husk getting about, or a little dirt of some kind sticking to one's slippers; but he said that he is regarded among his own household as an outcast, and a-, and is treated accordingly. Nevertheless, I am glad to say that he has nailed his colours to the mast, and has no intentions of surrendering. If the man without sand on his floor is treated thus, how will it fare with the one who

sands his floor properly! A little while back, someone writing to the papers told us how it ought to be done. He commenced by letting his birds fly loose in the room; but, after having been taught the errors of his ways, he shut them up in cages, seated himself comfortably in the centre of the room, lighted his pipe, and was able to view his feathered prisoners with a quiet mind, and amidst that domestic harmony which should prevail even in the house of an aviculturist. To my mind, this was retrogression, not progression. He evidently had not the same grit in him as has our canary friend. But I am wandering. I do not have sand on the floor of my bird-room. Most of the birds I have kept for these many years have been large ones; and for such a sandy floor would probably be a mistake. I have one piece of floor-cloth running the whole length of the room, and 9 ft. wide--the widest I could obtain: this covers a very large part of the floor. A nurse- girl comes six days a week to attend to my feathered children; and one of her duties is to clean the floor every day. This plan has many advantages and many disadvantages; but with large birds I doubt if it is not as good as any other. My ideas of cages are perhaps peculiar. The ordinary cage is sometimes useful, sometimes, perhaps, almost necessary; but I do not favour it. All the cages in my bird-room have been specially made according to my own directions, some of them I now know are not quite as they should be; but they still answer the purpose very well, better than would any I could obtain ready made. Two are slightly over 4 ft. x 2 ft. x 5! ft. high. The more modern ones are from 4 ft. to 6 ft. long, about 2 ft. deep, and from 2 ft. to 3 ft. high. One is placed at the top of another, the upper ones having gable roofs. Most of them can be divided into two or into tee sections, 2 ft. long each, by running in divisions, should it be neces- sary. All the doors of these cages last mentioned are about 2 ft. x 2 ft., vith an extra door of the same size for the longer cages, so that one side can 3e thrown open; and wide open these doors usually are, for they are closed mly when a bird is encaged for some special reason. The bottoms of all he cages are kept well supplied with sand, grit, cuttle-bone, rock salt, egg- shells (baked and ground), and finely ground oyster shell. Some of the :ages have been fitted up with little shelves, on which are placed most of he food saucers and drinking w^ater, so that both are kept free from hoppings. The cages are mostly set on stands, which raise them at least >ne foot above the floor; and there is a space of several inches between the ages and the w r all. I consider these last-named arrangements to be of pecial value. Mice cannot climb into the cages and disturb the inmates, ior soil the food; and cockroaches have to content themselves with such craps of food as may happen to have been scattered on to the floor, doreover, if a bird should fall down behind the cages, instead of getting LXe d and dying miserably, it lands on the floor, hops quietly forth from nder the cages, and is itself again; and the open space beneath and behind

the cages tends to cleanliness and pure air. Each cage should have at least two sides of wood, the remainder being built round with straight wire, not wire-netting. About the room, but not coming too near the window, nor over that part of the floor which is uncovered--and which is usually clean, and forms my customary path--there are several natural boughs of various sizes, and portions of trees, fixed about, artificial perches being mostly excluded. There are usually, also, a few nesting boxes about; but I trust more to the aviary for all nesting purposes, the bird-room being used more as a shelter from cold and wet. But, of course, with many kinds of birds totally different arrangements would have to be made; and in my bird- room and aviary there is a quiet work of change perpetually going on, according to the natures and requirements of my various pets. I have never been able to detect a bird-insect of any kind in the bird- room itself, notwithstanding that some of the cages, or houses, are old, with ample accommodation for millions of mites. I smear the parts where cages rest on one another and on the stands thickly with soft soap as bought; it is the duty of the nurse to constantly well rub over every part of every cage with a damp cloth; and occasionally I personally doctor any cage that I think may be likely to require it with a liberal supply of fir-tree oil. At night I sometimes make a tour of inspection with a candle, to see if any traces of the prowling foe can be discovered. In short, I go in for clean- liness and prevention; and the results are certainly satisfactory so far as the absence of mite and disease is concerned. The floor and floor-cloth are washed every week-day with carbolic soap; and every drop of water used for cleansing purposes is fortified with permanganate of potash. The room is over the kitchen, and the kitchen flues run up the wall by the side of the fire-place, and make the room very dry, so that the moisture is rather beneficial than otherwise. In another room, this daily floor-washing might not be wise. Certainly my birds never seem to suffer from this cause: I have invariably been able to trace every case of cold, and the like, to over exposure out of doors. The food and water vessels are scattered far and wide, so that every bird may have a chance; none of the vessels are of metal; and the washing saucer is placed on the floor, on a large tray. A thermometer reports the temperature, and the lowest degree of cold touched during the night. For a good part of the year, I keep a hurricane lamp burning in the bird-room all through the night. This practice has much to be said in its favour. I am in London, and am shut in by houses, and the bird-room is dark; and the evenings so rapidly close in on a dull day that my birds used often to go to roost before their supper was served: for fresh food for the Soft Bills, and fresh water, are always given at least twice every day. Nov they have grown accustomed to the light, most of them will feed to a much later hour than they were able to do formerly; and they can get to then food betimes in the morning, fog or no fog. And the lamp is invaluable ir a room where migratory birds are kept. Instead of knocking themselves

about, and knocking other birds off their perches, as they used to do, they now fly round and round the room until they have had enough of it, and then quietly compose themselves to sleep as if nothing had happened; and by the time I go to bed everything is quiet. Of course, I burn a much stronger light, two lamps in fact, during the earlier part of the dark evenings, a much softer light prevailing during the night. A panic in a bird-room in which there is a light is a very unlikely occurrence, and even if such a thing should happen little or no mischief would befall the inmates. I do not believe in the wisdom of keeping delicate Foreign birds through an English winter without artificial heat. I am well aware that many foreign birds can stand a great deal of cold; but not many of them can do so with impunity, although the effects may not immediately be apparent. The longer I keep birds, the more I believe in the wisdom of keeping them warm, dry, and comfortable. For some years, I warmed my bird-room with a gas fire; but the expense was so considerable that the gas had to give way to the less convenient, but less costly, paraffin. I place a paraffin stove between the window and the fire-place, and near to the latter, cover it with a wire extinguisher-like guard: and on the top of the latter I place a pan of water for evaporation purposes. The lamp, also, lends its help in warming the room. But I must again press upon you the importance of having the room well ventilated, but without draughts, especially during the winter months. If all the cages be mounted on stands as I have suggested, mice cannot do much harm. Nevertheless, they are highly objectionable tenants, and should be evicted or otherwise disposed of. Traps will catch a few, now and then, but are practically of no use. I allow one hole to be always open, their favourite hole. Down this I drop a piece of bread and butter, well smeared over with phosphor paste, taking great care that none of the paste is left outside. The mice disappear: sometimes a feeble outbreak of the attack takes place in a month or two, but a second dose frees me of them for from twelve to eighteen months. On the morning following the laying down of the poison, I promptly remove any dead mice I may find; and those which die beneath the flooring seem to dry up, and do not smell! I once found such an one, as perfect and dry as a mummy. In some particulars, I have not described my bird-room just as it is, but rather as it should be, so that this little sketch of it may be the more useful to my readers. But they will please bear in mind that circumstances alter cases, and that what is best for one room may not be the best in another; and that a different class of birds may require various modifications of various details.

Since publication of the first number of the Magazine in November, 1894, there have been fourteen Editors and co-Editors. Through every possible vicissitude during the past seventy-five years they have managed to produce the Magazine without a break--a Magazine of ever-increasing stature, unrivalled in its field. Members have every reason to feel grateful to the Society's fifty-two Original Members, especially to those who first took office and got the Society under way. Unfortunately, with the passing of time, the majority have been forgotten, even their names being known to but few. It is the present intention to remind Members, by way of brief bio- graphies, of Editors down the years. Limited space prevents anything but the briefest notice. In a few cases little noteworthy is discoverable and in others it has not been possible to trace photographs. Dr. C. S. Simpson Original Member. Hon. Editor, 1894-1896 (with H. R. Fillmer): Hon. Secretary, 1894-1896. Dr. Charles S. Simpson was in medical practice in Brighton and, with his friend H. R. Fillmer, edited the first two volumes of the Magazine. He was an ardent supporter and on the Council, of the Cage Bird Club, and a Member of the United Kingdom Foreign Cage Bird Society-- forerunners of the Society. He in no way left his mark as an aviculturist but he was a keen exhibitor and judged at the Crystal Palace Show. His main interest seems to have been parrakeets. Very definitely one of the principal founders of the Society. H. R. Fillmer Original Member. Hon. Editor, 1894-1896 (with Dr. C. S. Simpson); 1896-1899: Hon. Secretary, 1896-1899: Hon. Treasurer, 1894-1897: Vice-President, 1925-1942. Horatio Rutter Fillmer died at Hassocks, Sussex, on 23rd February, 1942, at the age of 79. He was formerly a solicitor practicing in Brighton. Fillmer was a staunch supporter of the Cage Bird Club and of the United Kingdom Foreign Cage Bird Society. He has been described as the " mainspring " of the Society during its formative years--a description with which few would disagree. He does, however, seem to have been something of a weathercock. In 1901 the Society and its Magazine were at a pretty low level, and it was then that Fillmer severed his connection with the Society and resuscitated the Foreign Bird Exhibitors' League as the Foreign Bird Club. He acted as Secretary-Treasurer and Editor of its new magazine Bird Notes. Fillmer stipulated that there should be no competition between the two magazines, but to an extent this was inevitable.
