algorithms.reference: T. S. THOMSON--BREEDING THE EUROPEAN STARLING
algorithms.bodyText: (Sturnus vulgaris) By T. S. Thomson (Hoole, Cheshire, England) It has been written that the Starlings flock together during the winter, and in April they split up into pairs, but I find that the breeding cycle is continuous with birds which are resident in this country. A breeding pair of European Starlings will spend quite a few weeks in the autumn at the old nest, cleaning it out and adding a little fresh material, which may be later rejected when the nest is properly made in the spring. In captivity it was not found necessary to provide the birds with nest-boxes except in the breeding period. If nest-boxes were not removed after nesting, the birds used them as sleeping quarters. While it should always be recommended that breeding pairs of softbills have a compartment to themselves, Starlings will breed on the colony system. In the first season with this species some years ago, seven wild caught birds were enclosed in an aviary 30 ft. x 20 ft. As sexing is not an easy matter, the pairing up was left to the birds. Two pairs produced eggs. As the writer was working 100 miles from home, only returning home at the weekends, it was considered best to concentrate on one nest only. The other nest which was situated in the 6 ft. x 9 ft. catching up compartment in the aviary, was shut off. An opening was made in the roof netting near the nest and this second pair were left to rear their young on the semi-liberty system, which had been successfully practiced with other species. The first pair were to be treated as aviary birds and their young reared under aviary conditions as a first breeders medal was at stake. This required the registration and verification of the breeding by officials at various stages. For the past few years Starlings have been kept in good condition on little more than poultry pellets as the mainstay of their diet. However, when breeding was practiced a much more varied menu was offered. An insectile mixture (Haiths) formed the base. Starlings were often observed an lawns probing for food which includes the grass-devouring wireworms and the occasional earthworm is also taken. However, if earthworms are not a regular addition to an aviary kept Starling's diet, it will probably refuse them if they are offered at the vital period when young are in the nest. This was found to be the case here, not only with Starlings but also Blackbirds and Thrushes. Mealworms were offered and readily accepted, :ogether with gentles. As these two items are easily obtainable, the nreeding Starlings enjoyed them as a regular addition to the insectile mixture. Rotten fruit, mainly apples and pears were offered in season, is were scraps from the household, including bones to pick over. In the wild, the Starling feeds its young mainly on insects, and other nvertebrates. Beetles, weevils, larvae and the grubs of flies add variety.

T. S. THOMSON--BREEDING THE EUROPEAN STARLING It may be observed catching high-flying insects on the wing, in a swallow- like manner. Gentle " factories " were set up to provide regular supplies. These were funnel-shaped units, the top part holding the fish scraps used to propagate the gentles which dropped to the second story, consisting of a container with sand/sawdust mixture, before dropping again into a tray to which the birds had access. This tray contained an earth compost mixture about one inch deep in which the steady drop of gentles found refuge until removed by the Starlings. The provision of regular supplies of mealworms was a problem, the writer, as stated above, being absent on week days when the birds were left on their own. About a pound (weight) of mealworms were left in an open tray with suitable overlapping edges to prevent their escape. The tray contained leafy compost to give the mealworms cover and to spread the supply over as long a period as possible. However, a meal- worm tray did not prove a success as the Starlings quickly scattered its contents in their efforts to find the mealworms; which they preferred to the gentles. Under normal conditions with the breeder present daily, very frequent supplies of mealworms is desirable; little and often being the order of the day. While five or more eggs are a Starling's normal clutch, it is advisable to reduce the number of young. Far better to produce two healthy youngsters than a nest of weaklings dying off one after the other. After the young hatch, all but the strongest three are removed, and after a few days only two are left to be reared. This practice is to be recommended in the breeding of most species of softbills and even hardbills. Even in the wild the casualty rate in young in the nest is high. This may be the result of where the survival of hole-fed nestlings depends on the survival of the fittest. The parents do not enter the nest-box after the young are old enough to reach the hole of the box where they are fed. From this stage the sanitation of the nest is neglected and any young which succumb do not greatly add to the mess as they decay. Both parents attend to the young and it may be of interest to many to know that both birds share the incubation of the eggs, the hen, however, doing the larger part of this task. It was observed that whenever the hen left the eggs, the cock bird would immediately take over the incubation, until relieved in turn by the hen. When the young become self-supporting it is important to maintain the supply of live food for a few weeks before they are gradually weaned on to the insectile mixture. A small daily supply of live food is desirable when this stage is reached, but not necessary, Over a period of five seasons young were ringed in the nest with close rings and no losses were incurred as a result of such action; even although the Starling's maintained a high standard of nest sanitation in the early stages of rearing the young. Two and sometimes three lots of young may
algorithms.reference: T. S. THOMSON --1969 BREEDING RESULTS AT HOOLE
algorithms.bodyText: be reared in the one season. The breeding of Starlings by aviculturists in England is neglected, the cost of producing young being much more than the market price of the birds. Young were bred from an all-white starling hen (dark eyed), but no rare-feathered offspring were obtained, even when sons were paired back to white mother bird. If the white Starling had been red-eyed (albino) it would have been possible to produce their kind, as is practiced at present with cinnamon and lutino greenfinches. There are also other mutations in existence including pied, cinnamon and silver, which would give a wide scope for any breeder. It is good practice to provide alternative nesting sites for birds being bred in captivity but the Starlings' requirements are easily met, a lovebird type nest-box being readily accepted. When colony breeding is practiced, extra nest-boxes are desirable. In courtship the cock hounds the hen quite a lot, driving her into the nest-box, where she finds refuge. More squabbling will be noted between a courting cock and hen than between rival birds, but, of course, this depends on the size of the unit in which breeding birds are housed, the larger the better. When birds are kept on the colony system more than one feeding-point is recommended. It is desirable to install birds in an aviary some months before the breeding season, leaving it to the late Spring might result in negative results.

By T. S. Thomson (Hoole, Cheshire, England) After a winter of repeated cold spells followed by a wet spring, the 1969 breeding season was considered a fairly satisfactory one. Success was achieved with 31 species while three failed to produce any young. Approximately 430 birds were reared to maturity. This number includes over 100 young from several species of liberty birds which were kept in confinement all season, as a result of the editorial comment in the March/ April issue of the Magazine. Some of the small foreign young will not probably live to reproduce. On the other hand, Green Cardinals reared strong healthy young practically without any extras. Pheasants, Quail and Partridge totalled about no birds and British birds 170 plus, including 3 ver 80 Softbills which are the subject of this report. Thirty-two Songthrushes, Turdus philomelos , seven Mistle Thrushes, T - viscivorus, 13 Starlings, Sturnus vulgaris , one Fieldfare, T. pilarus, 11 Blackbirds, T. merula and 19 Hedgesparrows, Prunella modularis were eared to maturity. Enclosures of various sizes were used, ranging from [ 5 ft- by 6 ft., to 90 ft. by 80 ft. In past seasons some of the above species iad reproduced without any attention, finding all the food necessary, dowever, breeding successes were usually limited to the first rounds. In

T. S. THOMSON-- 1969 BREEDING RESULTS AT HOOLE an effort to maintain an ideal environment throughout the season, wild rabbits were introduced into an aviary in order to crop the grass which, if allowed to grow long, restricts the feeding area. However, the rabbits had to be removed. It was quite a surprise to find that they were able to climb up fruit trees, sometimes up to 12 ft., eating bark or the current year shoots. The damage was too extensive hence their removal. Geese prove suitable as grass cutters but the scythe has to supplement their efforts. In another enclosure a perforated hose pipe fed from a 300 gallon tank, maintained ideal worm activity during dry spells when the ground would normally be rock hard. Autumn leaves spread on bare patches in other aviaries kept the birds active. Lawn mowings were also used. Three maggot " factories " were in constant production, two fed with fish waste and the other with scraps from the butcher. A compost heap of about four cubic yards, prepared in the autumn, provided large quantities of reddish-type earthworms. About 2 ins. of compost, full of worms were skimmed off, about a bucketful a time, and placed in metal trays. With pheasants kept in most of the enclosures housing the breeding softbills, the additional supplies of live food had to be guarded with 3- inch wire netting covers. In one aviary young Quail soon found the live food. In another young Waterhens made frequent raids, without parental escort, on the maggot trays. Breeding pairs of Song Thrushes were housed in aviaries of various dimensions. With one-year-old birds it is normal practice to put three together in order to sex them. In one enclosure 70 ft. by 70 ft., two young hens with a young cock raised two rounds each. The enclosure is a vegetable garden and as the season advanced frequent hoeing left the soil in a dust bath condition. While the borders of the garden planted with pear trees and soft fruit bushes, provided some live food, it was necessary to supplement the natural live food supplies with maggots. Data compiled over 10 seasons indicate one-year-old stock do not produce as many young as older birds. One 10 year-old Song Thrush did not la}/ daily and birds about this age have smaller clutches. Also best results are obtained early in the season. The trio of Song Thrushes had occasional skirmishes but generally they were occupied with their domestic duties. The first two nests were built fairly close together, about 15 ft. apart, considering the space available. It was of interest to record the cock s part in the rearing of both broods. Observations reveal cock Song Thrushes, Mistle Thrushes and Blackbirds feed the newly-hatched young, the hens mainly occupied with the brooding. When a cock bird arrived at the nest the hen would raise herself and allow the cock to feed the young. On occasion a hen would hold live food for some time in her bill, before passing it on. This may have been taken direct from the cock or picked out of the nest after the young were fed. With the two nests hatching a few days apart the cock Thrush attended both broods. Normally where three young Song Thrushes are being sexed by the method indicated above,
algorithms.reference: T. S. THOMSON-- 1969 BREEDING RESULTS AT HOOLE
algorithms.bodyText: the odd bird is removed, especially where the enclosure is of modest dimensions. \ oung hens on their own have built, layed and reared young of others. The breeding results from Song Thrushes housed in various sized aviaries indicate it is not so much the extent of the unit but the availability of adequate supplies of live food, which influences successful results. In addition the provision of live food throughout the season, whether as a supplement or a natural supply in a large aviary, had a bearing on the number of young reared. It is not sufficient to offer live food when the young hatch and during the rearing period. The annual urge to reproduce is so strong in bird life, many kept in confinement attempt to breed under adverse conditions, resulting in failure. Results from breeding pairs housed in similar conditions in 20 ft. by 6 ft. aviaries reveals a marked difference in the total young reared, when live food is rationed. A con- tinuous supply of live food first offered before the season begins results in an early start to the season, in more rounds per pair, a shorter interval between nests and more young per round. Under ideal conditions four rounds were achieved. To support ideal breeding conditions it is desirable to remove the young as soon as they are self-supporting, normally within a week of fledging. With a limited supply of live food young birds were maintained in good condition on a diet of poultry pellets fed from a hopper, 10 to 12 birds being housed in 15 ft by 5 ft. aviaries. As one who has frequently advocated the reduction of broods of most species of British either by removing eggs or young at an early age, the research with breeding Song Thrushes calls for some qualification of this advice. In cases when parent birds, whatever the species, are not able to find enough food, the numbers raised may be smaller than if they had started with a smaller brood. With some breeding pairs of Song Thrushes housed in what was considered better than natural conditions, double brooding " was practiced. Young were removed from pairs which would benefit from a reduction in the brood size and given to ideally housed pairs. It was most necessary that all the young in a double brood nest were of the same age and stamina. In spite of careful matching, young in a double brood nest developed erratically, resulting in death and rejection from the nest. The greatest number reared from double broods of seven and eight was five. The growth of young in normal size broods frequently varied, this being most noticeable at the ringing period which could be spread over three to four days. Long dry spells also had a bearing on the different rate of growth of the young in the same nest. The smaller the brood-size the less variation in the young. In addition to breeding in aviaries of various sizes, the liberty method added to the successes. There are many variations of this method of rearing birds. With the trio of Song Thrushes referred to above, it was intended to remove the 70 ft. by 70 ft. nylon netting roof of their aviary. A pair of Blackbirds were also nesting with the Thrushes and last season,

T. S. THOMSON-- 1 969 BREEDING RESULTS AT HOOLE 1968, they were liberated after rearing a first round. After liberation the Blackbirds returned to the compound and completed a second round. It was intended to repeat the process with the Song Thrushes this season but the views expressed about this method of keeping birds dictated that they be confined to their aviary, there being several other species involved. On the other hand, a pair of Song Thrushes were specially housed in a 15 ft. by 6 ft. aviary having a roof opening. When the young hatched this skylight type of exit was opened up. The entrance/exit was specially sited to retain the young, being in the middle of the flight netting. A branch was placed immediately under the opening and after the parents had become accustomed to flying in and out, it was removed before the young fledged. With this method, as an additional precaution to retain the young, clipping a wing has proved satisfactory. Where there is no desire to retain the young it has been found that the best arrangement for exits and entrances is provided by making openings at ground level and also in the flight roof netting. Another point of interest associated with the liberty breeding method is a bird's ability to search for natural food on being released. It has been found that birds kept on a diet of meal- worms and maggots were incapable of searching for worms and cases have occurred where Blackbirds refused supplies dug up and thrown down for them. A study was made of the rate of growth in the young Song Thrushes reared under the various conditions. It is normally difficult to better the results obtained in the wild but this was achieved during prolonged dry spells. The results from aviaries where special action was taken to maintain earthworm activity compared favourably with results from liberty breeding. The total number of Thrushes reared must greatly exceed that of birds nesting in the wild, with the added protection given. Cock Song Thrushes would come into song each time nest building was nearing completion and the eggs being laid. On more than one occasion a com- pleted nest was abandoned, another being built immediately. Some nests were built within two days, there being a few days interval before the first eggs appeared. Much of what has been written about Song Thrushes probably applies to Blackbirds, Mistle Thrushes and Fieldfares, but with fewer pairs employed it was not possible to obtain relative data to all that covered the case of the former. One pair of Mistle Thrushes reared seven young from three rounds. They were overwintered in a 40 ft. by 100 ft. aviary on a diet of apples and poultry pellets plus earthworms which increased in supply as the Spring advanced. Their aviary was opened up to a 80 ft. by 90 ft. planted compartment with matured fruit trees pruned down to 12 ft. Within a week the Mistle Thrushes commenced nest building,, selecting a site 3 ft. 6 ins. off the ground. This was quite exposed, the many prefabricated nesting sites being ignored. With the trees not yet in leaf such sites, made up of shrub cuttings, are provided for the birds.
algorithms.reference: T. S. THOMSON-- 1969 BREEDING RESULTS AT HOOLE
algorithms.bodyText: especially Greenfinches. Over 100 prefabricated nesting sites are furnished each season. 1 hree young Mistle Thrushes were reared from the four out of the five eggs which hatched. The young were fed entirely on small earthworms. As soon as the young were self-supporting they were moved to a 20 ft. by 12 ft. aviary. A bird-keeper from the local Zoo remarked on seeing the young Mistle Thrushes, that two or three pairs nesting in the Zoo grounds has only started building. Within a week of the young leaving the nest it was rebuilt by the birds. The inside lining of grasses was removed down to the mud base and fresh grasses added to complete the nest. Eggs soon followed and all went well until the young were a few days old. A prolonged wet spell with torrential rain saturated the nest. One young Mistle was found dead some distance away from the nest. The hen continued to brood continually, the young being fed by the cock. Observations revealed the hen was reluctant to leave the soaked young, even to allow the cock to feed them. The exceptional wet conditions left the young in a weak state and they died off. Again within a few days the Mistle Thrushes started another nest, this time on a sloping roof of about 50 degrees. Much material fell to the ground and it was considered in the bird's interest to fix a 2 in. batten to retain the nest which was 13 ft. up. It was also sheltered by overhead cover and while exposed to view it was more or less an ideal site. Again five eggs produced four young, all of which were reared. By this time maggots were available and a few were taken to supplement the natural supply of worms found in the aviary. It was intended to foster out Mistle Thrushes under Song Thrushes but no nests were available with young of a comparable age. A pair of Fieldfares, together with two young partly hand-reared the previous season, were housed with the Mistle Thrushes. A special study was made of their behavipur, from late winter until the fruit tree foliage made observations difficult. The Fieldfare proved awkward aviary inmates, it being necessary to fix up individual feeding points for each bird. Apples were spiked on branches and each bird guarded the area adjacent to the food supply. Poultry pellets and Softbill food mixed was provided in separate dishes placed up to 20 ft. apart. While the Mistle Thrushes kept very much together and fed from the same spot, the most frequent activity recorded was the continuous bickering between the Fieldfares. With the coming of the breeding season it was of interest to record the gradual reconciliation. The species is reported to be sociable in the wild, nesting in colonies. From the limited observations made here there must ae quite a lot of squabbling before the birds settle down. The cock Fieldfare with tail erect, body leaning forward and wings dropped would olerate the approach of the hen to within a foot or two. After a brief iriel skirmish both birds would alight quite close together, the cock Posturing with the flickering of the wings and twitching of the tail in the irect position. The cock Fieldfare would also run towards the hen with

T. S. THOMSON --1969 BREEDING RESULTS AT HOOLE puffed breast and tail up. While the birds were noisy when compared with the Mistle Thrushes, no song was noted. A low warble was noted from time to time. With the increase in the volume of the spring chorus it was difficult to isolate individual efforts. The aviary shelter used as a hide was surrounded by aviaries containing many different species. The varied Starling's song with some mimicry, frequently added to the vocal confusion. One rewarding moment of the many hours of observation was the recording of the Tree Sparrow's weaver-like buzzing song and dance as it displayed to its mate. The cock sparrow with both feet firmly gripping the perch would draw himself up at an angle, leaning towards the hen and with a swaying action emit a continuous unmusical song. The Fieldfare's winter quarters were extended by opening up their enclosure to the adjacent 80 ft. by 90 ft. compound. Normal practice is to keep breeding pairs of the various species in the same enclosure all the year round or in ad ; acent units from which they can freely enter without having to resort to catching the birds up. Very few species are domestica- ted sufficiently to tolerate the terrible experience of being manhandled, certainly no British species. Unlike the Mistle Thrushes which went to nest immediately on being introduced to the large planted enclosure, no inclination to commence nesting was noted with the Fieldfares. It was two months before nest building was noted; by this time the trees were in full leaf. The nest was built in a fork of two five-inch branches with very little screening. It was similar to a Blackbird's in shape but much more straggly, some of the grasses draping down from the bulk of the nest. The concave-shaped interior was more rounded than the flattish finish of the Mistle Thrushes' nest, but not so deep as a Song Thrush's. The five eggs resembled that of a Blackbird s but were about that of a Song Thrush in size. When the young Fieldfares hatched it was necessary to use a step ladder to inspect the nest and note the development of the birds. Maggots supplemented the earthworms and other live food found by the birds. One young was missing at an early age, less than 48 hours old. Daily examinafions of the others indicated an early variation in their development and another died about the fifth day. Of the three remaining one gradually lost ground by the time the others left the nest and it was never seen again. The two survivors made reasonable progress and addi- tional feeding points were set up at ground level. At about a month after fledging one of the young Fieldfares was found dead in a going-light con- dition. The other was present when the annual round-up and roll call was made in October. The Fieldfares broke into an early moult by the end of July, ruling out the hope of a second round. The two-year-old Fieldfares never made any attempt at nesting. In addition to the rings they were distinguished from the parents, retaining some of the juvenile spotting after the first moult. Only when the Fieldfares encroached into the Mistle Thrush's nesting area was there any sign of pugnacious activity. At the end of the 1968 season Mistle Thrushes, Purple-headed Glossy Starlings, Lamprocolius purpuriceps , Fieldfares, Blackbirds, Song

T. S. THOMSON --1969 BREEDING RESULTS AT HOOLE 249 Thrushes and Starlings were housed in three interconnecting aviaries and the order of " peck " or dominance was as listed, Mistle Thrushes on top with the native Starling last. . r ^ wo P a * rs blackbirds, one in the 70 ft. by 70 ft. aviary and the other in one 30 ft. by 100 ft., together with Song Thrushes and many finches, reared two rounds each. Blackbirds are considered more difficult species than Song Thrushes. There is, of course, no sexing problem. Hedge Sparrows were able to raise young in the large enclosures without any special care being offered. At least 100 square feet is provided and in some cases over 300, when stocking large compounds, finches being the most numerous. Starlings, like the Hedge Sparrows, were left to fend for themselves. They reared young in enclosures where the supply of maggots was rationed, having to compete with Song Thrushes and Blackbirds. With Starlings it has been noted on several occasions that incubation starts before the clutch is complete, resulting in one or two younger chicks having to compete with others hatched a day or two earlier. Under perfect conditions with a plentiful supply of live food the complete brood could be raised. However, with hole nesters any retarded young quickly succumb and frequently they are left decaying in the nest. Early culling of the young is desirable. The native Starling's neglect of nest hygiene is all too apparent if the nest-box is examined after the young fledge. On the other hand Glossy Starlings maintain a clean nest and continually add bits of leaves as the young develop. On occasion half grown young Glossys have been partly covered in the freshly added nesting material. The breeding cycle of the native Starling seems a more or less continuous affair. About a month after the young of the last round have fledged, the cock bird will revisit the nest and spend quite a lot of time in subdued song accompanied with wing flicking. This is repeated continually throughout the winter and during mild spells the old nests are removed and sometimes a few fresh grasses added. In the first week of February a Starling laid a clutch of eggs. No doubt the abnormal mild weather in January was a contributory factor. By the time the clutch was completed arctic conditions returned and the hen did not sit. There are several recordings over several seasons of young Song Thrushes and Blackbirds " fostering " younger birds, offering them food and even attempting to brood them. Young birds have been observed carrying nesting material. Young Mistle Thrushes have been heard to utter chattering calls before fledging. Where young Song Thrushes and Blackbirds were mixed with young Mistle Thrushes losses have occurred when the latter take up guard on the feeding dishes. t( British bird breeders have everything to gain by concentrating on the easier " to breed species. Many species are beyond the capability of the breeders to establish domesticated strains. It is one thing to breed from robust wild-caught stock and another to reproduce young of the necessary stamina after several generations.
algorithms.address: 250 W. D. CUMMINGS--PARTIAL SUCCESS WITH THE LILAC-BREASTED ROLLER
algorithms.bodyText: Although Mr. Thomson has made no formal claims, the above would appear to be an account of the first breeding of the Fieldfare, Tuvdus pilaris , in Great Britain or Northern Ireland, and possibly of the Mistle Thrush, T. viscivorus also. Any member or reader knowing of a previous breeding of this species in Great Britain or Northern Ireland is requested to communicate at once with the Hon. Secretary.
algorithms.table: * # * PARTIAL SUCCESS WITH THE LILAC-BREASTED ROLLER AT KESTON By W. D. Cummings (Barnes, London, England) *
algorithms.bodyText: I was very interested in W. Collard s article on the breeding of the Lilac-breasted Roller, Coracias caudata, in captivity in Natal ( Avicult . Mag. 75 : 95-6). The editorial comment was that there appeared to be no previous records of the species breeding in captivity. The word " successfully " should have been added, for I mentioned with a few details in the Keston breeding notes, for 1965"66 I believe, that we hatched two young from, I suspect, a rather ancient but very tame hen, originally procured from Peter Parrish, which fell immediately in love with a magnificent cock that we had only had for a few months and which was flown to us specially by a good friend in East Africa. The latter was to be paired to one of these two tame Lilac-breasts we already had, and which I had tried unsuccessfully to pair together over a couple of years; and it was the only bird I could have positively identified as a cock on sight. Since the sexes are identical in colouring and indulge in similar display beha- viour, and are also solitary out of the breeding season, sexing them is not easy. Keeping two such birds in one aviary together, except for the brief breeding period is just about impossible. I am talking about fit, healthy birds, not newly-imported ones. They bicker and chivvy each other constantly. I introduced the two birds we had to the recently-arrived cock by putting him in a middle, larger compartment and opening up the inter-connecting doors. Rollers are intelligent birds and it took one of the two only thirty seconds before it flew through the door of the shelter, through the bob-hole, and out into the flight to land next to a rather surprised cock bird. Immediately she landed she postured for copulation to take place. It was not successful straight away but did take place a few minutes later, I had already put in a chewed-up parakeet nestbox, which they took to straight away. I didn't look into the nestbox at all, for the cock would get very excitable, displaying vigorously with a display that is closely allied to an aggressive territorial display and would end with him noisily chasing
J. BELL & D. BRUNING--BREEDING OF THE EUROPEAN AVOCET

the hen round the aviary if she came off too often. My opportunity came later when I found the hen very dejected with bad head injuries. I took her away and looked into the nest-box. To my surprise I found two healthy, fat, nude youngsters. They were almost reptilian-looking and one was several days older than the other, the oldest being about nine to ten days old. I naturally thought the quarrel was over who should feed the young ones so left the cock with them. However, they were dead next day. The hen never fully recovered from her beating-up, and I never had a chance to try again. The diet was maggots, mealworms, fresh mince-meat and locusts. I sometimes gave them newts but individual birds would go on and off certain foods for several weeks at a time. I imagine their natural diet is subject to strong seasonal changes.
algorithms.table: # # # BREEDING OF THE EUROPEAN AVOCET IN THE NEW YORK ZOOLOGICAL PARK (Recurvirostra avosetta) By Joseph Bell and Donald Bruning (New York, U.S.A.)
algorithms.bodyText: Delicate and graceful, the European Avocet Recurvirostra avosetta , has always been popular and much sought after for avicultural collections. The Bronx Zoo first exhibited this species in 1905, but not until the 1964 opening of a new exhibit for waterbirds, the Aquatic Bird House, was there a really suitable place in the Zoo to keep and breed shorebirds of any type. One display in the new building was designed to represent a tropical marsh, with a series of shallow, mud-bottom waterways coursing between small islands and flat bars of land, and surfaced with a lush growth of aquatic plants, an ideal location to maintain avocets. Two w r ere established there as soon as the exhibit was completed and more were added as they became available. The flock had reached a total of six specimens by the fall of 1968. Also living in the 9 metres wide by 8 metres deep, simulated habitat display are pairs or groups of: Chilean Grebe Podiceps rolland chilensis , Sun-Bittern Eurypyga helias , Common Jacana Jacana spinosa , Black-necked Stilt Himantopus mexicanus , African Spur-winged Plover Vanellus spinosus , Greenshank Tringa nebidaria , White-winged Black Tern Chlidonias leucopterus , European Hoopoe Upupa epops and African Grey-headed Kingfisher Halcyon leucocephala. On 1 5th April, of the current year (1969), a pair of European Avocets was observed attempting to build a nest in an open situation near the middle of the exhibit. Unfortunately, the site that they had chosen was only a short distance away from an active, Black-necked Stilt, nest. The stilts, tending a full clutch of eggs, were highly aggressive at this point, z

252 J. BELL & D. BRUNING--BREEDING OF THE EUROPEAN AVOCET They drove the avocets away. Stilts are regular breeders at the Zoo and little difficulty is experienced in artificially hatching the eggs, or in hand- rearing the young. The stilts were removed and their eggs placed in an incubator. On 22nd April the avocets were seen building a new nest, not far from the original site, and at 10 a.m. the following day an egg was noted in their simple, water-weed lined scrape. Within half an hour the egg disappeared from the nest and was subsequently found in the water, broken. Common Jacanas were suspected of being the culprits for three of them had been observed running back and forth over the nest site. The Jacanas were also removed from the exhibit. The avocets third attempt to nest was in a more fortunate location, protected by plantings near the rear of the exhibit. Eggs were laid on 25th, 27th, 29th April and 1 st May. Because of the previous disturbances, it was deemed wise to remove part of the clutch for artificial incubation, as an insurance measure. Two eggs were taken for this purpose but a mechanical failure resulted in an early death for the embryos. The remaining eggs incubated by both parents hatched on 22nd and 24th May respectively. The chicks remained at the nest site until the younger of the two was fully one day old. During the latter part of this period, however, the older hatchling started to wander short distances away picking up, and some- times eating, small mealworms tossed into the area. Within two days of hatching, both of the chicks were feeding from the regular food dishes in the exhibit. Both parents brooded the chicks repeatedly and became increasingly aggressive towards the other birds in the display as the chicks grew stronger and wandered over a wider area in the aviary. The greatest amount of pressure was exerted against the non-breeding flock of avocets. A tragedy was discovered on the morning of 29th May when one of the chicks was found drowned in one of the deeper sections of the pool. The remaining young avocet continued to thrive but the aggressive nature of the parents become so intense that great concern was felt for the welfare of the other birds in the exhibit. By 7th June the situation had become so acute that it was necessary to make some move to alleviate this pressure. The chick and one of the parents were removed to an off-exhibit aviary where they settled easily and the young bird continued to progress and grow. By the latter part of the month of July, the young bird was fully as large as an adult and could only be distinguished on sight by a faint, rust-coloured wash on the upper back. The juvenile and parent were returned to the exhibit on 25th July and quickly settled down with the rest of the avocet flock. The first recorded captive breeding of the European Avocet took place in Regent's Park, London, in the Spring of 1907. An excellent account of that event appeared in the Avicultural Magazine (Vol. V, No. 9, pp. 258-263) authored by Mr. R. I. Pocock, Superintendent of the Zoological Gardens at that time. The authors felt, however, that captive breedings of this species are rare and each occurrence worthy of a note, recording details.

algorithms.sectionHeader: BRIAN BERTRAM--HILL MYNAHS AND TRADE IN THEM FROM INDIA 253 HILL MYNAHS AND THE TRADE IN THEM FROM INDIA
algorithms.author: By Brian Bertram
algorithms.bodyText: Hill Mynahs are becoming increasingly popular as pets, being justly enowned for their talking ability. They have only very rarely been )r ed in captivity, mainly because they are usually kept singly in cages, rhe thousands imported annually into Europe and North America have >een captured in the wild, the great majority of them in India. This irticle describes the methods of capture of, and the subsequent trade n, Hill Mynahs in different parts of India, the information given being *ased on my own observations and enquiries during two years of field york in India on the social and vocal behaviour of these birds. First, lowever, the nomenclature and distribution of Hill Mynahs needs larification. Nomenclature * n x 957 > E. J- Boosey reported in the Avicultural Magazine the reeding of Greater Hill Mynahs at Keston Foreign Bird Farm. The ubsequent confusion in later issues over the correct identity and nomen- lature of the species bred was due largely to the use of old and disagreeing fference books. Two recent authoritative works, Ripley (1961) and eters (1962) have now clarified the nomenclature, and in this way super- sded earlier reference works. I shall be dogmatic in order to be brief. The terms Hill Mynah " and " Grackle " are synonymous for birds f the genus Gracula\ the earlier generic name Eulabes is now outdated, he name Grackle is best avoided since it leads to confusion with ther unrelated Grackles. The word " Hill " must be included to avoid infusion with other related genera also called Mynahs. Except for racula ptilogenys endemic to Ceylon, all Hill Mynahs are at present eated as races of the species Gracula religiosa; there are 10 such races, >und in South-East Asia from India eastwards; the four main races are salt with briefly below. (Although this is the classification of Hill lynahs generally accepted at present, and is used in this article, study of le behaviour and calls of these birds in the field and in captivity makes clear that G. r. indica and G. r. intermedia would not interbreed if teir ranges were to meet, and that they should therefore be considered 1 be distinct species.) Gracula religiosa intermedia is the Greater Hill Mynah of the bird trade, id the race of Hill Mynah by far the most commonly imported to this >untry. It is the race bred by Boosey at Keston, and is found in Nepal, orthern India (particularly Assam), Burma, Indo-China, and Thailand.
algorithms.sectionHeader: 254 BRIAN BERTRAM--HILL MYNAHS AND TRADE IN THEM FROM INDIA
algorithms.bodyText: Gracula religiosa indica is the Lesser Hill Mynah of the bird trade, less commonly imported into England, and found in south-west India and Ceylon. It is easily distinguishable from G. r. intermedia by its considerably smaller size, more slender build, and different wattle arrange- ment, as illustrated in the accompanying photograph. Gracula religiosa peninsularis is found only in north-east peninsulai India, particularly in Orissa to the south-west of Calcutta. It differs from G. r. intermedia really only in being slightly smaller. Gracula religiosa religiosa is the Javan Hill Mynah of the bird trade relatively rarely imported into this country, and distributed through Malaya, Sumatra, Java, Borneo and some of the nearby islands. It is considerably larger than G. r. intermedia. The six other races of Gracula religiosa have restricted island distribu- tions and are virtually never imported into England.

In South India, Hill Mynahs of the race indica are captured in larg< numbers with nets or bird lime when large flocks gather to feed on loca concentrations of fruit or nectar. Most of the indica so taken are adul birds, which rarely become very tame and which are largely unable t< learn new sounds. As pointed out by Ali (1963) this method of capture taking adult birds, is probably the main reason for the poor reputatioi of the Lesser Hill Mynah as a talking bird. A few young indica are take] from the nest before fledging, are kept locally, and learn to talk quite well but since adult indica are cheaper and easier to obtain, they are ofte substituted by dishonest dealers. In consequence, indica have acquire* the reputation of being unable to learn to imitate human speech, an therefore they command lower prices. In North India, Greater Hill Mynahs (i.e. the race intermedia) ar occasionally captured when adult by some of the hill peoples. Stick coated with bird lime are attached to trees just coming into fruit, and tb winter flocks of Hill Mynahs land on these and become entangled. A the birds so caught used to be eaten--curried Hill Mynah is apparent! a Naga delicacy. Recently, however, the bird dealers in India ha\ discovered that if they buy cheaply these wild-caught adult intermedi (and, sometimes, trim the wattles of these unfortunate birds), they ca often pass them off as expensive young birds to those ignorant of th differences between adults and young or ignorant of the need to obtain young bird if it is to be taught to talk. The great majority of intermedia captured are taken from nests up to fortnight before fledging. Most of these nests are in high tree holes, i some cases artificial basket nests are used, as described in an earlier artic (Bertram 1968). These young birds gape widely, and are easily fed t hand. In India only a diet of moistened gram-powder is used. To indue
algorithms.sectionHeader: BRIAN BERTRAM--HILL MYNAHS AND TRADE IN THEM FROM INDIA 255
algorithms.bodyText: neat or live food would improve the health and appearance of these )irds, but would be more expensive to the dealers, and is never done. The young birds reach Calcutta two or three weeks after capture, and are :hen sent abroad by air, usually fairly soon since the demand for them s high, particularly at the beginning of the breeding season. In the wild, greater Hill Mynahs fledge between April and September, and are ndependent of their parents very soon after. In captivity, if fed by hand, hey will continue for months to gape for food; thus a " gaper " bought in anuary has not come straight from the nest. Crates of young Greater Hill Mynahs converge on the big Calcutta )ird market from the following three main districts. From Assam mainly from the Garo Hills District) come about 5,000 young intermedia >er year. From Nepal, along the border with India, come annually bout 1,200 young intermedia. From Orissa, south-west of Calcutta, ome each year about 4,500 young peninsularis\ these latter are almost ndistinguishable from young intermedia , with which they are mixed by he dealers in Calcutta and all sold together as Greater Hill Mynahs; they irobably learn to talk equally well. These estimates of numbers are tased on several conflicting estimates from various sources; the numbers Iso vary considerably from year to year.

The numbers of indica captured probably have almost no effect on the opulation of this South Indian race. The 4,500 or so youn peninsular is iken annually from Orissa represents an appreciable drain on this limited opulation; control measures are needed, and should be relatively simple ) operate. The range of the race intermedia stretches for hundreds of tiles to the east of India; the taking of a few thousand birds from the astern end of this range will have no significant effect on the population f this race as a whole; the gradual deforestation occurring throughout le region must be much more important.

algorithms.address: 256 R. MOSS--REARING RED GROUSE AND PTARMIGAN IN CAPTIVITY
algorithms.sectionHeader: REARING RED GROUSE AND PTARMIGAN IN CAPTIVITY By Robert Moss
algorithms.bodyText: (The Nature Conservancy, Blackhall, Banchory, Kincardineshire, Scotland) People often rear red grouse and ptarmigan in captivity with varying success. At the Nature Conservancy at Banchory in Kincardineshire, we receive a number of requests for advice on rearing each year. To meet these requests, I have written this article which summarizes our experien- ces in rearing grouse over the last ten years and ptarmigan over several years. Eggs To rear red grouse and ptarmigan, you usually have to get eggs from wild birds. To get warm eggs back off the hill we use a large thermos flask filled with wheat at 99 0 F (37 0 C). We actually take the wheat out at a slightly higher temperature than this and allow it to cool off when we are picking up the eggs, using a thermometer to get the correct temperature. The chances of success in rearing vary enormously and depend mainly on the quality of the clutches you happen to have picked up. Although the hatchability of eggs from wild birds is usually over 90%, the viability of the chicks varies a lot. This variation in the chicks apparently depends on the state of the hen which laid a particular clutch. If the food (heathei in the case of red grouse) which she was eating when she laid the eggs was of good nutritive value then the eggs are likely to be of good quality and the chicks hatching from them will survive well. But if the heather was poor either badly browned over the winter or late in growing during spring then many of the chicks from that clutch will probably die. These differences in egg quality are the major reason for differences ir the breeding production of wild grouse and ptarmigan in different years and at different moors. In our experience, one extreme was shown b} eggs from a hill in the Cairngorms where we take an interest in the ptarmigan. In 1968 the ptarmigan in the wild failed to rear any youn# at all, which was unusually poor breeding, and we managed to rear # quarter of the chicks that hatched from three clutches of eggs taken nearby At the other extreme, we reared all the chicks hatched from a clutch of a grouse moor where breeding was good in 1959- We have seen al intermediate stages also. Thus if chicks die inside a fortnight aftei hatching, and a post mortem shows no evidence of disease, then there if probably nothing that could have been done to save them. They wen foredoomed before they hatched. It is a good thing to be aware of this point, as it saves unnecessary discouragement and self-recrimination. We have found this difference between eggs of good and poor qualit) in Scottish ptarmigan and red grouse. In Iceland, wild ptarmigan nearly
algorithms.sectionHeader: R. MOSS--REARING RED GROUSE AND PTARMIGAN IN CAPTIVITY
algorithms.bodyText: always rear large broods, and heavy mortality in the first 1-2 weeks is therefore unlikely to occur with chicks from Icelandic eggs. This may be because of the known fact that the food of Icelandic ptarmigan is of better nutritive value than the food eaten by Scottish ptarmigan. We do not know whether North American and European ptarmigan are of Scottish type or Icelandic type in their food and chick survival. Hatching Still-air incubators are quite good for hatching eggs which are already far on in incubation, say two weeks or more of the full three-week period. However, we have not had very good results using fresh eggs in still-air incubators. I understand that forced-draught incubators are quite satisfactory, but we use bantams, which are more convenient for small batches of eggs that are all at different stages of incubation. To bring out chicks in a still-air incubator, we always make sure there is plenty of moisture. Grouse eggs require more moisture than chicken eggs and we add extra water trays to bring the surface area of water inside the incubator up to at least twice the amount provided by the manufac- turer. We have found it impossible to make a still-air incubator too moist. According to the instructions issued by some manufacturers, the usual still-air incubators are designed to run at a relative humidity of 70%. But when the humidity in them is actually measured, it turns out to be 30% or less, depending on the weather at the time. Even if the surround- ing air is quite moist, the rise in temperature inside the incubator itself lowers the relative humidity, in spite of the water trays provided as part of the incubator. However, a relative humidity of 30% will hatch hens' eggs and 40% is quite adequate for grouse eggs.

Although a good clutch of chicks will survive almost any method of rearing, the number of poorer chicks which survive depends on the care you give in rearing. The best method is to use Calor gas brooders and I shall describe this in detail below, but it is rather expensive. You can also rear grouse using a bantam hen. The disadvantages are that not all bantams are good mothers and that the bantam may be a carrier of a disease which kills the chicks. It is also possible to rear grouse using an infra-red brooder, but this provides only a small circle of heat in the middle of the brooder house. This is good enough if you have lively chicks from eggs of good quality, but poorer chicks often seem to be lethargic or stupid and will crouch in a corner of the brooder house, and get chilled away from the heat. You will not have this trouble with Calor gas brooders, which give more uniform heat all over the floor area. To rear chicks we use light, steel-framed aluminium-cladded brooder houses, with a polystyrene lining on the lower half of the walls for insulation.
algorithms.figure: daritex window daritex window V wire mesh window brooder aluminium dadding expanded polystyrene insulation Brooder House
algorithms.bodyText: There is a " claritex " window in the roof and on the front of the house and a wire-covered window at the back which is provided with shutters. We use this wire-covered window to watch the chicks' behaviour, so it is not a necessary feature of the house. The floor is of wire mesh on a removable wooden frame, consisting of a double layer of J-in. wire mesh for the first two weeks. The double layer prevents the chicks getting their legs caught in the wire in the first two weeks, but as they get older it begins to get clogged with droppings and so is changed to a single layer. About 20 birds can be reared in such a house, with a ten-foot square run attached. We usually keep the chicks inside the house for about ten days before letting them out into the run through a pophole in the side of the brooder house. Heat is provided for six weeks using a Maywick pheasant brooder which runs off propane gas. It is wise to use a regulator including a two-way switch connected to a reserve cylinder as well as to the supply cylinder. This automatically switches over to the reserve cylinder when the supply cylinder runs out, and keeps the brooder going. Turkey starter, pheasant starter and partridge starter are all perfectly good foods for young grouse. However, you should avoid foods which use meat and bone meal as a source of protein--on one occasion we used a 258 R. MOSS--REARING RED GROUSE AND PTARMIGAN IN CAPTIVITY
algorithms.sectionHeader: R. MOSS REARING RED GROUSE AND PTARMIGAN IN CAPTIVITY 2^Q
algorithms.bodyText: turkey starter containing this and the chicks hardly grew at all for two weeks. . ^icks sometimes do not learn quickly enough to feed if the food is srniply given m a feeding tray. A good way to get them started feeding is to sprinkle the light-coloured food over a dark surface, such as a dark- coloured sod of upturned peat. The contrast in colour seems to attract the chicks to peck at the food, and they soon learn to eat it. It is essential to give some green food. Heather is best, but if this is not available, some other green food will do, though not so well. For the first ten days, whilst the chicks are confined to the brooder house, they are given sods of heather. Then they are let out into the run which is set up on short heather. This is moved twice a week, on to gradually taller heather as the birds get older. Feather-pecking can be a problem, especially if the birds are allowed to remain on short vegetation as they get bigger. You can reduce feather- pecking by providing cover, such as longer heather or, if this is not possible, cut branches. The proprietary preparation " Curb " is effective in inhibiting feather-pecking, but must be applied before the habit becomes really well-established. Whatever system is used, hygiene and cleanliness are essential, as in a husbandry. The biggest killing disease in our experience is cocci- diosis, to which grouse seem to be much more susceptible than ptarmigan. This trouble usually strikes when the birds are aged three weeks or more, well past the stage of early deaths due to poor-quality eggs. Fortunately' coccidiosis may be cured by the drugs on sale for this disease in poultry.' A disadvantage of the sulpha drugs commonly used for treating coccidiosis is the fact that they tend to damage the birds' kidneys. However, new drugs that are now available do not have this disadvantage, and in future we intend to add one of them to the birds' water as a matter of routine, because we have been troubled by coccidiosis in every year without exception. Breeding in Captivity Once the birds are full-grown, they can easily be kept in captivity, and vill lay fertile eggs. We use cages of the sort illustrated in the Iiagram, but almost any reasonably draughtproof cage which has as much )r more floor space, and enough cover to allow the hen to hide from the '*ck will probably do. We prefer to keep the birds on wire, to make leaning easier and prevent disease. We feed the adult birds Grouse Maintenance Pellets, which are made by Ranks, for most of the year, and Arouse Breeders' Pellets from mid-March to the end of June. They do >etter if they are given a small amount of heather; a good way of doing this s to bundle up a handful of heather with an elastic band and hang it from he side of the cage. One bundle every two days is enough. When the
algorithms.figure: 260 R. MOSS--REARING RED GROUSE AND PTARMIGAN IN CAPTIVITY rrrr; rrn r~m \0x25A0 rrrrrr rrrrr removable elaritex mesh ire door wire floor tray for droppings Breeding Cage
algorithms.bodyText: birds are laying, we also give them limestone or shell grit as well as the usual quartz or granite grit. The birds usually begin to lay in late April or early May and a typical hen will lay 20-30 eggs if each egg is removed the day it is laid. We usually remove the eggs like this, but on several occasions we have provided grouse with nesting material and plenty of cover and find that they will hatch and rear a clutch of eggs with no trouble. In fact they make better mothers than the bantams, largely because they speak the same language as the chicks. We have not done this with hen ptarmigan, but I can see no reason why it should not be successful. Our limited experience of ptarmigan indicates that they do better in captivity than grouse. We usually lose a few grouse over the winter and many hens succumb to egg peritonitis in the laying season. The peri- tonitis appears to have been getting more frequent as our breeding stock becomes further removed from its wild origins. However, out of eighteen ptarmigan we reared in 1968, only one died over winter and all ten hens laid and survived the breeding season. One of the main problems with breeding grouse in spring is that cock birds get very aggressive, and may peck the hens to death. This is because the hens are unable to escape from the cock in the cages, as they would in the wild. Also, we may be pairing incompatible birds--say an aggressive cock with a timid hen. We provide small shelters consisting of a foot-square piece of plywood leaning against the side of the cage and plenty of cover
algorithms.sectionHeader: R. MOSS REARING RED GROUSE AND PTARMIGAN IN CAPTIVITY 261
algorithms.bodyText: so that the hen can hide and avoid attacks of the cock. If she is out of sight when he is feeling aggressive he does not try to seek her out. We sometimes reduce damage by sharing one cock between two hens on alternate days by shooing the cock through the pophole in the breeding cages each day. Sometimes the cock will severely damage one hen and leave the other alone. If other methods fail, the cock can be inhibited from pecking the hen by mild " de-beaking "--clipping his upper man- dible so that the blood just flows. This may have to be repeated once or twice as his bill grows again. In 1969 only one of our cock ptarmigan attacked a hen, and he stopped when his beak was clipped.

We have been hatching eggs from 20-30 captive grouse each year for four years now, and did so on a smaller scale in previous years. Many of our breeding birds are therefore four generations or more removed from the original wild stock. I said earlier that the quality of eggs from the wild varies a great deal, depending on the nutritive value of the food eaten by the hen that laid them. It might appear from this that breeding birds in captivity ought to lay eggs of good quality every year, because they get plenty of good food. At first the breeding results were encouraging and supported this view. Despite a fairly poor hatchability of 70%, due mostly to clear eggs, 80% of the chicks which hatched survived in 1966. Hatchability remained fairly constant at 70% from 1966 to 1968, but fell to 40% in 1969. The survival of the chicks after hatching fell from 80% in 1966 to 70% in 1967, 50/o in 1968, and 60% in 1969. I understand that a similar decrease in vigour occurs when breeding stocks of partridges and pheasants are kept in captivity. Although poor grouse eggs may be produced in the wild because the hen's food is of poor quality, this does not appear to be the reason in captivity, where we give food of high quality all the time. We do not know the reason in captivity, but there is a slight indication that the cocks, rather than the hens, may be at fault. In 1967 we took in a few wild eggs and in 1968 bred from two hens hatched from these eggs, mating them with cocks from the captive stock. Chicks hatched out from the eggs of these hens survived just as poorly as the rest of the captive stock-- thus performing like their father's stock and not like their mother's. I have now described the complete breeding cycle, and I wish you luck in your rearing. Unfortunately, I must end on an unhelpful note by saying that we are unable to help anybody by providing eggs for rearing purposes. This is because we use for research purposes all the eggs our birds lay, and have no surplus for general distribution.
262 MRS. K. M. SCAMELL--BREEDING THE SPOTTED-WINGED STARE

(Saroglossa spiloptera) By Mrs. K. M. Scamell (Newdigate, Surrey) The Spotted-winged Stare, Saroglossa spiloptera , is a species of Starling about 9J in. in length. The adult male is very dark-brownish-grey above with black markings. The wings have a band of white patches across the flight feathers which are pointed and black. Cheek patches aie dark grey-brown and the chin and throat are deep chestnut rufous. The chest is reddish-white as are the sides of the belly and the remainder of the underparts are white. The eye is yellow with a dark brown iris. The beak and legs are grey-black. The centre tail feathers are grey-black and the outer tail feathers dark brown. The adult hen is dark brown above with black and dark grey markings. The wings also carry a band of white patches across the flight feathers which are pointed and blackish- brown. Cheek patches are brown and the chin, throat and chest are whitish streaked with brown. The underparts are mostly whitish except near the wings where they are greyish with a little fulvous. Eyes, beak and legs are similar to the male's, but the centre tail feathers are dark brown and the outer ones medium brown. The species has been recorded up to 5,000 ft. elevation and distribution is said to be throughout the Himalayas and also in Annam and S.W. China. It is an erratic winter visitor to Burma as far South as the Southern Shan States. Breeding has been recorded in the Himalayas from Mandi, in Himachel Pradesh, to Nepal. The species is said to be gregarious and particularly fond of flower nectar. It is also frugivorous and eats insects. It has a wild twisting flight which occurs without apparent reason and as suddenly finishes. The nesting sites are found in tree hollows or old barbet's holes, 20 to 30 ft. up and the eggs are usually three or four in number and coloured pale blue with reddish-brown specks and blotches. We purchased our pair of Spotted-winged Stares from a Southall dealer on June 5th, 1967. They had been imported two or three weeks and were in fair condition. The species are not often available in the U.K. and we could not recall having seen them before. They were given an aviary to themselves and during the following winter moved to another aviar\ with a shelter heated to 45 0 F. They are very simple feeders and contrary to the records of their feeding in the wild, they ate only insectivorous food with the minimum of fruit, just a little grated apple and grated carrot. They are not greedy birds but they are very shy, and have a high-pitched screech when flying. They ignored live food and nectar. After we had had the birds 12 months, they suddenly became very excited, flying wildly and calling to each other. We felt that at last they might be in breeding condition. Nest-boxes, both with half-open fronts and with entrance holes only, had been provided in various positions in the flight
algorithms.figure: Avicult. Mag Copyright] Spotted-winged Stare. Male parent. [Derek Washington Copyright] Spotted-winged Stare. Parent birds [Derek Washington
Avicult. Mag Copyright ] Spotted-winged Stare. Young bird. [Derek Washington Copyright ] Spotted-winged Stare. Young birds [Derek Washington
algorithms.bodyText: MRS. K. M. SCAMELL--BREEDING THE SPOTTED-WINGED STARE 263 which is planted with evergreens and measures 16 ft. long x 4 ft. widex 6 ft. 6 in. high. The shelter measures 4 ft. long x 2 ft. wide by 7 ft. 6 in. high to the ridge and also had a nest-box. The aviary is the first one of a block of six. Mealworms, maggots and nectar were offered from time to time but were ignored. A week later the hen was missing for long periods and we thought she might be nesting inside the shelter. This was not so and the remainder of the wet summer passed with no nesting attempt. As before, the birds moulted in late October and spent the second winter in their aviary but shut in the shelter at night and during daytime frosts. In the Spring of 1969 we added two further nest-boxes, one in the flight and one replacing the one in the shelter, about 6 ft. up. Each box has a sloping roof and measures 10 in. high x 7 in. deep x 6 in. wide and has a 2 4 in. diameter entrance hole over a perch. Live food was offered from time to time as was nectar, but always refused. In early June the pair were very active and in very fine condition and on the 16th June to our surprise the mealworms and maggots were all consumed for the first time since we possessed the birds. On the 23rd June fresh privet leaves were seen in the shelter under the new nest-box. Live food was fed twice daily and was all consumed, but little insectivorous food was eaten. The hen bird was rarely seen and on the 3rd July the cock was seen in the flight with something white in its beak and we now felt fairly sure that one or more chicks had hatched. Live food disappeared quickly. On the 9th July I just had to know if there were any young in the nest so when both birds weie in the flight my husband stood on a box but was unable to see anything through the nest hole. However something like a beak jabbed gently at his finger and we were at last satisfied that at least one young bird was inside! The 12th July was very hot, about 8o* F. The hen was seen to chase the cock in the flight so that it clung to the wire netting. Even so it managed to get into the shelter and possibly do its share of feeding! Shortly afterwards the nest was again checked, this time using a torch. One young bird was seen, quite large and mostly naked. The nest consisted of a pad of leaves covering the whole floor of the box, but no other material. Mealworms and gentles were fed six times during the day, also some earthworms, but the latter were not touched and very little insectivorous food was eaten. The last feed was given at 9 p.m. but at 7.30 a.m. next morning all the live food had gone. The temperature remained in the 8o's until the 17th July when it dropped to 72 0 F. Live food consumption had remained fairly constant until the latter date when at 1.30 p.m. some mealworms remained from the two morning feeds. This was unusual as they normally consumed the mealworms first. There was also a bad smell in the shelter, the sort that bird breeders dread as it indicates the death of something, so especting the worst the nest was again checked by torchlight. T. wo young birds were seen alive and almost fully fledged. This was a great relief. Two days later we saw the body of a young Stare in the shelter where it had been deposited from the nest.

264 MRS. K. M. SCAMELL--BREEDING THE SPOTTED-WINGED STARE It had been dead many days and was only partially fledged. To be sure a further check on the nest-box was made and this time my husband saw two very lively young birds moving around the box. Their tails were over an inch long and they were so active that it seemed they were ready to leave the nest. Both parents had been seen to deposit faeces in the flight. During the next three days many of the mealworms supplied were mutilated in the food pot and mostly maggots only seemed to have been fed. The weather had become very hot again and early on the 26th July the first young Stare was seen in the flight. It was completely feathered and in colour was a dull edition of its mother. The second young bird was in the flight a few hours later. This bird was darker and carried more rufous on the chest and at the sides so we felt sure we had a young bird of each sex. The birds were strong and could fly well. In fact the young hen returned to its nest during the afternoon and was not seen again that day. The young cock stayed out and as far as we knew was perched on the flight all night which was dry and warm; 23 days had elapsed since we suspected that hatching had occurred, but as we never found any eggshells, the birds might be a few days younger. The next day the birds were in the flight most of the time, calling to be fed. They were very steady and the parents were less shy than usual and we were able to observe them feed live food on several occasions. It rained all night on the 28th July and all the next day with the temperature ranging between 62* F. and 48* F. The young birds were unaffected by the weather and never seemed to get really wet. They rarely go on the ground and I think this helps with young birds facing their first heavy rainstorm. At 8 a.m. on the 30th July all the insectivorous food had been eaten though there was live food still in the food pot. This was unusual as with softbills I generally have to restrict the live food before they will accept the insectivorous food. My diary for the 2nd August records, " Young Stares clamouring for food nearly all day. Both parents seen to feed only occasionally and the young birds are flying wildly and no longer enter the shelter. The following evening at about 8 p.m. the young birds were crying for food as usual but this time the parents seemed very excited, forcing one of the young birds to the ground." Though as far as we knew this was only the 9th day since the birds had left the nest, it seemed that the time had come to separate them from their parents. We caught the young birds up and caged them in the house for the night. They did not eat any of the food provided, so next morning we moved them to a large cage in one of the birdrooms well out of sight and, we hoped, hearing of the parents who seemed about to nest again. In a very little while the young Stares were feeding themselves with insectivorous food, a little grated apple and carrot and a few mealworms. They don't touch maggots. New leaves were seen on the shelter floor but as far as we know the parent hen did not lay again nor was she absent from the flight long
MRS. K. M. SCAMELL--BREEDING THE INDIAN BLUE CHAT

enough to incubate. Mealworms provided for the parents were again mutilated but gentles had been eaten freely. By the 20th September it seemed unlikely they would breed again this year so we placed the young Stares in a nearby aviary. As at the 6th October 1969 neither the parents or the young birds have moulted and the plumage of the latter seems unchanged since they left the nest. It is as follows: The juvenile male has a dark-brown head with the back a lighter brown, particularly at the edges of some of the feathers. The upper tail-coverts are reddish-brown and the tail is dark brown. The wings carry a similar white bar to those of the parents and the flight feathers are black. The chin and throat are whitish with dark brown streaks. The underparts are also whitish mixed with fulvous at the sides of the chest and belly and around the vent. The beak and legs are similar to the parents but the eyes are grey with dark irides. The juvenile hen has a medium brown head with dark brown face patches, a lighter brown back and dark brown tail. Chin and throat are whitish streaked with brown. The wing flight feathers are dark brown and carry similar white bars to those of the parents. Underneath the bird is whitish with a little fulvous showing on the sides of the belly and around the vent. The legs and beak are similar to those of the juvenile cock but the eyes are unlike the parents or the juvenile cock, they seem to be a darkish-brown with a suspicion of a lighter circle around the irides.

As described Mrs. Scamell has bred the Spotted-winged Stare, Saroglossa spiloptera. It is believed this may be a first success. Any member or reader knowing of a previous breeding of this species in Great Britain or Northern Ireland is requested to communicate at once with the Hon. Secretary.

algorithms.bodyText: By Mrs. K. M. Scamell (Newdigate, Surrey) The Indian Blue Chat, Luscinia brunnea , is distributed throughout the Himalayas during the summer months from May to September. The species winters mainly in the rainfall zone of S.W. India and Ceylon at elevations of between 2,500 and 5,000 ft. Breeding occurs only in the Himalayas between 5,000 and 10,000 ft. and from May to October. The Indian Blue Chat is not easily seen in its native habitat because it spends its life among low dense bushes, in the undergrowth and on the ground. It is said to be a confirmed skulker. In an aviary, however, the adult birds though generally on the ground do

266 MRS. K. M. SCAMELL--BREEDING THE INDIAN BLUE CHAT frequently perch for long periods and are easier to observe. When in breeding condition the male bird has a short distinctive song comprising three or four " peeps " each louder than the last and followed by a few sweet notes, all of which carry quite a distance. At such times the bird is perched on a high branch or perch in its aviary. The sexes are not alike. The male bird is dark or slatey-blue above with a very noticeable white supercilium. The sides of the head are blue- black. A large white streak crosses the throat and leads to the point of the chin. The remainder of the underparts are bright chestnut except the abdomen which is whitish. The female is olive-brown above and fulvous below with a lighter patch at the throat and abdomen. Male Indian Blue Chats are often imported into the U.K. but females are scarcer and the one we have is the only one I can ever recall having seen. We purchased our pair in London in November 1967. They were very young birds. We already had a cock bird and really only wanted the hen but the owner would not separate so we came away with the pair. They were given a large cage for the rest of the winter and lived together amicably. The food given was our normal insectivorous food plus a small daily ration of mealworms and gentles. Their general condition improved steadily so that on March 22nd 1968, we were able to move the pair to a new planted aviary which had a heated shelter. It was one of a range of six similar aviaries each flight measuring 12 ft. x 3 ft. x 6 ft. 6 in. high. The insulated cedarwood shelter for the six flights measures 18 ft. wide x 7 ft. 6 in. high x 3 ft. deep. The six compartments are separated by wire netting partitions and have half-glazed doors leading to the flights. Entrance holes above the doors can be closed by hinged alighting platforms and there is a communicating door between each flight. Lighting is controlled by a time switch, and tubular heaters, thermostati- cally controlled, keep the shelter from falling below 45 F. In the rather narrow flights of these six aviaries we have planted mature shrubs such as privet, box, cupressus and lonicera with an odd bamboo and azalea here and there. Pruning has to be frequent and quick in the breeding season. It was cool and wet during most of the 1968 summer. The cock bird soon came into breeding condition and his song was heard day after day but the hen was not interested. Most of the time she was puffed out and I had doubts whether she would become established. In September they both moulted and by the next month she became so aggressive to the cock that I had to separate them, leaving the hen in her aviary for the winter and caging the cock in a birdroom. In February 1969 the hen was carrying dead leaves to first one then another of a number of half-open nest-boxes we had placed in the flight and shelter. These " nests " did not get beyond pads of leaves. In early March we tried to pair the birds again but the hen would not accept her mate of the previous year. The adjacent aviary was empty so the cock bird was hastily ushered into safety.
