Avicult. Mag. Copyright] [Derek Washington Indian Blue Chat. Young female. Copyright] Indian Blue Chat. Young male. [ Derek Washington
algorithms.bodyText: MRS. K. M. SCAMELL--BREEDING THE INDIAN BLUE CHAT 267 We next tried our old male which had been a bachelor some years but he received the same treatment from the hen and had to be returned to his winter cage. During a fine spell of weather in April we opened the door between the two flights giving the pair the run of the two aviaries. This time the pair agreed and we observed no fighting. The hen soon resumed her nesting activities. In the wild the species nests on or near the ground and we expected her to choose one of the many nest-boxes placed low down in both flights and shelters. She again carried leaves first to one box, then after a day or two changed her mind. However on the nth May, to our surprise, she chose a nest-box in the cocks' aviary which was fastened to the roof of the flight and left there from the previous season when we had other occupants in that aviary. She was soon carrying masses of teased string and twine to her latest choice of a site so we shut the door of the flight and confined the pair to the one aviary. The first egg was laid on the 20th May in a very deep and large cup at the back of the nest-box and incubation commenced on the 24th May when either three or four eggs had been laid. The cock sang at intervals throughout the long days. Extra mealworms were given on the 3rd and 4 th June and when she was off the nest for a few moments on the latter day I checked it and just felt two small chicks. On the 6th June the cock was seen sparring with the hen who seemed very disturbed so we put him in the adjacent empty aviary where the hen had wintered and let the hen get on with the feeding alone. The cock sang just the same! The next day I was able to check the nest again and this time I thought there were three chicks. Shortly afterwards the hen was seen to feed a maggot and then a long thin earthworm. The young birds could be heard quite plainly but the only food which increased was mealworms. On the nth June two heads were seen above the nest, with beaks gaping. The weather had become very hot--around 75 *F_ during the last few days, with the sun beating down on the unprotected roof of the nest-box and we began to wonder if the young birds would survive this heat. In the wild, nesting is stated to occur low down and ilways in shady places so no more unsuitable site could have been chosen. We were also at fault in leaving the box in such a position. On the 13th [une the hen did not seem to be feeding much live food so we added small .arthworms and a few spiders to the food pot. Later that morning when entering the flight with more earthworms, loud protests from both parents Irew attention to a partly fledged bird on the ground. The hen was shut n the shelter for a few moments and the bird was returned to the nest. \.t 9 p.m. when the last of the earthworms were taken in, two heads were igain seen above the nest. The next day was again very hot and late that morning a young bird vas again seen scrambling under the shrubs in the flight. This time the Jarents wishes were respected and we left the bird alone. In the afternoon he young bird was seen lying on a stone slab exposed to the hot sunshine.

MRS. K. M. SCAMELL--BREEDING THE INDIAN BLUE CHAT It was placed in the shelter in the shade. Though the parents made the usual protests, the hen made no attempt to feed it nor did she visit the nest, so at 6 p.m. the nest was examined. Inside was one dead chick only partly fledged. I felt sure it was one of the two alive the previous evening. The bird in the shelter was now gaping weakly and as it seemed certain that it had been abandoned by its mother it was removed to the house and hand-fed with mealworms. Later these were supplemented with a well-moistened strained insectivorous food using a Thomas's feeder. The avian* was searched in case there were any more chicks but none were found so the door between the two flights was opened and the pair once again had the run of the two aviaries. We hand fed the sun'iving young bird for the next 12 days, when it apparently caught its claw in a cage wire and lost a lot of blood before we found what had happened. It died that night. We had become very attached to the little bird which had completely feathered, was stronger and could fly short distances but due to a weakness in one leg could not stand properly. Perhaps the hen knew best as I doubt if it would have ever overcome this defect. In the meantime the hen had repaired her old nest before we had got round to removing it. Then to our relief she abandoned it in favour of a nest-box in the shelter of her winter aviary. It was about 2 ft. 6 in. from the floor, faced east and was already half full of leaves. A large deep cup was built as before and four pale blue eggs were laid, the first about the 19th June. Incubation commenced on the 22nd June and one chick hatched on the 5th July (14 days). The next day there were two chicks End the day following these could be seen gaping. It was not until I looked again on the 10th July did I see that all the eggs had hatched and that there were four chicks in the nest. They were taking mealworms in quantity, a few gentles, but I doubt if any insectivorous food was eaten at all. It is always easier to succeed with a full clutch but I felt that a diet of mealworms alone would not rear healthy birds. With softbills a varied live food diet is essential. We had a culture of wax moths in a heated cupboard but they were not ready. There were no caterpillars about so it was back to the earthworms! We also obtained some white worms from a local fish farm. The earthworms quickly disappeared, the white worms more slowly. The next day was even hotter (80* F.) but the shelter door which faced south was kept shut and the nest was in shade. Sixty small earthworms were dug up, washed and supplied at intervals. All were consumed. A friend brought a large supply of ant eggs and these quickly disappeared, but whether they were hidden by the ants which came with them or fed to the young birds I was not quite sure. On the 14th July it was 84* F., and my husband found it hard digging to find 100 earthworms which were now supplied in five lots each day. The earthworms, small and red, were found coiled up in pockets in the baked ground (heavy clay!) which was at the side of our orchard and which

MRS. K. M. SCAMELL--BREEDING THE INDIAN BLUE CHAT 269 was chosen as the source of supply because it had never been dug before to our knowledge. It was free of any fertilisers and pesticides. On the 16th July (the 12th day since the first chick had hatched), the four young birds left the nest, two in the morning and two in the afternoon. The perching in the shelter had been added to by a number of thin branches placed on the floor. The door was kept shut and we guessed rightly that I it would be some days before they could fly as high as the open pophole. Feeding was a bit of a problem as we liked to place the food on the floor so that they would learn to feed themselves. Every time the door w 7 as opened the four birds dived at the half-inch partition netting and stuck their heads through. I felt sure they w r ould strangle themselves but other than scraping some of the feathers off their heads they came to no harm. Another 100 earthworms plus the usual mealworms and gentles w r ere fed |on each of the next three days and then reduced to nothing by the 21st July. By that time the ground was baked so hard it v~as very difficult to fork the ground at all and even more difficult to break up the" lumps of : 1 a} ! The young birds w T ere now finding their v r ay out of the pophole nto the flight so we fastened the shelter door back. One bird seemed smaller than the other three but all had grown since leaving the nest and vere flying strongly. On the 28th and 29th July the w eather at last broke, here was a big drop in temperature and we had nearly 2 in. of rain. Fhe first experience of rain did not seem to affect the four birds who kept 0 the bushes and hardly seemed to get wet. We separated one of them >n 3*th Juh (14 days after leaving the nest), caged it and gave it a pot vith insectivorous food, 12 gentles and three mealworms. It ate the live ood first and then a little of the insectivorous. The live food was repeated ind by the following morning much of the insectivorous food had gone as veil as the li\ e food. That day the other three were caught up, separately aged and fed in a similar way with similar results. The parents hardly nade a protest and at that time it looked as if they w r ould nest again but nstead started to moult within a few 7 days. The live food to the four oung birds w as steadily reduced so that the other food w^as consumed in quantity. On the 7th August two of the birds were given an empty aviary 7 dth a large shelter and the following day the remaining two joined them, .hey all feed from one pot in the shelter, very often perch high up and ave come along very w 7 ell indeed. They are no longer so w 7 ild but one as to check tv ice a day to find if they are all there as one or two are always 1 the bushes. From the coloration at this stage (20th August) there appears to be iree hens and one cock. The young hens are brown above with greyish eads. The w ings and tails are also brown with the edges of the feathers ghter. The brown chests are streaked with grey and a lighter throat atch show r s clearly. The sides of the chest are fulvous w 7 ith the remainder f the underparts lighter. The young cock, however, has a slatey-blue til and darker blue wing feathers, is much whiter underneath v 7 ith less
fulvous on the sides of the chest. Bluish feathers are developing on the throat and back. As yet there is no sign of a white supercilium.

As described Mrs. Scamell has bred the Indian Blue Chat, Luscinia brunnea. It is believed that this may be a first success. Any member or reader knowing of a previous breeding of this species in Great Britain or Northern Ireland is requested to communicate at once with the Hon. Secretary.

Recent news of the Pheasant Trust was given in a newsletter received in September. At a meeting of the Trust council in April it was decided that the name should be changed from the " Ornamental Pheasant Trust " to the " Pheasant Trust ", since it was felt that the former was rather misleading insofar as all pheasants are ornamental, and further tended to create in the minds of the general public a false impression as to the functions and aims of the Trust. It was felt that the new name would be less cumbersome and more appropriate. The breeding season of 1969 had been remarkably successful except in the case of the tragopans of which only three Cabot's and one Temminck's
algorithms.listItem: had been reared. Some of the more important results included the rearing of a total of 140 Mikado, 38 Monal, 19 Koklass, 12 Green Junglefowl, 45 Cheer and 7 Edwards's Pheasants. The number of Mikados was especially gratifying in view of the fact that at the end of 1968 there were probably not more than 120 birds of this species in captivity in the world. Since the beginning of the year the Trust had imported: 2/1 Siamese Firebacks, Lophura diardi , --/3 Green Junglefowl, Galius varius, 1/1 Malay Crestless Firebacks, Lophura e. erythrophthalma.
algorithms.bodyText: The female Green Junglefowl were received from Dr. K. C. Searle ol Hongkong and had already been mated with the three males which he had sent last year. As can be seen from the list of breedings above, two pairs nested successfully, the first time that this species has bred in the Trust's collection. The Malay Crestless Firebacks were most generously donated by Lord and Lady Medway and have settled down well, the female laying two eggs while in quarantine. The species has never before been represented in the Trust's collection. Following the first successful release by the Trust of Swinhoe's Pheasanl in Taiwan, a second re-introduction with birds dispatched from the Trust took place successfully in the Che-chi reserved Forest in October 1968.

Negotiations have begun with the Taiwan Government for the re-intro- iuction of the rarer Mikado Pheasant if a suitable high-altitude reserve ;an be found where the birds can subsequently be protected. Other re-introductions are proposed. The Cheer Pheasant, Catreus vallichi , is threatened with extinction in the wild where it is confined to the Himalayas. Young birds have been offered to the State Government of dhmachal Pradesh, and arrangements have been made for their release in a mitable reserve near Simla. It is hoped to send the first consignment of mung birds for release in the spring of 1970. Discussions are also taking >lace concerning the possible re-introduction of the Cheer Pheasant, the Himalayan Monal, Lophophorus impejanus , and the White-crested Kalij, T ,ophura leucomelana hamiltoni , to certain mountain reserves in Pakistan vhere the species were once common but are now threatened with :xtinction. Mr. Alan Bromby, the National Trust Warden of Brownsea Island, eported that one pair of Swinhoe's Pheasants on the island had raised our young this summer. Five adult birds were picked up dead during he previous winter and post-mortem examination of two revealed death rom avian tuberculosis, known to be present in the Peafowl which roam he island. Owing to the denseness of the cover it will not be possible 3 arrive at an accurate census until autumn or early winter. Three pairs f Blue Eared Pheasants on the island nested and since they had failed to ear their young in previous years, Mr. Bromby collected eighteen eggs rom the three pairs, from which he successfully hand-reared twelve young diich were released in August. At the Trust the rewiring and re-roofing of the last five open enclosures r as completed in the spring. These pens will be used for pairs of trago- ans. An additional twelve new pens were also constructed in the spring, ringing the total of large covered pens to eighty-six. Four cabinets, kindly donated to the Trust by the Trustees of the ritish Museum (Natural History), will be used to accommodate the tcreasing reference collection of skins and eggs.

An enquiry into lories and lorikeets is being undertaken to try to help le understanding of their requirements a little better. There seem to be certain problems which appear again and again, rincipally concerning diet. Practically everyone has their own different :cipe for nectar and some do not use nectar at all, preferring a fruit and :ed diet only. The scourge of feather plucking is very prevalent among lorikeets in iptivity, some species being more prone to it than others; this may be mnected with diet and captive conditions.

The enquiry goes into the breeding question in some detail; as in recent years more and more species are being bred and with the collected results of those bred successfully, those who were not so successful may, we hope, be helped. A questionnaire has been drawn up and it is hoped that all aviculturists keeping lorikeets, and willing to participate, will request a copy of it from the address given below and return it with the information required, no matter in what part of the world they live. It is hoped that when the results of these questionnaires are all sorted out, some of these problems will be answered. The full results of this survey will be published in the Avicultural Magazine and also each participant in the enquiry will be sent a copy oi the findings. The questionnaires will all be filed at the Harewood Bird Garden, Leeds, and will be available for inspection at any time. They should be requested from and returned to: Peter Brown, Curator , Harewood Bird Garden, Harewood, Nr. Leeds. .V. .V.

Secretary. 1 THE ORANGE-BELLIED FLOWERPECKER (Dicaeum trigonostigma) By Alan Booth (Hoylake, Yorkshire, England)
algorithms.bodyText: Most people in this country, I think, are unfamiliar with this group of birds. The Orange-bellied Flowerpecker, Dicaeum trigono stigma, found over most of S.E. Asia, is one of the most colourful. The following description is taken from Smythies' " Birds of Burma ". Length, 3J in. Male: upper parts, deep grey-blue; back and rump, orange-red; chin, throat and breast, pale grey; rest of under-parts, bright orange. Female: olive green above; rump, yellow; chin, throat and breast, ashy; rest of underparts, yellow; iris, dark brown; bill and legs, black in both sexes. I am now serving in the Merchant Navy and this does give some opportunity to bring home some birds, although in very small numbers. I saw these flowerpeckers on my third visit to Singapore, in one of the three bird shops on Rochor Road. There were approximately three dozen, of which only six were female. I bought two pairs at what I thought was a very low price--two pounds--which is much below the price they would be here at home. They were housed in two small cages and fed on a mixture of Horlicks and honey diluted with water. They were also given fresh fruit cut up very finely so that each piece could be swallowed whole. They were paired to reduce the risk of fighting. One paii did not fight at all but the other did, with even my intervention at times to separate them. They made only a sharp " tweet ", much like Zosterops. The male uttered this note rapidly, when approaching the female with all his feathers fluffed up, making him like a small black and orange ball. The only other observation which I made was that during the passing of the faecal sac the bird appeared to be very laboured and in great difficulty.
algorithms.page: 274 A - A ' PRESTWICH--RARE AND VANISHING AMAZONA PARROTS
algorithms.bodyText: I was later assured by Dr. Searle that this was quite normal for Flower- peckers as he had seen the same with the ones he had kept. The bird would then proceed to wipe the vent on the perch or bottom of the cage in a bobbing movement, which means that all perches had to be washed regularly. On reaching England only the two females were alive. One died on the morning of reaching London Zoo, the other died some 17 days later. This was, I am sure, due to not being able to give enough heat when we reached our cold weather again, as it dropped some 40* F. between the Canaries and Gibraltar. Next time I shall take them to the engine-room when extra heat is needed, whatever the species. This last female was the one which fought the male, and since Mr. Yealand later identified it as a Scarlet-backed Flowerpecker, this may have been the reason why they did not agree. On my return to Singapore, whenever that may be, I shall always be on the lookout for this and other species to bring home, this also applies to birds of all kinds and it does help me to acquire some knowledge in the event of my keeping birds when I return to land.
algorithms.table: # # * RARE AND VANISHING AMAZONA PARROTS By Arthur A. Prestwich The Parrot Ban in the U.S.A. was lifted in September, 1967. Since when Amazona species have enjoyed (?) an ever-increasing popularity and
algorithms.bodyText: the demand is described as quite fantastic. It is, of course, impossible to estimate with any degree of accuracy, but it is considered that, due to the very primitive methods of collecting and transporting, of no less than half a million birds captured, only about 10,000 reach the market alive. A drain which surely cannot be allowed to go on. There are 52 species and subspecies and of these many, especially island forms, while perhaps not in actual danger of extinction, still give cause for great concern. This is due in the main to forest clearance for agriculture, coupled with shooting and trapping. Some species are protected by law, but the law is very difficult to enforce. Special protec- tive measures are needed now, before it is too late. But it is imperative that they are enforced, otherwise fine species such as the Bahama Amazona leucocephala bahamensis , Little Caymen A. 1 . hesterna, Puerto Rico A. vittata vittata, Rothschild's A. barbadensis rothschildi , Guilding's A. guildingii , St. Lucia A. versicolor , and the Imperial A. imperialis will go the way of the Culebra Amazona Parrot A. vittata gracilipes and become extinct.

algorithms.bodyText: P. Farrant has had a rare breeding success, Mitchell's Lorikeet. Two young ones are now four months old, identical to their parents except that their beaks are darker. This is probably the first success since Clifford Smith was awarded the Society's Medal, in 1962.

Allen Silver reports that a correspondent B. Owen, Stafford, intimates a male Diamond Finch and a female Bengalese have reared five young. The Diamond made the nest and incubated by day and the Bengalese by night. The hybrids have been out of the nest for three weeks.

J. G. Hamilton, Walkerville, South Australia, used to maintain an extensive collection of parrakeets, but during recent years has been concentrating on two favourites--Princess of Wales's Parrakeets and Splendid Grass Parrakeets. Records covering the past 35 years show that during that time 902 Princess of Wales's were bred; the best season producing 64 from 16 mated pairs. The best result with the Splendid was 134 bred in one season.

P. Duijzend, Leersum, Holland, writes: " In 1928 my late father imported some Grey-headed Sheld-ducks Cusclycu ccmq. from Pretoria. One female is still living and so is now over 40 years old. She appears to be in perfect condition and was laying until seven years ago. I first bred this duck in the spring, 1929. I still have a pair of Egyptian Geese, the first new birds to arrive here after World War II, in January, 1946 .

Walther Langberg, Copenhagen-Vanl^se, reports: " My parrakeets have done very well this year. Three pairs of Princess of Wales s have a total of fourteen young on the perch; two pairs of Rock Pebblers, nine young; two pairs of Crimson-wings, five young; one pair of Pileated, seven young; three pairs of Many-coloured, twelve young; two pairs of Blue-wings, eight young. I have also bred lutino and pied Cockatiels, Stanley's and Elegants. The only failures were the blue Ringnecks, infertile eggs from both pairs ". # # * With reference to the Slender-billed Cockatoo bred by Dr. Alan Lendon. Mr. Ivor Gould, " Bird Keeping in Australia ", August, 1969, says that this is not a world first as the Long-billed Corella was bred in Wellington, New Zealand, three years ago by Mrs. C. Pullan. Mr. Gould writes: " They first bred in 1965 and reared one chick until it left the nest and was then attacked and killed. In 1966 they nested again and successfully hatched and reared two young birds. In 1967 two more were reared and in 1968 they hatched three and successfully reared them, this making a total of eight hatched in four years and seven reared by the parent birds which are still alive ".

In the July-August, 1969, number of the Magazine I mentioned that the White-tailed Eagle is now only a rare migrant. It is therefore the more interesting to learn the up-to-date results of an experiment by the Royal Society for the Protection of Birds. In an attempt to re-establish this species two young males and two young females, all from different eyries in north Norway, were taken to Fair Isle for release, in the summer, 1968. R. J. Porritt reports a breeding success at "Birdland", Cromer. He writes: " Our successful breeding of the Common Mynah Acridotheres tristis with a Crested Mynah A. cnstatellus took place in a large, well- planted aviary 100 ft. x 27 ft. " Towards the end of May, the two Mynahs built a nest in a privet bush about two feet from the ground. The nest was similar to a Blackbird's but much more untidy. Three greenish-blue eggs were laid. The first sign of youngsters was on the 20th June. When we looked there were three youngsters, one died within the next week and the other two fledged towards the end of July. Their appearance is similar to the Common Mynah. Unfortunately we have since lost one of the youngsters during a spell of very cold, wet and windy weather; the other is still fit and well ". A. A. P.

algorithms.bodyText: This is an excellent popular account of bird flight in all its aspects, written by an enthusiast who has not let knowledge of his subject erode his sense of its wonder and beauty. Descriptions of the mechanics of bird flight, clearly presented in every- day language are interspersed with vivid descriptions and personal reminiscences. In the latter the author's trained Peregrine " Princess " often figures. One suspects the author's admiration for birds of prey in general and Peregrines in particular may derive largely from his feelings for " Princess ". Whether behaviour that, in a crow, sparrow or pigeon would be attribu- ted solely to fear is, in a Peregrine, largely a result of its " fierce pride " (p. 7), or whether an American Peregrine really can catch any other American bird " if it seriously tries to do so " is, perhaps, debateable but the author's partiality for Peregrines is understandable in view of the pleasure they have given him. The book is illustrated with a number of good black and white drawings. Unlike many books that are aimed at a wide readership it gives a very full bibliography, and references to the sources of any possibly questionable statements. It can be recommended to all who wish to learn more about bird flight (with a good deal of other information by the way) without having to cope with technical jargon or dull and flavourless prose. D. G.

algorithms.bodyText: I am able to add some more details to what was said about the breeding of the Asian Green Starling at London Zoo, in the first two paragraphs on page 106 of Robin Restall's notes on this species in the September/October issue of the maga- zine. For when four of these starlings were bred in the Bird House (1957, I 958" 1959), I was employed there, and cared for the aviary they bred in. On the four occasions the breeding pair nested in the same place. This was on the peat moss floor of their aviary, in a crevice between two large rocks. The nest was a scrape in the peat moss, lined with a few feathers, twigs, and pieces of paper. Each time they laid two eggs, pale green with some spots. Only a single chick was ever reared at one time however. Whether one of the two eggs disappeared or whether one of the chicks died soon after hatching I cannot remember now. But I think the latter was usually the case. From some rather sketchy notes I have from the time, I know that in 1957 when two chicks were reared from two nests, the first chick left the nest after 22 days, the second after 21 days. The chicks were about three-quarters grown when they left the nest, and were grey, with darkly streaked whitish underparts. In the case of the first chick, my notes tell me that it started showing some green in its plumage approximately 28 days after leaving the nest. Unfortunately I do not know the incubation period. In the large central indoor aviary in the Bird House the breeding pair were housed with a wide variety of other species, including two other Asian Green/ Malay Glossy Starlings. Because of the many other birds sharing the aviary it was not possible to give them any special food when they were rearing young. When the youngsters left the nest they remained in the aviary with the four adults, and all lived amicably together. Eventually there were, I think, at one time seven of them living together in the aviary.

The Society year begins January 1st, but new members may join at any time and are entitled to the back issues of the AVICULTURAL BULLETIN, Roster for the current year and a copy of the By Laws. One membership includes husband and wife. The annual dues for domestic (Canada & Mexico included) membership are $4.00. Foreign dues are $5.00. Please send remittance to the Membership Secretary, Mrs. Marian Wagner, 565 East Channel Rd., Santa Monica, California 90402. Make your check payable to Avicultural Society of America. Foreign applicants please remit dues by International Bank Draft or Money Order only. The Avicultural Society of South Australia Founded 1928 The oldest Avicultural Society in Australia invites all interested in aviculture to become members. Subscription is #1 5s. 0 d. sterling per annum, and this includes a monthly magazine Bird Keeping in Australia mailed to all members. This is entirely original and deals with the keeping and breeding of many Australian and exotic species of birds. Please forward membership application and subscription to the Secretary, Eric Baxter, 17 Benjamin Street, Manningham, South Australia, 5086.
